PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a republication of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania. 
    This volume is a republication of the Code as supplemented through Ord. No. 25-2006, adopted January 11, 2007. 
    Part I of this volume contains the Home Rule Charter of the City. 
    Part II, the Code, is a recodification of the ordinances of the City of Wilkes-Barre of a general and permanent nature. As expressed in the Adopting Ordinance, the Code supersedes all such ordinances not included therein or recognized as continuing in force by reference thereto. 
    The chapters of the Code are arranged in alphabetical order and the sections within each chapter are catchlined to facilitate usage. Footnotes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant provisions of the state law have been included. The source of each section is indicated by the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the Comparative Table appearing in the back of the volume, any ordinance included herein can be readily found in the Code. 
Numbering System 
    The numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and municipal codes. Each section number consists of two component parts separated by a dash, the figure before the dash representing the chapter number and the figure after the dash indicating the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the first section of Chapter 1 is numbered 1-1 and the sixth section of Chapter 5 is 5-6. Under this system each section is identified with its chapter and, at the same time, new sections or even whole chapters can be inserted in their proper places, simply by using the decimal system for amendments. By way of illustration: If new material consisting of three sections that would logically come between Sections 5-4 and 5-5 is desired to be added, such new sections would be numbered 5-4.1, 5-4.2, 5-4.3, respectively. New chapters may be included by the addition of a decimal. after the chapter number, e.g., if the new material is to be included between Chapters 12 and 13 it will be designated as Chapter 12.5. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way, or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject, the next successive number being assigned to the article or division. 
Page Numbering System 
    The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a title of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the title. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
CHARTER CHT:1 CHARTER COMPARATIVE TABLE CHTCT:1 CHARTER APPENDIX A CHTAA:1 CHARTER APPENDIX B CHTAB:1 CHARTER APPENDIX COMPARATIVE TABLE CHTACT:1 CODE CD1:1 CODE APPENDIX CDA:1 CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES CCT:1 STATE LAW REFERENCE TABLE SLT:1 CHARTER INDEX CHTi:1 CODE INDEX CDi:1  
Index 
    The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of the headings being couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by municipal officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which he is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this Code is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental service, by which the Code will be kept up-to-date periodically. Upon the final passage of amendatory ordinances, they will be properly edited and the page or pages affected will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to the holders of the Code with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. Each such amendment, when incorporated into the code, may be cited as a part thereof, as provided in Section 5 of the Adopting Ordinance. 
    The successful maintenance of this Code up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the volume. As revised sheets are received it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publishers that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    This republished Code was prepared under the supervision of A. Lawton Langford, Corporate President, and Pattie F. Smith, Supplement Editor, with the able assistance of the MCC staff.

It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the City of Wilkes-Barre readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs. 
    The publication of this Code was under the direct supervision of George R. Langford, President, and Bill Carroll of the editorial staff of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project.

MUNICIPAL CODE CORPORATION Tallahassee, Florida  
FILE OF COUNCIL 
NO. 26 OF 1980 
Presented in City Council September 25, 1980 
_____ 
An Ordinance Adopting and Enacting a New Code of Ordinances of the City of Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania; Establishing the Same; Providing for the Repeal of Certain Ordinances Not Included Therein; Providing for the Manner of Amending Such Code; and Providing When Such Code and This Ordinance Shall Become Effective. 
Be It Ordained by the City Council of the City of Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania, and it is Hereby Ordained by Authority of the Same: 
    Section 1.  The Code of Ordinances, consisting of Chapters 1 to 32, each inclusive, is hereby adopted and enacted as the "Code of Ordinances, City of Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania," and shall be treated and considered as a new and original comprehensive ordinance which shall supersede all general and permanent ordinances of the City adopted on or before October 11, 1979, to the extent provided in Section 2 hereof. 
    Section 2.  All provisions of such Code shall be in full force and effect from and after the 9th day of October, 1980, and all ordinances of a general and permanent nature of the City of Wilkes-Barre, adopted on final passage on or before October 11, 1979, and not included in such Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein, are hereby repealed from and after the 9th day of October, 1980. 
    Section 3.  The repeal provided for in Section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance which is repealed by this ordinance. 
    Section 4.  Unless another penalty is expressly provided, a violation of any provision of such Code, or any provision of any other rule or regulation adopted or issued pursuant thereto, shall be punished by a fine of not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) and not more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and costs as provided in Section 1-7 of such Code. In default of the payment of such fine and costs, such person shall be imprisoned in the county jail for a period not exceeding ninety (90) days. 
    Section 5.  Any and all additions and amendments to such Code, when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the City Council to make the same a part of such Code, shall be deemed to be incorporated in such Code so that reference to the "Code of Ordinances, City of Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania," shall be understood and intended to include such additions and amendments. 
    Section 6.  In case of the amendment of any section of such Code for which a penalty is not provided, the general penalty as provided in Section 4 of this ordinance and Section 1-7 of such Code shall apply to the section as amended, or in case such amendment contains provisions for which a penalty, other than the aforementioned general penalty, is provided in another section shall be held to relate to the section so amended, unless such penalty is specifically repealed therein. 
    Section 7.  A copy of such Code shall be kept on file in the office of the City Clerk preserved in looseleaf form, or in such other form as the City Clerk may consider most expedient. It shall be the express duty of the City Clerk, or someone authorized by him, to insert in their designated places all amendments or ordinances which indicate the intention of the City Council to make the same a part of such Code, when the same have been printed or reprinted in page form, and to extract from such Code all provisions which may from time to time be repealed by the City Council. This copy of such Code shall be available for all persons desiring to examine the same. 
    Section 8.  It shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part of or portion thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the City of Wilkes-Barre to be misrepresented thereby. Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in Section 4 of this Ordinance. 
    Section 9.  This ordinance shall become effective on the 9th day of October, 1980. 
Approved: Date: /s/ T.V. McLaughlin

Ordinances that are not of a general and permanent nature are not codified in the Code Book and are considered "Omits." 
    In addition, by adding to this table with each supplement, users of this Code of Ordinances will be able to gain a more complete picture of the Code's historical evolution.

PART I - CHARTER[1] 
PREFACE 
    Pursuant to the adoption of the City Charter by the citizens of the City of Wilkes-Barre, the City, on January 5, 1976, inaugurated a new form of government. 
    As prescribed by the Charter, City Council has adopted an Administrative Code. The Code is intended to be an authoritative reference and guide to the organization and administration of the City of Wilkes-Barre. 
    The information contained herein should be used as the working guide of the City. 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 50-2004, § 1, adopted Oct. 7, 2004 amended the Home Rule Charter of the City. For complete derivation see the Charter Code Comparative Table. Printed herein as originally adopted is the Home Rule Charter of the City adopted by the electorate on November 4, 1975. Additions made for clarity are enclosed by brackets [ ]. 
State Law reference- Home Rule Charter and Optional Plans Law, 53 P.S. § 1-101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - BOUNDARIES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Boundaries, 53 P.S. Ch. 2; annexation of territory, 53 P.S. Ch. 4. 

Section 1:01. - Boundaries. 
    The boundaries of the City of Wilkes-Barre (hereinafter in this Charter called the "City") are the existing boundaries of the City at the time this Charter takes effect and as they may be lawfully changed. 
ARTICLE II. - POWERS OF THE CITY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- General powers and limitations of a home rule charter municipality, 53 P.S. §§ 1-301 et seq., 41301 et seq. 

Section 2:01. - Definition of powers. 
    Pursuant to the Constitution of the United States, the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania and Acts of the General Assembly of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, the City shall have and may exercise all powers of legislation and administration in relation to its municipal functions. The City shall have and may exercise any power and may perform any function not denied by the Constitution of the United States, the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, Acts of the General Assembly, in effect as of the effective date of this Charter, or of this Charter. 
Section 2:02. - Construction. 
    The powers of the City under this Charter shall be construed liberally in favor of the City, and the specific mention of particular powers in this Charter shall not be construed as limiting in any way the general powers stated in this Article. All possible powers of the City are to be considered as fully and completely as though they are specifically enumerated in this Charter. 
ARTICLE III. - COUNCIL-THE LEGISLATIVE BRANCH 

Section 3:01. - Composition. 
    There shall be a City Council of five (5) members nominated and elected by the qualified voters of the City by district. 
(Ord. No. 50-04, § 1, 10-7-04) 
Section 3:02. - Eligibility. 
    Only qualified voters domiciled in their respective districts of the City shall be eligible to hold the office of Council Member. 
(Ord. No. 50-04, § 1, 10-7-04) 
Section 3:03. - Election and terms. 
    The regular election of Council Members shall be held on the general municipal Election Day as established by the laws of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania. All five (5) Council members shall be elected at the first election under this Charter for a term of four (4) years. 
(Ord. No. 50-04, § 1, 10-7-04) 
Editor's note- The City Charter was changed by referendum in November, 2001. Due to various legal challenges, the City Council did not run in districts, nor reduce to five (5) members until the municipal election 2007. The case of Bergold v. Vonderheid, et.al., Luzerne County Docket Number 11064 of 2006, judicially determined that the referendum was considered formally implemented in 2003. In 1975 the Court of Common Pleas of Luzerne County, in reviewing the intent of the newly-enacted Charter determined that elections for Mayor, City Controller and City Council must be "co-terminous" or held during the same year. 
State Law reference- Municipal election shall be held biennially on the Tuesday next following the first Monday of November in each odd-numbered year, 25 P.S. § 2752. 
Section 3:04. - Compensation. 
    Each Council member elected at the first election under this Charter shall receive an annual salary in the amount of $5,000. The Chairman shall receive an additional $1,000 annually. Thereafter, the Council may determine the annual salary of Council members by ordinance, but no ordinance changing such salary shall become effective until the date of commencement of the terms of Council Members elected at the next regular election, provided that such election follows the adoption of such ordinance by at least six (6) months. 
(Ord. No. 7-90, § 1, 3-8-90) 
Code reference- Compensation of elected officials, § 2-142. 
Note- (NOTE: City Council has changed the salaries of the members several times since the enactment of this Charter in 1975 and 1976. However, since the Charter grants the Council the right to change the salaries by ordinance, a change in the Charter is not required and any ordinance passed need not be inserted as part of this Charter.) 
Section 3:05. - Vacancies. 
    The office of Council members shall become vacant upon death of the Member, resignation, removal from office in any manner authorized by law or forfeiture of the office. 
Section 3:06. - Forfeiture of office. 
    A Member of Council shall forfeit office if the Member: 
(1)  Lacks at any time during his term of office any qualification for the office prescribed by this Charter or by law. 
(2)  Violates any express prohibition of this Charter. 
(3)  Is convicted of a crime which results in a sentence of imprisonment being imposed, the maximum of which is in excess of one year whether or not suspended. 
(4)  Fails to attend four (4) consecutive regular meetings of the Council without being excused by Council. 
    In all cases of forfeiture, the Member shall be entitled to notice and a hearing in accordance with administrative procedures to be established by Council. 
Section 3:07. - Filling of vacancies. 
    A vacancy in the Council shall be filled by a majority vote of the remaining Members of Council. If the Council fails to act within thirty (30) days following the occurrence of the vacancy, the Court of Common Pleas of Luzerne County shall, upon petition of three (3) Members of Council or ten (10) qualified electors of the City, fill the vacancy in such office by appointment of a qualified resident of the City. The individual so appointed shall serve for the remainder of the unexpired term providing the vacancy occurs not more than ninety (90) days before the next general municipal election. 
    If the vacancy occurs more than ninety (90) days before the next general municipal election, the appointee as selected in the preceding paragraph shall serve until the first Monday of January next following said election. If a portion of the term remains beyond said date, an individual shall be elected at said general municipal election to serve from the first Monday of January following said election to the end of the term of the remaining Members of Council as provided in Section 3:03. 
Section 3:08. - General powers and duties. 
    Except as otherwise provided by this Charter, all powers of the City shall be vested in the Council and the Council shall provide for the exercise thereof and for the performance of all duties and obligations imposed on the City by law. 
Section 3:09. - Prohibitions. 
(1)  No Council Member shall hold any compensated appointive City office or employment during the term for which the Member was elected to Council. 
(2)  Except for the purpose of inquiry, the Council and its Members shall deal with the administrative service solely through the Mayor. 
(3)  Neither the Council nor any of its Members shall in any manner dictate the appointment or removal of any City administrative officers or employees whom the Mayor or his subordinate are empowered to appoint. 
(4)  Any Council member who has a financial interest, direct or indirect, or by reason of ownership of stock in any corporation in any contract with the City, or in the sale of any land, shall make known his or her interest and shall refrain from voting upon, or otherwise participating in the sale of such land or the making of such contract. 
Any Council Member who willfully conceals such interests shall be guilty of malfeasance in office. 
Violation of this Section with the knowledge expressed or implied of the person or corporation contracting with or making a sale to the City shall render the contract or sale voidable by the City. 
Section 3:10. - Investigations. 
    Council shall have power, by ordinance, to make or cause to be made, investigations, audits, or studies of the affairs of the City and the conduct of any City department, office or agency, and, for this purpose may retain professional and technical assistance, subpoena witnesses, administer oaths, take testimony, require the production of evidence, and provide funds for such investigations, audit or study. 
    The subject of such investigation, audit, or study shall be specifically stated in the authorizing ordinance. The final report shall be submitted to Council at a public meeting. 
Section 3:11. - Removal Powers. 
    Council shall have the power to remove from office for cause set forth in this section any person appointed to the office by Council, or with the advice and consent of Council. Mismanagement of official duties, malfeasance in office, committing a fraud upon the City, conviction of a felony, conviction of a crime which results in a sentence of imprisonment being imposed, the maximum of which is in excess of one (1) year whether or not suspended, or commission of any corrupt act or practice shall constitute grounds for removal. 
Section 3:12. - Independent audit. 
    The Council shall provide for an independent audit of all accounts of the City following the close of each fiscal year. Such audits shall be made by a Certified Public Accountant or firm of such accountants who have no financial interest, direct or indirect, in the fiscal affairs of the City government or any of its officers. No person or firm so selected shall serve in this capacity for more than five (5) consecutive years. 
    The audit should be performed in accordance with the generally accepted auditing standards and should lead to the expression of an opinion of the financial statements. A summary report of the audit shall be published promptly in a newspaper of general circulation in the City of Wilkes-Barre at least once a week for three (3) consecutive weeks. The complete audit shall be available at the office of the City Clerk during normal business hours. 
Section 3:13. - City clerk. 
    The Council shall appoint an officer of the City who shall have the title of City Clerk. The City Clerk shall give notice of Council meetings to its Members and the public, keep the Journal of its proceedings and perform such other duties and functions as are assigned to the City Clerk by general laws of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, in effect at the time of the adoption of this Charter, by this Charter, or by Council. 
Section 3:14. - Organization. 
    On the first Monday in January of each year, the City Council shall meet and organize by choosing a Chairman and such other officers as Council may determine necessary from among its Members. If the first Monday is a Legal Holiday, the meeting shall be held the first day following. 
Section 3:15. - Procedure. 
(1)  Rules: The Council shall determine its own rules and Order of Business. 
(2)  Meetings: Council shall hold a regular meeting at least once each month at such time and place as the Council may prescribe by rule. 
(3)  Special meetings: Special meetings may be held on the call of the Mayor or of at least three (3) Members of the Council at such time and place and under such conditions as the Council may prescribe by rule. (Note: The forgoing change from four (4) to three (3) was made as a result of the successful referendum of November 6, 2001 and Ordinance of Council No. 50 of 2004, to allow for judicial economy and to maintain consistency with the legislative mandate of City Council and the Third Class City Code of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.) 
(4)  Meetings Open to the Public: All meetings shall be public; however, the Council may recess for discussion in a closed or executive session. 
(5)  Voting: All action shall be at a public session; shall require a majority vote of Council, and shall be by Roll Call vote, and the vote of each member of the Council shall be entered into the Minutes of the meeting. 
(6)  The Council shall provide for keeping of a Journal of its proceedings. The Journal shall be a public record. 
    Residents of the City shall be entitled to address Council on any pending ordinance or resolution in such manner as Council shall provide by rule. 
Section 3:16. - Intentionally Left Blank: 
Section 3:17. - Quorum. 
    A Quorum of Council shall be three (3) Members. 
(Ord. No. 50-04, § 1, 10-7-04) 
ARTICLE IV. - LEGISLATION 

Section 4:01. - Ordinances in general. 
    Council may legislate by passage of an ordinance. All ordinances introduced shall be kept in a place accessible to the public at all reasonable times. Action on all ordinances shall take place during public meetings. 
Section 4:02. - Form of ordinance. 
    Every ordinance shall have a title clearly expressing its subject and every ordinance shall contain only one subject. 
Section 4:03. - Procedure. 
    An ordinance may be introduced by any member at any regular or special meeting of the Council without vote. 
    The City Clerk shall distribute a copy to each Council Member and to the Mayor and shall file and make available a reasonable number of copies in the office of the City Clerk. 
Section 4:04. - Final passage of ordinance resolution. 
    A minimum of seven (7) days must intervene between introduction and passage of an ordinance unless Council finds and declares a public emergency, affecting life, health, property, or the public peace. 
Section 4:05. - Effective date of legislation. 
    Every adopted ordinance except emergency legislation shall become effective at the expiration of thirty (30) days after passage by Council and approval by the Mayor, or repassage by Council over the Mayor's veto, or at a date specified therein, but not less than ten (10) days after adoption. 
Section 4:06. - Emergency ordinance. 
    An emergency ordinance may be adopted to meet a public emergency affecting life, health, property or the public peace. An emergency ordinance shall be introduced in the form and manner prescribed for ordinance generally, except that it shall be plainly designated as an emergency ordinance and shall describe in clear and specific terms the nature of the emergency. Every emergency ordinance shall automatically stand repealed as of the 91st day following the date on which it was adopted, but this shall not prevent reenactment of the ordinance if the emergency still exists. 
Section 4:07. - Submission to mayor and veto power. 
    Before any ordinance takes effect it must first be submitted to the Mayor for approval. The Mayor shall sign the ordinance within ten (10) days if approved, but if not, shall return it to Council stating objections. Council shall at its next meeting, reconsider the ordinance and may pass it over the Mayor's veto by the affirmative vote of four (4) Members of Council. (Note: The forgoing change from five (5) to four (4) was made as a result of the successful referendum of November 6, 2001 and Ordinance of Council No. 50 of 2004, to allow for judicial economy and to maintain consistency with the legislative mandate of City Council and the Third Class City Code of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.) 
    If the Mayor fails within ten (10) days after any ordinance is submitted to him to sign the ordinance and return it to Council, such ordinance shall be considered adopted at the expiration of the ten (10) day period. 
Section 4:08. - Recording of ordinances. 
    All ordinances shall be contained in permanent separate record books. The ordinance book and all other actions taken by Council at a public meeting shall be open and available for public inspection at normal business hours. 
Section 4:09. - Codification of ordinances. 
    Within two (2) years after the effective date of this Charter the Council shall provide for a codification with an index of all ordinances of the City. No later than three (3) months after the close of each year, Council, with the assistance of the City's legal department, shall classify ordinances according to the division and subdivision of the Code for insertion in the Code during said year. 
Section 4:10. - Action by resolution or motion. 
    Nothing in the Article is intended to preclude Council from taking appropriate action by resolution or motion. 
ARTICLE V. - THE EXECUTIVE BRANCH 

Section 5:01. - The mayor. 
    The Executive and Administrative power of the City shall be vested in the Mayor. The Mayor shall have control of and be accountable for the Executive branch of the City Government. 
Section 5:02. - Qualifications of the mayor. 
    The Mayor shall be a qualified voter of the City of Wilkes-Barre and be required to devote full time and attention to the performance of the functions of the office. 
Section 5:03. - Election and term of mayor. 
    The Mayor shall be chosen by a plurality of the votes cast at the municipal election and shall, being duly sworn, serve for a term of four (4) years from the first Monday of January 1976, and until a successor is elected and qualified. If the first Monday is a legal holiday, the term shall commence the first day following. 
Section 5:04. - Vacancy in the office of mayor. 
    A vacancy in the office of Mayor shall be filled by a majority vote of the remaining Members of Council. If the Council fails to act within thirty (30) days following the occurrence of the vacancy, the Court of Common Pleas of Luzerne County shall, upon petition of three (3) Members of Council or ten (10) qualified electors of the City, fill the vacancy in such office by the appointment of a qualified resident of the City. The individual so appointed shall serve for the remainder of the unexpired term providing the vacancy occurs not more than ninety (90) days before the next general municipal election. 
    If the vacancy occurs more than ninety (90) days before the next general municipal election, the appointee as selected in the preceding paragraph shall serve until the first Monday of January next following said election. If a portion of the term remains beyond said date, an individual shall be elected at said general municipal election to serve from the first Monday of January following said election to the end of the term as provided in Section 5:03. 
    Until the vacancy is filled, the Chairman of Council shall act as Mayor. If the Chairman of Council should resign or be unable to act, the Mayor shall be chosen by a majority vote of the remaining Members of Council to serve as Mayor until the vacancy is filled by election. 
Section 5:05. - Forfeiture of office. 
    The Mayor shall forfeit office if the Mayor: 
(1)  Lacks at any time during the term of office any qualification for the office prescribed by this Charter or by law. 
(2)  Violates any express prohibition of this Charter. 
(3)  Is convicted of a crime which results in a sentence of imprisonment being imposed, the maximum of which is in excess of one year whether or not suspended. 
Section 5:06. - Compensation. 
    The Mayor shall receive an annual salary in the amount of $30,000 until such amount is changed by Council. 
    City Council may determine the annual salary of the Mayor by ordinance, but no ordinance changing such salary shall become effective until the date of commencement of the term of the Mayor elected at the next regular election, provided that such election follows the adoption of such ordinance by at least six (6) months. 
(Ord. No. 7-90, § 1, 3-8-90) 
Code reference- Compensation of elected officials, § 2-142. 
Note- (NOTE: City Council has changed the salary of the Mayor several times since the enactment of this Charter in 1975 and 1976. However, since the Charter grants the Council the right to change the salary by ordinance, a change in the Charter is not required and any ordinance passed need not be inserted as part of this Charter.) 
Section 5:07. - Powers and duties of the mayor. 
    The Mayor shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  Execute, enforce and obey the ordinances of the City and the laws of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania. 
(2)  Inform Council and the public at least once each year on the financial and general conditions and requirements of the City. 
(3)  Provide Council with such information concerning finances and general conditions of the City as requested by Council. 
(4)  Submit proposed legislation to Council. 
(5)  Perform such other duties and exercise such other powers as stated in this Charter by law or ordinance. 
(6)  Organize and supervise all City officers and employees except as otherwise provided by this Charter. 
(7)  Unless otherwise provided, be responsible for the employment of personnel necessary for the effective operation of the City government. 
Section 5:08. - Appointments by the mayor. 
    The Mayor shall appoint with the advice and consent of Council: 
(1)  A City Attorney (Solicitor) and such permanent assistant Solicitors as may be necessary. 
(2)  All members of Boards and Commissions. 
(3)  Members of Authorities as provided by law. Unless otherwise provided by statute, any person so appointed shall hold office, unless removed during the term, for the period for which the Mayor is elected and until a successor is appointed and qualified. 
Section 5:09. - Removals by the mayor. 
    The Mayor may remove from office anyone appointed pursuant to Section 5:08, (1) and (2) unless otherwise provided by law. 
Section 5:10. - Deputy mayor. 
    In the event of the Mayor's temporary absence from the City, or temporary disability, the Director of Administrative Services shall act as Deputy Mayor. The Deputy Mayor shall exercise all the powers and discharge all the duties of the Mayor, except the power of appointment or removal from office. 
Section 5:11. - Director of administrative services. 
    The Mayor shall appoint an officer of the City who shall have the title of Director of Administrative Services. 
Section 5:12. - Director of planning. 
    The Mayor shall appoint an officer of the City who shall have the title of Director of Planning. 
Section 5:13. - Table of organization. 
    The Mayor shall annually file with Council no later than thirty (30) days after final adoption of the General Fund Budget, a Table of Organization describing the organization of all municipal agencies of the City government. 
ARTICLE VI. - ADMINISTRATION 

Section 6:01. - Director of administrative services. 
    The Director of Administrative Services shall be responsible for the operations of all City departments and agencies except as otherwise provided by this Charter or the Administrative Code of the City. 
Section 6:02. - Qualifications. 
    The Director of Administrative Services shall have administrative and executive ability as demonstrated by five (5) years of experience at the executive or administrative level either in public service or private industry, and such other qualifications as may be required by the City Administrative Code or Position Classification Plan. 
Section 6:03. - Vacancy in office of director of administrative services. 
    Should the Mayor fail to appoint a Director of Administrative Services within sixty (60) days of being sworn in as Mayor, or within sixty (60) days of the occurrence of any vacancy in the position, the Council shall make the appointment. 
Section 6:04. - Powers and duties. 
    The Director of Administrative Services, subject to the approval of the Mayor, shall appoint a Finance Officer and the heads of the departments under his direction and shall prescribe, subject to this Charter and the Administrative Code, rules and standards governing the matters under his jurisdiction. 
    The Director of Administrative Services shall: 
(1)  Keep the Mayor advised of the condition and future needs of the City and make such recommendations, as he shall deem necessary. 
(2)  Be responsible for the preparation of the Annual Budget, revenue collection, accounting and all other fiscal operations. 
(3)  Conduct research in administrative management for the improvement of the organization and practices of City government. 
(4)  Develop procedures and establish forms, which will provide efficiency and economy in the conduct of the City government. 
(5)  Perform such other duties as may be required by the Mayor, this Charter, or the Administrative Code. 
Section 6:05. - Removal. 
    The Director of Administrative Services may be removed by the Mayor. If the Mayor removes the Director of Administrative Services, the Mayor shall specify in writing and in detail his reasons for doing so and shall present this written statement to the Director of Administrative Services and the Council. 
ARTICLE VII. - PLANNING[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Pennsylvania Municipalities Planning Code, 53 P.S. § 10101 et seq. 

Section 7:01. - Director of planning. 
    The Director of Planning shall be responsible for the administration of the City's Comprehensive Plan and for other such functions as may be required by this Charter, the City Administrative Code, and the laws of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania effective as of the date of the adoption of this Charter. 
Section 7:02. - Qualifications. 
    The Director of Planning shall have had at least five (5) years experience in municipal planning with at least two (2) years of this experience at the Executive or Administrative level. 
Section 7:03. - Vacancy in office of director of planning. 
    Should the Mayor fail to appoint a Director of Planning within sixty (60) days of being sworn in as Mayor, or within sixty (60) days of the occurrence of any vacancy in the position, the Council shall make the appointment. 
Section 7:04. - Powers and duties. 
    The Director of Planning shall: 
(1)  Prepare, administer and keep the Mayor, City Council, and the City Planning Commission informed on all plans and programs affecting the physical development of the City. 
(2)  Coordinate and participate in the preparation of the City's Capital Improvement Program and Capital Budget. 
(3)  Advise the City Planning Commission in the exercise of its responsibilities and provide necessary staff assistance. 
(4)  Perform such other duties as may be required by the Mayor. 
Section 7:05. - Removal. 
    The Director of Planning may be removed by the Mayor. If the Mayor removes the Director of Planning, the Mayor shall specify in writing and in detail his reasons for doing so and shall present this written statement to the Director and to the City Planning Commission and to City Council. 
ARTICLE VIII. - LEGAL SERVICES (LAW DEPARTMENT) 

Section 8:01. - City attorney. 
    The City Attorney shall serve as chief legal advisor to the Mayor, the Council, and all City departments and agencies and shall represent the City in all legal proceedings and shall perform such other duties prescribed by this Charter or the City Administrative Code. 
Section 8:02. - Staff. 
    The City Attorney shall be a full-time employee of the City, responsible for staffing the City's legal office and may appoint temporary assistants as required. 
ARTICLE IX. - FINANCIAL PROCEDURES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal finance, 53 P.S. § 5401 et seq. 

Section 9:01. - Fiscal year. 
    The fiscal Year of the City shall begin on the first day of January and end on the last day of each year unless changed by the City Administrative Code. If there is such change subject to the proviso that the corresponding period or periods of time (or intervals) will prevail with respect to the dates set forth in Sections 9:02, 9:05, 9:06, and 9:09, then the dates provided therein will be changed by the Council accordingly. 
Section 9:02. - Submission of general fund budget. 
    On or before the fifteenth day of October of each year, the Mayor shall submit to the Council a budget for the ensuing year. Should the fifteenth day of October fall on a Saturday, Sunday or legally declared holiday, the final date of submission shall be the last working day preceding the date. 
Section 9:03. - Budget message. 
    The Budget shall be accompanied by a message, which shall include: 
(1)  An explanation of the expenditures and revenues in the proposed budget, indicating and explaining major change from the current year. 
(2)  An outline of proposed programs and an explanation of new, expanded, or abolished programs or functions. 
(3)  A summary of the City's debt position. 
(4)  Such other material that will inform the Council and the public of municipal goals. 
Section 9:04. - Budget. 
    The Budget shall provide a complete financial plan of all the City funds and activities for the ensuing Fiscal Year, and except as required by this Charter or the Administrative Code, shall be in such form, as the Mayor deems desirable. 
Section 9:05. - Capital program. 
    The Mayor shall present to Council, no later than September first of each year, a six (6) year Capital Improvement Program. The Program shall include: 
(1)  A list of all capital improvements which are proposed to be undertaken during the next six (6) years. 
(2)  Cost estimates and recommended financing and scheduling for each project. 
(3)  The estimated annual operating and maintenance cost of each project. 
(4)  The Capital Budget for the coming year. 
Section 9:06. - Council action on budget. 
    The Council shall hold a public hearing prior to the adoption of the Budget. Notification of the time and place of such hearing together with a general summary of the proposed Budget shall be published in one or more newspapers of general circulation at least two (2) weeks before the public hearing. The public hearing shall be held no later than December first. 
    After the public hearing, the Council may adopt the Budget with or without amendment. Council may amend the Budget by increasing or decreasing program funding, except debt requirements, or by adding or deleting programs. 
    If the amended Budget increases, decreases, or readjusts funding requirements by more than five (5) percent, or adds or deletes a program, the Budget shall be returned to the Mayor immediately for his comment and resubmission to the Council within three (3) normal City work days. 
    Council shall provide for another public hearing to be held within five (5) days after the Mayor has resubmitted the Budget. 
    The Council shall adopt the Budget on or before the thirty-first (31st) day of December of the Fiscal Year currently ending. 
Section 9:07. - Failure to adopt budget. 
    If the Council fails to adopt the Budget pursuant to Section 9:06 of this Charter, the Budget as last submitted by the Mayor shall be deeded adopted. 
Section 9:08. - Budget amendment. 
    During the month of January next following any municipal election at which Council members have been elected, the Mayor may submit an amended budget to Council and Council shall complete final consideration of the amended budget by February fifteenth (15th) of the same year. 
Section 9:09. - Council action on capital program. 
    The Council shall hold a public hearing on the Capital Improvement Program and Capital Budget for the ensuing year. Notification of the time and place of such hearing together with a general summary of the proposed program and Budget shall be published in one or more newspapers of general circulation at least two (2) weeks before the hearing. 
    After the public hearing, the Council shall adopt the Capital Program and the Capital Budget, with or without amendment on or before the thirty-first (31st) day of December of the current Fiscal Year. 
Section 9:10. - Tax levy. 
    Council shall establish tax rates and levy on the various subjects of taxation. 
Section 9:11. - Amendments after adoption. 
(1)  Emergency appropriations may be made by the Council to meet a public emergency affecting life, health, property or the public peace. Such appropriations may be made by emergency ordinance in accordance with the provisions of Section 4:06 of this Charter. 
(2)  Supplemental appropriations may be made by the Council by ordinance upon certification by the Mayor that there are available for appropriation revenues in excess of those estimated in the Budget. 
(3)  Transfer of appropriations may be made in accordance with provisions of the Administrative Code. 
Section 9:12. - Lapse of appropriations. 
    Every appropriation, except an appropriation for a Capital expenditure, shall lapse at the close of the Fiscal Year to the extent that it has not been expended or encumbered. 
Section 9:13. - Administration of budget. 
    The Mayor shall supervise the administration of the Annual and the Capital Budgets. 
ARTICLE X. - AUDIT AND CONTROL 

Section 10:01. - The controller. 
    The office of Audit and Control shall be headed by a City Controller. 
Section 10:02. - Qualifications of the controller. 
    The Controller shall be a qualified voter of the City of Wilkes-Barre and be required to devote full time and attention to the performance of the functions of the office. 
Section 10:03. - Election and term of controller. 
    The Controller shall be chosen by a plurality of the votes cast at the municipal election and shall, being duly sworn, serve for a term of four (4) years from the first Monday of January 1976, and until a successor is elected and qualified. If the first Monday is a Legal Holiday, the term shall commence the first day following. 
State Law reference- Municipal election shall be held biennially on the Tuesday next following the first Monday of November in each odd-numbered year, 53 P.S. § 2752. 
Section 10:04. - Vacancy in the office of controller. 
    A vacancy in the office of Controller shall be filled by a majority vote of the remaining Members of Council. If the Council fails to act within thirty (30) days following the occurrence of the vacancy, the Court of Common Pleas of Luzerne County shall, upon petition of three (3) Members of Council or ten (10) qualified electors of the City, fill the vacancy in such office by the appointment of a qualified resident of the City. The individual so appointed shall serve for the remainder of the unexpired term providing the vacancy occurs not more than ninety (90) days before the next general municipal election. 
    If the vacancy occurs more than ninety (90) days before the next general municipal election, the appointee as selected in the preceding paragraph shall serve until the first Monday of January next following said election. If a portion of the term remains beyond said date, an individual shall be elected at said general municipal election to serve from the first Monday of January following said election to the end of the term as provided in Section 10:03. 
Section 10:05. - Forfeiture of office. 
    The Controller shall forfeit office if the Controller: 
(1)  Lacks at any time during the term of office any qualification for the office prescribed by this Charter or by law. 
(2)  Violates any express prohibition of this Charter. 
(3)  Is convicted of a crime which results in a sentence of imprisonment being imposed, the maximum of which is in excess of one year whether or not suspended. 
Section 10:06. - Compensation. 
    The Controller shall receive an annual salary in the amount of $15,000 until such amount is changed by Council. 
    City Council may determine the annual salary of the Controller by ordinance, but no ordinance changing such salary shall become effective until the date of commencement of the term of Controller elected at the next regular election, provided that such election follows the adoption of such ordinance by at least six (6) months. 
(Ord. No. 7-90, § 1, 3-8-90) 
Code reference- Compensation of elected officials, § 2.142. 
Note- (NOTE: City Council has changed the salaries of the Controller several times since the enactment of this Charter in 1975 and 1976. However, since the Charter grants the Council the right to change the salary by ordinance, a change in the Charter is not required and any ordinance passed need not be inserted as part of this Charter.) 
Section 10:07. - Powers and duties of the controller. 
    The Controller shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  Examine, audit and verify all books, records and accounts of the various administrative and legislative units, departments, offices or officials under the control or supervision of the Mayor or Council, and for this purpose have access to all such books, records and accounts at any time. 
(2)  Examine and approve for payment all contracts, purchase orders, and other documents by which the City incurs financial obligations, having ascertained before approval that monies have been duly appropriated or provided for and allotted to meet such obligations. 
(3)  Audit and approve all bills, invoices, payrolls and other evidence of claims, demands, or charges paid from City funds. 
(4)  Submit reports to the City Council and the Mayor of any records deemed in violation of law or acceptable accounting procedures. 
(5)  Prepare and submit to Council and to the Mayor within sixty (60) days of the end of every fiscal year a complete financial statement of the affairs of the City with such comments, as the Controller deems appropriate. 
ARTICLE XI. - PERSONNEL 

Section 11:01. - Merit principle. 
    Appointments and promotions of subordinate officers and employees within departments shall be made by the departmental head on the basis of a personnel system which shall include written procedures for appointment and promotion based on merit and fitness as demonstrated by examination or other evidence of position competence. The personnel system shall be governed by personnel rules, which shall be established by the executive (Mayor) and submitted to the Council for its review and comments unless otherwise provided for or arrived at by collective bargaining. The personnel rules may provide for: 
(1)  The classification of all municipal positions, based on the duties, authority and responsibility of each position, with adequate provision for reclassification of any position whenever warranted by change of circumstances. 
(2)  A pay plan for all municipal positions. 
(3)  Methods for determining the merit and fitness of candidates for appointments and promotion. 
(4)  The policies and procedures regulating reduction in force and disciplinary action, including suspension and removal of employees. 
(5)  The hours of work, and provisions for sick and vacation leave and holidays, and provisions for overtime compensation. 
(6)  Grievance procedures, including procedures for the hearing of grievances. 
(7)  Other practices and procedures necessary to the administration of the municipal personnel system. 
Section 11:02. - Political activity of employees. 
    Employees of the City are especially prohibited from engaging in political activity during working hours and at any time utilizing the City offices for political activity. 
Section 11:03. - Labor relations officer. 
    The Mayor shall appoint a Labor Relations Officer who shall have had at least five (5) years experience in labor negotiations and collective bargaining. 
    The Labor Relations Officer may be employed on a retainer basis and shall represent the City together with one or more persons when so designated by the Mayor in labor negotiations and perform such other functions as required by the Administrative Code. 
ARTICLE XII. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Section 12:01. - Administrative code. 
    The City Council shall adopt an ordinance which shall be known as the city Administrative Code within sixty (60) days after the effective date of this Charter. 
    The Administrative Code shall establish the organizational structure and general operating procedures for the City government and appointed officers of the City. 
Section 12:02. - Abolition of elective office. 
    The office of the City Treasurer, which has been heretofore filled by election, is abolished. The duties attending to said office will be assigned to others under the terms of this Charter and the Administrative Code. 
Section 12:03. - Prohibitions. 
(1)  No elected official shall hold an elective office in a political party during the term for which the member is elected. 
(2)  No elected official shall hold any compensated appointive City office or employment until one year after the expiration of the term for which the member was elected. 
Section 12:04. - Fidelity bond. 
    All officers of the City shall file a surety bond with the City Clerk conditioned for the faithful discharge of their duties prior to commencing the duties of their office. The amount of each of the bonds shall be determined by Council. 
Section 12:05. - Penalties. 
    Council may include a penalty provision in any ordinance. 
Section 12:06. - Periodic review of Charter. 
    The Mayor and Council shall review this Charter at least once following decennial census report. Following review, a joint written report, together with any recommendation for amendment to the Charter shall be made to the Citizens of the City. 
    Amendment to this Charter shall be in conformity with the provisions of Act 62 of 1972, as Amended. 
Section 12:07. - Severability. 
    If any provision of this Charter cannot take effect because of the judgment of any court of competent jurisdiction, the remaining provisions of this Charter shall be given full force and effect as completely as if the provision or provisions held invalid had not been included herein. 
ARTICLE XIII. - TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS 

Section 13:01. - Officers and employees. 
    Nothing in this Charter, except as otherwise specifically provided, shall affect or impair the rights or privileges of persons who are officers or employees of the City at the time of its adoption. 
    Except as specifically provided by this Charter, if at the time this Charter takes effect, a City administrative officer or employee holds any office or position which is or can be abolished by or under this Charter, the person shall continue in such office or position until appropriate action is taken under provision of this Charter. 
Section 13:02. - Transfer of powers. 
    If a City Department, office, or agency is abolished by this Charter, the powers and duties given it by law may be transferred to the City Department, office or agency as designated in this Charter or the City Administrative Code. 
Section 13:03. - Ordinances superseded. 
    All City ordinances, resolutions, orders, and regulations which are in force when this Charter becomes fully effective are repealed to the extent that they are inconsistent with the effective operation of this Charter or of any ordinance adopted pursuant thereto. 
    To the extent that the Constitution and laws of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania permit, all laws relating to or affecting this City which are in force when this Charter becomes fully effective are superseded to the extent that they are inconsistent with the effective operation of this Charter or of ordinances adopted thereto. 
Section 13:04. - Ordinances continued. 
    All City ordinances, resolutions, rules and regulations, or portions thereof, in force when this Charter takes effect and not in conflict herewith, are hereby continued in force and effect until amended, superseded, or expired by their own terms. 
Section 13:05. - Schedule. 
    This Charter shall become effective on the first Monday of January, 1976.
