APPENDIX A - ADMINISTRATIVE CODE 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATIVE CODE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Mandate for administrative code, § 12:01. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-21. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the administrative code of the City of Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 1.01, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-22. - Purpose. 
    In accordance with the provisions of Act 62 of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, and in keeping with the mandate of Article 12, Section 12:01 of the Home Rule Charter of the City of Wilkes-Barre, the City Council of the City of Wilkes-Barre finds it necessary and proper to establish this Administrative Code providing for: 
(1)  The internal administrative structure of the municipality. 
(2)  The method of appointment of various municipal officers (and employees). 
(3)  The powers and duties of the legislative and executive branches of government. 
(4)  Organizational and procedural matters relating to the legislative and executive branches. 
(5)  Regulations and procedures pertaining to boards, commissions and authorities. 
(6)  Such other regulations as deemed necessary by city council for the proper disposition of municipal affairs. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 1.02, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-23. - Definitions. 
    Administrative branch shall mean those departments, bureaus, agencies or authorities, and their assigned personnel who are accountable to and under the authority of the chief executive officer, not to include, however the officers and personnel of the city controller or the city clerk. 
    Charter shall mean the Home Rule Charter of the City of Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania. 
    Chief executive officer shall mean the Mayor of the City of Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania. 
    City shall mean the city of Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania. 
    Council shall mean the City Council of the City of Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania. 
    For the purposes of this document, the words full time and attention as they apply to the offices of the mayor and controller shall be construed as requiring as much of their time, talent and efforts as shall be necessary to faithfully and efficiently administer the laws and provisions of the city and of the respective officers. 
    In any event, it shall require that other personal activities such as, but not limited to, business or professional pursuits or other occupations shall be subordinated to the duties of the offices to which the persons were elected. It is not the intent of this definition that persons elected to their offices need divest themselves of business, abandon a profession, or resign from a remunerative occupation unless the continued pursuit of same would interfere with the person's ability to carry out the duties of office. 
    For the purposes of this document, the words full time as they apply to the city attorney shall be construed as meaning that said attorney shall generally observe the same working schedule as other executive and administrative officers of the city and shall be available for advise or consultation during those hours. 
    With sufficient reasons, the mayor may direct permanent or temporary variations to the schedule of the city attorney to improve efficiency or to award compensatory time. 
    Chairperson shall mean that member of city council elected by the council to serve as presiding officer of that body and perform such other duties as deemed necessary by council. 
    Law shall mean all applicable laws of the United States of America, the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, the Wilkes-Barre City Charter, and all city ordinances. 
    Ordinance shall mean all ordinances adopted by the City of Wilkes-Barre, including this article. 
    State shall mean the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 1.03, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Secs. 2-24-2-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LEGISLATIVE BRANCH[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Council-Legislative branch, Art. III. 

Sec. 2-31. - Application of Charter. 
    All matters pertaining to the eligibility, election and term of office of members of council, and the composition, compensation and filling of council member vacancies, shall be as provided for in the Charter. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 2.01, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-32. - Organization. 
(a)  On the first Monday in January of each year, the city council shall meet and organize by choosing a chairperson and such other officers as council may determine necessary from among its members. If the first Monday is a legal holiday, the meeting shall be held the first day following. 
(b)  The council may, at any time, provide from its members for standing and ad hoc committees to assist it in overseeing municipal functions, to gather information for the development of municipal policy, to undertake investigations and to perform such other tasks as may be necessary for the conduct of municipal affairs. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 2.02, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Charter reference- Similar provisions to subsection (a), § 3:14. 
Sec. 2-33. - Office of the city clerk. 
(a)  The council shall appoint an officer of the city who shall have the title of city clerk. The city clerk shall give notice of council meetings to its members and the public, keep the journal of its proceedings and perform such other duties and functions as are assigned to the city clerk by general laws of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania in effect at the time of the adoption of the Charter, by this Code, or by Council. 
(b)  The city clerk shall be directly accountable to council and may hire such staff as deemed necessary, but only by consent of council. The salary schedule and administrative budget of the office of the city clerk shall be determined by council and appropriated and listed as a distinct category in the general fund budget. 
(c)  The hours of work, provisions for sick and vacation leave, overtime compensation and other personnel policies relating to the office of the city clerk and its appointed staff shall be set by council. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 2.03, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Charter reference- Similar provisions to subsection (a), § 3:13. 
Sec. 2-34. - Meetings and procedures. 
(a)  Council shall hold a regular meeting at least once each month at such time and place as the council may prescribe by rule. 
(b)  A quorum of council shall be three (3) members. Accordingly, the presence of a quorum at any regular or special meeting of council shall constitute a legitimate assembly of council capable of transacting such municipal affairs as are granted to the legislative branch by the Charter or by-laws. 
(c)  All meetings of council shall be public, except for the provisions cited in subsection (7). 
(1)  The city clerk shall provide for public notice of all regular and special meetings as required by law. 
(2)  Residents of the city shall be entitled to address council on any pending ordinances or resolutions in such manner as council shall provide by rule or any matter as the public deems necessary and in such manner as council shall provide by rule. 
(d)  Special meetings. Special meetings may be held on the call of the mayor or at least three (3) members of council at such time and place and under such conditions as the council may prescribe by rule, including but not limited to the adoption of a rule to restrict the agenda of a special meeting to a special item of business. The city clerk shall provide written notice of the time, date and place of such meeting to all members of council at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to the convening of any such meeting. 
(e)  Emergency meetings. Emergency meetings may be convened and conducted for the purpose of acting upon an emergency involving a clear and present danger to life or property. The city clerk shall attempt to give written and oral notice of an emergency meeting, and shall make every effort to notify members of council and the mayor of such meeting through the most expeditious means. Furthermore, members of city council shall not be in violation of subsection (c) when such emergency meetings are held. 
(f)  Voting. All official action shall be at a public session; shall require a majority vote of council; and shall be by roll call vote, and the vote of each member of the council shall be entered into the minutes of the meeting. 
(g)  Executive sessions. During any meeting of council the members may recess for discussion in a closed or executive session, but only for the purpose of considering dismissal or disciplining of, or hearing complaints or charges brought against an elected officer, an employee, or any other public agent unless such person requests a public hearing, or considering actions of the deliberating body with respect to labor negotiations. Such recess for discussion in a closed or executive session shall be upon notification to the public present and shall be for a period not to exceed thirty (30) minutes. 
(h)  Council shall determine its own rules and order of business. 
(i)  Council may act by the adoption of an ordinance, resolution or motion and such adoption shall require a majority vote of council at a public session. 
(j)  A majority vote of council shall be defined as a majority of those present, provided, however, the number present shall be at least a quorum. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 2.04, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007; Ord. No. 32-2007, § 1(2:04), 1-10-08) 
Charter reference- Procedure, § 3:15; quorum, § 3:17. 
Sec. 2-35. - General powers and duties. 
(a)  Generally. Except as otherwise provided by the Charter, all powers of the city shall be vested in the council and the council shall provide for exercise thereof and for the performance of all duties and obligations imposed on the city by law. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 2.05, 7-8-76; Ord. No. 8-02, § I, 3-26-02; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Charter reference- General powers and duties, § 3:08; investigations, § 3:10; removal powers, § 3:11; independent audit, § 3:12. 
Sec. 2-35.1. - Enumeration of powers. 
(a)  Legislation. The council shall legislate by adoption of ordinances as provided by the Charter, by law or by this Code. 
(b)  Investigations. Council, by ordinance, may make or cause to be made investigations, studies of municipal affairs or the conduct of city departments, bureaus or agencies. 
(c)  Audits. The council shall provide for an independent audit of all accounts of the city following the close of each fiscal year and may provide, by resolution, for audits of any City department, authority, commission or agency. 
(d)  Subpoena. Council may subpoena witnesses in any investigation of municipal affairs, and may provide for the administering of oaths, the production of evidence and the taking of testimony. 
(e)  Appropriations. Council shall appropriate all monies it deems necessary for the conduct of all branches of government in accordance with the requirements of the Charter or this article. 
(f)  Taxation. Council shall establish tax rates and levy on the various subjects of taxation. 
(g)  Budget. Council may amend the budget prior to or after its adoption, by increasing or decreasing program funds or by adding or deleting programs, except for debt requirements, and in accordance with the requirements of the Charter and of this article. The term "budget" shall mean the general fund, liquid funds and capital budgets of the city and any special purpose program budgets which are administered by the mayor or other agencies, bureaus or authorities of the city, unless otherwise provided by federal or state law. 
(h)  Removal powers. Council shall have the power to remove from office, for cause set forth in the Charter, any person appointed to an office by council or with the advice and consent of council, including the city clerk and the staff of the office of the city clerk; the city attorney and the attorney's assistants; all members of boards and commissions; members of authorities as provided by law, and such other officers and employees that may be appointed by council. 
(i)  (1)  Permits. Any person, individual, entity or corporation who or which intends to demolish all or part of any structure or building within the City of Wilkes-Barre shall first be required to obtain a permit from the office of code enforcement. Said permit must be obtained prior to the demolition of the structure or building. 
(2)  Inspections. The office of code enforcement shall inspect the structure or building prior to the issuance of the demolition permit to confirm, to the best of their ability, that all ordinances are being met and that there are no environmental, structural or other hazards which may be present. The office of code enforcement shall also inspect to ensure that the person, individual, entity or corporation performing the demolition work is qualified to do so, depending on the structure. 
(3)  Historic preservation. If the office of code enforcement receives a demolition request for a property or structure which has or may have historical significance, or if the property is listed on the historical register, the code enforcement officer shall have the authority, with the assistance of any certified professional, to deny the permit pending the final determination of its historical significance. The office of code enforcement reserves the right to hire, appoint or seek the advice of qualified professionals who can make an independent determination as to the historical significance of the property or structure. 
(4)  Asbestos abatement. No permit shall be provided by the office of code enforcement unless and until the person, individual, entity or corporation making the demolition request provides a certification from an authorized professional regarding the removal and abatement of any asbestos which may be in the building. 
(5)  Sewer line. Prior to demolition, the person, individual, entity or corporation performing the demolition work or the owner of the property shall provide to the city the exact location of the capped sewer line for the purposes of any new construction which may occur in the future. 
(6)  Denial of permits. The office of code enforcement shall have the power to deny a demolition permit for cause and the same may be appealed to the board of appeals. Nothing contained herein shall permit the office of code enforcement to deny a permit unless for a valid, constitutionally-protected purpose. The office of code enforcement shall be permitted the right to enlist the services of a qualified expert or engineer to support their findings. The cost of the same shall be borne by the contractor. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 2.06, 7-8-76; Ord. No. 8-02, § I, 3-26-02; Ord. No. 4-05, §§ I-IV, 4-14-05; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Charter reference- General powers and duties, § 3:08; investigations, § 3:10; removal powers, § 3:11; independent audit, § 3:12. 
Sec. 2-36. - Procedures for removal from office. 
(a)  In all matters of removal, council shall first determine that circumstances warrant the convening of a hearing. A hearing shall be convened only after a resolution to that effect is adopted by a majority of council. 
(b)  In said resolution council shall direct that written notice stating the time, date and place of such hearing be given to all council members, to the mayor, and to the official who is subject to removal. 
(c)  Any official who is subject to a hearing on removal under the Charter may conclude that he or she is in wrongful violation of the Charter provisions governing removal and may submit a written resignation to council and the mayor and waive the right to a hearing. The waiving of said hearing is, however, to be at the discretion of council. 
(d)  Any official who is subject to a hearing on removal shall have the right to be present at any hearing to examine his or her privilege of continuing in office. Any such official shall have the privilege of retaining counsel and of calling to testify any person he shall deem necessary to support his position. The hiring of counsel or the appearance of any person on behalf of the official to be dismissed shall be at the expense of the official and not of the city. 
(e)  Any official who is subject to hearing on removal under this section shall be given written notice, by certified mail, at least twenty (20) days prior to the date set for the hearing. Such notice shall declare the cause of the action, and the reasons for pursing such action, citing the provisions of the Charter or this Code, which are applicable. The notice shall further declare the time and place of hearing for consideration of removal and the privileges accorded an official who is subject to such hearing. 
(f)  The act of removal from office shall require the adoption of a resolution of council declaring and citing the causes for removal. 
(g)  Any official who is removed from office under the provisions of this section shall have the right to petition the appropriate Commonwealth Court for final disposition of said action. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 2.07, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Charter reference- Removal powers, § 3:11. 
Sec. 2-37. - Forfeiture of office. 
    Members of council shall be required to forfeit office in accordance with the provisions of Section 3:06 of the Charter. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 2.08, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-38. - Prohibited. 
    The council or any members shall not direct, control or interfere with any employee of the administrative branch. However, a member of council may communicate with an employee of the administrative branch for the purpose of inquiries pertaining to municipal business. Council or any of its members, or any authorized committee of council may request the mayor to provide for the presence of any member of the administrative branch at a meeting of council or a committee of council, for the purpose of securing information and/or advice in the development of municipal policy. In addition, the council may require the presence of any member of the administrative branch subsequent to the adoption of an ordinance calling for an investigation or audit of any municipal affairs and the issuance of a subpoena in connection with such investigation or audit. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 2.09, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Secs. 2-39-2-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LEGISLATIVE PROCEDURE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Legislation, Art. IV. 
Cross reference- Council rules and procedures concerning ordinances, resolutions and motions, Char. App. B § 2-140.9. 

Sec. 2-46. - Introduction of ordinances. 
(a)  The council may legislate by passage of an ordinance. Any member of council may introduce a proposed ordinance at any meeting of council. Every proposed ordinance shall be introduced in writing and may be given a first reading upon its introduction. Every ordinance shall be in a form deemed suitable by council and shall be limited to one (1) subject whose title shall be clearly expressed at the beginning of the ordinance. 
(b)  An ordinance, which repeals or amends an existing ordinance shall set out the section or subsection to be repealed or amended and shall identify the proposed changes. 
(c)  Every proposed ordinance shall be distributed by the city clerk to members of council and to the mayor. After passage at first reading, a reasonable number of copies shall be kept available for the public in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 3.01, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Charter reference- Ordinances in general, § 4:01; form of ordinance, § 4:02; procedure, § 4:03. 
Sec. 2-47. - Action requiring an ordinance. 
    In addition to the requirements provided by law or the Charter, the council shall act by ordinance to: 
(1)  Amend any ordinance. 
(2)  Alter or abolish any governmental entity of the municipality. 
(3)  Provide for a fine or other penalty or establish a rule or regulation for which a fine or penalty is imposed. 
(4)  Adopt budgets. 
(5)  Levy taxes or impose service charges or permit fees. 
(6)  Grant, renew, or establish a franchise. 
(7)  Adopt or amend a zoning, subdivision or other regulation pertaining to land use. 
(8)  Undertake investigations. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 3.02, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-48. - Procedures relating to passage of ordinances. 
(a)  Except for emergency ordinances, all ordinances shall require two (2) readings. The first reading may occur upon the introduction of the proposed ordinance during a regular or special meeting of council. 
(b)  Proposed ordinances shall be distributed in accordance with section 2-46(c) prior to the first reading period. No action shall be taken with respect to any proposed ordinance, except emergency ordinances, until the minimum of seven (7) days has passed since the date of the first reading. 
(c)  The second reading of a proposed ordinance shall occur at a subsequent meeting of council provided such meeting occurs after seven (7) days interim as required in subsection (b) above. 
(d)  The passage of an ordinance shall require affirmative votes of a majority of Council. 
(e)  Every adopted ordinance except emergency ordinances shall become effective at the expiration of thirty (30) days after passage by council and approval by the mayor, or a repassage by council and approval by the mayor's veto, or at a date specified therein, but not less than ten (10) days after adoption. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 3.03, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Charter reference- Procedure, § 4:03; final passage of ordinances, § 4:04; effective date of legislation, § 4:05. 
Sec. 2-49. - Submission to mayor and veto power. 
(a)  Before any ordinance takes effect it must first be submitted to the mayor for approval. The mayor shall sign the ordinance within ten (10) days of approval or, if he does not sign, shall return it to council stating his objections. Council may at its next meeting reinstate the ordinance and may pass it over the Mayor's veto by the affirmative vote of four (4) members of Council. 
(b)  If the mayor fails within ten (10) days after any ordinance is submitted to him to sign the ordinance and return it to council, such ordinance shall be considered adopted at the expiration of the ten (10) days. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 3.04, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007; Ord. No. 18-2008, § 1, 9-11-2008) 
Charter reference- Similar provisions, § 4:07. 
Sec. 2-50. - Emergency ordinances. 
(a)  Council may adopt, repeal or reenact emergency ordinances in accordance with Article IV, Section 4:06 of the Charter. 
(b)  Emergency ordinances shall require only one (1) reading and may be adopted and made effective on the same day as such ordinance is presented at the council meeting. 
(c)  Ordinances of any emergency nature shall be plainly written as such and shall contain a declaration stating that an emergency exists and describing it in clear and specific terms. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 3.05, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-51. - Recording and codification of ordinances. 
    The recording and codification of ordinances shall be as provided for in the Charter and in such other manner as may be approved by council. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 3.06, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Charter reference- Recording of ordinances, § 4:08; codification of ordinances, § 4:09. 
Sec. 2-52. - Actions of council by resolution. 
(a)  Council may act by the adoption of resolution when, in the opinion of a majority of its members, the passage of an ordinance is deemed inappropriate to the business under consideration by council. 
(b)  Council may adopt resolutions to: 
(1)  Establish its rules of procedure. 
(2)  Establish standing or ad hoc committees. 
(3)  Direct the city clerk to undertake various tasks. 
(4)  Undertake the preparation of reports or studies. 
(5)  Request information or advice from personnel in the administrative branch. 
(6)  Invoke special ceremonial proceedings. 
(7)  Appoint personnel or confirm appointments. 
(c)  In addition to the preceding sections, the council may wish to adopt resolutions, which reflect the opinion, attitude or position of a majority of its members with respect to any municipal issue. The act of resolution may be appropriate where it is the sense of council that its position on any issue should be clear and uniquely identifiable from that of the chief executive, other units of government or other municipal agencies. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 3.07, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Charter reference- Action by resolution, § 4:10. 
Sec. 2-53. - Actions of council by motion. 
    The act of motion shall be used by council within the context of parliamentary procedures as it adopts to dispose of its order of business. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 3.08, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Charter reference- Action by motion, § 4:10. 
Secs. 2-54-2-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - MAYOR[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Charter reference- The executive branch, Art. V. 

Sec. 2-61. - Generally. 
(a)  The executive and administrative power of the city shall be vested in the mayor who, as chief executive officer, shall have control of and be accountable for the executive branch of the city government. 
(b)  All matters relating to qualifications, election and term of office, vacancy, forfeiture and compensation of the mayor shall be as provided for in the Charter. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 4.01, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Charter reference- Similar provisions to subsection (a), § 5:01. 
Sec. 2-62. - Powers and duties. 
    The mayor shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  Execute, enforce and obey the ordinances of the city and the laws of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania. 
(2)  Inform council and the public at least once each year on the financial and general conditions and requirements of the city. 
(3)  Provide council with such information concerning finances and general conditions of the city as requested by the council. 
(4)  Submit proposed legislation to council. 
(5)  Perform such other duties and exercise such other powers as stated in the Charter, by law or by ordinance. 
(6)  Organize and supervise all city officers and employees except as otherwise provided by the Charter and the administrative code. 
(7)  Unless otherwise provided, be responsible for the employment of personnel necessary for effective operation of the city government. 
(8)  Pursuant to subsections (6) and (7), above, the mayor may prescribe administrative regulations to: 
a.  Authorize a department head or other officer responsible to the mayor to appoint or remove subordinates under any department, unless otherwise provided by the Charter. 
b.  Designate an officer or employee to perform the duties of any office or position in the administrative branch unless otherwise provided by the Charter or by law. 
c.  Prescribe, or delegate the responsibility to prescribe, such rules and regulations as shall be deemed necessary for the operation of the administrative branch. 
d.  Direct any department or office in the administrative branch to perform for any other department or office. 
(9)  The mayor shall sign and execute on behalf of the city, together with the controller and such other officers as prescribed in this Code, all bonds, notes, contracts and written obligations for the city. 
(10)  The mayor shall sign and execute all intergovernmental agreements or contracts for the receipt and expenditure of federal or state funds, or for the purpose of the city's financial and/or other participation in any intergovernmental undertaking involving the city or any department, office, or agency thereof, subject to the adoption of a resolution or ordinance by council. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 4.02, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Charter reference- Similar provisions to subsections (1) through (7), § 5:07. 
Sec. 2-63. - Appointments. 
(a)  The mayor shall appoint with the advice and consent of Council: 
(1)  A city attorney and such permanent assistant solicitors as may be necessary. 
(2)  All members of boards and commissions. 
(3)  Members of authorities as provided by law. 
(b)  Unless otherwise provided by statute, any person so appointed shall hold office, unless removed during the term, for the period for which the mayor is elected and until a successor is appointed and qualified. 
(c)  The mayor shall, in addition to the preceding positions, appoint: 
(1)  A director of administrative services. 
(2)  A director of planning. 
(3)  Such other officers or employees of the administrative branch as necessary pursuant to section 2-61(7) of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 4.03, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Charter reference- Similar provisions to subsections (a) and (b), § 5.08; appointment of director of administrative services, § 5:11; appointment of director of planning, § 5:12. 
Sec. 2-64. - Removals by the mayor. 
(a)  The mayor may remove the city attorney and all members of boards and commissions except as otherwise provided by law. 
(b)  The mayor may remove any member of the administrative branch except as provided by law or by the Charter. 
(c)  The mayor may delegate to any member of the administrative branch the power to remove subordinates as provided for in subsection 2-61(8)a. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 4.04, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Charter reference- Removals by the mayor, § 5:09. 
Secs. 2-65-2-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - ADMINISTRATIVE DEPARTMENTS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Charter reference- Administration, Art. VI. 

Sec. 2-71. - Number and types. 
(a)  The city shall have administrative departments of the type, form and number delineated in its table or organization. Pursuant to Section 5:13 of the Charter, said table shall be filed annually by the mayor with council no later than thirty (30) days after final adoption of the general fund budget. 
(b)  The table of organization shall provide: 
(1)  A list of all departments and their general function. 
(2)  A list of the bureaus or offices within departments and their function. 
(3)  The interrelationships between departments including the lines of authority. 
(4)  An enumeration of the maximum number of personnel by function within each bureau as set by salary ordinance. 
(5)  Such other information as may be deemed necessary by the mayor or council for effective administration of city undertakings. 
(c)  If it becomes apparent that the organizational structure needs to be altered, the mayor may change the table of organization with the approval of council. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 5.01, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Charter reference- Table of organization, § 5:13. 
Sec. 2-72. - Director of administrative services. 
    The director of administrative services shall be responsible for the fiscal and administrative functions of the city, including general supervision of all officers in the executive branch. Specifically, the director of administrative services shall: 
(1)  Supervise personnel policies and practices enumerated in the Wilkes-Barre City Personnel System. 
(2)  Prepare the annual budget in manner and form directed by the mayor. 
(3)  Be responsible, subject to the approval of the mayor, for revenue collection, accounting practices and all other fiscal operations including the appointment of a finance officer. 
(4)  Subject to the approval of the mayor, appoint, promote, suspend, dismiss and remove the heads of executive departments or their subordinates and take other appropriate disciplinary action. 
(5)  Perform such other duties as may be required by the mayor, Charter, law or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 5.02, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Charter reference- Appointment of director of administrative service, § 5:11. 
Sec. 2-73. - Director of planning. 
    The director of planning shall: 
(1)  Prepare and administer all plans and programs affecting the physical development of the city, and inform the mayor, city council and city planning commission of such plans and programs. 
(2)  Prepare in conjunction with the department of administrative services the city's capital budget in a manner prescribed by this Code and in a form approved by the mayor. 
(3)  Aid the planning commission in exercise of its responsibilities. 
(4)  Provide for the implementation of zoning rules and ordinances. 
(5)  Coordinate the redevelopment and community development activities of the city. 
(6)  Perform such other functions as may be required by ordinance, law or the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 5.03, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Charter reference- Appointment of director of planning, § 5:12. 
Cross reference- Planning generally, Ch. 22. 
Sec. 2-74. - Appointment and qualifications of department heads. 
    Department heads shall be appointed by the mayor or on the authorization of the mayor by the director of administrative services unless otherwise provided by law. They shall be chosen on the basis of executive and administrative qualifications appropriate to the duties of their respective departments. They shall be subject to removal at the discretion of the mayor, subject to limitation of the Charter, this Code or other applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 5.04, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-75. - Duties of administrative department heads. 
    Each department head shall: 
(1)  Direct the performance of all duties and responsibilities required of his department and its subordinate agencies as provided by statute, this Administrative Code or other ordinance of the city, and such other duties as may be required by the mayor which are not in conflict with law or ordinances. 
(2)  Subject to provisions of applicable law, this Code, and existing collective bargaining agreements, department heads shall: 
a.  With the written approval of the mayor appoint subordinate officers and employees within their respective Departments and shall, with the written approval of the mayor, remove any such officers or employees. 
b.  Reprimand, suspend or otherwise discipline subordinates of their respective departments provided that the mayor or the director of administrative services has first approved. 
(3)  Prescribe the internal organization of the department and the duties of subordinate officers and employees of the department, with the approval of the mayor or the director of administrative services. 
(4)  Assign functions, powers and duties to subordinate officers and employees within the department and modify such assignments as need appears. 
(5)  Supervise the department and its employees in accordance with the provisions of this Code. 
(6)  subject to the approval of the mayor or the director of administrative services, provide such service, labor, materials and equipment as my be requisitioned by any department or subordinate agency of the city subject to the same audit as other expenditures incurred. 
(7)  Submit to the mayor or the director of administrative services such reports as they may request. 
(8)  Keep informed of progress in administrative and operational practices in his respective field and institute within his department those practices he deems appropriate. 
(9)  Establish and supervise such in-service training programs as he deems beneficial to the improvement of services. 
(10)  Be responsible to the mayor and director of administrative services for the effective administration of his department and all activities assigned to it. 
(11)  Delegate to division heads or other subordinates such of his powers as he may deem necessary for efficient administration, except that such delegation with respect to personnel items and signing of requisitions shall be in writing and approved by the mayor or the director of administrative services. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 5.05, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Secs. 2-76-2-83. - Reserved.
