DIVISION 7. - AUDIT AND CONTROL[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- With revisions and updates through February, 2007 provided by the city, provisions of 2-97 were renumbered as 2-98-2-104. 

Sec. 2-96. - City controller-Head of office. 
    The office of audit and control shall be headed by a city controller. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 7.01, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-97. - Same-Powers and duties. 
    The city controller shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  Examine, audit and verify all books, records and accounts of the various administrative and legislative units, departments, offices or officials under the control or supervision of the mayor or council, and for this purpose have access to all such books, records and accounts at any time. 
(2)  Examine and approve for payment all contracts, purchase orders, and other documents by which the city incurs financial obligations, having ascertained before approval that monies have been duly appropriated or provided for and allotted to meet such obligations. 
(3)  Audit and approve all bills, invoices, payrolls and other evidence of claims, demands or charges paid from city funds. 
(4)  Submit reports to the city council and the mayor of any records deemed in violation of law or contrary to accepted accounting procedures. 
(5)  Prepare and submit to council and to the mayor within sixty (60) days of the end of every fiscal year a complete financial statement of the affairs of the city with such comments as the controller deems appropriate. 
(6)  Employ a Deputy and/or other personnel essential to the accomplishment of his duties. 
(7)  Delegate any duty and/or responsibility to the deputy controller that he shall deem necessary. 
(8)  Audit authorities of the city as he deems appropriate and not contrary to law. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 7.02, 7-8-76; Ord. No. 15-02, §§ 7.03-7.08, 9-12-02; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-98. - Approval of warrants and appropriations. 
    No monies shall be paid out of the city treasury except upon appropriation previously made by council and upon warrant pursuant thereto, which warrant shall explicitly state the purpose for which the money is to be drawn. No work shall be hired to be done, no materials purchased, no contracts made and no order issued for the payment of any monies in any amount, which will cause the sums appropriated to specific purposes to be exceeded. 
    The city controller shall review all purchase orders and warrants for the expenditures of city money prior to the city undertaking any obligation, and, only if satisfied that such expenditures are within the budget allotment pertaining thereto, controller shall sign said warrant and/or purchase order before it is presented to the city finance officer for payment or disbursement of funds. In so doing, it is the intention of the city council that the controller perform a pre-audit of all claims and demands against the city prior to payment. The controller shall approve all warrants for payment and authorize purchase orders thereof, only if satisfied that such payments and purchase orders are in accordance with law. The controller shall only approve such warrants and purchase orders that have sufficient appropriations and monies available. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 7.02, 7-8-76; Ord. No. 15-02, § 7.03, 9-12-02; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-99. - Monitoring, processing and payment of obligation. 
    It shall remain the responsibility and obligation of the city controller to monitor the payment of all bills and obligations of the City of Wilkes-Barre. Consequently, the controller shall report to council and the citizens of the City of Wilkes-Barre on a monthly basis, detailing the payment status regarding all bills and obligations of the City of Wilkes-Barre (whether direct or those for which the city shall have ultimate responsibility by virtue of its guaranty or assumption of responsibility), as well as the then current and comprehensive financial condition of the city. The report of the city controller, which shall be submitted to the city council within two (2) weeks after the close of the month, shall, among other things, define the status of the city's payment of all accounts payable and other claims and obligations as well as the status of the general fund and all other funds of the city. The report shall detail the aged status of the accounts payable and obligations and delineate whether the payable is 30, 60 or 90 days from the date of receipt of the invoice or claim. Any bills, obligations or invoices of the City of Wilkes-Barre which are not paid pursuant to the most favorable terms of any contract with a vendor or are not otherwise paid within forty-five (45) days of receipt of any invoice require that the chief executive officer and city controller provide to city council a written explanation of the reasons why the bill, obligation, claim or invoice is not paid. 
    Henceforth and commencing immediately upon the final enactment of this article, all bills, obligations, invoices, purchase orders and/or documentation of any type defining any alleged financial obligation of the City of Wilkes-Barre currently or in the future in the possession of the chief executive officer and/or the administrative branch, including but not limited to any Department or Bureau of the City of Wilkes-Barre, shall, within twenty-four (24) hours of their receipt, be forwarded to the office of the city controller. The city controller shall, within fourteen (14) days of the final enactment of this article, report on the existence and status of all invoices, purchase orders, vouchers, and obligations presently received, claimed or of which the Administrative Branch has notice. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 7.02, 7-8-76; Ord. No. 15-02, § 7.04, 9-12-02; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-100. - Investigation. 
    The city controller is authorized to make investigation into the financial affairs of the City of Wilkes-Barre and conduct of any department, office or agency of the City of Wilkes-Barre and may issue subpoenas for these purposes. The controller, upon issuance of a subpoena, shall provide city council with a copy of said subpoena and shall provide a written status report to city council every thirty (30) days regarding any investigation. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 7.02, 7-8-76; Ord. No. 15-02, § 7.05, 9-12-02; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-101. - Timely payment. 
    It is the intention of City Council that, consistent with the Home Rule Charter, the administrative code and the efficient and orderly administration of the fiscal affairs of the City of Wilkes-Barre, that all proper bills, invoices and financial obligations properly submitted to the city be satisfied or processed in accordance with the payment terms negotiated between the City of Wilkes-Barre and the vendor and, in any event, the city controller, as stated above, is directed to report the status of all outstanding accounts payable by the City of Wilkes-Barre. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 7.02, 7-8-76; Ord. No. 15-02, § 7.06, 9-12-02; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-102. - Execution of contracts, obligations and approval of purchase orders. 
    Henceforth, all purchase orders, vouchers, contracts and obligations of the City of Wilkes-Barre shall require the prior approval of the city controller. The city controller will assign a purchase order number prior to the authorization for purchase of any and all materials and/or labor for the benefit of the City of Wilkes-Barre. All contracts and written obligations of the City of Wilkes-Barre shall, henceforth, require the signature of the city controller in addition to the signature of any and all other required officials of the City of Wilkes-Barre. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 7.02, 7-8-76; Ord. No. 15-02, § 7.07, 9-12-02; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-103. - Inclusion of chief executive officer's information. 
    The Mayor shall provide monthly financial status reports to the City Controller by the fifteenth day following the end of each calendar month, listing and stating the status of all the revenues and expenditures of the city and shall, at that time, also provide a balance sheet of the general fund of the city, identifying all assets and liabilities of the general fund. The mayor's report shall be included in the report of the city controller to city council each month. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 7.02, 7-8-76; Ord. No. 15-02, § 7.08, 9-12-02; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Secs. 2-104-2-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - PERSONNEL[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Charter reference- Personnel, Art. XI. 

Sec. 2-106. - Personnel system. 
(a)  The city shall establish a personnel system based on merit. Such system shall be governed by personnel rules and regulations, which shall be established by the mayor and submitted to council for its review and comment. 
(b)  Such rules shall have as their foundation: 
(1)  Nondiscrimination because of race, religion, sex or national origin. 
(2)  Just and equitable conditions of employment. 
(3)  Uniform basis of compensation for like classified positions. 
(4)  Tenure of employment subject to good behavior, satisfactory work performance, requirements of the city and availability of funds. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 8.01, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-107. - Residency. 
(a)  Required. All persons employed by the City of Wilkes-Barre, and members of boards, authorities and commissions, shall be residents of the city, unless specifically excused by action of city council. 
(b)  Certificate of residency; liability for city taxes. All city employees and members of boards, authorities and commissions shall be required to sign a certificate of residency, and that said certificate shall declare his or her residence to be within the City of Wilkes-Barre, and the understanding that he or she is, and intends to be, liable for all validly-enacted taxes which are applicable to residents of the City of Wilkes-Barre. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 8.02, 7-8-76; Ord. No. 3-86, § 1, 3-9-86; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-108. - Blanket bond. 
    Any officer or employee of the city who is or may be required to give bond to the city conditioned for the faithful performance of his duties, except such officers and employees who are required by law to give individual bonds, may be covered by a public employees' blanket bond, the amount and coverage thereof to be determined by the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 8.03, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Charter reference- Fidelity bond for officers, § 12:04. 
Sec. 2-109. - Compensation. 
(a)  The council shall approve each year an ordinance known as the "salary ordinance." Such ordinance shall affix the number of permanent employees of the city and their maximum rate of compensation for that year. 
(b)  The mayor, at his discretion, may provide compensation for a position at a rate less than that specified in the salary ordinance provided that such compensation is not in violation of the established personnel procedures or collective bargaining agreement. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 8.04, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Secs. 2-110-2-115. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - FINANCE[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Charter reference- Financial procedures, Art. IX. 

Sec. 2-116. - General fund budget. 
(a)  The general fund budget shall be submitted, adopted and amended in conformance with Article IX of the Charter. 
(b)  Pursuant to Section 9:06 of the Charter, council may adopt the general fund budget as submitted by the mayor with or without an amendment. Council may amend the budget by increasing or decreasing program funding, except debt requirements, or by adding or deleting programs. 
    If the amended budget increases, decreases or readjusts funding requirements by more than five (5) percent, or adds or deletes a program, the budget shall be returned to the mayor immediately for his comment and resubmission to the council within three (3) normal city work days. Council shall provide for another public hearing to be held within five (5) days after the mayor has resubmitted the budget. 
    For this purpose: 
(1)  Five (5) percent increase or decrease shall mean five (5) percent of the total budget as submitted by the mayor. 
(2)  Five (5) percent readjustment shall mean the summation of all changes made in disbursements divided by the total budget disbursement as submitted by the mayor. 
(c)  Pursuant to Section 9:11 (3) of the Charter, transfer of appropriations may be made by the mayor as follows: 
(1)  Within a department, transfers from one (1) line to another may not exceed in the aggregate, three (3) percent of the total departmental budget. 
(2)  From one (1) department to another, transfers may not exceed in the aggregate, one-quarter (1/4) of one (1) percent of the total department budget. 
(3)  Transfers of funds appropriated for council's use may not be made without the approval of Council. 
(d)  The general fund budget shall be fixed at the total amount as it is stated at the time of adoption and may not exceed that amount. 
Any other changes beyond those above shall require council approval. 
All monies received in excess of the budgeted amount shall be placed in a separate account until appropriated by council. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 9.01, 7-8-76; Ord. No. 3-86, § 2, 3-9-86; Ord. No. 61-93, 12-21-93; Ord. No. 42-98, § 1, 6-4-98; Ord. No. 17-01, § 1, 12-12-01; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-117. - Capital budget. 
(a)  The capital budget shall be submitted and adopted in conformance with Article IX of the Charter. 
(b)  During the course of the year, the mayor may transfer among lines or projects in the aggregate, sums not to exceed five (5) percent in the aggregate of the total budget. Any transfers needed shall require council approval. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 9.02, 7-8-76; Ord. No. 3-86, § 3, 3-9-86; Ord. No. 61-93, 12-21-93; Ord. No. 42-98, § 2, 6-4-98; Ord. No. 17-2001, § 2, 12-12-01; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-118. - Other budgets. 
(a)  All other budgets shall be submitted, amended and adopted in a manner similar to the capital budget, unless otherwise provided for by federal or state law or city ordinance. 
(b)  Procedure for transfers between line items or projects shall be the same as for the capital budget. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 9.03, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-119. - City finance officer. 
(a)  Appointment. Subject to the approval of the mayor, the director of administrative services shall appoint a finance officer of the city. 
(b)  Duties and responsibilities: 
(1)  Such finance officer shall carry out such duties and exercise such powers with respect to the receipt and disbursement of public monies as are provided by general law or required by judicious fiscal management, and in addition thereto, shall receive for deposit from the departments of the city government all city monies collected by such departments. 
(2)  The city finance officer shall disburse all such funds in accordance with warrants issued to him therefor and duly signed by the city controller and the mayor or director of administrative services. 
(3)  The city finance officer shall furnish such fidelity bond and insurance as is required by law and appropriate fiscal management. He shall also furnish such insurance protection as is deemed necessary against the loss of funds through fire, burglary, larceny, theft, robbery, or forgery. 
(4)  Perform such other duties as may be required for sound and efficient financial management. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 9.04, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-120. - Deputy finance officer. 
    There shall be a deputy finance officer appointed by the director of administrative services with the approval of the mayor. He shall perform such duties, as the finance officer shall direct including the authority to receive and disburse public funds. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 9.05, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-121. - Appropriations. 
(a)  No monies shall be paid out of the city treasury except as previously budgeted and upon warranty pursuant thereto, which warrant shall state the purpose for which the money is to be drawn. 
(b)  The Mayor may make transfers of appropriations in accord with Article IX, Section 9:01, Paragraph Three (3) of this Ordinance. 
(c)  The Council may make supplemental appropriations for any lawful purpose in conformance with Section 9:01, Paragraph Two (2) of the Charter. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 9.06, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-122. - Accounting procedures. 
    The director of administrative services and the city finance officer shall establish procedures of accounting and financial management. Such procedures shall be verified by a certified public accountant as in conformance with generally acceptable accounting practices, and shall be approved by the mayor and city controller. 
    Such procedures, including but not limited to a chart of accounts, shall be compiled and filed with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 9.07, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-123. - Budget operation. 
(a)  The mayor shall be responsible for the overall administration of all budgets. The director of administrative services shall, under the mayor's direction supervise such administration. 
(b)  The budget shall be administered in conformance with the accounting procedures devised pursuant to section 2-122. 
(c)  If at any time during the budget year the director of administrative services shall ascertain the probability of a cash deficit he shall immediately inform the mayor. Upon approval of the mayor, action shall be undertaken so as to forestall, as far as possible, the making of commitments and expenditures in excess of the revenue to be realized during the fiscal year. 
(d)  Monthly, a list of disbursements made by the city pursuant to all budgets shall be submitted to council for its review and comment. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 9.08, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-124. - Purchasing. 
(a)  The mayor shall be responsible for the establishment and maintenance of an efficient purchasing system. The system shall be delineated in the accounting procedures established pursuant to section 2-122. 
(b)  The purchasing system shall also include a current inventory of city property and shall provide for an annual physical inventory. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 9.09, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-125. - Depositories of city funds. 
(a)  The city finance officer shall deposit all city funds and all city taxes collected by him in such banks or other financial depositories having an office within the City of Wilkes-Barre, as designated by city council. 
(b)  All such deposits shall be made in the name of the city and all designated depositories shall be institutions insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation or the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 9.10, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-126. - Temporary investment of city funds. 
    The mayor or his delegate shall have power to provide for temporary investment of city funds in U.S. Treasury bills, or in savings accounts, share accounts and certificates of deposit of institutions insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation or the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. Provided, however, that the mayor or his delegate shall not invest more than forty (40) percent of any fund in excess of five hundred thousand ($500,000.00) in any one (1) depository without the approval of city council. The mayor or his delegate shall have the authority to dispose of securities and withdraw any funds as is necessary. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 9.11, 7-8-76; Ord. No. 19-82, § 1, 7-8-82; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-127. - Audits. 
    Audits shall be carried out in a manner prescribed by this Charter or other sections of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, § 9.12, 7-8-76; with revisions and updates through February, 2007) 
Sec. 2-128. - Contracts. 
(a)  Authorization to award contracts for professional services and purchase of insurance and bonds in excess of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) shall be vested in the City Council of the City of Wilkes-Barre. 
(b)  Other contract administration. All other contract administration for the city, including, but not limited to, authority as to preparation of specifications, letting of bids and awarding of contracts, with the exception of subsection (a) above, shall be vested in the mayor and the executive branch, provided that any proposed contracts in excess of twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) for whatever purposes will be referred by the mayor to council for its approval before undertaking. 
(c)  Provided further that any expenditure of eighteen thousand five hundred dollars ($18,500.00) or more, subject to the annual adjustment authorized by the Third Class City Code, will require competitive bidding after proper advertisement. Exceptions to this competitive bidding requirement are: 
(1)  Expenditures for professional services. 
(2)  Expenditures for purchase of insurance or bonds. 
(3)  Expenditures necessitated by an emergency. 
(4)  Expenditures for patented items. 
(d)  The necessary administrative procedures including bidding procedures, recommendation on low bids, acceptance of change orders and signature or required documents shall be enumerated in a document on the file with the city clerk and shall be followed in all cases unless otherwise provided for by federal or state law or city ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 19-76, 7-8-76; Ord. No. 4-82, § 1, 2-25-82; Ord. No. 3-86, § 4, 3-9-86; Ord. No. 41-88, §§ 1, 2, 7-12-88; Ord. No. 42-98, §§ 3, 4, 6-4-98; Ord. No. 17-01, § 1, 12-12-01; Ord. No. 15-03, § 1, 8-19-03; Ord. No. 23-04, § 1, 3-25-04; Ord. No. 53-04, § 1, 9-23-04; with revisions and updates through February, 2007; Ord. No. 13-2010, 5-6-10; Ord. No. 5-13, 4-11-2013) 
Secs. 2-129-2-140. - Reserved. 
APPENDIX B - CITY POLICY 
DIVISION 1. - COUNCIL RULES AND PROCEDURE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 16-88, adopted Mar. 10, 1988, was not enacted as a specific amendment or addition to the Code, but is incorporated herein as a new Div. 10, §§ 2-140.1-2-140.14, to Ch. 2, Art. II, at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 2-140.1. - Authority. 
(a)  Charter. The Charter of the City of Wilkes-Barre provides that council may determine its own rules of procedure for meetings. The following set of rules shall be in effect upon their adoption by the council, and until such time as they are amended or new rules adopted in the manner provided by these rules. 
(Ord. No. 16-88, § 1(1.1), 3-10-88; Ord. No. 1-92, § 1(1.1), 1-23-92) 
Sec. 2-140.2. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this division, shall, for the purpose of this division, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Administrative branch shall mean those departments, bureaus, agencies or authorities, and their assigned personnel, who are accountable to and under authority of the chief executive officer, not to include, however, the officers and personnel of the city controller or the city clerk. 
    Chairman shall mean that member of city council elected by the council to serve as presiding officer of that body and perform such other duties as deemed necessary by the council. 
    Chairman pro tempore shall mean that member of city council present having the most consecutive tenure in office to serve as the presiding officer of that body in the absence of the chairman and vice-chairman. 
    Charter or City Charter shall mean the Home Rule Charter of the City of Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania. 
    Chief executive officer shall mean the mayor of the City of Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania. 
    City shall mean the City of Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania. 
    City attorney or solicitor shall mean that appointed officer who shall serve as chief legal advisor to the mayor, the council, and all city departments. 
    Clerk shall mean the appointed officer of the city who shall have the title of city clerk. 
    Council shall mean the city council of the City of Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania. 
    Vice-chairman shall mean that member of city council elected by the council to serve as presiding officer of that body in the absence of the chairman. 
(Ord. No. 16-88, § 2, 3-10-88; Ord. No. 1-92, § 2, 1-23-92) 
Sec. 2-140.3. - General rules. 
(a)  Meetings to be public. All official (except where the state "Sunshine Law" allows executive sessions for certain limited topics) meetings of council shall be open to the public. The journal of proceedings shall be open to public inspection. 
(b)  Quorum. A majority of the members of the city council shall constitute a quorum and shall be necessary for the transaction of business. If a quorum is not present, those in attendance will be named and they shall adjourn to a later time. 
(c)  Journal of proceedings. An account of all proceedings of the council shall be kept by the city clerk and shall be entered in a book constituting the official record of the council. 
(d)  Right of floor. Any member desiring to speak must first be recognized by the chair, and shall confine his remarks to one (1) subject under consideration or to be considered. 
(e)  City attorney. The city attorney, or the assistant city attorney, shall attend all meetings of the council unless excused and shall, upon request, give an opinion, either written or oral, on questions of law. The city attorney shall act as the council's parliamentarian. 
(f)  City clerk. The city clerk shall attend all meetings of council, unless excused, and shall keep the official minutes (journal) and perform such other duties as may be requested by the council and duties required by the Charter and general law. 
(g)  Officers and employees. Department heads of the city or their authorized representative are requested to attend meetings of council when there is pertinent business from their department on the council agenda. If they are unable to attend, the item will be held over to next meeting. 
(h)  Parliamentary practice rules. The rules of parliamentary practice as contained in Robert's Rules of Order, most recent edition, shall govern the council in all cases to which they are applicable; provided, that they are not in conflict with these rules, with the ordinances and Charter of the City of Wilkes-Barre or the laws of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania. The parliamentarian will interpret and the presiding officer shall enforce the rules of parliamentary practice and the presiding officer's enforcement shall be final and conclusive unless overturned by a majority vote of the council. 
(i)  Cell phones. All meeting participants and attendees will silence or turn off cell phones while the meeting is in session. 
(Ord. No. 16-88, § 3(3.1)-(3.8), 3-10-88; Ord. No. 1-92, § 3(3.1)-(3.8); Ord. No. 2-2014, § 1, 3-13-14) 
Sec. 2-140.4. - Types of meetings. 
(a)  Regular meetings. The council shall meet in the council chambers for regular, adjourned and special meetings. The regular council meetings are to commence at 5:00 p.m., on the second and fourth Thursday of each month, unless otherwise specified. The city clerk shall have the authority to substitute meeting dates when they conflict with legal holidays. 
(b)  Work sessions. The council shall meet in the council chambers for work sessions. The work sessions are to commence at 5:00 p.m., on the second and fourth Tuesday of each month, unless otherwise specified. The city clerk shall have the authority to substitute meeting dates when they conflict with legal holidays. These work sessions should be informal and flexible. No formal action shall be taken. 
(c)  Special meetings. Special meetings may be called by the mayor or by any three (3) members of the council. The call for a special meeting shall be filed with the city clerk in written form, except that announcement of a special meeting during any regular meeting at which all members are present. The call for a special meeting shall specify the day and the hour of the special meeting and shall list the subject or subjects to be considered. 
    Only such business may be transacted at a special meeting as may be listed in the call for said meeting or an incident thereto. A special meeting may be called for the transaction of general business. 
(d)  Adjourned meetings. Any meeting of council may be adjourned to a later date and time; provided, that no adjournment shall be for a longer period than until the next regular meeting. 
(e)  Emergency meetings. Emergency meetings may be convened and conducted for the purpose of acting upon an emergency involving a clear and present danger to life or property. The city clerk shall attempt to give written and oral notice of an emergency meeting, and shall make every effort to notify members of council and the mayor of such meeting through the most expeditious means. Furthermore, members of city council shall not be in violation of the public notification sections of the Home Rule Charter and Administrative Code. 
(f)  Executive sessions. Executive sessions or closed meetings may be held in accordance with the provisions of the State "Sunshine Law" Act. 
(g)  Attendance of media at council meetings. All meetings of the city council and its committees shall be open to the media, except those allowed closed by the state "Sunshine Law," freely subject to recording by radio, television and photographic services at any time; provided, that such arrangements do not interfere with the orderly conduct of the meeting. 
(h)  Addressing the council. Any person desiring to address the council shall fill out a speaker registration form in its entirety prior to the start of the meeting. The form must be received by the chair before the meeting commences. 
    Persons shall address the council only when the order of business moves to public discussion. Speakers may begin their presentation after first securing the permission of the chair. 
    Additional comments from those in attendance concerning topics being presented before council may be allowed with the approval of the council chairman. 
(i)  Manner of addressing council. No persons are allowed to address council beyond the rail. The only exception is the speaker who has the floor during public discussion and is seated/standing center front of the council dais that is reserved for public presentation. 
(Ord. No. 16-88, § 4(4.1)-(4.9), 3-10-88; Ord. No. 33-2007, § 1(4.3), 1-10-08; Ord. No. 1-2008, § 1(4.9), 1-22-08; Ord. No. 6-2011, § 1(4.9), 4-28-11; Ord. No. 4-2013, § 1, 3-26-13; Ord. No. 3-2014, § 1, 4-10-14; Ord. No. 4-2014, § 1, 4-10-14) 
Sec. 2-140.5. - Chairman; duties. 
(a)  Chairman, vicechairman and chairman pro tempore. The chairman shall preside at all meetings of the council. In the absence of the chairman, the vice-chairman shall preside. In absence of both chairman and vice-chairman, the chairman pro tempore shall preside. 
(b)  Call to order. The meetings of the council shall be called to order by the chairman. 
(c)  Preservation of order. The chairman shall preserve order and decorum, prevent attacks on personalities or the impugning of members' motives, and confine members in debate to the question under discussion. 
(d)  Points of order. The chairman shall determine all points of order, subject to the right of any member to appeal to the council. If any appeal is taken, the question shall be, "Shall the decision of the Chairman be sustained," and the council shall decide by a majority vote. 
(e)  Raise a question of privilege. A question of privilege permits a request relating to the rights and privileges of any member to be brought up for possible immediate consideration because of its urgency while business is pending and the request or motion would otherwise be out of order. 
    Questions of privilege may relate to council organization or existence; to the comfort of its members with respect to heating, ventilation, lighting and noise or other disturbance; to the conduct of the offices and employees or of visitors; to the punishment of its members; or to the accuracy of published reports of its proceedings. 
    Questions of personal privilege shall relate to an incorrect record of a members' participation in a meeting contained in minutes, approved in his or her absence, or to charges circulated against a members character. 
(Ord. No. 16-88, § 5(5.1)-(5.5), 3-10-88; Ord. No. 1-92, § 5(5.1)-(5.5), 1-23-92) 
Sec. 2-140.6. - Order of business. 
(a)  Agenda. All reports, communications, ordinances, resolutions, contract documents, or other matters to be submitted to the council by the administrator shall be submitted prior to each council meeting and shall be delivered to the city clerk, whereupon the clerk shall prepare a calendar of such matters together with such additional matters that he may have to present, in conformity with the prescribed order of business as hereinafter provided, and shall furnish a copy to each member of council, the mayor, controller, administrator and the city attorney in advance of the meeting. 
    The general rules as to the order of business in a regular meeting shall be as follows: 
(1)  Pledge of allegiance; 
(2)  Roll call; 
(3)  Public discussion; 
(4)  Resolutions; 
(5)  Ordinances; 
(6)  Communications and minutes; 
(7)  Presentations by council members; 
(8)  Adjournment. 
(b)  Consent agenda. Those items of a general nature that would not normally be debated, i.e., such as, resolutions of a congratulatory nature, motions for hearings, notice for communications, contracts, and minutes being filed and any other miscellaneous item that Council would ordinarily adopt on consent, shall be placed on a separate agenda known as the "Consent Agenda" and all items will be adopted upon the consent of the council. 
    The Chairman may, at his discretion, or any member may request the chair to remove any item from the consent agenda for consideration as a separate issue. 
    If the chair refuses to remove an item upon request, the members may, upon a second, appeal the majority of the council. 
(c)  Matters not on the agenda. No matters shall be presented to the council by the administrative heads of departments if they do not appear on the agenda except those determined by the chair to be of urgent nature, and the same, when so presented, shall have the written approval of the mayor before presentation to the council. 
(d)  Presentation by members of council. The agenda shall provide a time when the mayor or any council member may bring before the council any business that he feels should be deliberated upon by the council. These matters need not be specifically listed on the agenda. 
(e)  Reading of minutes. Unless a reading of the minutes of a council meeting is requested by a majority of the council, such minutes, when signed, shall be considered approved without reading; provided, that the clerk shall deliver a copy thereof to each member of council and shall have the same available for public inspection in accordance with the Freedom of Information Act and the City Charter. 
(f)  Matters to be placed on agenda. No matter will appear on the work session agenda unless it is forwarded to the city clerk's office no later than 3:00 p.m., on the Thursday prior to the scheduled work session. 
(g)  Bid openings. Bid proposals submitted for council action should be submitted at least two (2) weeks (fourteen (14) days) prior to any council action. 
(Ord. No. 16-88, § 6(6.1)-(6.5), 3-10-88; Ord. No. 1-92, § 6(6.1)-(6.7), 1-23-92; Ord. No. 22-04, § I(6.6), 3-25-04) 
Sec. 2-140.7. - Rules of debate. 
(a)  Questions under consideration. When a question is presented and seconded, it is under consideration and no motion shall be received thereafter, except to adjourn, to lay on the table, to postpone, or to amend until the question is decided. These motions shall have preference in the order in which they are mentioned and the first two (2) shall be decided without debate. 
(b)  As to the chairman. The chairman, or such other member of the council as may be presiding, may move, second, and debate from the chair, subject only to such limitations of debate as are, by these rules, imposed upon all members and shall not be deprived of any of the rights and privileges of a councilman by reason of his being presiding chairman. 
(c)  Getting the floor; improper references to be avoided. Every member desiring to speak for any purpose whatsoever shall address the chairman and upon recognition shall confine himself to the question under debate. A member may only speak once on the same subject but may speak to clear up a matter of fact or explain a material part of his speech, except that a member, after moving a question, may once again speak on the same subject. 
(d)  Interruption. A member, once recognized, shall not be interrupted when speaking unless it is to call him to order or as herein otherwise provided. If a member, while speaking, is called to order, he shall cease speaking until the question of order is determined by the chairman, and if in order, he shall be permitted to proceed. Any member may appeal to the council from the decision of the chairman upon a question of order; then without debate the chairman shall submit to the council the question, "Shall the decision of the Chair be sustained," and the council shall decide by a majority vote. 
(e)  Privilege of closing debate. The councilman moving the adoption of an ordinance or resolution shall have the privilege of closing the debate. 
(f)  Roll call. Upon any roll call, there shall be no discussion or explanation given by any member voting, and he shall vote "yes" or "no," unless he shall first receive special permission from the council to explain his vote. A member of the council may abstain from voting on any matter. 
(Ord. No. 16-8, § 7(7.1)-(7.6), 3-10-88; Ord. No. 1-92, § 7(7. 1)-(7.6), 1-23-92) 
Sec. 2-140.8. - Voting. 
(a)  Generally. The affirmative vote of three (3) members of council shall be necessary to adopt any ordinance or any budget motion. The "yeas" and "nays" shall be recorded after each vote. Resolutions shall require a majority of members constituting a quorum, and the "ayes" and "nays" shall be entered in the minutes. An "absentation vote" shall be recorded as "non-vote." 
(b)  Tie vote. In the event of a tie in votes on any motion, the motion shall be considered lost. 
(c)  Vote taken. Roll call shall be taken by the clerk. The names of the members of the body shall be called in the order of seating at the council table, from left to right. The seating arrangements shall be made each year at the reorganization meeting of council, by a majority vote of the council. 
(d)  Conflict of interest. No member of the council shall vote on any question in which he has a financial interest other than the common public interest or on any question concerning his own conduct. 
(Ord. No. 16-88, § 8(8.1)-(8.4), 3-10-88; Ord. No. 1-92, § 9(8.1)-(8.4), 1-23-92; Ord. No. 33-2007, § 1(8.1), 1-10-08) 
Sec. 2-140.9. - Ordinances, resolutions and motions. 
(a)  Form. All ordinances and resolutions shall be presented in writing. 
(b)  City attorney to approve. All ordinances and resolutions shall be approved as to form and legality by the city attorney and must be submitted to the attorney at the close of work on the Thursday prior to the work session. 
(c)  Distribution of ordinances. The city clerk shall prepare copies of all proposed ordinances for distribution to all members of council and the administration. 
(d)  Reading by title only. Upon being introduced, each proposed ordinance shall be read by title only, unless any member of council request a full reading of the ordinance. 
(e)  Numbering ordinances and resolutions. Upon passage, a number shall be assigned to each ordinance or resolution by the city clerk. 
(f)  Ordinance passage procedure. When passed finally by the council, an ordinance shall require to be signed by all members voting in the affirmative and forwarded to the mayor for his signature of approval and then attested by the city clerk and it shall be immediately filed and thereafter preserved in the office of the city clerk. 
(g)  Veto by the mayor. Ordinances vetoed by the Mayor shall require the affirmative vote of four (4) members of Council for passage over the veto. 
(Ord. No. 16-88, § 9(9.1)-(9.7), 3-10-88; Ord. No. 1-92, § 9(9.1)-(9.7), 1-23-91; Ord. No. 25-2008, § 1, 11-20-08) 
Cross reference- Legislative procedures, Char. App. A § 2-31 et seq. 
Sec. 2-140.10. - City clerk. 
(a)  Duties generally. The city clerk shall: 
(1)  Serve as clerk of the council, by virtue of his office, and keep its minutes and records of its proceedings in appropriate form to be kept in his office. 
(2)  Maintain and compile the ordinances and resolutions of the city as required by the Charter and general law. 
(3)  Have custody and safely keep the seal of the city and all records and documents, reports, papers and maps required to be filed in his office by the Charter and general law. 
(4)  Perform such other duties as may be provided by general law, the Charter and ordinances of the city. 
(b)  Affixing city seal. The city clerk shall cause the city seal to be affixed to instruments and writings when authorized by any ordinance or resolution or when necessary to exemplify any document or record in his office or to certify any act or paper, which, from the records in his office, shall appear to have been a public act of the city or a public document. He shall not affix the seal or cause or permit it to be affixed to any instrument or writings or other paper except as provided in this section, unless required by Charter or general law. 
(c)  Notices to attend meetings of council. The city clerk shall issue notices to the respective members of the council and to all other persons whose attendance may be required at any meeting of the council. The city clerk shall, whenever a special meeting of the council is called in accordance with law, issue and cause notices thereof to be served upon the members of the council and any other persons whose presence may be required. 
(d)  Disposition of actions of governing body. All matters acted upon by the council at any duly called meeting which, in their opinion, requires such action shall be officially communicated by the city clerk to the officer, employee, board, body, commission or other agency for whatever request or action is to be taken by such officer, employee, board, body, commission or other agency. 
(e)  Fees. The city clerk shall charge and receive for the use of the city such fees for searches, transcripts and certifications as shall be authorized by resolution of the council. 
(f)  Written communications. Interested parties, or their authorized representatives, may address the council by written communication in regard to any matter concerning the city's business or over which the council has control at any time by direct mail or by addressing the city clerk and copies will be distributed to the council members. 
(Ord. No. 16-88, § 10(10-1)-(10-6), 3-10-88; Ord. No. 1-92, § 10(10.1)-(10.6), 1-23-92) 
Sec. 2-140.11. - Decorum. 
(a)  By council members. While the council is in session, the members must preserve order and decorum, and a member shall neither, by conversation or otherwise, except as herein provided, delay or interrupt the proceedings, the peace of the council, disturb any member while speaking, or refuse to obey the orders of the council or its presiding officer. 
(b)  By persons. Any person making impertinent or slanderous remarks or who shall become boisterous while addressing the council shall forthwith be barred from further audience before the council by the presiding officer, unless permission to continue or again address the council is granted by the majority of the vote of the council or a quorum thereof. 
(c)  Persons authorized to be within the council rail. No person, except city officers or their representatives, shall be permitted within the rail in front of the council or shall be permitted within the rail in front of the council or shall be permitted to disturb any councilman while on the dais during any meeting without the express permission of the council. 
(Ord. No. 16-88, § 11(11.1)-(11.3), 3-10-88; Ord. No. 1-92, § 11(11.1)-(11.3), 1-23-92) 
Sec. 2-140.12. - Suspension of the rules. 
    Any rule may be suspended with the approval of all members who are present. The vote on any such suspension shall be taken by a vote and entered upon the record. 
(Ord. No. 16-88, § 12, 3-10-88; Ord. No. 1-92, § 12, 1-23-92) 
Sec. 2-140.13. - Amendment of these rules. 
    These rules may be amended, or new rules adopted, by a majority vote of all members of the council. 
(Ord. No. 16-88, § 13, 3-10-88; Ord. No. 1-92, § 13, 1-23-92) 
Sec. 2-140.14. - Adjournment. 
    A motion to adjourn shall always be in order and deduced without debate. 
(Ord. No. 16-88, § 14, 3-10-88; Ord. No. 1-92, § 14, 1-23-92) 
DIVISION 11. - OPEN RECORDS 

Sec. 2-140.15. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this division is to comply with the requirements of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania and provide the citizens of the City of Wilkes-Barre with a clear and concise policy for the inspection of public records. 
(Ord. No. 2-03, § 1, 1-22-03) 
Sec. 2-140.16. - Definitions. 
    Public records. Any account, voucher or contract dealing with the receipt or disbursement of funds by Wilkes-Barre City, use or disposal of services or of supplies, materials, equipment, or other property and any minute, order or decision by Wilkes-Barre City, or agent thereof, fixing the personal or property rights, privileges, immunities, duties or obligations of any person(s). "Public records" shall not include any report, communication or other record or paper, the publication of which would disclose the institution, progress or result of any investigation, and/or litigation undertaken by Wilkes-Barre City or its agents in the performance of its official duties, it shall also not include any record, document, material, exhibit, pleading, report, memorandum or other paper, access to or the publication of which is prohibited, restricted or forbidden by statute law or order or decree of court, or which would operate to the prejudice or impairment of a person's reputation or personal security, or which would result in the loss by the city of federal funds, excepting therefrom however the record of any conviction for any criminal act. 
    Record. Any document maintained by an agency, in any form, whether public or not. 
    Requester. A person who is a resident of the commonwealth and requests a record pursuant to this act. 
    Response. Access to a record or an agency's written notice granting, denying or partially granting and partially denying access to a record. 
Note- Each office/department will provide the necessary information to complete subsection 2-140.17(1) (Time for inspection); subsection 2-140.17(2) (Form of requests) [and/or] section 2-140.19 (Response to requests). 
(Ord. No. 2-03, § 2, 1-22-03; Ord. No. 43-04, § I, 9-7-04) 
Sec. 2-140.17. - Open records requirements and procedure. 
(a)  General rule. Unless otherwise provided by law, a public record shall be accessible for inspection and duplication by a requester in accordance with this policy. A public record shall be provided to a requester in the medium requested if the public record exists in that medium; otherwise, it shall be provided in the medium in which it exists. Public records shall be available for access during the regular business hours of Wilkes-Barre City. Nothing in this act shall provide for access to a record which is not a public record. 
(b)  Requests. Wilkes-Barre City may, but is not required to fulfill verbal requests for access to records and anonymous requests for access to records. In the event that the Requester wishes to pursue the relief and remedies provided for in this policy of the city or under Pennsylvania Law, the requester must initiate such relief with a written request. 
(c)  Written requests. A written request for access to records may be submitted in person, by mail, to the city office. A written request shall be addressed to the office from which the record is being sought. A written request should identify or describe the records sought with sufficient specificity to enable the agency to ascertain which records are being requested and shall include the name and address to which the city should address its response. A written request need not include any explanation of the requester's reason for requesting or intended use of the records. 
(d)  Creation of a public record. When responding to a request for access, Wilkes-Barre City shall not be required to create a public record which does not currently exist or to compile, maintain, format or organize a public record in a manner in which the agency does not currently compile, maintain, format or organize the public record. 
(e)  Conversion of an electronic record to paper. If a public record is only maintained electronically or in other non-paper media, the city shall, upon request, duplicate the public record on paper when responding to a request for access in accordance with this policy. 
(f)  Retention of records. Nothing in this act is intended to modify, rescind or supersede any record retention and disposition schedule established pursuant to Pennsylvania law. 
(g)  Redaction. If the city determines that a public record contains information which is subject to access as well as information which is not subject to access, the city's response shall grant access to the information which is subject to access and deny access to the information which is not subject to access. If the information which is not subject to access is an integral part of the public record and cannot be separated, the office of the requested record shall redact from the public record the information which is not subject to access, and the response shall grant access to the information which is subject to access. The city may not deny access to the public record if the information which is not subject to access is able to be redacted. 
(h)  Fees. The city shall set forth a fee schedule for the copying of public records. All fees shall be paid prior to the release of the public record. In the event the fees are not paid at prior to the release of the public record, the office is not required to release the record. 
(Ord. No. 43-04, § II, 9-7-04) 
Sec. 2-140.18. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 43-04, § II, adopted Sept. 7, 2004, amended the former §§ 2-140.17, 2-140.18 and enacted a new sections as set out herein. The former §§ 2-140.17, 2-140.18 pertained to requests for public records and fees, respectively and derived from Ord. No. 2-03, §§ 3, 4, adopted Jan. 22, 2003. 
Sec. 2-140.19. - Response to requests. 
(a)  General rule. Upon receipt of a written request for access to a record, the city shall make a good faith effort to determine if the record requested is a public record and to respond as promptly as possible under the circumstances existing at the time of the request but shall not exceed five (5) business days from the date the written request is received by the city. If the city fails to send the response within five (5) business days of receipt of the written request for access, the written request for access shall be deemed denied. 
(b)  Exception. Upon receipt of a written request for access, if the city determines that one (1) of the following applies: 
(1)  The request for access requires redaction of a public record in accordance with subsection (a). 
(2)  The request for access requires the retrieval of a record stored in a remote location; 
(3)  A timely response to the request for access cannot be accomplished due to bona fide and specified staffing limitations; 
(4)  A legal review is necessary to determine whether the record is a public record subject to access under this act; 
(5)  The requester has not complied with the city's policies regarding access to public records; or 
(6)  The requester refuses to pay applicable fees authorized by section 2-140.17(h) of this policy, 
the city shall send written notice to the requester within five (5) business days of the city's receipt of the request for access. The notice shall include a statement notifying the requester that the request for access is being reviewed, the reason for the review and a reasonable date that a response is expected to be provided. If the date that a response is expected to be provided is in excess of thirty (30) days, following the five (5) business days allowed for in subsection (a), the request for access shall be deemed denied. 
(c)  Denial. If the city's response is a denial of a written request for access, whether in whole or in part, a written response shall be issued and include: 
(1)  A description of the record requested. 
(2)  The specific reasons for the denial, including a citation of supporting legal authority. If the denial is the result of a determination that the record requested is not a public record, the specific reasons for the city's determination that the record is not a public record shall be included. 
(3)  The typed or printed name, title, business address, business telephone number and signature of the public official or public employee on whose authority the denial is issued. 
(4)  Date of the response. 
(5)  The procedure to appeal the denial of access under this act. 
(d)  Certified copies. If city's response grants a request for access, the office from which the record was requested shall, upon request, provide the requester with a certified copy of the public record if the requester pays the applicable fees. 
(Ord. No. 2-03, § 5, 1-22-03; Ord. No. 43-04, § III, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 1-06, § III, 3-7-06) 
Sec. 2-140.20. - Appeals process. 
    If a written request is denied or deemed denied, the requester may file an appeal to Wilkes-Barre City Council within fifteen (15) days of the mailing date of the City of Wilkes-Barre's denial. The appeal shall state the ground upon which the requester asserts that the record is a public record and shall address any grounds set forth by the City of Wilkes-Barre for the denial of the request. 
    Wilkes-Barre City Council shall make a final determination on the appeal within forty-five (45) days of the date the appeal is received. Wilkes-Barre City Council may hold a hearing on the issue within the forty-five-day period. If city council determines that the denial was correct, it shall provide a written explanation for its findings. 
    The requester may appeal Wilkes-Barre City Council's final determination to the court of common please or to the district justice within thirty (30) days of the final determination. 
(Ord. No. 2-03, § 6, 1-22-03)

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances, City of Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania" and may be so cited. Such Code may also be cited as the "Wilkes-Barre Code." 
Charter reference- Mandate for codification, § 4:09. 
State Law reference- Authority to codify ordinances, 53 P.S. § 36014.1. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances and resolutions passed by the city council, the following definitions and rules shall be observed, unless clearly indicated to the contrary: 
    Charter. The word "Charter" shall mean the Charter of the City of Wilkes-Barre as adopted by the electors on November 4, 1975, and any amendments thereto, a copy of which is printed in this volume. 
    City. The words "the city" or "this city" shall mean the City of Wilkes-Barre, in Luzerne County, Pennsylvania. 
    City council. The words "city council" or "the council" shall mean the City Council of the City of Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania. 
    Code. Reference to "this Code" or "the Code" shall mean the Code of Ordinances, City of Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania, as designated in section 1-1. 
    Computation of time. Whenever a notice is required to be given or an act to be done a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be had, the day on which such notice is given or such act is done shall be excluded in computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be had shall be included. Whenever any act required to be done pursuant to the provisions of this Code falls on a Sunday or legal holiday, that act shall be performed on the next succeeding business day. 
    County. the term "county," "the county" or "this county" shall mean Luzerne County, Pennsylvania. 
    C.P.S.A. The abbreviation "C.P.S.A." shall mean the latest provisions in Purdon's Consolidated Pennsylvania Statutes Annotated. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
    Highway. The term "highway" shall include any street, alley, highway, avenue or public place or square, bridge, viaduct, tunnel underpass, overpass or causeway in the city, dedicated or devoted to public use. 
    Joint authority. Words purporting to give authority to three (3) or more officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such officers or other persons, unless it is otherwise declared. 
    Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
    Number. Any word importing the singular number shall include the plural and any word importing the plural number shall include the singular. 
    Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Officers, departments, etc. Except as otherwise specifically provided, whenever any officer, department, board, commission or other agency is referred to by title alone, such reference shall be construed as if followed by the words "of the City of Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania." Whenever in accordance with the provisions of this Code any specific act is required to be done by any designated officer or official of the city, such act may be performed by any duly authorized member of his department. 
    Or, and. "Or" may be read "and," and "and" may be read "or," if the sense requires it. 
    Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The word "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, corporations, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. Whenever used with respect to any penalty, the word "person," as applied to partnerships or associations, shall mean the partners or members thereof, and as applied to corporations, the officers thereof. 
    Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    P.S. the abbreviation "P.S." shall mean the latest provision in Purdon's Pennsylvania Statutes annotated. 
    Public place. The words "public place" shall mean any street, alley, park, canal, waterway, beach, public building or any place of business or assembly open to the public or frequented by the public. 
    Roadway. The word "roadway" shall mean that portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic. 
    Shall, may. The word "shall" is mandatory, and the word "may" is discretionary. 
    Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of the street between the curb, or the lateral line of the roadway and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    Signature or subscription. The term "signature" or "subscription" shall include a mark when a person cannot write. 
    State or commonwealth. The word "state" or "commonwealth" shall be construed to mean the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania. 
    Street. The term "street" shall include any highway, alley, street, avenue or public place, square, bridge, viaduct, underpass, overpass, tunnel or causeway in the city, dedicated or devoted to public use. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Time standard. Whenever certain hours are named in this Code, they shall mean standard time or daylight saving time as may be in current use in the city. 
    Written or in writing. The term "written" or "in writing" shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
    Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year. 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
Sec. 1-4. - History notes. 
    The history notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this Code are not intended to have any legal effect but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the section. 
Sec. 1-5. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any ordinance not inconsistent with this Code: 
(1)  Promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness; 
(2)  Providing for an appropriation or for the levy of taxes or for an annual budget; 
(3)  Annexing territory to the city or excluding territory as a part of the city; 
(4)  Granting any franchise, permit, easement, right-of-way or other right; 
(5)  Adopted for purposes which have been consummated; 
(6)  Relating to the salaries of the city officers or employees; 
(7)  Naming, renaming, opening, accepting or vacating streets or alleys in the city; 
(8)  Relating to zoning; 
(9)  Relating to the internal organization of the city government; the creation, appointment, duties, authority, etc., of city departments, officers, boards, etc.; and the operations of the various city departments; 
(10)  Creating municipal authorities; 
(11)  Relating to claims and demands against the city; 
(12)  Amending traffic-control maps; 
(13)  Relating to the operation of the flood control works; 
(14)  Establishing building lines or street lines; 
(15)  Relating to the placement of electric wires underground; 
(16)  Relating to street paving lien procedures; 
(17)  Relating to bonds of city officials and employees; 
(18)  Providing for laying of public sewers; 
(19)  Any ordinance approving, authorizing or otherwise relating to any contract, agreement, lease, deed or other instrument; 
(20)  Any temporary or special ordinance; 
and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length herein. 
(Ord. No. 31-68, § 3, 10-15-68) 
Sec. 1-6. - Code does not affect prior offenses, rights, etc. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing, before the effective date of this Code. 
Sec. 1-7. - General penalty for violations of Code and ordinances; continuing violations. 
    Whenever in this Code or in any ordinance of the city an act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or misdemeanor, or wherever in such Code or ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any such ordinance shall, upon summary conviction thereof in a summary proceeding before a magistrate of the city, be sentenced to pay a fine not to exceed six hundred dollars ($600.00) per violation and costs, except when a specific penalty is otherwise provided. In default of the payment of such fine and costs, such person shall be imprisoned in the county jail for a period not exceeding ninety (90) days. Each and every day upon which any person violates or continues to violate the provisions of this Code shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 30-93, §§ 2, 3, 10-14-93) 
Charter reference- Authority for penalty provisions, § 12:05. 
Sec. 1-8. - Amendments to Code. 
(a)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code shall be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section _____ of the Code of Ordinances, City of Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania, is hereby amended to read as follows:...". The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(b)  If a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language shall be used: "That the Code of Ordinances, City of Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania, is hereby amended by adding a section, to be numbered _____, which said section reads as follows: ...". The new section shall then be set out in full as desired. 
Charter reference- Legislation, Art. IV. 
Sec. 1-9. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city council or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code, and shall also include all amendments to the Charter during the period. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections _____ to _____ (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but, in no case, shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
Sec. 1-10. - Severability of parts of Code and ordinances. 
    If a court of competent jurisdiction should hold one or more sections or a part of a section of this Code or of an ordinance passed hereafter invalid, such holding shall not affect the remainder of the Code or ordinance nor the context in which such section, sections or part of a section so held invalid may appear, except to the extent that an entire section or part of a section may be inseparably connected in meaning and effect with the section, sections or part of a section so held invalid. 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Corporate seal. 
    The common and corporate seal of the city shall be a BEEHIVE with the inscription "SEAL OF THE CITY OF WILKES-BARRE, PENNSYLVANIA, INCORPORATED 1871," thereon. 
(Ord. of 3-6-1899, § 1)

    The following municipal authorities have been created and are hereby continued in effect:
