Sec. 2-3. - Sales of personal property. 
    No city personal property shall be disposed of by sale or otherwise except upon approval of council by ordinance or resolution. In cases where council shall approve a sale of city personal property, it shall estimate the sale value of the entire lot to be disposed of. If council shall estimate such sale value to be less than two hundred dollars ($200.00), it shall require a notice of the proposed sale to be posted for at least ten (10) days on the bulletin board in the city hall, describing and itemizing the property to be sold and directing that bids may be made thereon at the office of the city clerk. Thereafter, council may sell such property, in whole or in part, for the best price or prices obtainable. If council shall estimate the sale value to be two hundred dollars ($200.00) or more, the entire lot shall be advertised for sale once in at least one newspaper, in accordance with the provisions of 53 P.S. § 35109, and sale of the property so advertised shall be made to the best responsible bidder; and the bids shall not be opened until at least ten (10) days after the advertisement. Council may sell any such property at auction, but the provisions as to notice contained in this section shall be likewise observed as to the holding of such auction sales. The provisions of this section shall not be mandatory where city personal property is to be traded-in or exchanged for new city personal property. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 53 P.S. § 36917. 
Sec. 2-4. - Contracts awarded by city. 
(a)  Extensions of time, modifications or changes in methods of payment. Any contract with the City of Wilkes-Barre approved and awarded by city council requiring an extension of time, modification or change in the method of payment, other than outlined in the original contract document, any significant alteration to the work to be performed or for any other matter shall be made only on the approval of the city council. 
(b)  Change orders in excess of $10,000.00. Any change order, or any combination of change orders, in excess of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) shall be made only on the approval of the city council. 
(c)  Exception for emergency situations. Provided, however, that the mayor, when, in his judgment, an emergency situation warrants it, may authorize the letting of contracts up to the amount of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) without the prior approval of council, but must notify council of such expenditures and the reason therefor. 
(d)  [Contracts for professional services, etc.] Authorization to award contracts for professional services and purchase of insurance and bonds in excess of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) shall be vested in the City Council of the City of Wilkes-Barre. 
(e)  [Other contract administration.] All other contract administration for the city, including, but not limited to, authority as to preparation of specifications, letting of bids and awarding of contracts, with the exception of paragraph (a) above, shall be vested in the mayor and the executive branch, provided that any proposed contracts in excess of twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00), for whatever purposes, will be referred by the mayor to council for its approval before undertaking. 
(Ord. No. 18-86, §§ 1, 2, 2-13-86; Ord. No. 34-86, § 1, 2-27-86; Ord. No. 17-01, §§ 3, 4, 12-12-01) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 17-86, §§ 1, 2, adopted Feb. 13, 1986, as amended by Ord. No. 34-86, § 1, adopted Feb. 27, 1986, enacted the provisions codified as § 2-4 above. Since said ordinances did not specifically amend the Code, the manner of codification has been at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 2-5. - Appointments to boards, authorities and commissions. 
(a)  The mayor shall, after being notified of an existing vacancy on any board, authority or commission of the City of Wilkes-Barre, notify the city council of any such vacancy within seven (7) days from the date that the vacancy occurs. 
(b)  All appointments and reappointments must be submitted and approved by city council within a two-month period from the date that the existing vacancy occurs. 
(c)  If city council does not approve the appointments or reappointments within the two-month period from the date that the existing vacancy occurs, city council shall amend the creating legislation of any board, authority or commission to reduce the number of its members by eliminating that seat of the member where a vacancy occurs; provided, that the total membership of any board, authority or commission shall not be reduced beyond the minimum number provided for such seats in the federal or state statute under which the board, authority or commission was created. 
(Ord. No. 31-86, § 1, 2-27-86) 
Editor's note- Section 2-5 is derived from Ord. No. 31-86, § 1, adopted Feb. 27, 1986. This ordinance, being nonamendatory of the Code, has been codified herein at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 2-6. - Automobile insurance requirements for vehicles used in the conduct of city business. 
(a)  Any officer and/or employee of the City of Wilkes-Barre utilizing their private vehicle for the conduct of any city business or function shall file with the city administrator automobile liability insurance coverage as follows: $100,000.00 each person/$300,000.00 per occurrence. 
(b)  Any officer and/or employee who fails to file said insurance coverage with the city administrator shall not be allowed to use their private vehicle for any city business and will not be compensated in any manner for use of said vehicle. 
(c)  Officers and/or employees shall file with the administrator a renewal of said coverage within ten (10) days from the expiration date of the previous coverage. 
(d)  Any officer and/or employer who is unable to obtain insurance coverage or has their insurance cancelled for any reason must report that fact to the city administrator immediately. 
(Ord. No. 66-88, §§ 1-4, 12-8-88) 
Editor's note- Being not specifically amendatory of the Code, §§ 1-4 of Ord. No. 66-88, adopted Dec. 8, 1988, have been incorporated herein as a new § 2-6 at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 2-7. - Transfer of insurance proceeds to designated city officer for certain fire losses. 
(a)  Designation of officer. The city finance officer or his designee is hereby appointed as the designated officer who is authorized to carry out all responsibilities and duties stated herein. 
(b)  Definitions applicable to this section. A "fire loss" or "claim for fire damage" is defined as any loss occurring after the effective date of this ordinance [Ordinance No. 1-95] and covered under a policy of fire insurance, including any endorsements or riders to the policy. 
(c)  Municipal certificate required before payment of claims. No insurance company, association or exchange (hereinafter the "insurer") doing business in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania shall pay a claim of a named insured for fire damage to a structure located within the City of Wilkes-Barre (hereinafter the "municipality") where the amount recoverable for the fire loss to the structure under all policies exceeds seven thousand five hundred dollars ($7,500.00) unless the named insured or insurer is furnished by the municipal officer with a municipal certificate pursuant to section 508(b) and unless there is compliance with sections 508(c) and (d) and the provisions of this section. 
(d)  Procedure for payment of claims. After full compliance with the requirements of section 508(b)(1)(i), the insurer shall pay the claim of the named insured; provided, however, that if the loss is agreed upon by the named insured and the insurer equals or exceeds sixty (60) percent of the aggregate limits of liability on all fire policies covering the building structure, the following procedures must be followed: 
(1)  The insurer shall transfer from the insurance proceeds to the municipal officer the aggregate of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) for each fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) of a claim and for each fraction of that amount of a claim, provided (1) that this section is to be applied such that if the claim is fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) or less, the amount transferred to the municipality shall be two thousand dollars ($2,000.00); and (2) that if at the time of a loss report the named insured has submitted a contractor's signed estimate of the costs of removing, repairing or securing the building or other structure in an amount less than the amount calculated under the foregoing transfer formula, the insurer shall transfer to the municipality from the insurance proceeds the amount based upon the estimate. 
(2)  The transfer of proceeds shall be on pro-rata basis by all companies, associations or exchanges insuring the building or other structure. Policy proceeds remaining after the transfer to the municipality shall be disbursed in accordance with the policy terms. 
(3)  After the transfer, the named insured may submit a contractor's signed estimate of the costs of removing, repairing or securing the building or other structure, and the designated officer shall return the amount of the funds transferred to the municipality in excess of the estimate to the named insured if the municipality has not commenced to remove, repair or secure the building or other structure. 
(4)  Upon receipt of proceeds under this section, the municipality shall do the following: 
a.  The municipal officer shall place the proceeds in the separate fund to be used solely as security against the total costs of removing, repairing, or securing the building or structure which are incurred by the municipality. Such costs shall include, without limitation, any engineering, legal or administrative costs incurred by the municipality in connection with such removal, repair or securing of the building or any proceedings related thereto; and 
b.  It is the obligation of the insurer when transferring the proceeds to provide the municipality with the name and address of the named insured. Upon receipt of the transferred funds and the name and address of the named insured, the municipal officer shall contact the named insured, certify that the proceeds have been received by the municipality and notify the named insured that the procedures under this subsection shall be followed; and 
c.  When repairs, removal or securing of the building or other structure have been completed in accordance with all applicable regulations and orders of the municipality and the required proof of such completion received by the municipal officer, and if the municipality has not incurred any costs for repairs, removal or securing, the fund shall be returned to the named insured. If the municipality has incurred costs for repairs, removal or securing of the building or other structure, the costs shall be paid from the fund, and if excess funds remain, the municipality shall transfer the remaining funds to the named insured; and 
d.  To the extent that interest is earned on proceeds held by the municipality pursuant to this section, and retained by it, such interest shall belong to the municipality. To the extent that proceeds are returned to the named insured, interest earned on such proceeds shall be distributed to the named insured at the time that the proceeds are returned. 
(5)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the ability of the municipality to recover any deficiency. Furthermore, nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the municipality and the named insured from entering into an agreement that permits the transfer of funds to the named insured if some other reasonable disposition of the damaged property has been negotiated. 
(e)  Authority of municipality to enact procedures and regulations. The city council may by resolution adopt procedures and regulations to implement section 508 and this section and may by resolution fix reasonable fees to be charged for municipal activities or services provided pursuant to section 508 and this section, including, but not limited to, issuance of certificates and bills, performance of inspections and opening separate fund accounts. 
(f)  Penalty for violation. Any owner of property, any named insured or any insurer who violates this section shall be subject to a penalty of up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) per violation. 
(Ord. No. 19-92, §§ 1-5, 9-10-92; Ord. No. 1-95, Arts. 1-4, 1-26-95)

Sec. 2-9. - Reimbursement for expenses. 
(a)  Definitions. 
    An "extraordinary emergency expense" shall be those expenses, and those related costs and fees that are incurred by the city for actual costs or charges for labor, materials, and any other costs associated with the use of: (a) specialized extinguishing or abatement agent, chemical neutralizer or similar equipment or material that is employed to monitor, extinguish, confine, neutralize, contain, clean, or remove any material that is involved in a fire, and/or (b) the operation or employment of specialized equipment for the rescue, extrication, removal, and/or stabilization of persons injured in a motor vehicle accident or motor vehicle fire. 
An "extraordinary emergency expenses" shall also include the abatement and disposition of hazardous materials, spills, releases, or the threat of spills or releases of hazardous materials, spills, releases, utility line breaks or leaks, and other imminent or perceived or potential threats to the health, safety, and welfare of the public that may be detailed or contemplated. 
    An "extraordinary emergency" is a service performed by any city department or employee(s) or any public or private sector organization or agency directly associated with the migrating the hazard or potential hazard or involved in providing services to implement a protective action. 
(b)  Administration. The council of the city shall collect all fees a follows: 
(1)  Fees and costs, including overhead costs, shall encompass all personnel, equipment, materials, and maintenance expenses in such a form as to insure for full reimbursement for charges from both the public and private sectors actually rendered. 
(2)  A particular cost or fee schedule need not be set forth in this section or elsewhere in the city ordinance or by further formal action by the city council. The city council's approval of this section shall constitute authorization for the fire department to collect all such fees and costs, including overhead costs. 
(3)  The fire department will submit a bill for all such costs, fees and charges and expenses, to the owner, agent, or manager of the vehicle or fixed facility which caused the need for such extra-ordinary, with a demand that full remittance be made within thirty (30) days of receipt. 
(4)  In cases of hardship, or where circumstances are such that a full remittance cannot be made to the fire department within the thirty-day period, the fire department may enter into negotiations with the owner or his agent for an extended payback period of time not to exceed six months. 
(5)  All monies received under the provisions of this article shall be placed into the general fund of the City of Wilkes-Barre. 
(6)  All fees shall, from time to time, be set by resolution of city council of the City of Wilkes-Barre after consultation with the fire chief of the City of Wilkes-Barre. 
(c)  Litigation. The fire department may enforce provisions of this article by civil action in a court of competent jurisdiction for the collection of any amounts due hereunder plus attorneys' fees or for any other relief that may be appropriate. 
(d)  Emergency services. 
(1)  Nothing in this article shall authorize any city bureau, department, or personnel or staff members to refuse or delay an emergency service to any person, firm, organization or corporation that has not reimbursed the fire department for extra-ordinary services. 
(2)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to demand reimbursement to the fire department for those municipal services that are normally provided to city residents and others as a matter of the city's general operating procedure, and for which the levying of taxes or the demand for reimbursement is normally made. 
(Ord. No. 30-04, §§ 1-4, 6-15-04) 
Sec. 2-10. - Sale or lease of real property. 
(a)  No city owned real property shall be sold or leased unless the transaction is formally authorized and approved by city council by resolution. 
(b)  Any determination of property value shall be made by formal appraisal or by the opinion of the city assessor. 
(c)  Factors which city council may consider related to the sale of city real property will include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Purchase price; 
(2)  Proposed use; and 
(3)  Proximity of city property to property of proposed purchaser, if applicable. 
(Ord. No. 5-2018, 6-13-18) 
Secs. 2-11-2-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EMPLOYEE AND OFFICER BENEFITS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance relating to the salaries of the city officials or employees saved from repeal, § 1-5(6). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-141. - Wages and salaries generally. 
(a)  The number of officers and employees of all departments of the city, and the rate of compensation thereof, shall be and the same are fixed and established as set forth in a schedule on file in the clerk's office, and the rates of compensation as set forth in such schedule are the maximum rates and not necessarily the rate at which the person must be hired, except as provided in union contract and not changeable. 
(b)  In case of an emergency or unusual labor requirements the mayor is hereby authorized and empowered to employ such numbers of extra employees above the maximums mentioned above as may be necessary for the proper carrying on of the work of the departments, with the approval of city council, at the compensation set forth in the schedule adopted by subsection (a). 
(c)  All salaries and wages provided in this section shall be paid biweekly through the regular payrolls of the departments. 
(Ord. No. 51-77, §§ 1-3, 12-15-77) 
Sec. 2-142. - Compensation of elected officials. 
    The annual salary of each of the members of city council is set at eight thousand nine hundred dollars ($8,900.00); the annual salary of the chairperson of the city council is set at ten thousand four hundred dollars ($10,400.00); the annual salary of the city controller is set at twenty-four thousand nine hundred dollars ($24,900.00); and the annual salary of the mayor is set at fifty-three thousand nine hundred dollars ($53,900.00). 
(Ord. No. 11-78, 4-27-78) 
Editor's note- The salaries set out above reflect those enacted by Ord. No. 7-90, adopted March 3, 1990, which ordinance amended the Charter. 
Charter reference- Compensation of council, § 3:04; compensation of mayor, § 5:06; compensation of controller, § 10:06. 
Secs. 2-143-2-147. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - EMPLOYEES' PENSION FUND 

Sec. 2-148. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this division, the following words shall have the meaning herein assigned to them: 
    Employee is meant to include all persons in the service of the city creating the pension fund and pension board. 
Specifically excluded from the term "employee" are members of the city firemen's pension fund and city policemen's pension fund. 
    Joint coverage member of the retirement fund shall mean a city employee who shall have become a member of the retirement fund subsequent to the last date permitted by the city for statement or preference concerning social security coverage, or who, having become a member on or before such date, shall have filed with the pension board a written statement that he elects social security coverage under an agreement with the federal secretary of health, education and welfare entered into by the state. 
    Salary is hereby defined, for the purpose of calculating a pension under this division to include all amounts received by a city employee as base salary, double time, overtime, longevity, holiday pay, shift differential and annual sick leave buy back, but shall not include court pay, retirement sick leave buy back and medical buy out. 
    Single coverage member of the retirement fund shall mean a city employee who shall have become a member of the retirement system on or before the last date permitted by such city for statement of preference concerning social security coverage and who either shall have filed with the pension board a written statement that he does not elect social security coverage under any agreement with the federal secretary of health, education and welfare entered into by the state, or shall not have filed with the pension board any written statement. 
(Ord. No. 43-76, §§ VI, XV, 12-27-76; Ord. No. 20-91, § 2, 9-12-91) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 2-149. - Continuation of benefits under prior pension ordinance. 
    This division does not diminish the rights or privileges of any former city employee entitled to benefits under File of Council #677 of 1927 or any present municipal employee entitled to benefits under the aforementioned file of council. 
(Ord. No. 43-76, § III, 12-27-76) 
Sec. 2-150. - Employees required to join. 
    Any person now in the employ of the city and under the provisions of this division is hereby required to become a member of the pension system. Any person hereafter becoming an employee of the city shall be required to become a member of the pension fund within thirty (30) days from the date of such employment. 
(Ord. No. 43-76, § XVI, 12-27-76) 
Sec. 2-151. - Participants. 
    The benefits conferred by this division shall apply to all persons employed in any capacity by, or holding positions in the city; provided that the provisions of this division shall not apply to members of the city firemen's pension fund and city policemen's pension fund. 
(Ord. No. 43-76, § XII, 12-27-76) 
Sec. 2-152. - City employees' pension board. 
(a)  There is hereby created a board, to be known as the "city employees pension board" [and which] shall consist of the following: 
(1)  The mayor of the City of Wilkes-Barre. 
(2)  The city administrator. 
(3)  The director of human resources 
(4)  The finance officer. 
(5)  The city controller. 
(6)  A member of the city council elected by the council. 
(7)  Three (3) participants of said pension plan. 
The mayor shall serve as the president of the pension fund. It shall be the duty of said pension board to register all persons employed by the city at the date of the passage hereof, and to administer the collection and distribution of the funds herein provided for and to make such reasonable rules in the premises as such pension board may deem necessary to carry into effect the provisions of this division, as amended. No member of this board shall be compensated for their representation to said board except for the normal compensation paid for their administrative or employed position within the general fund budget of the City of Wilkes-Barre. A city secretary shall record the minutes of all board meetings and approved minutes shall be filed and stored in the office of the city clerk for the current year and thereafter in the office of records management of the City of Wilkes-Barre. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the pension board to receive and return and when deemed advisable to invest the funds payable in accordance with the provisions of this division and to pay over by warrant or check the amount due to such employees. 
(Ord. No. 43-76, § IV, X, 12-27-76; Ord. No. 14-98, § 1(A), 5-28-99) 
Sec. 2-153. - Contributions by employees; refunds. 
    All new employees of the city and all present employees of the city not presently enrolled into the city employees' pension fund but required to become a member of the system as specified in this division, shall pay into the board of pensions monthly an amount equal to five (5) percentum of their monthly salaries or wages. Payment of the monthly amount or contributions herein mentioned shall cease and be discontinued at the time the beneficiary receives the pension herein provided. If for any cause any employee contributing to the pension fund shall cease to be an employee of the city before the employee becomes entitled to a pension, the total amount of the contributions paid into the pension fund by such employee shall be refunded to him in full without interest. If any such employee shall have returned to him the amount contributed as aforesaid, and shall afterward reenter the employ of the city such employee shall not be entitled to the pension designated until twenty (20) years after such reemployment, unless he shall return to the pension fund the amount withdrawn, in which event that period of twenty (20) years shall be computed from the time the employee first enters the service of the city. In the event of the death of any such employee, before such employee becomes entitled to the pension aforesaid, such total amount of contributions paid into the pension fund by such employee shall be paid over to the beneficiary or beneficiaries designated by such employee, or if no beneficiary has been so designated, then to the estate of such deceased employee. 
    All new employees hired after January 1, 1999 and prior to January 24, 2001, shall pay into the board of pensions monthly an amount equal to five (5) percent of their monthly salaries and wages. 
(Ord. No. 43-76, § VIII, 12-27-76; Ord. No. 1-81, § 1, 2-12-81; Ord. No. 14-98, § 1(G), 5-28-99; Ord. No. 60-2004, § 6(G), 9-7-04) 
Sec. 2-154. - Contributions by city. 
    The city council hereby annually sets aside, apportions and appropriates out of all taxes and income of the city unto the pension board a sum sufficient to maintain the pensions or compensations due under this division. 
(Ord. No. 43-76, § XI, 12-27-76) 
Sec. 2-155. - Retirement. 
(a)  Every person now or hereafter employed by the City of Wilkes-Barre of the age of fifty (50) years and upwards, who shall have been so employed for a period of twenty (20) years or more shall, upon application to the pension board herein created, be retired from service and shall during the remainder of his or her life, receive the pension or compensation fixed by this article subject to such qualifications as are contained in this division. 
(b)  In addition, an employee of the city who currently contributes to the pension fund and who has worked for the city for a continuous period of ten (10) years or more, but less than twenty (20) years, and during this period of service was a member of the pension system, shall be entitled to a partial pension at the rate of two and one-half (21/2) percent for each year of service but not to exceed nineteen (19) years or forty-seven and one-half (471/2) percent of his or her best three years average annual wages, provided the employee was working for the city at the time of retirement. 
(c)  An employee who was first employed by the City of Wilkes-Barre prior to January 24, 2001, who currently contributes to the pension fund and who has worked for the city for a continuous period of ten (10) years or more, shall, upon application to the pension board, be retired from service and shall, during the remainder of his or her life, receive the pension or compensation fixed by this division subject to such qualifications as are contained in this article, provided, however, that if such employee elects to have his or her monthly pension determined in accordance with this early retirement provision commencing before attaining the age of fifty (50), said pension benefit shall be reduced by four (4) percent for each year or a pro rata share of four (4) percent for a portion of each year such employee's age is short of age fifty (50). 
(d)  Every person hired and employed by the City of Wilkes-Barre after July 1, 1998 and prior to January 24, 2001, and having reached the age of fifty (50) years and upwards, and who shall have been employed for a period of twenty (20) years or more shall be eligible to make application to the pension board created, to be retired from service and shall for the remainder of his or her life receive a pension or compensation fixed by this division subject to the qualifications as are contained in this division. 
(Ord. No. 43-76, § V, 12-27-76; Ord. No. 29-88, § 1, 5-10-88; Ord. No. 34-93, § 1, 11-9-93; Ord. No. 53-94, § 2, 11-22-94; Ord. No. 14-98, § 1(B), (C), 5-28-99; Ord. No. 60-2004, §§ 3-5, 9-7-04) 
Sec. 2-156. - Benefits. 
(a)  During the lifetime of any person in the employment of the city, and after the enactment of Ordinance No. 14-96, such person shall be entitled to receive as a pension annually from the fund set aside for that purpose fifty (50) percentum of the amount which he or she received during the member's highest two-year average salary, such person to be paid in monthly payments, retroactive to January 1, 1995. Any person who shall have been so employed shall receive a service increment of one and one-quarter (11/4) percent for each and every year of service over twenty (20) years with a maximum cumulative service increment of not more than ten (10) percent and a maximum annual pension of not more than sixty (60) percent of the amount which would constitute the average annual salary or wages which he or she received during the last or any five (5) years of his or her employment by such city, whichever is higher, such pension to be paid in monthly payments. Should any person so employed after twenty (20) years of service voluntarily retire or be in any manner deprived of his or her position or employment before attaining the age of fifty-five (55) years, such person shall be entitled to the pension above-mentioned; but such pension shall not commence until he or she has attained the age of fifty-five (55) years. In addition, should any person so employed after ten (10) years of service voluntarily leave, be dismissed or in any manner deprived of his or her position or employment before the age of sixty-two (62) years, such person shall be entitled to the partial pension above-mentioned in section 2-155 at the rate of two and one-half (21/2) percent for each year of service, but such pension shall not commence until he or she has attained the age of sixty-two (62) years. However, any person contributing at the rate of three and one-half (31/2) percent and not having paid the difference between three and one-half (31/2) and five (5) percent two (2) years prior to retirement or termination would have their pension proportionately reduced by the forty (40) percent of social security at age sixty-two (62). Should any employee, however, become totally and permanently disabled, after ten (10) years of service and before attaining the age of sixty-two (62) years, he shall be entitled to the pension. Proof of total and permanent disability shall consist of the sworn statement of three (3) practicing physicians, designated by the board, that the employee is in a permanent condition of health which would permanently disable him from performing the duties of his position or office. 
(b)  The pension to be paid joint coverage members according to the provisions of the federal Social Security Act and applicable state laws, payable after the age and upon that portion of annual compensation on which Social Security benefits are payable, shall be reduced by an amount equal to forty (40) percentum of the primary insurance amount of social security paid or payable to the member. Such reduction shall be subject to the following provisions: 
(1)  Upon attainment of the age at which social security benefits are payable to a beneficiary receiving a pension or upon retirement of a contributor after attaining that age, his eligibility to the old-age insurance benefit and the primary insurance amount of social security upon which the reduction in the pension shall be based, shall be computed by the board in the manner specified in the federal Social Security Act, except that in determining such eligibility and such amount only wages or compensation for services performed in the employ of the city shall be included. 
(2)  The reduction shall not apply to a pension for total and permanent disability payable under this section. 
(3)  Whenever the amount of the reduction from the pension shall have been once determined, it shall remain fixed for the duration of the pension, except that any decrease in the primary insurance amount under the social security act shall result in a corresponding decrease in the amount of the reduction from the pension. 
(4)  The total sum, including social security benefits, to be received upon retirement by an employee who is a member of the fund at the time of the agreement shall not be less than the allowance that would be paid by the retirement system in the absence of the agreement. 
(5)  The reduction shall not apply to a pension for any employee who has completed twenty-eight (28) years of continuous service with the City of Wilkes-Barre meeting all other requirements for retirement; provided, that any employee affected by this provision immediately begins to have an amount equal to five (5) percent of his or her monthly salary or wages paid into the pension fund within the first pay period after the effective date of this subsection (5) [June 7, 1998]. 
(Ord. No. 43-76, § VI, 12-27-76; Ord. No. 34-78, § 1, 11-30-78; Ord. No. 24-80, § 1, 10-23-80; Ord. No. 29-88, § 1, 5-10-88; Ord. No. 27-90, § 1, 8-9-90; Ord. No. 20-91, § 1, 9-12-91; Ord. No. 34-93, § 2, 11-9-93; Ord. No. 14-96, § 1, 5-23-96; Ord. No. 14-98, § 1(D), 5-28-99) 
Sec. 2-157. - Benefits not subject to attachment, assignment or transfer. 
    The compensation or pension mentioned in this division shall not be subject to attachment or execution and shall be payable only to the beneficiary designated by this division and shall not be subject to assignment or transfer. 
(Ord. No. 43-76, § XIV, 12-27-76) 
Sec. 2-158. - Computation of time of service. 
    The time of service specified in this division, namely, twenty (20) years shall be computed from the time of the first or original employment. Such employment shall consist of service to the city and need not be continuous; provided, however, that for purposes of qualifying for a ten-year pension such employee's service to the city must be continuous, unless, however, such employment was involuntarily terminated. 
(Ord. No. 43-76, § XIII, 12-27-76) 
Sec. 2-159. - Election by joint coverage members. 
(a)  Since the city has entered into an agreement with the state to place certain employees under the federal Social Security Act, the pension board may authorize any joint coverage member of the retirement system to elect according to the provisions of this section to receive compensation without the reduction provided for in section 2-156, provided he shall make a lump-sum payment to the pension board, or installment payments as may be approved by the board, equal to the difference between the amount of the accumulated fund to his credit in the fund as of the last date for which salary or wages were paid and the amount which would have been to his credit in such fund if contributions had been made on that portion of his salary or wages on which social security allowances are payable, at the same rate as made on that portion of his salary or wages in excess thereof, from the time that such salary or wages became subject to social security coverage. Such election shall be made, in writing, in the form prescribed by the pension board, and shall be accompanied by the lump-sum payment or an agreement as to installment payments herein required. 
(b)  The pension board may authorize any member to make the election herein provided at any time, and if made prior to retirement, such member shall, in addition to any lump-sum or installment payments required, pay to the board contributions on his entire salary or wages thereafter received at the rate provided in this division for monthly salary or wages in excess of that on which social security allowances are payable. 
(c)  The rate of payment under this section, for any person presently a member of the pension system shall be five (5) percent of the person's monthly salary or wages. This figure represents the figure which is paid if and when a person's salary is in excess of social security limits for which social security payments are made. 
(Ord. No. 43-76, § VII, 12-27-76) 
Sec. 2-160. - Credit for military service. 
(a)  Any member of the city employees' pension fund, who was hired by the City of Wilkes-Barre prior to January 24, 2001, who has not already bought back military service time, who is a contributor and who has actively served in the Armed Forces of the United States subsequent to September 1, 1940, with the exception of time spent on active duty with any reserve force, and who was not a member of the city's employees' pension fund prior to such military service, shall be entitled to have full credit for each year or fraction thereof not to exceed five (5) years of such service, upon his or her payment to the city employees' pension fund of an amount equal to that which the member would have paid had he or she been a member of the city employees' pension fund during the period for which the member desires credit at a contribution rate of five (5) percent of what the member's annual salary would have been had the member been employed by the City of Wilkes-Barre during the period of military service for which the member desires credit. 
(b)  All employees of the city who are now contributors to the pension fund, and all those known employed by the City of Wilkes-Barre from and after the effective date of this section, if required to become contributors to the pension fund shall be subject to the provisions of this section. 
(c)  The foregoing military service credit provision shall extend to and establish credit towards the minimum requirement for age and or service. 
(d)  Any member previously serving as a full-time employee with the City of Wilkes-Barre under the Comprehensive Employment Training Act (CETA), or the Manpower Program, or any person previously serving as a full-time employee of any authority, board or commission, the majority of whose board members are appointed by the mayor of the city with the advice and consent of city council, and who is presently a member or a retired member of the Wilkes-Barre City Pension Fund, shall be entitled to exercise the option of receiving credit for service with the city while so previously employed by the city or while previously employed under either the Comprehensive Employment Training Act (CETA) or the Manpower Program or while previously serving as a full-time employee of any authority, board or commission, the majority of whose board members are appointed by the mayor of the city with the advice and consent of city council, provided the member pays into the pension fund an amount equal to the contributions which the member would have made to the pension plan had the person been a member of the pension plan during such previous employment, as aforesaid, plus an appropriate interest rate to be set by the Wilkes-Barre City Employees' Pension Fund Board. The exercise of this option for service with the city is for pension purposes only and not for seniority purposes. 
(Ord. No. 43-76, § IX, 12-27-76; Ord. No. 15-90, § 1, 5-10-90; Ord. No. 35-93, § 1, 11-9-93; Ord. No. 53-94, § 1, 11-22-94; Ord. No. 60-2004, §§ 1, 2, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 16-06, § 1, 9-21-06) 
Sec. 2-161. - Entitlement to interest on pension contributions by persons deprived of employment. 
    Should any employee of the city be dismissed, voluntarily retire, resign or be in any manner deprived of his or her position of employment with the city without receiving any future benefits from the city employees' pension fund, then, and in that event, the employee shall be entitled to an interest at the rate of five (5) percent per annum on the employee's own pension contributions which are withdrawn. January 1, 1984, shall be the effective date for calculating the aforesaid interest. This provision shall not be retroactive prior to January 1, 1984. Should a recipient of benefits under this provision re-enter upon employment with the city, then, and in the event, he or she must return to the city employees' pension fund the amount previously withdrawn, together with the interest paid thereon, in order to re-establish his or her position with the city employees' pension fund. 
(Ord. No. 49-83, § 1, 1-12-84; Ord. No. 29-88, § 1, 5-10-88) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 49-83, enacted Jan. 12, 1984, amended Ord. No. 43-76, adopted Dec. 17, 1976, by adding a § VII.I, which provisions have been included herein as § 2-161 at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 2-162. - Cost of living increase. 
    Those members of the Wilkes-Barre City Employees Pension Fund who retired prior to January 1, 1984, on pension shall receive a cost of living increase of two (2) percent for each year that they have been on pension, effective April 1, 1984. Any member of the city employees' pension fund who retired or shall retire after January 1, 1984, shall not be eligible for the aforesaid cost of living increase. 
(Ord. No. 8-84, 3-22-84) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 8-84, enacted March 22, 1984, amended Ord. No. 43-76, adopted Dec. 27, 1976, codified herein as Art. II, Div. 2, by adding the provisions set out above, but did not specify the exact manner of their inclusion. Therefore, the editor, at his discretion, has included the provisions of Ord. No. 8-84 as a new § 2-162. 
Sec. 2-163. - Optional forms of payment. 
(a)  At the time that an employee applies to be placed on a pension, the employee must elect to receive a standard pension as herein set forth or one (1) of the following optional forms of payment: 
(1)  A ten-year certain and continuous life annuity. Under this form, benefits are payable for the member's lifetime but with the added guarantee that if the member should die before receiving at least one hundred twenty (120) monthly payments, then monthly payments are continued to the member's beneficiary or estate until the balance of the one hundred twenty-guaranteed payments have been made. 
Example: A member age 65 entitled to a monthly benefit of $500.00 payable for life, only could elect to receive $480.25 ($500.00 × 0.9605) monthly under the 10-year certain and continuous life annuity form. 
(2)  Survivor annuities. Under these forms of payment, a percentage (either 50%, 75% or 100%) of the member's monthly benefit is continued, following the member's death, to the member's surviving beneficiary for the duration of the beneficiary's lifetime. Note that if the beneficiary should die before the member, benefits continue in the reduced amount to the member and cease completely upon the member's death. 
Example: A member age 65 with a beneficiary age 62 entitled to a monthly pension of $500.00 payable for life only could elect to receive one of the following: 
a.  50% survivor annuity-The member would receive $445.50 monthly ($500.00 × 0.8910). Upon the member's death, the surviving beneficiary would receive $222.75 monthly ($445.50 × 0.5) for life. 
b.  75% survivor annuity-The member would receive $422.25 monthly ($500.00 × 0.8449). Upon the member's death, the surviving beneficiary would receive $316.84 monthly ($422.45 × 0.75) for life. 
c.  100% survivor annuity-The member would receive $401.70 monthly ($500.00 × 0.0834). Upon the member's death, the surviving beneficiary would receive $401.70 monthly ($401.70 × 1.00) for life. 
(b)  The amount payable under the optional forms shall be actuarially equivalent to the amount otherwise payable under the standard pension (i.e., an annuity for the employee's lifetime only) where actuarial equivalence is based on the 1983 group annuity table (male rates with ages set back one (1) year) and interest at eight (8) percent per annum compounded annually. 
(Ord. No. 28-90, § 1, 8-9-90) 
Sec. 2-164. - Election of optional payment forms by former city employees receiving standard pensions. 
    All former city employees who are currently receiving a standard pension under this pension fund, shall be afforded the opportunity to elect to receive one of the optional forms of payment as set forth in section 2-163, by making such election in writing to the keeper of the records of the pension board within thirty (30) days after the former city employee's receipt of written notice from the keeper of the records of the pension board of the former city employee's right to elect an optional form of payment. 
(Ord. No. 20-91, § 3, 9-12-91) 
Sec. 2-165. - Survivor annuities. 
    Every person employed by the City of Wilkes-Barre prior to January 24, 2001 shall make their election with regard to optional forms of payment, even though they intend to defer retirement, at the time of their completion of ten (10) consecutive years of service with the City of Wilkes-Barre. 
    Any member of the pension fund that has completed twenty-eight (28) years of service with the City of Wilkes-Barre and has reached all other requirements for pension eligibility shall be entitled to have paid monthly benefits in the amount of one hundred (100) percent of their eligible pension based on the high three-year average of the employee's annual salary or wages, and said percentage shall be continued, following the members death, to the member's surviving spouse for the duration of the spouse's lifetime. 
(Ord. No. 14-98, § 1(E), (F), 5-28-98; Ord. No. 25-06, § 1, 1-1-07; Ord. No. 30-2007, § 1(E), 12-13-07) 
Sec. 2-166. - Payment of pension fund from workers' compensation. 
    Should any employee of the City of Wilkes-Barre who is a member of the city employees pension fund be placed on workers' compensation as a consequence of a work related injury and/or occupational disease, said employee shall pay to the City of Wilkes-Barre City Employees Pension Fund an amount equal to five (5) percent of said employee's monthly salary or wages for the entire period that said employee remains on workers' compensation, and shall commence the payment of the same within thirty (30) days following said employee's receipt of his or her first workers' compensation benefit check. Those employees hired on or after January 1, 1999 and prior to January 24, 2001, shall pay into the pension fund an amount equal to five (5) percent of said employee's monthly salary or wages for the entire period that said employee remains on workers' compensation and shall commence the payment of the same within thirty (30) days following said employee's receipt of his or her first workers' compensation benefit check. 
(Ord. No. 14-98, § 1(H), 5-28-98; Ord. No. 60-2004, § 7(H), 9-7-04) 
Sec. 2-166.1. - Monthly pension benefit. 
    If any employee or former employee who was employed by the City of Wilkes-Barre prior to January 24, 2001, dies before the commencement of his or her retirement benefits, and who has completed ten (10) years or more of continuous service, such employee's or former employee's beneficiary shall be entitled to receive a monthly pension benefit equal to the monthly pension benefit the employee or former employee would have received had he or she retired as of the date of death; said pension payment shall be computed on the assumption that the employee or former employee was age fifty (50) at the time of death. 
(Ord. No. 30-2007, § 1(I), 12-13-07) 
Sec. 2-167. - Dispatching services-Severance package. 
    In July of 1998, Luzerne County began to perform all dispatching services for the City of Wilkes-Barre. As a result, a severance package was offered to all public safety dispatchers employed on July 14, 1998, to encourage retirement by August 1, 1998. To that end, the following language shall apply only to those public safety dispatchers employed with the City of Wilkes-Barre on July 14, 1998, and who also retired no later than August 1, 1998: 
(1)  Public safety dispatchers employed with the City of Wilkes-Barre on July 14, 1998, and who also retired no later than August 1, 1998, shall have the ability to purchase years of service and/or age from the nonuniformed pension fund at a rate of two hundred sixty-seven dollars and eighty-five cents ($267.85) per month for either service time or age. 
(2)  Said public safety dispatchers shall begin receiving pension benefits effective August 1, 1998. 
(3)  The city will pay the portion of the employee's contribution that represents the employee's regular contribution five (5) percent to the pension fund on August 15, 1998. 
(4)  The city will pay the portion of the employee's contribution that represents the city's contribution five (5) percent to the pension fund on December 30, 1998. 
(5)  The balance of the severance will then be payable to the employee in three (3) equal installments on August 31, 1999, August 31, 2000, and August 31, 2001. 
(Ord. No. 48-98, § 1, 8-23-98) 
Sec. 2-168. - Employees permitted to buy back time served. 
    Effective January 1, 2002, city employees are permitted to buy all of the time which represents time served as a City of Wilkes-Barre employee and a participant in another city pension fund into the city pension fund in which they currently participate. 
    The buyback amount shall be calculated by the city and shall include an amount equal to the employee's contributions, plus interest at a rate established by the city at the time of the buyback. 
    The buyback must be initiated at the time of hire into another city job classification or after the effective date of Ordinance No. 13-01 [December 22, 2001], whichever is later. 
(Ord. No. 13-01, § I, 12-12-01) 
Sec. 2-169. - Amendments-Nonuniformed pension fund. 
    Effective for members of the nonuniformed pension fund hired on or after January 24, 2001, the following amendments shall apply to Ordinance No. 13-01: 
    Pension funds for employees other than police or city-paid firemen. Cities may create a pension fund for the pensioning of employees of said cities who are not members of the police force or city-paid fire department thereof, surviving spouses of retired members if council so elects and the families of such as may be injured or killed in the service, in the manner, under the conditions and subject to the qualifications following. As used in this subdivision "employees" included officers and officials of the city, whether elected or appointed. 
    Pension board-Duties. In any city which creates such pension fund, there shall be created a board to be known as the pension board, consisting of the mayor, the city controller, the superintendent of finance, and two (2) employees to be chosen by the employees contributing to the pension fund and, if members of council participate in the pension fund and are members of the fund, a member of council, chosen by council. It shall be the duty of said board to register all persons employed by the said city, and to administer the collection and distribution of the fund herein provided for, and make such reasonable rules in the premises as such board may deem necessary to carry into effect the provisions of this act. 
    Retirement age. Every person, now or hereafter employed by any city which has created such pension fund and pension board as hereinbefore provided, of the age of sixty (60) years and upwards, who shall have been so employed for a period of twenty (20) years or more, shall, upon application to the board of pensions herein created, be retired from service and shall, during the remainder of his or her life, receive the pension or compensation fixed by this act, subject to such qualifications as are herein contained. 
    Retirement allowance-Proof of disability; joint and single coverage members defined. During the lifetime of any person in the employment of any city crating such pension fund and pension board as hereinbefore provided, he or she shall be entitled to receive as a pension annually, from the fund set aside for the purpose, fifty (50) percent of the amount which would constitute the average annual salary or wages which he or she received during the last or any five (5) years of his or her employment by the said city, whichever is the higher, said pension to be paid in semi-monthly payments. Should any persons so employed, after twenty (20) years of service, be dismissed, voluntarily retired, or be in any manner deprived of his or her position or employment before attaining the age of sixty (60) years, upon continuing a monthly payment to the fund equal to the last amount due and paid monthly while in active service, said person shall be entitled to the pension above-mentioned, notwithstanding he or she has not attained the age of sixty (60) years at the time of his or her separation from the service of such city, but said pension shall not commence until he or she has attained the age of sixty (60) years at the time of his or her separation from the service of such city, but said pension shall not commence until he or she has attained the age of sixty (60) years. Should any employee however, become totally and permanently disabled, after ten (10) years of service and before attained [attaining] the age of sixty (60) years, he or she shall be entitled to the said pension. Proof of total and permanent disability shall consist of the sworn statement of three (3) practicing physicians, designated by the board, that the employee is in a permanent condition of health which would permanently disable him or her from performing the duties of his or her position or office. 
    For the purpose of this article on pensions, the following words shall have the meaning herein assigned to them: 
    Joint coverage member of the retirement system shall mean a city employee who shall have become a member of the retirement system subsequent to the last date permitted by such city for statement or preference concerning Social Security coverage, or who, having become a member on or before such date, shall have filed with the retirement board a written statement that he or she elects Social Security coverage under an agreement with the federal secretary of health, education and welfare entered into by the commonwealth. 
    Single-coverage member of the retirement system shall mean a city employee who shall have become a member of the retirement system on or before the last date permitted by such city for statement of preference concerning Social Security and who either shall have filed with the retirement board a written statement that he or she does not elect Social Security coverage under any agreement with the federal secretary of health, education and welfare entered into by the commonwealth, or shall not have filed with the retirement board any written statement. 
    Where a city has entered into an agreement with the commonwealth to place certain employees under the federal Social Security Act, the pension to be paid joint coverage members according to the provisions of this section payable after the age and upon that portion of annual compensation on which Social Security benefits are payable, shall be reduced by an amount equal to forty (40) percent of the primary insurance amount of Social Security paid or payable to the member. Such reduction shall be subject to the following provisions: 
(1)  Upon attainment of the age at which Social Security benefits are payable by a beneficiary receiving a pension or upon retirement of a contributor after attaining that age, his eligibility to the old age insurance benefit and the primary insurance amount of social security upon which the reduction in the pension shall be based, shall be computed by the board in the manner specified in the federal Social Security Act, except that in determining such eligibility and such amount only wages or compensation for services performed in the employ of the city shall be included. 
(2)  The reduction shall not apply to a pension for total permanent disability payable under this section. 
(3)  Whenever the amount of the reduction from the pension shall have been once determined, it shall remain fixed for the duration of the pension, except that any decrease in the primary insurance amount under the Social Security Act shall result in a corresponding decrease in the amount of the reduction from the pension. 
(4)  The total sum, including Social Security benefits, to be received upon retirement by an employee who is a member of the system at the time of the agreement shall not be less than the allowance that would be paid by the retirement system in the absence of the agreement. 
If council elects, by ordinance, to make such payments, the surviving spouse of an employee who retired on pension or is killed in the service on or after January 1, 1960, shall, during his lifetime or so long as he does not remarry, be entitled to receive a pension calculated at the rate of fifty (50) percent of the pension member was receiving or would have been entitled to had he been retired at the time of his death. 
    Retirement allowances; full coverage; payments. Where a city has entered into an agreement with the commonwealth to place certain employees under the federal Social Security Act, the pension board may authorize any joint coverage member of the retirement system to elect according to the provisions of this section to receive compensation without the reduction provided for in section 4343, provided he shall make a lump-sum payment to the pension board, or installment payments as may be approved by the board, equal to the difference between the amount of the accumulated fund to his credit in the fund as of the last date for which salary or wages was paid and the amount which would have been to his credit in such fund if contributions had been made on that portion of his salary or wages on which Social Security allowances are payable, at the same rate as made on that portion of his salary or wages in excess thereof, from the time that such salary or wages became subject to Social Security coverage. Such election shall be made, in writing, in the form prescribed by the pension board, and shall be accompanied by the lump-sum payment or an agreement as to installment payments herein required. 
    The pension board may authorize any such member to make the election herein provided at any time, and if made prior to retirement, such member shall, in addition to any lump-sum or installment payments required, pay to the board contributions on his entire salary or wages thereafter received at the rate provided in this act for monthly salary or wages in excess of that on which Social Security allowances are payable. 
    Amount of payments into fund; repayment before retirement. The employees of any city creating such pension fund and pension board shall pay into the board of pensions monthly an amount equal to two (2) percent of their monthly salaries or wages, and if council elects, by ordinance, to make such payments, an additional amount not to exceed one percent if deemed necessary by council to provide sufficient funds for payments to the surviving spouses of members who were retired on pension or killed in the service, which shall be applied to the purposes of the fund. Payment of the monthly amount or contribution herein mentioned shall cease and be discontinued at the time the beneficiary received the pension herein provided. If for any cause any employee contributing to the pension fund shall cease to be an employee of the city before the said employee becomes entitled to a pension, the total amount of the contributions paid into the pension fund by such employee shall be refunded to him or her in full, without interest. If any such employee shall have returned to him or her the amount contributed as aforesaid, and shall afterward reenter the employ of the city, said employee shall not be entitled to the pension designated until twenty (20) years after said reemployment, unless he or she shall return to the pension fund the amount withdrawn, in which event that period of twenty (20) years shall be computed from the time said employee first enters the service of the city. In the event of the death of any such employee, before the said employee becomes entitled to the pension aforesaid, the said total amount of contributions paid into the pension fund by said employee shall be paid over to the estate of said deceased employee. 
    Determination of liability upon extension of Social Security. Where a city has entered into an agreement with the commonwealth to place its employees under the federal Social Security Act, the pension board shall appoint an actuary and may fix his compensation. The actuary shall determine the present value of the liability on account of pensions payable under the provision of section 4343 of this Act to employees who are members of the system on the effective date of the agreement, and shall offset the value of any assets in the pension fund to determine the unfunded liability. The city may make such payments as it desires toward the unfunded liability until the accumulated reserve equals the present value of the liability. The actuary shall also determine the amount which shall be contributed, annually, into the fund on account of service of all new and original members subsequent to the effective date of the agreement. 
    Employees shall pay into the board of pensions, monthly, an amount equal to three and one-half (31/2) percent of that portion of monthly compensation on which Social Security allowances are payable and five (5) percent of any monthly compensation in excess of that on which social security allowances are payable. The remainder of the needed annual contribution for service subsequent to the date of the agreement, as shall be paid by it to the board of pensions by annual appropriations. The provisions of this section shall, in all applicable cases, supersede the provisions relating to contributions in section 4344 and section 4348 of this Act. 
    Payments by laborers optional. Any person holding a position in any such city as a laborer, at a per diem wage, shall not be compelled to pay or contribute toward the pension fund herein provided for, but shall have the option or choice of so doing and, in that event only, of becoming entitled to the pension provided by this Act. 
    Heads of departments to certify list of employees. The head of every department and office employing persons entitled to receive a pension shall certify to the board of pensions all persons so employed and the amount of salary or wages which are paid to said employees, together with dismissals, resignations, or terminations of service and, from the records of their office or department, shall furnish such other relevant information as the board of pensions shall require, in the case of a volunteer fireman, "head of department or office" shall mean the president or secretary of the board of trustees of the volunteer fire company involved. 
    Receipt, investment and payment of funds. It shall be the duty of the board of pensions to receive and retain and, when deemed advisable, to invest the funds payable in accordance with the provisions of this subdivision of this article, and to pay over by warrant or check the amount due to said employees. 
    Appropriations and contributions to fund. The council may annually set aside, apportion, and appropriate, out of all taxes and income of such city, unto the board of pensions, a sum sufficient to maintain the pensions or compensation due hereunder on account of the city contributions for all employees except volunteer firemen. On account of volunteer firemen who become members of the pension fund, the board of trustees of the volunteer fire company employing and paying them shall annually contribute to the board of pensions a sum equal to the same percentage of its participating payroll as the amount contributed by the city for the same year bears to its participating payroll. 
    Application. The benefits conferred by this subdivision of this article shall apply to all persons employed in any capacity by, or holding positions in, or, in the case of a volunteer fireman, rendering services recognized and accepted by, the cities creating a pension fund and pension board in accordance with its provisions, but this subdivision shall not apply to employees of such departments, bureaus, or offices as are otherwise protected by pension authorized by this Act. 
    Any volunteer fireman may become a member of such a pension fund, as of the date of his original employment or of the inception of the pension fund, whichever is later, upon his making back contributions, and if the volunteer fire company or board of trustees thereof employing and paying him agrees to contribute and contributes to the pension fund, from time to time, the sums hereinbefore required. 
    Computation of time of service. The time of service herein specified, namely, twenty (20) years, shall be computed from the time of the first or original employments, said employment to consist of service to the city and need not be continuous. 
    Funds payable to be free of attachment. The compensation or pension herein mentioned shall not be subject to attachment or execution, and shall be payable only to the beneficiary designated, and shall not be subject to assignment or transfer. 
    Definitions. The term or phrase "employee," "employed," by the city" or "in the employment of any city," as used in this section, is meant to include all persons in the service of cities creating a pension fund and a pension board in accordance with the provisions thereof, who are not now otherwise protected by pensions authorized by this act, and any volunteer fireman who becomes a member of the pension fund. 
    Volunteer fireman shall mean a driver of firefighting apparatus or ambulances, regularly employed and paid by a volunteer fire company, rendering services recognized and accepted by a city. 
    Beneficiaries of fund not to be employed by city. No person or persons who shall have become a beneficiary shall be employed by the said city any capacity, excepting in an office elected by popular vote, but during such elected term he or she shall not be entitled to a pension. 
(Ord. No. 13-01, §§ II-IX, 12-12-01) 
Sec. 2-170. - Limited vested benefit. 
(a)  Should a member of the pension fund terminate employment before reaching the date which would have been the member's earliest retirement date had the member continued employment by meeting the minimum age and minimum period of continuous service requirements but after having completed twelve (12) years of full-time service, the member shall be entitled to vest his or her retirement benefits subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The member must file with the management board of the pension fund a written notice of his or her intention to vest; 
(2)  The member must include in the notice the date the member intends to terminate his or her service as an employee; 
(3)  The termination date shall be at least thirty (30) days later than the date of notice to vest; 
(4)  The member must be in good standing with the city on the date of notice to vest; and 
(5)  The board shall indicate on the notice to vest the rate of monthly pay of the member as of the date of said notice to vest or the highest average annual salary which the member received during any five (5) years of service preceding said date, whichever is the higher. 
(b)  Upon reaching the date which would have been the member's earliest retirement date had the member continued his or her employment with the city, the member shall notify the board, in writing, that the member desires to collect his or her pension. The amount of retirement benefits the member is entitled to receive under this section shall be computed as follows: 
(1)  The initial determination of the member's base retirement benefits shall be computed on the salary indicated on the notice to vest; and 
(2)  The portion of the base retirement benefits due the member shall be determined by applying to the base amount the percentage that his or her years of service actually rendered bears to the years of service which would have been rendered had the member continued to be employed by the city until his or her earliest retirement date. 
(Ord. No. 3-2013, § I, 2-28-13) 
DIVISION 3. - PAID FIREMEN'S PENSION FUND[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 10. 
State Law reference- Firemen's pension fund, 53 P.S. § 39320 et seq. 

Sec. 2-171. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this division, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section, unless the context clearly requires otherwise: 
    Children shall mean children of a member or of a deceased member, but limited to children who are under eighteen (18) years of age. 
    Fund shall mean the "paid firemen's pension fund." 
    Member shall mean a person employed by the city as a paid and uniformed member of the bureau of fire. 
(Ord. No. 43-68, § 3, 1-21-69) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 2-172. - Fund continued; purpose of fund generally. 
(a)  In accordance with and pursuant to the provisions of the Act of June 23, 1931, P.L. 932, Art. XLIII, Sec. 4230 et seq., as amended, there is hereby continued in the city a pension fund to be designated as the "paid firemen's pension fund," for the purpose of providing pensions to the members of such fund and to such other beneficiaries as shall be specified in this division. Such fund shall receive property and funds and shall hold and distribute funds for the purpose and benefit of the members and other beneficiaries of the fund. 
(b)  Any and all rights which have become vested under and pursuant to the ordinance adopted under File of Council No. 29 of 1966, and amendments thereto shall be deemed to continue in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 43-68, §§ 1, 2, 1-21-69) 
Sec. 2-173. - Board of managers-Established; composition; appointment of members. 
    The paid firemen's pension fund shall be under the direction and control of a board of managers consisting of the mayor, city administrator, director of human resources, the city controller, the fire chief, and two (2) members of the pension plan duly chosen by the members of the pension plan. Of the members chosen by the members of the bureau of fire, one (1) shall be chosen for a term of two (2) years and one (1) for a term of four (4) years. Biennially thereafter, one (1) manager shall be chosen for a term of four (4) years to take the place of the members whose term expires. In case of a vacancy among the managers chosen by the members of the bureau of fire, a successor shall be chosen by such members for the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 43-68, § 4, 1-21-69; Ord. No. 14-70, § 1, 3-3-70; Ord. No. 17-98, § 1, 5-28-98; Ord. No. 58-98, § 1, 9-24-98) 
Sec. 2-174. - Same-Powers and duties. 
    The paid firemen's pension fund shall be applied under such regulations as the board of managers shall prescribe. It shall be the duty of the board of managers to present to the city council, annually, a detailed statement of its assets and liabilities on or before the first meeting of the city council in February of the following year. The board of managers shall have the authority to do all things necessary to provide an effective and a financially sound fund and incur such expenses as they deem appropriate for such purposes. 
(Ord. No. 43-68, § 5, 1-21-69; Ord. No. 17-98, § 1, 5-28-98) 
Sec. 2-175. - Acceptance and administration of gifts, grants, devises, etc. 
    The city may take by gift, grant, devise or bequest any money or property, real, personal or mixed, for the benefit of the paid firemen's pension fund. In such cases, the city shall observe all and singular the conditions and directions of the donors, and such property shall be administered by such of the board of managers who are officers of the city. Unless there is a specific ordinance adopted with reference to such gift, grant, devise or bequest, the same shall be transferred by such officers to the fund. 
(Ord. No. 43-68, § 6, 1-21-69) 
Sec. 2-176. - Investment of funds. 
    If any funds under this division are invested, they shall be invested in accordance with the provisions of the Fiduciaries Investment Act, 20 Pa. C.S.A. § 7301 et seq., and the amendments thereto. 
(Ord. No. 43-68, § 7, 1-21-69) 
Sec. 2-177. - Members of fund designated. 
    All members on January 1, 1969, and all subsequent members shall be considered members of the paid firemen's pension fund. 
(Ord. No. 43-68, § 8, 1-21-69; Ord. No. 2-2010, 3-25-11) 
Sec. 2-178. - Contributions of members. 
(a)  There shall be paid into the paid firemen's pension fund by each member in the manner prescribed in this division five (5) percent of the salary of each member. Such sum shall be deducted at each payroll period by the city finance officer and shall be paid by him forthwith to the treasurer of the fund. 
(b)  The term salary shall include a base monthly salary; such base monthly salary includes longevity, service out of rank, overtime, night differential and holiday pay. There shall be no contributions computed on the purchase of accumulated sick day buy-back. Purchase of sick pay is not salary for any purpose of this division. This definition of salary shall be retroactive to January 1, 1969. 
(Ord. No. 43-68, § 9, 1-21-69; Ord. No. 16-77, § 1, 5-12-77) 
Sec. 2-179. - Contributions by city from taxes. 
    The city shall pay annually to the paid firemen's pension fund the sum of money not less than one-half of one percent nor more than three (3) percent of all city taxes levied by the city, other than taxes levied to pay interest on or to extinguish the debt of the city or any part thereof, such sum to be paid at least quarterly during the fiscal year of the city, but the city council may exceed the limitations imposed by this section if an additional amount is deemed necessary to provide sufficient funds for payments to widows of members retired on pension or killed or who die in the service. 
(Ord. No. 43-68, § 10, 1-21-69) 
Sec. 2-180. - Accumulation of funds from tax on fire insurance companies. 
    The city treasurer is hereby directed to receive from the treasurer of the state the portion of the tax paid on premiums by foreign fire insurance companies, as provided in 72 P.S. § 2262, or amendments thereto, due to the city, and to pay over the same, when and as soon as the tax from time to time is received by him, to the treasurer of the paid firemen's pension fund. 
(Ord. No. 43-68, § 11, 1-21-69) 
Sec. 2-181. - Use of funds; persons eligible to receive pension payments. 
    The paid firemen's pension fund shall be applied, under such regulations as the board of managers shall prescribe, for the benefit of such members of the bureau of fire as shall receive honorable discharge therefrom by reason of service or age or disability, widows or widowers of retired members, and the families of such as may be killed or who die in the service. All such pensions as shall be allowed to those who are retired by reason of the disabilities or of service or age shall be in conformity with a uniform scale together with service increments as hereinafter provided. Benefits allowed from such fund to families of such as are killed or who die in service shall take into consideration the member's widow or widower and his or her minor children under eighteen (18) years of age, if any survive. 
    Such regulations shall prescribe a minimum period of continuous service not less than twenty (20) years, and a minimum age not less than fifty (50) years, after which members of the bureau of fire may be retired or elected to be retired on pension from active duty, an such members as are retired shall be subject to service, from time to time, as a firemen's reserve in cases of emergency until unfitted for such service, when they may be finally discharged by reason of age or disability. Upon the death of a member who retires on pension or who could have retired on pension, or is killed or dies in the service, payments as provided in this article shall be made to his widow or widower during her or his life; and if there be no widow or widower, but there are children who are eligible, payment shall be made to them until such children reach age eighteen (18). 
(Ord. No. 43-68, § 12, 1-21-69; Ord. No. 8-2008, § 1, 6-12-08; Ord. No. 11-2009, § 1, 9-10-09) 
Sec. 2-182. - Pensions and service increments. 
(a)  Payments of pensions shall not be a charge on any fund in the treasury of the city or under its control save the firemen's pension fund herein provided for. The basis of the pension of a member shall be determined by the monthly salary of the member at the date of retirement, or the highest average annual salary which he received during any five (5) years of service preceding retirement, whichever is the higher, whether for disability, or by reason of age or service, and except as to service increment provided for in subsection (b) of this section, shall be one-half the annual salary of such member at the time of retirement computed at such monthly or average annual rate, whichever is higher. Lump sum vacation pay is not salary and, therefore, shall not be included in any calculation of annual salary for the purpose of computation of pensions. In the case of the payment of pensions to members for permanent injury incurred in service, and to families of members killed or who die in service, the amount and commencement of the payment of pensions shall be fixed by regulations of the board. Such regulations shall not take into consideration the amount and duration of workmen's compensation allowed by law. Payments to widows of members retired on pension or killed in the service on or after January 1, 1960, or who die in the service on or after January 1, 1968, shall be the amount payable to the member or which would have been payable and had he been retired at the time of his death. 
    The pension benefit of firefighters retiring on or after January 1, 1994, shall be computed as a percentage equal to two and one-half (21/2) percent of each year of service up to twenty (20) years, plus one and one-quarter (11/4) for each year of service in excess of twenty (20) years reduced by one-third ( 1/3 ) of one percent for each month by which the benefit commencement date precedes the retiree's fiftieth birthday. Effective January 1, 1997, there shall be a cap of seventy-five (75) percent on the service increment for years of service in excess of twenty (20) years. Said cap shall be reduced by seventy (70) percent effective June 29, 1999. It is understood that the first one hundred dollars ($100.00) of this figure shall count as the service increment as required in subsection (b)(1) of this section, and as required under 53 P.S. section 39322(b)(1).
