(b)  In addition to the pension which is authorized to be paid from the firemen's pension fund by this division and notwithstanding the limitations therein placed upon such pensions and upon contributions, every contributor who shall become entitled to the pension shall also be entitled to the payment of a "service increment" in accordance with and subject to the conditions hereinafter set forth: 
(1)  Service increment shall be the sum obtained by computing the number of whole years after having served the minimum required by this division during which a contributor has been employed by the city and paid out by the city treasury and multiplying the number of years so computed by an amount equal to one-fortieth of the retirement allowance which has become payable to such contributor in accordance with the provisions of this division. In computing the service increment, no employment after the contributor has reached the age of sixty-five (65) years shall be included, and no service increment shall be paid in excess of one hundred ($100.00) per month. 
(2)  Each contributor shall pay into the pension fund a monthly sum in addition to his pension contribution, which shall not exceed the sum of one dollar ($1.00) per month; and provided, that such service increment contribution shall not be paid after a contributor has reached the age of sixty-five (65) years. 
(3)  Any person who is a member of the department on the effective date of the ordinance from which this division was derived who has already reached the age of sixty-five (65) years shall have his service increment computed on the years of employment prior to the date of reaching his sixty-fifth birthday. 
(4)  Service increment contributions shall be paid at the same time and in the same manner as pensions, and may be withdrawn in full, without interest, by persons who leave the employment of such city, subject to the same conditions by which retirement contributions may be withdrawn, or by persons who retire before becoming entitled to any service increment. 
(5)  All members of the bureau of fire who are now contributors to the pension fund and all those employed by the city hereafter, if required to become contributors to the pension fund, shall be subject to the provisions of this division. 
(c)  For the purpose of computation of pension there shall be added to the base monthly salary one-twelfth of the total additional compensation received for service out of rank, overtime, night differential and holiday pay earned during the twelve (12) calendar month period which preceded the effective date as of which the pension first became due and payable. At no time shall the purchase of accumulated sick pay buy-back be included in the computation of any pension under this division. This subsection is to be retroactive to January 1, 1969. 
(Ord. No. 16-77, § 13, 5-12-77; Ord. No. 4-85, 2-14-85; Ord. No. 20-96, § 1, 9-19-96) 
Sec. 2-183. - Continuation of previous pension payments. 
    All benefit payments being received by members of any previous pension fund of the bureau of fire, or their respective widows, shall continue to be paid from the paid firemen's pension fund. 
(Ord. No. 43-68, § 14, 1-21-69) 
Sec. 2-184. - Separation from service prior to retirement. 
    If for any cause any member of the bureau of fire contributing to the pension fund shall cease to be a member of the bureau of fire before he becomes entitled to a pension, the total amount of the contributions paid into the pension fund by such member shall be refunded to him in full without interest. If any such member shall have returned to him the amount contributed, and shall afterward again become a member of the bureau of fire, he shall not be entitled to the pension designated until twenty (20) years after his reemployment, unless he shall return to the pension fund the amount withdrawn, in which event the period of twenty (20) years shall be computed from the time the member first became a member of the bureau of fire, excluding therefrom any period of time during which the member was not employed by the bureau of fire. In the event of the death of a member of the bureau of fire not in the line of service before the member becomes entitled to the pension aforesaid and such member is not survived by a widow or family entitled to payments as hereinbefore provided, the total amount of contributions paid into the pension fund by the member shall be paid over to his estate. In case of the death of a member not in the line of service before the member becomes entitled to the pension aforesaid and such member is survived by a widow eligible to receive benefits as hereinbefore provided, the total amount of contributions paid into the pension fund by the member shall be paid over to such widow. 
(Ord. No. 43-68, § 15, 1-21-69) 
Sec. 2-185. - Credit for military service. 
(a)  Effective as of the date of the final passage of this section, all members of the bureau of firemen's relief pension fund, who have not already bought back military service time, who are contributors, who served in the armed forces of the United States subsequent to September 1, 1940, and who were not members of the bureau of firemen's relief pension fund prior to such military service shall be entitled to have full credit for each year or fraction thereof not to exceed five (5) years of such service, upon his or her payment to the bureau of firemen's relief pension fund of an amount equal to that which the member would have paid had he or she been a member of the bureau of firemen's relief pension fund during the period for which the member desires credit at a contribution rate of five (5) percent of what the member's annual salary would have been had the member been employed by the City of Wilkes-Barre during the period of military service for which the member desires credit. 
(b)  Any fireman who is presently a member of the firemen's pension fund and who desires to purchase military service pursuant to the foregoing provision must do so by August 1, 1976; and anyone who subsequently becomes a member must purchase such military service within six (6) months of his first payment to the pension fund pursuant to section 2-178. 
(c)  The foregoing military service credit provision shall extend to and establish credit towards the minimum requirements for age or service and for service increments for the purpose of retirement. 
(Ord. No. 11-75, § 1, 6-5-75; Ord. No. 14-06, § 1(7A), 9-21-06) 
Sec. 2-186. - Not subject to attachment, assignment, levy, etc. 
    All pensions granted under this division, and every portion thereof, shall not be subject to pledge, assignment or transfer and shall be exempt from attachment and shall not be seized, taken or subject to detainer or levied upon by virtue of an execution or any process or proceeding whatsoever. 
(Ord. No. 43-68, § 16, 1-21-69) 
Sec. 2-187. - Payments to be charged only to the fund. 
    Payments of pensions under this division shall not be a charge on any fund in the treasury of the city or under its control, save the paid firemen's pension fund provided for in this division. 
(Ord. No. 43-68, § 17, 1-21-69) 
Sec. 2-188. - Honorable or general discharge required for credit for military service. 
    In order for a member to receive credit for years of service spent in military service, the member must have received an honorable or general discharge. 
(Ord. No. 17-98, § 1, 5-28-98; Ord. No. 58-98, § 1, 9-24-98) 
Sec. 2-189. - Pension fund meetings. 
    The director of human resources shall be charged with the duties of scheduling and advertising the pension fund meetings. The minutes of each meeting shall be recorded and filed with the office of the city clerk within thirty (30) days of the date of each meeting. All meeting minutes, records, and any and all documents associated with the pension funds are the property of the City of Wilkes-Barre. Any city employee who is a duly appointed member of the pension board shall be entitled to receive time off with pay to attend pension fund meetings held during his regularly scheduled work shift. 
(Ord. No. 17-98, § 1, 5-28-98) 
Secs. 2-190-2-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - FIREFIGHTERS' PENSION FUND[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 10. 

Sec. 2-201. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this division is to establish benefits payable to firefighters or beneficiaries of firefighters who are appointed to the bureau of fire of the city after the enactment of the ordinance from which this division derives. A funding policy for the bureau of firemen's relief is also established by this division. 
(Ord. No. 25-76, § 1, 7-8-76; Ord. No. 17-80, § 1, 7-10-80; Ord. No. 103-86, § 1, 10-9-86; Ord. No. 6-93, § 1, 2-25-93; Ord. No. 21-95, § 1, 7-13-95) 
Sec. 2-202. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this division, the following terms shall have the meanings herein defined unless the context clearly indicates a contrary intention: 
    Layoff. A layoff is a nonvoluntary termination of employment of the participant excepting disciplinary action taken by the city relative to the participant. 
    Monthly compensation. Monthly compensation consists of basic monthly compensation, plus longevity payments, acting officers pay, EMT bonuses, overtime pay, night shift differential, educational incentive payments, holiday pay, and annual buy back of sick leave. 
    Normal retirement age. Normal retirement age shall be age fifty (50). 
(Ord. No. 25-76, § 2, 7-8-76; Ord. No. 17-80, § 2(B), (C), 7-10-80; Ord. No. 103-86, § 2(B), (C), (H), 10-9-86; Ord. No. 20-89, § 1, 5-9-89; Ord. No. 3-93, § 2(C), 2-25-93; Ord. No. 21-95, § 2(B), (C), (H), 7-13-95) 
Sec. 2-203. - Participants. 
    A participant is a firefighter who is appointed to the bureau of fire of the city and becomes a member of the pension fund after July 8, 1976. Specifically the term "participant" does not include a former firefighter who had been appointed previously to the bureau of fire of the city and whose employment was subsequently terminated. If such a former firefighter is reappointed to the bureau of fire of the city, his rights under the existing paid firemen's pension fund for the City of Wilkes-Barre shall be preserved. 
(Ord. No. 25-76, § 2, 7-8-86; Ord. No. 17-80, § 2(A), 7-10-80; Ord. No. 103-86, § 2(A), 10-9-86; Ord. No. 6-93, § 2(A), 2-25-93; Ord. No. 21-95, § 2(A), 7-13-95) 
Sec. 2-204. - Bureau of firemen's relief. 
(a)  Bureau of firemen's relief is the administrative bureau to administer the firefighter's pension fund. Said bureau of firemen's relief is composed of five (5) members who shall be as follows: 
(1)  The mayor; 
(2)  The director of human resources; 
(3)  The city controller; and 
(4)  Two (2) participants of the pension plan duly elected by the total membership of the participants of the plan. 
(b)  The bureau of firemen's relief shall make, and upon approval of the mayor, promulgate its own rules and regulations pertaining to the administration of this division or any other applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 25-76, § 2, 7-8-86; Ord. No. 17-80, § 2(G), 7-10-80; Ord. No. 30-80, § 1, 11-12-80; Ord. No. 103-86, § 2(G), 10-9-86; Ord. No. 3-93, § 2(G), 2-25-93; Ord. No. 21-95, § 2(G), 7-13-95; Ord. No. 15-98, § 1, 5-28-98; Ord. No. 59-98, § 1, 9-24-98) 
Sec. 2-205. - Participant's contributions. 
(a)  Each participant shall be required to contribute to the bureau of fireman's relief an amount equal to five (5) percent of his or her monthly compensation effective January 1, 1996. The City of Wilkes-Barre is authorized to deduct said contribution from the participant's monthly compensation and to remit that sum to the bureau of firemen's relief. 
(b)  The term "salary" [contribution] shall include a base monthly salary. The base monthly salary includes longevity, service out of rank, overtime, night differential, holiday and purchase of accumulated annual sick day buy-back. 
(Ord. No. 25-76, § 2, 7-8-76; Ord. No. 17-80, § 2(F), 7-10-80; Ord. No. 28-82, § 1, 9-23-82; Ord. No. 103-86, § 2(F), 10-9-86; Ord. No. 95-87, § 1, 12-10-87; Ord. No. 3-93, § 2(F), 2-25-93; Ord. No. 19-94, § 1, 11-22-94; Ord. No. 21-95, § 2(F), 7-13-95) 
Sec. 2-206. - Early retirement. 
    A participant who has completed twenty (20) years of service may elect to retire prior to attainment of age fifty (50); provided, however, that if such participant elects to have his monthly pension determined in accordance with the provisions of this division commence before attainment of age fifty (50), said pension benefit shall be reduced by four (4) percent for each year such participant's age is short of age fifty (50). 
(Ord. No. 25-76, § 2, 7-8-76; Ord. No. 17-80, § 2(D), 7-10-80; Ord. No. 103-86, § 2(D), 10-9-86; Ord. No. 3-93, § 2(D), 2-25-93; Ord. No. 21-95, § 2(D), 7-13-95) 
Sec. 2-207. - Permanent and total disability. 
    A participant shall be deemed to be permanently disabled if he or she has been totally and permanently physically or mentally disabled by bodily injury or disease so as to be prevented from engaging in the regular duties of a fireman of the bureau of fire of the city, and shall be entitled for disability if the bureau of firemen's relief shall determine that he or she is so permanently disabled on the basis of written reports obtained from a physician designated by the bureau of firemen's relief. 
(Ord. No. 25-76, § 2, 7-8-76; Ord. No. 17-80, § 2(E), 7-10-80; Ord. No. 103-86, § 2(E), 10-9-86; Ord. No. 3-93, § 2(E), 2-25-93; Ord. No. 21-95, § 2(E), 7-13-95) 
Sec. 2-208. - Benefit generally. 
    A participant who has completed twenty (20) years of service and has attained normal retirement age shall receive from the pension fund administered by the bureau of firemen's relief for the rest of his or her life a monthly pension equal to: 
(a)  Fifty (50) percent of his or her average monthly compensation for the firefighter's final year average salary; plus 
(b)  An additional monthly pension equal to one and twenty-five one-hundredths percent (1.25%) of his or her average salary multiplied by the complete years of service in excess of twenty (20) years. 
Effective January 1, 1997, there shall be a cap of seventy-five (75) percent on the service increment for years of service in excess of twenty (20) years. Said cap shall be reduced to seventy (70) percent effective June 29, 1999. 
(c)  A participant who has completed twenty (20) years of service and elects early retirement shall receive a monthly pension for life reduced by four (4) percent for each year short of age fifty (50). 
(d)  If a participant who has completed ten (10) or more years of service but less than twenty (20) years of service retires or terminates his or her employment, such participant shall receive a monthly pension for life equal to fifty (50) percent of his or her average monthly compensation for the firefighter's final year average salary prior to retirement or termination of employment multiplied by a fraction, the numerator of which shall be the number of full years of service completed and the denominator of which shall be twenty (20), which pension shall commence when the participant attains age fifty (50). If, however, such participant elects to receive said monthly benefit upon termination of employment, the monthly benefit to which he or she is entitled shall be further reduced by four (4) percent times each year short of age fifty (50). 
(e)  If the employment of a participant with less than ten (10) years of service terminates and such participant or his or her spouse or children are not entitled to disability [or] pension benefits under the provisions of this division, the net of the total of the participant's contributions plus interest calculated at the rate of five (5) percent per annum, less the total of all pension, disability or other payments made to the participant, his or her spouse or children, shall be refunded to the participant or paid to the estate of the deceased participant. 
(f)  If a participant dies, while employed as a firefighter by the City of Wilkes-Barre, leaving no spouse or no children entitled to pension benefits under the provisions of this division, the net total of the participant's contributions plus interest calculated at the rate of five (5) percent per annum, less the total of all pension, disability or other payments made to the participant, shall be refunded to the estate of the deceased participant. 
(g)  If a participant has his or her employment terminated by reason of layoff and the participant does not elect to exercise options available to him to her under this division, the participant shall be entitled to elect as follows as to how he or she wants his or her pension contributions maintained: 
(1)  If the employment of a participant is terminated by reason of a layoff, then the participant shall be allowed to withdraw from the pension fund the net of the total of the participant's contribution plus interest calculated at the rate of five (5) percent per annum, less the total of all pension payments made to the participant and/or his or her spouse or children. 
(2)  The participant may elect to leave the net of the total of the participant's contributions within the bureau of firemen's pension relief fund. 
(3)  The participant shall be entitled to exercise option (1) above at anytime during the layoff period. 
(4)  If the participant exercises option (1) above, then upon being rehired or called back to work the participant shall be allowed to repay all monies withdrawn from the fund and shall be given credit for the time period of employment for which pension funds were withheld. If the participant elects to repay pension fund monies, he or she must elect to do so within six (6) months from the date of rehire and is required to serve written notice of his or her intentions to the pension board during this six-month time period. The participant shall repay all monies to the pension fund within twenty-four (24) months of the date of written notice of the pension board of the participant's election to repay withdrawn monies. Failure to comply with the time requirements of this subsection shall disqualify the participant from exercising the options available to him or her under this subsection. 
(5)  Any participant who elects option (1) above shall be precluded from buying back or being given credit for the time period for which the participant was laid off. 
(6)  If the participant exercises option (2) above, then upon being rehired the participant shall be entitled to have full credit for the time period which the participant was laid off; provided, that upon the participant being rehired, the participant shall make payment to the bureau of fireman's pension relief fund the contributions which would have been paid on the actual wages which the participant would have received had he or she not been laid off. The participant shall have six (6) months from the date of rehire to serve written notice to the pension board of his or her intentions to exercise this option. The participant shall be required to repay within twenty-four (24) months of the date of written notice to the pension board of the participant's election to repay contributions which would have been paid on the actual wages which the participant would have received had he or she not been laid off. Failure to comply with the time requirements of this subsection shall disqualify the participant from exercising the options available under this subsection. 
(7)  Any participant who elects option (2) above shall not have his or her continuity of service broken for the time period during which said participant made contribution to the pension fund prior to the layoff time period. A participant who elects option (2) and (6), and complies with all time restraints as set forth in option (6), shall be given full credit for the layoff time period for purposes of pension benefits and computation of service time. 
(8)  If a participant elects option (1) above, and does not repay net contributions and interest within the time frames set forth in this division, then the participant shall be precluded from calculating past contributions made to the pension board and service time prior to the layoff towards his or her pension computations and benefits. 
(Ord. No. 25-76, § 3, 7-8-76; Ord. No. 17-80, § 3, 7-10-80; Ord. No. 103-86, § 3, 10-9-86; Ord. No. 3-93, § 3, 2-25-93; Ord. No. 21-95, § 3, 7-13-95; Ord. No. 21-96, § 1, 10-10-96) 
Sec. 2-209. - Disability benefits. 
(a)  If the participant has become permanently and totally disabled in the line of duty, such participant shall receive a monthly disability benefit equal to fifty (50) percent of his or her average monthly compensation for the firefighter's final year average salary prior to the commencement of the disability; and if the participant has service time in excess of twenty (20) years, the participant shall be entitled to additional monthly benefits as per section 2-208(b) of this division; or if the participant who has become permanently and totally disabled in the line of duty has not been employed for a period of at least five (5) years prior to the commencement of the disability, such participant shall receive a monthly disability benefit equal to fifty (50) percent of his or her average monthly compensation at the time participant became totally and permanently disabled, computed on the assumption that the participant has attained five (5) years of service at the classification attained at the time the participant became totally and permanently disabled, which benefits shall continue until the disabled participant is determined to be no longer disabled and is under normal retirement age, or until the death of the disabled participant, whichever is the first to occur. 
(b)  If a participant who becomes disabled, which disability is not service connected, he or she shall be entitled to a monthly disability benefit if he or she has completed five (5) or more years of service. A disability benefit payable hereunder shall be as follows: 
(1)  If the participant has completed at least twenty (20) years of service, such participant shall receive a monthly disability benefit equal to fifty (50) percent of his or her average monthly compensation for the firefighter's final year average salary prior to the commencement of the disability; and if the participant has service time in excess of twenty (20) years, the participant shall be entitled to additional monthly pension benefits as per section 2-208(b) of this division, which benefits shall continue until the disabled participant is determined to be no longer disabled and is under normal retirement age or until the death of the disabled participant, whichever is the first to occur. 
(2)  If the participant has completed less than twenty (20) years of service, which disability is not service connected, the disabled participant shall receive a monthly disability benefit equal to fifty (50) percent of his or her average monthly compensation for the firefighter's final year average salary prior to commencement of disability multiplied by the ratio of the actual full years of service completed years to twenty (20) years of service, which monthly disability benefit shall continue until the disabled participant is determined to be no longer disabled and is under normal retirement age or until the death of the disabled participant, whichever is the first to occur. 
(c)  In order to qualify for a nonservice related disability pension, a participant hired after the effective date of this section [October 4, 1998] must have completed at least six (6) years of service. 
(Ord. No. 25-76, § 4, 7-8-86; Ord. No. 17-80, § 4, 7-10-80; Ord. No. 28-82, § 2, 9-23-82; Ord. No. 103-86, § 4, 10-9-86; Ord. No. 3-93, § 4, 2-25-93; Ord. No. 21-95, § 4, 7-13-95; Ord. No. 15-98, § 1, 5-28-98; Ord. No. 59-98, § 1, 9-24-98) 
Sec. 2-210. - Survivor's benefits. 
(a)  If a participant dies in the line of duty, a monthly pension shall be payable to his or her spouse until her or his death equal to the monthly pension benefit the participant would have received had he or she retired as of the date of death, computed on the assumption the participant had completed twenty (20) years of service and was age fifty (50). If the deceased participant had service time in excess of twenty (20) years, the pension benefit due is to be computed allowing for additional monthly benefits as per section 2-208(b) of this division. 
(b)  If a participant dies in the line of duty who leaves no surviving spouse, a monthly pension shall be paid to the guardian of or for the benefit of such participant's dependent children who are under the age of eighteen (18) years, which payments shall continue until such time as the youngest of such children attains the age of eighteen (18) years, which benefit shall be equal to the monthly pension benefit the participant would have received had he or she retired as of the date of death, computed on the assumption the participant had completed twenty (20) years of service and was age fifty (50). 
(c)  If a retired participant dies, his or her spouse shall receive a pension benefit equal to the monthly pension benefit the participant was receiving, which benefit shall continue until such spouse's death. 
(d)  If a retired participant dies, who was receiving a pension benefit under this division, leaving dependent children who are under the age of eighteen (18) and his or her spouse has predeceased the participant, a monthly pension shall be paid to the guardian of or for the benefit of such participant's dependent children under the age of eighteen (18) years, which payments shall continue until such time as the youngest of such children attains the age of eighteen (18) years, which benefit shall be equal to the monthly pension benefit the participant was receiving at the time of his or her death. 
(e)  If a participant dies before retirement, whose death is not service connected, but has completed twenty (20) years of service, such participant's spouse or, if the participant's spouse has predeceased him or her, the participant's dependent children under the age of eighteen (18) years shall be entitled to receive a monthly pension benefit equal to the monthly pension benefit the participant would have received had he or she retired as of the date of death, said pension payments to be computed on the assumption that the participant was age fifty (50) at the time of said death. 
(f)  If the participant dies before retirement not in the line of duty, but who has completed ten (10) or more years of service but less than twenty (20) years of service, such participant's spouse or dependent children under the age of eighteen (18) years shall be entitled to receive a monthly pension benefit equal to the monthly pension benefit the participant would have received had he or she retired as of the date of death. Said pension payments will be computed on the assumption that the participant was age fifty (50) at the time of said death. 
(g)  If the spouse of a deceased participant dies who was receiving a pension benefit under this division, payments will be made to the guardian of or for the benefit of the participant's surviving children under the age of eighteen (18) years, which payments shall continue until the youngest such child attains the age of eighteen (18) years. 
(Ord. No. 25-76, § 5, 7-8-76; Ord. No. 17-80, § 5, 7-10-80; Ord. No. 28-82, § 3, 9-23-82; Ord. No. 103-86, § 5, 10-9-86; Ord. No. 21-89, § 1, 5-9-89; Ord. No. 3-93, § 5, 2-25-93; Ord. No. 21-95, § 5, 7-13-95; Ord. No. 7-2008, § 1, 6-12-08) 
Sec. 2-211. - Funding policy. 
(a)  The City of Wilkes-Barre shall every two (2) years hire a qualified actuary to prepare an actuarial report providing the pension costs in the form of a normal cost and an unfunded past service liability. In the first year after such report has been prepared, the city shall include in its budget and contribute during the next succeeding fiscal year an amount sufficient to cover one hundred (100) percent of the normal cost plus the unfunded liability minus the amount of the members' contributions. Any reduction due to member contributions shall be computed by the qualified actuary. Such actuary shall also calculate the incremental normal cost and the incremental unfunded past service liability with respect to any benefit improvements and the city shall pay such incremental normal cost and one hundred (100) percent on such incremental unfunded past service liability in the next succeeding fiscal year after such report has been prepared. 
(b)  The first actuarial report pursuant to the ordinance which enacted this division shall be prepared as of January 31, 1987, and every two (2) years thereafter on or before January 31 of the submitting year and shall be submitted to the officer of the city responsible for preparing the budget by September 1, which report shall serve as one of the bases for determining the cost of the pension fund for the budget of the city for the immediately succeeding year. The first such actuarial report shall be prepared as of January 31, 1987, and shall be submitted to the city officer responsible for preparing the budget by September 1, 1987, which report shall serve as one of the bases for the city's contribution to the Pension Fund for the calendar year 1988. 
(Ord. No. 25-76, § 6, 7-8-76; 7-8-76; Ord. No. 17-80, § 6, 7-10-80; Ord. No. 103-86, § 6, 10-9-86; Ord. No. 3-93, § 6, 2-25-93; Ord. No. 21-95, § 6, 7-13-95) 
Sec. 2-212. - Military service credit. 
(a)  Effective as of the date of the final passage of the ordinance enacting this division, all members of the bureau of firemen's relief pension fund who are contributors and who served in the armed forces of the United States subsequent to September 1, 1940, and who were not members of the bureau of firemen's relief pension fund prior to such military service shall be entitled to have full credit for each year or fraction thereof not to exceed five (5) years of such service upon their payment to the bureau of firemen's relief pension fund of the sum of the following: 
(1)  An amount equal to that which they would have paid had they been members during the period for which they desire credit; and computation of said sum will be based on: 
a.  The actual wages which they would have received if they had been members at the time for which credit is requested giving consideration to the wages then paid for the period of service involved. 
b.  If the period of service was prior to July 18, 1976 (the date as of which the bureau of firemen's relief pension fund came under the jurisdiction of council), the rate of contribution will be the amount which would have been contributed by such member had he been employed with the fire department of the city during the period of his military service. 
c.  If the period of service was on or after July 18, 1976, the rate of contribution will be the rate in existence during such period of service. 
(2)  The amount the city paid on behalf of the firemen prorated and determined as follows: 
a.  Ascertain the amount contributed to the bureau of firemen's relief pension fund then in existence during each calendar year for which credit is requested; and if a fraction of a year is involved for such year, the amount contributed will be multiplied by that fraction. 
b.  Divide the amount contributed by the city for each of such years by the number of firemen on the payroll of the city as of July 1 of each of said respective years. 
c.  Add the quotient obtained for each of said years. 
(b)  Any fireman who is presently a member of the bureau of firemen's relief pension fund and who desires to purchase military service pursuant to the foregoing provisions can do so at any time prior to his or her retirement, and anyone who subsequently becomes a member can purchase such military service at any time prior to his or her retirement. 
(c)  The foregoing military service credit provision shall extend to and establish credit towards the minimum requirements for age or service and for service increments for the purpose of retirement. 
(d)  In order for a member to receive credit for years of service spent in military service, the member must have received an honorable or general discharge. 
(Ord. No. 17-80, § 7, 7-10-80; Ord. No. 103-86, § 7, 10-9-86; Ord. No. 3-93, § 7, 2-25-93; Ord. No. 21-95, § 7, 7-13-95; Ord. No. 15-98, § 1, 5-28-98; Ord. No. 59-98, § 1, 9-24-98) 
Secs. 2-213-2-220. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 14-03, § 1, adopted Aug. 19, 2003, rescinded and repealed §§ 2-213, 2-214, which pertained to buyback of time allowed; amendments-Firemen's relief pension fund, respectively and derived from Ord. No. 12-01, §§ I-XI, adopted Dec. 12, 2001. 
DIVISION 5. - POLICE PENSION FUND ASSOCIATION[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Police generally, Ch. 23. 
State Law reference- Police pension fund, 53 P.S. § 39301 et seq. 

Sec. 2-221. - Composition. 
    The police pension fund association shall consist of the chief of police, the sergeants of police, the captain of detectives, the detectives, inspectors of police, lieutenant of police, the police clerk, all patrolmen and other officers attached to the bureau of police, including the policemen specially detailed for service at the city greenhouse. The police pension fund association shall, immediately after its incorporation, elect a president, vice president, secretary and treasurer. The treasurer shall be required to give bond in double the amount of the monies that may come into his possession. The city shall in nowise be liable for the proper application of any monies after the same shall have been received by the treasurer of the association, or for the payment of any sum or sums of money except as in this division specified. 
(Ord. No. 320, § 2, 1-2-20) 
Sec. 2-222. - Meetings, reports. 
    The police pension fund association shall keep full and accurate accounts of all its transactions. It shall have full power to make rules for the transaction of its business, the application of its funds, its time and place of meeting. The association shall meet at least once a month at a stated time, at such times as it may designate for the transaction of such business as may properly come before it. All meetings shall be opened to the public. A majority of the association shall have power to transact business. All incidental expenditures necessary to the transaction of the business of the association shall be provided for from the pension fund. No money except as heretofore set forth shall be paid out of the pension fund except for the purpose of pensions for the members of the bureau of police and other officers, their widows and children contemplated in this ordinance. The treasurer of the association shall give a surety bond to the city in a sum not less than double the probable amount of money that shall come into his hands for the faithful performance of his duties. The premium on said bond shall be paid out of the pension fund. The association shall make an annual report to the city council on the first Monday of January in each year. The report shall give an account of all receipts and disbursements of the fund and of such other matters as shall properly be embodied in such report. 
(Ord. No. 320, § 6, 1-2-20; Ord. No. 32-65, § 3, 12-21-65) 
Sec. 2-223. - Powers and duties. 
    The police pension fund association shall make rules, bylaws and regulations. They shall prescribe the conditions and the sum to be paid by the members to entitle them to membership. All sums of money paid by persons to become members of the association shall be paid to the treasurer of the police pension fund association, and shall be used for the payment of pensions to the officers or employees, their widows and children entitled thereto under this division. That any policeman or other officer now in the bureau of police who shall have served twenty-five (25) years or more shall be entitled, upon his application for a pension, to receive the same before the organization of the police pension fund association provided for in this division. 
(Ord. No. 320, § 9, 1-2-20) 
Sec. 2-224. - Creation of fund. 
    There shall be created by the police pension fund association a fund that shall be given by bequest, legacy, gifts or donations made to such pension fund, or from funds subscribed by the public, or for unclaimed articles in possession of the police, which shall be known as the police pension fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 320, § 3, 1-2-20) 
Sec. 2-225. - Use of fund. 
    The police pension fund shall be used for the pensioning of the officers and employees of the police department and widows and children as hereinafter provided. No person shall be eligible for any benefits from the fund except those who give their time exclusively to the work of the bureau of police and widows and children as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 320, § 5, 1-2-20; Ord. No. 32-65, § 2, 12-21-65) 
Sec. 2-226. - Police pension commission. 
    The police pension fund shall be under the care and control of the president, vice-president, secretary and treasurer of the association and to two (2) other members selected by the association as directors. The finance officer shall serve as a director of the association. These officers, together with the directors of the association, shall be known as the police pension commission. 
(Ord. No. 320, § 5, 1-2-20; Ord. No. 32-65, § 2, 12-21-65; Ord. No. 3-78, § 1, 2-9-78) 
Sec. 2-227. - Contribution by police officers. 
    Each member of the bureau of police, who is a member of the police pension fund, shall pay into the pension fund a monthly charge of five (5) percent of the monthly salary received by such police officer from the city. 
(Ord. No. 320, § 4, 1-2-20; Ord. No. 32-65, § 1, 12-21-65; Ord. No. 16-70, § 3, 6-2-70; Ord. No. 44-76, § 1, 12-17-76) 
Sec. 2-228. - Contributions by city. 
    There shall be paid by the city annually to the police pension fund association, an organization hereafter to be incorporated and having in charge the distribution of the police pension funds for the members of the bureau of police in the city, not less than one-half (1/2) of one (1) percent nor more than three (3) percent of all city taxes levied by the city other than taxes levied to pay interest on or extinguish the debt of the city or any section thereof; but the city council may exceed the limitations imposed by this section if an additional amount is deemed necessary to provide sufficient funds for payments to widows of members retired on pension or killed or who die in the service. 
(Ord. No. 320, § 1, 1-2-20; Ord. No. 1125, § 1, 6-4-46; Ord. No. 15-57, § 1, 12-30-57; Ord. No. 16-70, §§ 1, 2, 6-2-70) 
Sec. 2-229. - Retirement. 
    Every patrolman, officer or other paid employee in the bureau of police who shall have served in the bureau for a minimum period of at least twenty (20) continuous years, may be retired from active duty with a pension. The pension is to date from the time the patrolman, officer or other paid employee in the bureau shall have filed his application for retirement with city council, or, if retired by action of city council, upon the date which city council designates. 
(Ord. No. 320, § 8, 1-2-20; Ord. No. 1135, § 1, 12-3-46) 
Sec. 2-230. - Pension benefits generally. 
    The pension which shall be paid to all pensioned or retired policemen or other officers shall be one-half the salary which such officer or employee shall receive from the city at the time he makes application to be placed on the pension list; provided, however, that from and after January 1, 1970, the minimum annual total pension and retirement allowances of any kind, including inter alia service increments, which shall be paid to police officers and employees receiving pensions and retirement allowances on such date and to those thereafter becoming eligible therefore, shall be three thousand one hundred twenty-five dollars ($3,125.00). Lump sum vacation pay is not salary and, therefore, shall not be included in any calculation of salary for the purpose of computation of pension. This section shall not be construed to increase the benefits or allowances of any kind being paid or to be paid under sections 2-232(b) and 2-333. 
(Ord. No. 16-70, § 4, 6-2-70; Ord. No. 74-88, § 1, 12-8-88) 
Sec. 2-231. - Survivor's benefits following death after retirement or during line of duty. 
(a)  The surviving spouse of a member of the police force or a member who retires on pension who dies, or if no spouse survives or if she or he survives and subsequently dies, then the children under the age of eighteen (18) years of a member of the police force or a member who retires on pension who dies on or after September 1, 1965, shall, during her or his lifetime, or until reaching the age of eighteen (18) years in the case of a child, be entitled to receive a pension calculated at the rate of one hundred (100) percent of the pension or retirement allowance, such retirement allowance including service increment, the member was receiving or would have been receiving had he or she been retired at the time of his or her death; provided, however, that the minimum annual pension or retirement allowances of any kind paid to a surviving spouse under this section or to be divided equally among the surviving children of the member hereunder shall be two thousand three hundred forty-three dollars ($2,343.00). 
(b)  The surviving spouse of a member of the police force or a member who retires on pension who dies on or after January 1, 1960, but prior to September 1, 1965, shall, during her or his lifetime, be entitled to receive a pension calculated at the rate of one hundred (100) percent of the pension or retirement allowance, such retirement allowance including service increment, the member shall receive or would have been receiving had he or she been retired at the time of his or her death. 
(Ord. No. 32-65, § 4, 12-21-65; Ord. No. 16-70, §§ 5, 6, 6-2-70; Ord. No. 2-71, §§ 1, 2, 3-16-71; Ord. No. 9-2008, § 1, 6-12-08; Ord. No. 12-2009, § 1, 9-10-09) 
Sec. 2-232. - Disability and survivor's benefits outside line of duty. 
(a)  Any police officer who has less than ten (10) years of service and who is totally disabled due to injuries or mental incapacities not in line of duty and is unable to perform the duties of a police officer on or after December 1, 1964, shall be entitled to a pension of twenty-five (25) percent of his or her annual compensation. For such injuries or mental incapacities incurred after ten (10) years of service, the pension shall be fifty (50) percent of his or her annual compensation. For such injuries or mental incapacities incurred after six (6) years of service but less than ten (10) years of service the pension shall be that portion of fifty (50) percent of his or her annual compensation as his or her whole years of service bears with twenty (20) years. 
(b)  This disability pension shall be payable to the police officer during his or her lifetime and if he or she shall die, the pension payment that he or she was receiving shall be continued to be paid to his or her spouse if she or he survives but if she or he subsequently dies, or if the police officer is not survived by a spouse, the pension shall be payable to and divided accordingly between his or her surviving children under the age of eighteen (18) years. 
(c)  If any police officer who has less than ten (10) years of service dies, due to causes not in line of duty, his or her surviving spouse shall be entitled to a pension of twenty-five (25) percent of his or her annual compensation. For such death after ten (10) years of service, the aforementioned pension shall be fifty (50) percent of his or her annual compensation. 
(d)  The aforesaid death pension shall be paid to the police officer's spouse, if she or he survives, or if she or he subsequently dies, or if the police officer is not survived by a spouse, the pension shall be payable to and divided accordingly among his or her surviving children under the age of eighteen (18) years. 
(e)  Such pensions shall not be affected by virtue of any payments being made under the Pennsylvania Occupational Disease Act. 
(Ord. No. 16-70, §§ 3-6, 6-2-70; Ord. No. 20-70, § 1, 6-23-70; Ord. No. 12-2009, § 2, 9-10-09) 
Sec. 2-233. - Waiver of pension. 
    Any person entitled to a pension from the police pension fund may decline to accept all or any part of such pension by a waiver signed and filed with the police pension fund. Such waiver may be revoked in writing at any time but no payment of the waived pension shall be made covering the period such waiver was in effect. 
(Ord. No. 7-56, § 1, 8-21-56) 
Sec. 2-234. - Refund of contributions. 
    If for any cause any member of the police force contributing to the pension fund shall cease to be a member of the force before he becomes entitled to a pension, the total amount of the contributions paid into the pension fund by such member shall be refunded to him in full, without interest. If any such member shall have returned to him the amount contributed and shall afterward again become a member of the police force, he shall not be entitled to the pension designated until twenty (20) years after his reemployment unless he shall return to the pension fund the amount withdrawn, in which event the period of twenty (20) years shall be computed from the time the member first became a member of the police force, excluding therefrom any period of time during which the member was not employed by the police force. In the event of the death of a member of the police force not in the line of service before the member becomes entitled to the pension aforesaid and such member is not survived by a widow or family entitled to payments as provided in this division, the total amount of contributions paid into the pension fund by the member shall be paid over to his estate. 
(Ord. No. 16-70, § 6, 6-2-70) 
Sec. 2-235. - Funding, apportionment. 
    Payments for allowances shall not be a charge on any other fund in the treasury of the city or under its control save the police pension fund herein provided for. The basis of the apportionment of the pension shall be determined by the rate of the monthly pay of the member at the date of injury, death, honorable discharge or retirement, and, except as to service increments provided for in section 2-236, shall not in any case exceed in any year one-half (1/2) the annual pay of such member computed at such monthly rate. 
(Ord. No. 2-60, § 1, 3-15-60) 
Sec. 2-236. - Service increment. 
(a)  In addition to the retirement allowance which is authorized to be paid from the police pension fund by the third class city code, and notwithstanding the limitations therein placed upon such retirement allowances and upon contributions, every contributor who shall become entitled to a retirement allowance shall also be entitled to the payment of a "service increment" in accordance with and subject to the conditions set forth in this section. 
(b)  Effective December 31, 1999, service increments for those bargaining unit members who retired on or after January 1, 1997, or who retire in the future, and who have served in excess of twenty (20) full years and have reached the age of fifty (50) prior to said retirement, shall be entitled from this date forward to the sum obtained by computing the number of whole years (after twenty (20) full years of service) and multiplying the number of whole years so computed by an amount equal to one and one-quarter (1.25) percent of the members' final salary. Such increments shall be subject to a cap of seventy (70) percent. There shall be no retroactivity of the aforementioned increased service increments prior to December 31, 1999. 
(c)  Each contributor, from and after January 18, 1952, shall pay into the retirement fund a monthly sum in addition to his pension contribution, which shall be equal to one-half of one percentum of his salary; provided, that such payment shall not exceed the sum of one dollar ($1.00) per month; and provided, that such service increment contribution shall not be paid after a contributor has reached the age of sixty-five (65) years. 
(d)  Persons who are contributors on the effective date of this ordinance from which this section was derived who have already reached the age of sixty-five (65) years shall have their service increment computed on the years of employment prior to the date of reaching their sixty-fifth birthday. 
(e)  Service increment contributions shall be paid at the same time and in the same manner as pension contributions, and may be withdrawn in full, without interest, by persons who leave the employment of the city, subject to the same conditions by which retirement contributions may be withdrawn, or by persons who retire before becoming entitled to any service increment. 
(Ord. No. 2-60, § 1, 3-15-60; Ord. No. 6-99, § 1, 2-11-99) 
Secs. 2-237-2-245. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - BUREAU OF POLICEMEN'S RELIEF[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 31-88, adopted June 7, 1988, repealed Ord. No. 26-76, adopted July 8, 1976, as amended by Ord. No. 11-79, adopted Mar. 8, 1779; Ord. No. 18-80, adopted July 10, 1980; and Ord. No. 37-82, adopted Nov. 18, 1982, from which ordinances Art. III, Div. 6, §§ 2-246-2-257, of Ch. 2, pertaining to the bureau of policemen's relief, was derived. Sections 1-7 of Ord. No. 31-88 enacted provisions relative to the same subject matter which have been included herein as a new Div. 6, §§ 2-246-2-257. 
Cross reference- Police generally, Ch. 23. 

Sec. 2-246. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this division is to establish benefits payable to policemen or beneficiaries of policemen who are appointed to the bureau of police of the City of Wilkes-Barre after July 8, 1976. A funding policy for the bureau of policemen's relief is also established by the division. 
(Ord. No. 31-88, § 1, 6-7-88; Ord. No. 55-88, § 1, 10-13-88) 
Sec. 2-247. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this division, the following terms shall have the meanings herein defined unless the context clearly indicates a contrary intention: 
    Layoff. A layoff is a nonvoluntary termination of employment of the participant excepting disciplinary action taken by the city relative to the participant. 
    Monthly compensation. Monthly compensation consists of basic monthly compensation plus longevity payments, acting officers' pay, bonuses and other special forms of compensation. 
    Normal retirement age. Normal retirement age shall be age fifty (50). 
(Ord. No. 31-88, § 2(B), (C), (H), 6-7-88; Ord. No. 55-88, § 2(B), (C), (H), 10-13-88; Ord. No. 34-90, § 1, 9-11-90) 
Sec. 2-248. - Participants. 
    A participant is a policeman who is appointed to the bureau of police of the city and becomes a member of the pension fund after July 8, 1976. Specifically, the term "participant" does not include a former policeman who had been appointed previously to the bureau of police of the city and whose employment was subsequently terminated. If such a former policeman is reappointed to the bureau of police, his rights under the existing paid policemen's pension fund for the city shall be preserved. 
(Ord. No. 31-88, § 2(A), 6-7-88; Ord. No. 55-88, § 2(A), 10-13-88) 
Sec. 2-249. - Bureau of policemen's relief. 
(a)  Designation; members enumerated. Bureau of policemen's relief is the administrative bureau to administer the said policemen's pension fund. Said bureau of policemen's relief is composed of five (5) members who shall be as follows: 
(1)  The city finance officer; 
(2)  The city administrator; 
(3)  The city controller; and 
(4)  Two (2) participants of the pension plan duly elected by the total membership of the participants of the plan. 
(b)  Authority to make rules of administration. The bureau of policemen's relief shall make and, upon approval of the mayor, promulgate its own rules and regulations pertaining to the administration of this ordinance or any other applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 31-88, § 2(G), 6-7-88; Ord. No. 55-88, § 2(G), 10-13-88) 
Sec. 2-250. - Participant's contributions. 
    Each participant shall be required to contribute to the bureau of policemen's relief an amount equal to five (5) percent of each participant's compensation. The City of Wilkes-Barre is authorized to deduct said contribution from the participant's monthly compensation and to remit that sum to the bureau of policemen's relief. 
(Ord. No. 31-88, § 2(F), 6-7-88; Ord. No. 55-88, § 2(F), 10-13-88; Ord. No. 3-96, 2-15-96) 
Sec. 2-251. - Early retirement. 
    A participant who has completed twenty (20) years of service may elect to retire prior to attainment of age fifty-five (55); provided, however, that if such participant elects to have his monthly pension determined in accordance with the provisions of this division commence before attainment of age fifty-five (55), said pension benefit shall be reduced by four (4) percent for each year such participant's age is short of age fifty-five (55). 
(Ord. No. 31-88, § 2(D), 6-7-88; Ord. No. 55-88, § 2(D), 10-13-88) 
Sec. 2-252. - Permanent and total disability. 
    A participant shall be deemed to be permanently disabled if he or she has been totally and permanently physically or mentally disabled by bodily injury or disease so as to be prevented from engaging in the regular duties of a policeman of the bureau of police of the city, and shall be entitled for disability if the bureau of policemen's relief shall determine that he or she is so permanently disabled on the basis of written reports obtained from a physician designated by the bureau of policemen's relief. 
(Ord. No. 31-88, § 2(E), 6-7-88; Ord. No. 55-88, § 2(E), 10-13-88) 
Sec. 2-253. - Benefits generally. 
    A participant who has completed twenty (20) years of service and has attained normal retirement age shall receive from the pension fund administered by the bureau of policemen's relief for the rest of his or her life a monthly pension equal to: 
(a)  Fifty (50) percent of his or her average monthly compensation for the last five (5) years prior to his or her retirement; plus, 
(b)  Effective December 31, 1999, service increments for those bargaining unit members who retired in or after January 1, 1997, or who retire in the future, and who have served in excess of twenty (20) full years and have reached the age of fifty (50) prior to said retirement, shall be entitled from this date forward to the sum obtained by computing the number of whole years (after twenty (20) full years if service) and multiplying the number of whole years so computed by an equal to one and one-quarter (1.25) percent of the member's final salary. Such increments shall be subject to a cap of seventy (70) percent. There shall be no retroactively of the aforementioned increased service increments prior to December 31, 1999. 
(c)  A participant who has completed twenty (20) years of service and elects early retirement shall receive a monthly pension for life reduced by four (4) percent for each year short of age fifty-five (55). 
(d)  If a participant who has completed ten (10) or more years of service but less than twenty (20) years of service retires or terminates his or her employment, such participant shall receive a monthly pension for life equal to fifty (50) percent of his or her average monthly compensation for the last five (5) years prior to retirement or termination of employment multiplied by a fraction, the numerator of which shall be the number of full years of service completed and the denominator of which shall be twenty (20), which pension shall commence when the participant attains age fifty-five (55). If, however, such participant elects to receive said monthly benefits upon termination of employment, the monthly benefit to which he or she is entitled shall be further reduced by four (4) percent times each year short of age fifty-five (55). 
(e)  If the employment of a participant with less than ten (10) years of service terminates and such participant or his or her spouse or children are not entitled to disability or pension benefits under the provisions of this division, the net of the total of the participant's contributions plus interest calculated at the rate of five (5) percent per annum, less the total of all pension, disability, or other payments made to the participant, his or her spouse or children, shall be refunded to the participant or paid to the estate of the deceased participant. 
(f)  If a participant dies while employed as a policeman by the City of Wilkes-Barre, leaving no spouse or no children entitled to pension benefits under the provisions of this division, the net total of the participant's contributions plus interest calculated at the rate of five (5) percent per annum, less the total of all pension, disability or other payments made to the participant, shall be refunded to the estate of the deceased participant. 
(g)  If a participant has his or her employment terminated by reason of layoff and the participant does not elect to exercise options available to him or her under this division, the participant shall be entitled to elect as follows as to how he or she wants his or her pension contributions maintained: 
(1)  If the employment of a participant is terminated by reason of a layoff, then the participant shall be allowed to withdraw from the pension fund the net of the total of the participant's contribution plus interest calculated at the rate of five (5) percent per annum, less the total of all pension payments made to the participant and/or his or her spouse or children. 
(2)  The participant may elect to leave the net of the total of the participant's contributions within the bureau of policemen's pension relief fund. 
(3)  The participant shall be entitled to exercise Option (1) above at anytime during the layoff period. 
(4)  If the participant exercises Option (1) above, then, upon being rehired or called back to work, the participant shall be allowed to repay all monies withdrawn from the fund and shall be given credit for the time period of employment for which pension funds were withheld. If the participant elects to repay pension fund monies, he or she must elect to do so within six (6) months from the date of rehire and is required to serve written notice of his or her intentions to the pension board during this six-month time period. The participant shall repay all monies to the pension fund within twenty-four (24) months of the date of written notice to the pension board of the participant's election to repay withdrawn monies. Failure to comply with the time requirements of this subsection shall disqualify the participant from exercising the options available to him or her under this subsection. 
(5)  Any participant who elects Option (1) above shall be precluded from buying back or being given credit for the time period for which the participant was laid off. 
(6)  If the participant exercises Option (2) above, then upon being rehired the participant shall be entitled to have full credit for the time period which the participant was laid off; provided, that upon the participant being rehired, the participant shall make payment to the bureau of policemen's pension relief fund the contributions which would have been paid on the actual wages which the participant would have received had he or she not been laid off. The participant shall have six (6) months from the date of rehire to serve written notice to the pension board of his or her intentions to exercise this option. The participant shall be required to repay within twenty-four (24) months of the date of written notice to the pension board of the participant's election to repay contributions which would have been paid on the actual wages which the participant would have received had he or she not been laid off. Failure to comply with the time requirements of this subsection shall disqualify the participant from exercising the options available under this subsection. 
(7)  Any participant who elects Option (2) above shall not have his or her continuity of service broken for the time period during which said participant made contribution to the pension fund prior to the layoff time period. A participant who elects Options (2) and (6) and complies with all time restraints as set forth in subsection (6) shall be given full credit for the layoff time period for purposes of pension benefits and computation of service time. 
(8)  If a participant elects Option (1) above and does not repay net contributions and interest within the time frames set forth in this division, then the participant shall be precluded from calculating past contributions made to the pension board and service time prior to the layoff towards his or her pension computations and benefits. 
(Ord. No. 31-88, § 3, 6-7-88; Ord. No. 55-88, § 3, 10-13-88; Ord. No. 5-99, § 1, 2-11-99) 
Sec. 2-254. - Disability benefits. 
(a)  If the participant has become permanently and totally disabled in the line of duty, such participant shall receive a monthly disability benefit equal to fifty (50) percent of his or her average monthly compensation for the last five (5) years prior to the commencement of the disability; and if the participant has service time in excess of twenty (20) years, the participant shall be entitled to additional monthly benefits as per section 2-253(b) of this division; or if the participant who has become permanently and totally disabled in the line of duty has not been employed for a period of at least five (5) years prior to the commencement of the disability, such participant shall receive a monthly disability benefit equal to fifty (50) percent of his or her average monthly compensation at the time participant became totally and permanently disabled, computed on the assumption that the participant has attained five (5) years of service at the classification attained at the time the participant became totally and permanently disabled, which benefits shall continue until the disabled participant is determined to be no longer disabled and is under normal retirement age, or until the death of the disabled participant, whichever is the first to occur. 
(b)  If a participant becomes disabled, which disability is not service connected, he or she shall be entitled to a monthly disability benefit if he or she has completed five (5) or more years of service. A disability benefit payable hereunder shall be as follows: 
(1)  If the participant has completed at least twenty (20) years of service, such participant shall receive a monthly disability benefit equal to fifty (50) percent of his or her average monthly compensation for the last five (5) years prior to the commencement of the disability; and if the participant has service time in excess of twenty (20) years, the participant shall be entitled to additional monthly pension benefits as per section 2-253(b) of this division which benefits shall continue until the disabled participant is determined to be no longer disabled and is under normal retirement age or until the death of the disabled participant, whichever is the first to occur. 
(2)  If the participant has completed less than twenty (20) years of service, the disabled participant shall receive a monthly disability benefit equal to fifty (50) percent of his or her average monthly compensation for the last five (5) years of employment prior to commencement of disability, multiplied by the ratio of the actual full years of service completed years to twenty (20) years of service, which monthly disability benefit shall continue until the disabled participant is determined to be no longer disabled and is under normal retirement age or until the death of the disabled participant whichever is the first to occur. 
(Ord. No. 31-88, § 4, 1-7-88; Ord. No. 55-88, § 4, 10-13-88) 
Sec. 2-255. - Survivor's benefits. 
(a)  If a participant dies in the line of duty, a monthly pension shall be payable to his or her spouse until her or his death, equal to the monthly pension benefit the participant would have received had he or she retired as of the date of death, computed on the assumption the participant had completed twenty (20) years of service and was age fifty (50). If the deceased participant had service time in excess of twenty (20) years, the pension benefit due is to be computed allowing for additional monthly benefits as per section 2-253(d) of this division. 
(b)  If a participant dies in the line of duty who leaves no surviving spouse, a monthly pension shall be paid to the guardian of or for the benefit of such participant's dependent children who are under the age of eighteen (18) years, which payments shall continue until such time as the youngest of such children attains the age of eighteen (18) years, which benefit shall be equal to the monthly pension benefit the participant would have received had he or she retired as of the date of death, computed on the assumption the participant had completed twenty (20) years of service and was age fifty-five (55). If the deceased participant had service time in excess of twenty (20) years, the pension benefit due is to be computed allowing for additional monthly benefits as per section 2-253(d) of this division. 
(c)  If a retired participant marries and subsequently dies, his or her spouse shall receive a pension benefit equal to the monthly pension benefit the participant was receiving, which benefit shall continue until such spouse's death. 
(d)  If a retired participant dies, who was receiving a pension benefit under this division, leaving dependent children who are under the age of eighteen (18) and his or her spouse has predeceased the participant, a monthly pension shall be paid to the guardian of or for the benefit of such participant's dependent children under the age of eighteen (18) years, which payments shall continue until such time as the youngest of such children attains the age of eighteen (18) years, which benefit shall be equal to the monthly pension benefit the participant was receiving at the time of his or her death. 
(e)  If a participant dies before retirement, whose death is not service connected, but has completed twenty (20) years of service, such participant's spouse or, if the participant's spouse had predeceased him or her, the participant's dependent children under the age of eighteen (18) years shall be entitled to receive a monthly pension benefit equal to the monthly pension benefit the participant would have received had he or she retired as of the date of death; said pension payments are to be computed on the assumption that the participant was age fifty (50) at the time of said death. If the deceased participant had service time in excess of twenty (20) years, the pension benefit due is to be computed allowing for additional monthly benefits as per section 2-253(b) of this division. 
(f)  If the participant dies before retirement not in the line of duty, but who has completed ten (10) or more years of service but less than twenty (20) years of service, such participant's spouse or, if participant's spouse has predeceased him or her, the participant's dependent children under the age of eighteen (18) years shall be entitled to receive a monthly pension benefit equal to the monthly pension benefit the participant would have received had he or she retired as of the date of death; said pension payments will be computed on the assumption that the participant was age fifty (50) at the time of said death. 
(g)  If the spouse of a deceased participant dies who was receiving a pension benefit under this division, payments will be made to the guardian of or for the benefit of the participant's surviving children under the age of eighteen (18) years, which payments shall continue until the youngest such child attains the age of eighteen (18). 
(Ord. No. 31-88, § 5, 6-7-88; Ord. No. 55-88, § 5, 10-13-88; Ord. No. 34-90, § 5, 9-11-90; Ord. No. 10-2008, § 1, 6-12-08) 
Sec. 2-256. - Funding policy. 
(a)  The city shall every two (2) years, or more frequently if provided by state law, hire a qualified actuary to prepare an actuarial report providing the pension costs in the form of a normal cost and an unfunded past service liability. In the first year after such report has been prepared, the city shall include in its budget and contributions during the next succeeding fiscal year an amount sufficient to cover one hundred (100) percent of the normal cost plus the unfunded liability minus the amount of the members contributions. Any reduction due to member contributions shall be computed by the qualified actuary. Such actuary shall also calculate the incremental normal cost and the incremental unfunded past service liability with respect to any benefit improvements and the city shall pay such incremental normal cost and one hundred (100) percent on such incremental unfunded past service liability in the next succeeding fiscal year after such report has been prepared. 
(b)  The first actuarial report pursuant to this division shall be prepared as of January 1, 1988, and every two (2) years or more frequently thereafter on or before January 1 of the submitting year and shall be submitted to the officer of the city responsible for preparing the budget by the last business day in September, which report shall serve as one of the bases for determining the cost of the pension fund for the budget of the city for the immediately succeeding year. The first such actuarial report shall be prepared as of January 1, 1988, and shall be submitted to the city officer responsible for preparing the budget by the last business day in September, 1988, which report shall serve as one of the bases for the city's contribution to the pension fund for the calendar year 1989. 
(Ord. No. 31-88, § 6, 6-7-88; Ord. No. 55-88, § 6, 10-13-88) 
Sec. 2-257. - Military service. 
(a)  Effective as of the date of the final passage of this division, all members of the bureau of policemen's relief pension fund, who were hired by the City of Wilkes-Barre prior to January 24, 2001, who have not already bought back military service time, who are contributors, who have actively served in the Armed Forces of the United States subsequent to September 1, 1940, and who were not members of the bureau of policemen's relief pension fund prior to such military service, shall be entitled to have full credit for each year or fraction thereof not to exceed five (5) years of such service, upon his or her payment to the bureau of policemen's relief pension fund of an amount equal to that which the member would have paid had he or she been a member of the bureau of policemen's relief pension fund during the period for which the member desires credit at a contribution rate of five (5) percent of what the member's annual salary would have been had the member been employed by the City of Wilkes-Barre during the period of military service for which the member desires credit. 
(b)  Any policeman who is presently a member of the bureau of policemen's relief pension fund or becomes a member subsequently and desires to purchases military service pursuant to the foregoing provisions must do so within the first fifteen (15) years of service, pursuant to the rules and regulations as established by the board of the bureau of policemen's relief pension fund. 
    Any policeman who is presently a member of the bureau of policemen's relief pension fund and who desires to purchases city service pursuant to the foregoing provisions must do so within three (3) years of January 14, 1993, and anyone [who] subsequently becomes a member must purchase such city service within three (3) years of his first payment to the pension fund, pursuant to the rules and regulations as established by the board of the bureau of policemen's relief pension fund. 
(c)  The foregoing military service and city service credit provision shall extend to and establish credit towards the minimum requirements for age or service and for service increments for the purpose of retirement. 
(Ord. No. 31-88, § 7, 6-7-88; Ord. No. 55-88, § 7, 10-13-88; Ord. No. 41-92, 1-14-92; Ord. No. 12-93, § 7, 6-10-93; Ord. No. 5-99, § 2, 2-11-99; Ord. No. 14-06, § 1, 9-21-06; Ord. No. 15-06, § 1, 9-21-06) 
Sec. 2-258. - Calculation of pension. 
    The pension shall be calculated on the average of the last one year of service. Simultaneously, lump sum retirement sick leave buy back shall be removed from pension calculations. Annual sick leave buy back shall remain in the pension calculation even though paid in correlation with lump sum retirement sick leave buy back. 
(Ord. No. 3-96, 2-15-96) 
Sec. 2-259. - Payment of costs. 
    Payments of the salary of the president and all administrative expenses for the new police relief pension fund shall be made from the fund assets themselves and not from the city funds. This provision shall be retroactive to the date of the most recent state auditor's findings. 
(Ord. No. 3-96, 2-15-96) 
Sec. 2-260. - Time served buyback permitted. 
    Effective January 1, 2002, city employees are permitted to buy all of the time which represents time served as a City of Wilkes-Barre employee and a participant in another city pension fund into the city pension fund in which they currently participate. 
    The buyback amount shall be calculated by the city and shall include an amount equal to the employee's contributions, plus interest, at a rate established by the city at the time of the buyback. 
    The buyback must be initiated at the time of hire into another city job classification or after the effective date of this section [December 22, 2001], whichever is later. 
(Ord. No. 11-2001, § I, 12-12-01) 
Sec. 2-261. - Amendments-Policemen's relief pension fund. 
    Effective for members of the policemen's relief pension fund hired on or after January 24, 2001, the following amendments shall apply to Ordinance No. 11-2001: 
    Police pension fund; direction of. Cities shall establish, by ordinance, a police pension fund, to be maintained by an equal and proportionate monthly charge against each member of the police force, which shall not exceed annually four (4) percent of the pay of such member and an additional amount not to exceed one percent of the pay of such member to be paid by such member of the municipal corporation to provide sufficient funds for payments required by subsection (d) section 4303 to surviving spouses or if no spouse survives or if such person survives and subsequently dies then to the child or children under the age of eighteen (18) years, of members of the police force or of members retired on pension or who die in service; which fund shall at all times be under the direction and control of council but may be committed to the custody and management of such officers of the city or citizens thereof, or corporations located therein, as may be designated by council, and applied, under such regulations, as council may, by ordinance, prescribe, for the benefit of such members of the police force as shall receive honorable discharge therefrom by reason of age or disability, surviving spouses or if no spouse survives or if such person survives and subsequently dies, then to the child or children under the age of eighteen (18) years, of members of the police force or of members retired on pension; but such allowances as shall be made to those who are retired by reason of the disabilities of age shall be in conformity with a uniform scale, together with service increments as hereinafter provided. Any compensation paid to a corporate custodian of the police pension fund shall be paid from the general fund of the city. 
    Retirement final discharge. Such ordinance shall prescribe a minimum period of continuous service, not less than twenty (20) years, and, when any minimum age is prescribed, a minimum age of fifty (50) years, after which members of the force may retire from active duty, and such members as are retired shall be subject to service, from time to time, as a police reserve until unfitted for such service, when they may be finally retired by reason of age or disability. 
    With the approval of council, any member of the police pension fund who is a contributor and who served in the armed forces of the United States subsequent to September 1, 1940, and who was not a member of the police pension fund prior to such military service, shall be entitled to have full credit for each year or fraction thereof, not to exceed five (5) years of such service upon his payment to the police pension fund of an amount equal to that which he would have paid had he been a member during the period for which he desires credit, and his payment to such fund of an additional amount as the equivalent of the contributions of the city on account of such military service. 
    Allowances and service increments. 
(a)  Payments for allowances shall not be a charge on any other fund in the treasury of the city or under its control save the police pension fund herein provided for. The basis of the apportionment of the pension shall be determined by the rate of the monthly pay of the member at the date of injury, death, honorable discharge, or retirement, whichever is the higher, and except as to service increments provided for in subsection (b) of this section, shall not in any case exceed in any year one-half the annual pay of such member computed at such monthly or average annual rate, whichever is the higher. 
(b)  In addition to the retirement allowance which is authorized to be paid from the police pension fund by this Act, and notwithstanding the limitations therein placed upon such retirement allowances and upon contributions, every contributor who shall become entitled to the retirement allowance shall also be entitled to the payment of a "service increment" in accordance with and subject to the conditions hereinafter set forth. 
(1)  Service increment shall be the sum obtained by computing the number of whole years after having served the minimum required by this Act during which a contributor has been employed by such city and paid out of the city treasury, including credit for military service as provided in section 4302, and multiplying the said number of years so computed by an amount equal to one-fortieth of the retirement allowance which has become payable to such contributor in accordance with the provisions of this act. In computing the service increment, no employment after the contributor has reached the age of sixty-five (65) years shall be included, and no service increment shall be paid in excess of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per month. 
(2)  Each contributor, from and after the effective date of this amendment, shall pay into the retirement fund a monthly sum in addition to his or her retirement contribution, which shall be equal to one-half of one percent of his or her salary; provided, that such payment shall not exceed the sum of one dollar ($1.00) per month; and provided, that such service increment contribution shall not be paid after a contributor has reached the age of sixty-five (65) years.
