ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 12-1-12-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LITTER AND DISPOSAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 60-90, adopted Dec. 13, 1990, being not specifically amendatory of the Code, has been treated as superseding provisions formerly codified as Art. II, §§ 12-16-12-30, of Ch. 12, pertaining to similar matter and derived from Ord. No. 55-86, §§ 1-9, adopted May 13, 1986. 

Sec. 12-16. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Variable Fee Municipal Litter and Disposal Ordinance of the City of Wilkes-Barre." 
(Ord. No. 60-90, § 1, 12-13-90; Ord. No. 44-91, § 1, 12-12-91; Ord. No. 39-92, § 1, 12-10-92; Ord. No. 23-93, § 1, 8-12-93) 
Sec. 12-17. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein: 
    Aircraft: Any contrivance, now known or hereafter invented, used or designated for navigation or for flight in the air. 
    City: The City of Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania. 
    Commercial establishment(s): Any property in the city for other than residential purposes, whether or not such purpose is for profit and including, but not limited to, restaurants, hotels, cafes, clubs, dormitories, cafeterias, dealers in consumable foodstuffs and industrial or manufacturing entities of any nature whatsoever. 
    Garbage: Animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
    Individual dwelling unit: A residential unit or units, under one roof, designed or arranged for occupancy by four (4) households or less with the exception of the exemption for an owner who lives in a dwelling unit which he owns as provided for in the definition of multifamily dwelling unit. 
    Litter: Any waste material, including, but not limited to, "garbage," "refuse" and "rubbish" which, if thrown or illegally deposited, could tend to create a danger to the public health, safety and welfare. 
    Multifamily dwellings: Individual residential units, under one (1) roof, designed or arranged for occupancy by more than five (5) households living as families with separate and individual facilities whether the same be occupied or not. An owner who lives in a dwelling with more than one (1) residential unit shall not include his unit in calculating the total number of individual residential units under one (1) roof. 
    Park: A park, reservation, playground, beach, recreation center or any other public area in the city owned or used by the city and devoted to active or passive recreation by the public. 
    Person: Any natural person, corporation, partnership and association of individuals, whether or not incorporated and whether or not organized for endeavors of profit, charity, education or civic purposes or any other purpose whatsoever. 
    Private premises: Any dwelling, house, building or other structure designed or used either wholly or in part for private residential purposes, whether inhabited or temporarily or continuously uninhabited or vacant, and shall include any yard, grounds, walk, driveway, porch, steps, vestibule or mailbox belonging or appurtenant to such dwelling, house, building or other structure. 
    Public place: Any and all streets, sidewalks, boulevards, alleys or other public ways and any and all public parks, squares, spaces, grounds and buildings. 
    Refuse: All solid waste (except body waste), including garbage, rubbish, street cleanings, and dead animals. 
    Rubbish: Solid waste consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardboard, yard clippings, wood, glass, bedding and similar materials. 
    Vehicle: Every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a public or private roadway, including devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Ord. No. 60-90, § 2, 12-13-90; Ord. No. 44-91, § 2, 12-12-91; Ord. No. 39-92, § 2, 12-10-92; Ord. No. 23-93, § 2, 8-12-93; Ord. No. 13-2015, 8-13-15) 
Sec. 12-18. - Duties imposed. 
    It shall be the duty of every person owning or occupying property within the city, as a result of or incidental to which refuse is accumulated, to provide for commercial or municipal collection and disposal of the same as follows: 
(1)  Refuse container regulations. Refuse containers shall be made of metal, hard plastic or hard rubber and shall be equipped with suitable handles and tight-fitting covers. Refuse containers shall be maintained in good condition. Any container that does not meet the provisions of this article for refuse storage and collection or that may have ragged or sharp edges or any defect liable to hamper or injure the person collecting the contents thereof shall be promptly disposed of and replaced upon notice from either the department of public works or the bureau of health. Refuse containers, dumpsters and compact systems located outside shall be stored on or above a smooth surface of nonabsorbent material such as concrete or machine-laid asphalt and shall be kept clean and maintained in good repair and shall be insect-proof and rodent-proof. 
(2)  Responsibility to provide refuse containers. In individual dwelling units it shall be the responsibility of the occupants of each dwelling unit to furnish refuse containers for the temporary storage of refuse until removal from the premises. In multifamily dwellings it shall be the responsibility of the owner, operator or agent in control of such multifamily dwelling to furnish refuse containers for the temporary storage of refuse until removal from the premises. 
(3)  Duty to place for collection and disposal: 
a.  Generally. All refuse shall be placed in authorized city bags as provided for hereinafter and shall be placed for collection in a refuse container. Refuse containers shall be placed for collection not closer than six (6) inches to and not more than eighteen (18) inches from the cartway (hard top surface of roadway) of the road. The refuse container shall not be placed for collection prior to 5:00 p.m., prevailing time, on the day prior to that regularly scheduled for collection. 
b.  Precollection practices required for certain substances. Cardboards, tree trimmings and hedge clippings or any other similar material shall be cut to a length not to exceed three (3) feet and shall be securely tied in bundles not more than two (2) feet thick before being deposited for collection. 
(4)  Noncollectible items. No person shall deposit or place any ashes, dirt, stones, bricks, building materials or discarded furniture, or any other item not defined as refuse for collection. Any deposits of the aforementioned noncollectible items will not be collected and the violator will be subject to fines as provided for in this article. 
(5)  Effective January 10, 1994, the City of Wilkes-Barre shall commence a user-fee charge program for refuse picked up by the city shall be placed in refuse bags authorized by the city. The refuse bags will be specially designed and be distributed through commercial outlets only. The cost of the bags shall be reviewed on an annual basis and shall be modified according to all costs associated with the collection and disposal of municipal refuse. The cost of thirty-gallon refuse bags shall be two dollars ($2.00) per bag or five (5) bags for ten dollars ($10.00). The cost of fifteen-gallon refuse bags will be one dollar and twenty-five cents ($1.25) per bag or five (5) bags for six dollars and twenty-five cents ($6.25). 
(6)  Weight of refuse limitation. No person shall place greater than thirty (30) pounds of refuse or other authorized material in a thirty-gallon city-designated bag or fifteen (15) pounds of refuse or other authorized material in a fifteen-gallon city-designated bag for municipal collection. 
(7)  Amending fee rates. The fee set forth in this article may hereafter be modified by city council via resolution. 
(8)  Implementation of user-fee program. The department of public works in conjunction with the finance office shall be responsible for establishing programs for the distribution and sale of bags, collection of funds and the promulgation of rules and regulations as they apply to refuse pickup and disposal. 
(9)  Multifamily dwellings and commercial establishments. It shall be the responsibility of all commercial establishments and the owners of all multifamily dwellings to arrange for the collection and disposal of their own refuse as herein defined. Such persons shall, upon reasonable demand of the department of public works, furnish to such department satisfactory evidence of their undertaking to do so, whether by contract with commercial haulers or otherwise. 
(10)  Applicability of special regulations. The regulations of title 16, chapter II, subchapter B, part 1301 of the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission, as the same may from time to time be amended, are incorporated herein and made a part hereof. 
(11)  Private/commercial collection of municipal solid waste. Private or commercial haulers of garbage are allowed to collect garbage throughout the City of Wilkes-Barre between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. daily. 
(12)  Documentation. All persons and properties covered under this section, upon reasonable demand of the City of Wilkes-Barre's Department of Public Works, shall furnish to such department, satisfactory evidence or documentation related to refuse removal or collection, whether by contract with commercial haulers or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 60-90, § 3, 12-13-90; Ord. No. 44-91, § 3, 12-12-91; Ord. No. 39-92, § 3, 12-10-92; Ord. No. 23-93, § 3, 8-12-93; Ord. No. 13-94, § 1, 4-14-94; Ord. No. 13-97, § 1, 5-8-97; Ord. No. 21-97, § 1, 7-10-97; Ord. No. 5-04, § I, 2-12-04; Ord. No. 17-2008, 8-7-08; Ord. No. 26-2008, § I, 12-11-08; Ord. No. 20-2012, 12-13-2012) 
Sec. 12-19. - Prohibitions. 
    No person shall: 
(1)  Throw or deposit litter in or upon any street, sidewalk or other public place within the city except in public receptacles expressly provided for that purpose. 
(2)  Throw or deposit litter on any private property, whether vacant or improved, occupied or unoccupied, except that the owner or person in control of private property may maintain authorized private receptacles for collection as provided herein. 
(3)  Place litter in an authorized public or private receptacle in such manner as might permit it to be carried or deposited by the elements upon any public place or upon private property. 
(4)  Cast, place, sweep or deposit anywhere within the city any refuse in such a manner that it may be carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk, alley, sewer, parkway or other public place or into any occupied premises within the city. 
(5)  While a driver or passenger in a vehicle, throw or deposit litter upon any public place or private property. 
(6)  Drive or move any truck or other vehicle within the city unless such vehicle is so constructed or covered as to prevent any load, contents or litter from being blown or deposited upon any street, alley or other public place. Nor shall any person drive or move any vehicle or truck within the city the wheels or tires of which carry onto or deposit in any street, alley or other public place mud, dirt, sticky substances, litter or foreign matter of any kind. 
(7)  Throw or deposit litter in any park within the city except in public receptacles and in such a manner that the litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any part of the park or upon any street or other public place. Where public receptacles are not provided, all such litter shall be carried away from the park by the person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere as provided herein. 
(8)  Throw or deposit litter in any fountain, stream or any other body of water in a park or elsewhere within the city. 
(9)  While in an aircraft, throw out, drop or deposit within the city any litter, handbill or any other object. 
(10)  Not being a bona fide resident of the city, deposit any refuse, litter or other item for collection or disposal whether in accordance with the provisions of this article or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 60-90, § 4, 12-13-90; Ord. No. 44-91, § 4, 12-12-91; Ord. No. 39-92, § 4, 12-10-92; Ord. No. Ord. No. 23-93, § 4, 8-12-93) 
Sec. 12-20. - Creation of Wilkes-Barre Clean Streams Trust Fund. 
(a)  Purpose of fund. There is hereby created a "Wilkes-Barre Clean Streams Trust Fund" for the purpose of paying a reward of three hundred dollars ($300.00) to the person found by the trustees of the fund, as hereinafter designated, to have given information leading to the arrest and conviction of any person found guilty of violating section 12-19(8) of this article. 
(b)  Number, appointment, term. The trustees of the fund shall be three (3) in number and shall be appointed, at the discretion of the chair, to serve for the term of the duration of council. 
(c)  Appropriation. The fund shall be established, initially, by an appropriation of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) to be drawn from the council contingency of the city's 1986 General Fund Budget, and such sum is hereby appropriated for this purpose, with the provision that at such time as city property is sold, the proceeds of which are not otherwise encumbered, one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) of those proceeds shall be used to reimburse the council contingency. The fund shall be augmented, from time to time, by such additional appropriations or private contributions as may be made to it. 
(d)  Deposit and withdrawal. Monies appropriated or donated to the use of the fund shall be maintained in a separate account in a depository to be designated by the trustees and shall be drawn upon the signature of any two (2) of them as provided for in the rules and regulations of the depository institution. 
(e)  Existence. The fund shall continue in existence until such time as all monies herein appropriated, hereafter appropriated or privately contributed have been exhausted. 
(Ord. No. 60-90, § 5, 12-13-90; Ord. No. 44-91, § 5, 12-12-91; Ord. No. 39-92, § 5, 12-10-92; Ord. No. 23-93, § 5, 8-12-93; Ord. No. 4-97, § 1, 2-20-97) 
Sec. 12-21. - Declaration of nuisance. 
    Any unauthorized accumulation of litter on any premises, whether public or private, is hereby declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited. Failure of the responsible person(s) to immediately remove any existing accumulation of litter after notice from the department of health or other designated representative of the city shall be deemed a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 60-90, § 6, 12-13-90; Ord. No. 44-91, § 6, 12-12-91; Ord. No. 39-92, § 6, 12-10-92; Ord. No. 23-93, § 6, 8-12-93) 
Sec. 12-22. - Grant of authority to refuse municipal collection and disposal service. 
(a)  The department of public works shall have the authority to refuse municipal collection and disposal service to any premises on which refuse is placed for collection in violation of the terms of section 12-18 of this article. 
(b)  Upon the refusal of service as herein provided, the department of health or the department of public works, as the case may be, shall cause a citation to be issued against the owner of such premises, alleging a violation of the relevant section(s) of this article and any other applicable ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 60-90, § 7, 12-13-90; Ord. No. 44-91, § 7, 12-12-91; Ord. No. 39-92, § 7, 12-10-92; Ord. No. 23-93, § 7, 8-12-93) 
Sec. 12-23. - Enforcement provisions as to open or vacant property. 
(a)  Notice to remove. The health officer, or other duly appointed representative of the city, is hereby authorized and empowered to notify the owner of any open or vacant private property within the city or the agent of such owner to properly dispose of litter located on such owner's property which is dangerous to public health, safety or welfare. Such notice shall be by registered mail, addressed to such owner at his last-known address. 
(b)  Action upon noncompliance. Upon the failure, neglect or refusal of any owner or agent so notified to properly dispose of litter dangerous to the public health, safety or welfare within seventy-two (72) hours after receipt of written notice provided for in subsection (a) of this section, or within seventy-two (72) hours after the date of such notice if the same is returned to the city post office department because of its inability to make delivery thereof, provided the same was properly addressed to the last-known address of such owner or agent, the principal health officer is hereby authorized and empowered to pay for the disposing of such litter or to order its disposal by the city. 
(c)  Charge included in tax bill. When the city has effected the removal of such dangerous litter or has paid for its removal, the actual cost thereof, plus accrued interest at the rate of ten (10) percent per annum from the date of the completion of the work, if not paid by such owner prior thereto, shall be charged to the owner of such property on the next regular tax bill forwarded to such owner by the city, and such charge shall be due and payable by such owner at the time of payment of such bill. 
(d)  Recorded statement constitutes lien. Where the full amount due the city is not paid by such owner within ten (10) days after the disposal of such litter, as provided for in subsections (a) and (b) of this section, then, and in that case, the health officer shall cause to be recorded in the county prothonotary's office a sworn statement showing the cost and expense incurred for the work, the date of the completion of the work and the location of the property on which the work was done. The recordation of such sworn statement shall constitute a lien and privilege on the property and shall remain in full force and effect for the amount due in principal and interest, plus costs of court, if any, for collection until final payment has been made. Such costs and expenses shall be collected in the manner fixed by law for the collection of taxes and, further, shall be subject to a delinquent penalty of ten (10) percent in the event same is not paid in full on or before the date the tax bill upon which such charge appears becomes delinquent. Sworn statements recorded in accordance with the provisions thereof shall be prima facie evidence that all legal formalities have been complied with and that the work has been done properly and satisfactorily and shall be full notice to every person concerned that the amount of the statement, plus interest, constitutes a charge against the property designated or described in the statement and that the same is due and collectible as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 60-90, § 8, 12-13-90; Ord. No. 44-91, § 8, 12-12-91; Ord. No. 39-92, § 8, 12-10-92; Ord. No. 23-93, § 8, 8-12-93) 
Sec. 12-24. - Penalties. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon summary conviction thereof in a summary proceeding before a district justice of Luzerne County, be sentenced to pay a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and all court costs and related costs to the effective restoration of the defaced property and in addition to the fine and costs levied violators are subject to a term of imprisonment not to exceed ninety (90) days. Further, the city requests that a minimum of twenty-five (25) hours but not more than one hundred (100) hours of community service be directed by the judicial officer presiding over the case. 
(Ord. No. 60-90, § 9, 12-13-90; Ord. No. 44-91, § 9, 12-12-91; Ord. No. 39-92, § 9, 12-10-92; Ord. No. 23-93, § 9, 8-12-93; Ord. No. 14-95, § 2, 5-11-95) 
Cross reference- General penalty, § 1-7. 
Sec. 12-25. - Creation of the office of refuse and disposal fee collector. 
    There is hereby created the office of refuse and disposal fee collector, to which shall be appointed such municipal officer or corporation as may, from time to time, be designated by ordinance. The fee collector shall exercise such powers and duties and receive such compensation as shall be designated by such ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 60-90, § 10, 12-13-90; Ord. No. 44-91, § 10, 12-12-91; Ord. No. 39-92, § 10, 12-10-92; Ord. No. 23-93, § 10, 8-12-93) 
Sec. 12-26. - Enforcement. 
    This article shall be enforced by a person designated by the department of public works or such other person(s) as from time to time might be designated by the city administrator. 
(Ord. No. 23-93, § 11, 8-12-93) 
Sec 12-27. - Fee for recyclable newsprint, commingled recyclable aluminum cans and recyclable ferrous containers. 
    The annual fee for collection of recyclable newsprint, commingled recyclable aluminum cans and recyclable ferrous containers shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(Ord. No. 22-93, § 1, 8-12-93; Ord. No. 4-04, § I, 2-12-04; Ord. No. 26-2008, § II, 12-11-08; Ord. No. 20-2012, 12-13-2012) 
Sec. 12-28. - Deposit of garbage declared nuisance. 
    The deposit of any garbage, litter, noncommercial, commercial material in violation of this article shall be declared a nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 14-95, § 1, 5-11-95) 
Secs. 12-29-12-35. - Reserved.

ARTICLE IV. - RECYCLING 

Sec. 12-60. - Establishment. 
    There is hereby established a program for the single-stream collection of commingled recyclable materials as defined under this article from residential premises within the City of Wilkes-Barre. 
(Ord. No. 87-86, 8-12-86; Ord. No. 18-88, 3-24-88; Ord. No. 19-90, 8-9-90; Ord. No. 25-2007, § I, 11-8-07; Ord. No. 4-2012, 3-8-2012) 
Sec. 12-61. - Definitions. 
    Community activities: Events, sponsored in whole or in part by a municipality, or conducted within a municipality and sponsored privately, which include, but are not limited to, fairs, bazaars, socials, picnics and organized sporting events that will be attended by two hundred (200) or more individuals per day. 
    Permitted recyclable materials under single-stream program: Aluminum cans, aluminum foil, 1-7 plastics, cardboard, cereal boxes, color paper, detergent bottles, empty aerosol cans, envelopes [with or without window], egg cartons, file folders, glass jars and bottles, hard and soft cover books, juice and milk cartons, junk mail, newspaper and inserts, magazines and brochures, multi-3-ply paper, white paper, paperboard boxes, phone books and catalogs, plastic milk jugs, plastic soda bottles, pots and pans, school papers, small metals, tin cans, and water bottles. 
(Ord. No. 87-86, 8-12-86; Ord. No. 18-88, 3-24-88; Ord. No. 19-90, 8-9-90; Ord. No. 25-2007, § II, 11-8-07; Ord. No. 26-2008, § III, 12-11-08; Ord. No. 4-2012, 3-8-2012) 
Sec. 12-62. - Disposal. 
(a)  All permitted recyclable materials under the single-stream recycling program may be deposited into a single or multiple containers without being separated. Newspaper may be collected separately from the container so long as it is placed in brown paper bags and placed curbside. Cardboard also may be collected separately from the container so long as it is cut-down and bundled with string and placed curbside. As so prepared, these materials shall be placed at the curbside to be collected at times as herein designated or shall be placed in designated recycling shelters at any time. 
(b)  The appropriate city authorities are hereby authorized to designate, by regulation, the days and times for the collection of single-stream recycling materials and leaf waste. 
(Ord. No. 87-86, 8-12-86; Ord. No. 18-88, 3-24-88; Ord. No. 19-90, 8-9-90; Ord. No. 25-2007, § III, 11-8-07; Ord. No. 4-2012, 3-8-2012) 
Sec. 12-63. - Vesting of ownership, unauthorized collection prohibited. 
    From the time of placement at the curb of any recyclable items enumerated herein, pursuant to the provisions of this article and the regulations issued hereunder, such recyclable items shall become and be the property of the City of Wilkes-Barre. It shall be a violation of the terms of this article for any person, other than authorized personnel of the city, to collect, pick-up, or cause to be collected or picked up, any such items. Each such collection or pick-up in violation hereof shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. 87-86, 8-12-86; Ord. No. 18-88, 3-24-88; Ord. No. 19-90, 8-9-90; Ord. No. 25-2007, § IV, 11-8-07; Ord. No. 4-2012, 3-8-2012) 
Sec. 12-64. - Sale or donation. 
    Notwithstanding any provision of this article, any person having ownership of the same, may sell or donate recyclable items enumerated herein to any person, partnership or corporation, whether operating for profit or not for profit; provided, however, that such materials may not be placed for collection at, nor collected from the curbside. 
(Ord. No. 87-86, 8-12-86; Ord. No. 18-88, 3-24-88; Ord. No. 19-90, 8-9-90; Ord. No. 25-2007, § V, 11-8-07; Ord. No. 4-2012, 3-8-2012) 
Sec. 12-65. - Commercial recycling. 
(a)  There is hereby established a requirement that all commercial, institutional and municipal establishments participate in recycling of at minimum recyclable aluminum beverage cans, high-grade office paper and corrugated paper and leaf waste, as those terms are herein defined; however, commercial, institutional, and municipal establishments are recommended to participate to the fullest extent in the single-stream recycling program. 
(1)  Recyclable aluminum beverage cans. Beverage cans constructed solely of aluminum. 
(2)  High-grade office paper. White computer paper, bond, letterhead and ledger. 
(3)  Corrugated paper. Cardboard shipping and receiving boxes. 
(4)  Leaf waste. Leaves, garden residue, shrubbery and tree trimmings, and similar material, but not including grass clippings. 
(b)  Disposal. Each commercial, institutional and municipal establishment located within the City of Wilkes-Barre will obtain a recycling hauler of their choice and properly separate recyclable aluminum cans, high-grade office paper, and corrugated paper from general waste/refuse as directed by their recycling hauler. The commercial, institutional and municipal establishments and their recycling haulers will determine the time and location for pickup of the recyclable items. The City of Wilkes-Barre will not pick up or remove recyclable items from any commercial, institutional and municipal establishments. 
(c)  Mixed use commercial and residential properties. In the event that a property is a mixed-use commercial and residential building and/or structure, all residential units are required to pay the recycling fee and participate in the city's recycling program. 
(d)  Community activities. There is hereby established a requirement that any sponsor of a community activity must provide for the separation, storage and collection of the following items: 
(1)  Recyclable aluminum beverage cans. 
(2)  High-grade office paper. 
(3)  Corrugated paper. 
(4)  Leaf waste. 
(Ord. No. 87-86, 8-12-86; Ord. No. 18-88, 3-24-88; Ord. No. 19-90, 8-9-90; Ord. No. 25-2007, § VI, 11-8-07; Ord. No. 26-2008, § IV, 12-11-08; Ord. No. 4-2012, 3-8-12; Ord. No. 25-2015, § 1, 1-14-16) 
Sec. 12-66. - Penalties. 
    Any person, partnership or corporation who violates or fails to comply with any provision of this article or any regulation promulgated thereunder, with the exception of those persons violating section 12-63, shall, upon conviction thereof in a court of summary jurisdiction, be punishable by fines of not more than fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first offense, not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the second offense, and not more than one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00) for the third offense. Any person who violates section 12-63 shall, upon conviction thereof, be sentenced to pay a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) and not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00). 
(Ord. No. 87-86, 8-12-86; Ord. No. 18-88, 3-24-88; Ord. No. 19-90, 8-9-90; Ord. No. 25-2007, § VII, 11-8-07; Ord. No. 4-2012, 3-8-2012) 
Secs. 12-67-12-75. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VI. - COLLECTION OF WHITE GOODS 

Sec. 12-91. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings given to them in this section, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    City means the City of Wilkes-Barre, Luzerne County, Pennsylvania. 
    Collector means the City of Wilkes-Barre's Department of Public Works or its designated agent, authorized by the City of Wilkes-Barre to collect, transport and dispose of white goods. 
    White goods means large items, made primarily of metal, including, but not limited to, the following: washers, dryers, dishwashers, water heaters, air conditioners (no freon), refrigerators (no freon), stoves, grills, lawnmowers, tire rims, bicycles, metal doors, car parts, wheel barrows, hub caps, metal fans, metal lawn furniture, which cannot be handled, in most instances, by normal solid waste processing, collection or disposal methods. 
(Ord. No. 27-98, § 1, 6-4-98) 
Sec. 12-92. - White goods collection and disposal. 
(a)  The City of Wilkes-Barre, Department of Public Works is hereby authorized to collect white goods, haul and dispose of same in accordance with this article and as permitted by the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, Department of Environmental Resources. 
(b)  White goods, which consist of mainly appliances and all metal, shall be disposed of separately from commingled recycling, newspapers, and municipal solid waste. All residents of Wilkes-Barre except multifamily units of more than nineteen (19) shall be eligible for this service. All white goods containing sealed refrigeration systems or systems using freon gas must have compressors/condensers removed before collection of said appliance can be made. All refrigerator/freezer doors must be removed when placed at curbside. No commercial/institutional type of white goods/appliances will be accepted for collection by the city. 
(c)  The collection and disposal of white goods shall be from time to time, prescribed by the city as part of a clean-up campaign. 
(d)  Nothing in this article shall prohibit any person not regularly engaged in the business of collecting white goods for profit, from hauling and disposing of their own white goods in accordance with this article and as permitted by the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, Department of Environmental Resources. 
(Ord. No. 27-98, § 2, 6-4-98) 
Sec. 12-93. - Vesting of ownership; unauthorized collection prohibited. 
    From the time of placement at the curb of any white goods enumerated herein, pursuant to the provisions of this article and the regulations issued hereunder, such white goods shall become and be the property of the City of Wilkes-Barre. It shall be a violation of the terms of this article for any person, other than authorized personnel of the city, to collect, pick up, or cause to be collected or picked up, any such items. Each such collection or pickup in violation hereof shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. 27-98, § 3, 6-4-98) 
Sec. 12-94. - Enforcement. 
    The provisions of this article shall be enforced by the bureau of code enforcement and the police department of the city. 
(Ord. No. 27-98, § 4, 6-4-98) 
Sec. 12-95. - Penalties. 
    Whoever violates any provision of this article shall be guilty of a summary offense and shall upon conviction before a district magistrate of Luzerne County be fined not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) together with the costs of prosecution or be imprisoned for not more than thirty (30) days. Every violation of the provisions of this article shall be deemed a separate offense for each and every day such violation continues and shall be subject to the penalty imposed by this section for each and every such separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 27-98, § 7, 6-4-98) 
Secs. 12-96-12-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL OF YARD WASTE 

Sec. 12-101. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings given to them in this section, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    City means the City of Wilkes-Barre, County of Luzerne, Pennsylvania, a Pennsylvania municipal corporation or agency of the City of Wilkes-Barre. 
    Collector means the City of Wilkes-Barre's Department of Public Works or its designated agent, authorized by the City of Wilkes-Barre to collect yard waste. 
    Yard waste means leaves, garden residues, weeds, brush, shrubbery and tree trimmings, and similar materials, including grass clippings. Yard waste shall not include bulk items such as oversized tree limbs, large rocks, any household items or dirt. 
(Ord. No. 28-98, § 1, 6-4-98) 
Sec. 12-102. - Residential yard waste 
    All residents of the city shall separate yard waste from other municipal solid waste. The yard waste shall either be placed in regular plastic garbage bags or paper bags specifically designed for yard waste disposal, near the curb for municipal collection on designated days by the department of public works or its designated agent. City designated trash bags are not to be used for the collection of yard waste. The city shall collect only two (2) bags of yard waste per household, during each collection period. 
(Ord. No. 28-98, § 2, 6-4-98) 
Sec. 12-103. - Commercial or institutional establishments. 
    The city shall not be responsible for the collection of yard waste from commercial or institutional establishments. 
(Ord. No. 28-98, § 3, 6-4-98) 
Sec. 12-104. - Commingling of yard waste and municipal solid waste. 
    No person shall commingle yard waste with municipal solid waste. Any such commingling shall constitute a violation of this article and subject the violator to the penalty provisions hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 28-98, § 6, 6-4-98) 
Sec. 12-105. - Penalties. 
    Whoever violates any provision of this article shall be guilty of a summary offense and shall upon conviction before a district magistrate of Luzerne County be fined not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) together with the costs of prosecution or be imprisoned for not more than thirty (30) days. Every violation of the provisions of this article shall be deemed a separate offense for each and every day such violation continues and shall be subject to the penalty imposed by this section for each and every such separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 28-98, § 7, 6-4-98) 
Chapter 13 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Cemetery, Ch. 8; transportation of hazardous materials and waste, § 10-31 et seq.; food and food handlers, Ch. 11; garbage and refuse, Ch. 12; noise, Ch. 17; nuisances, Ch. 18; utilities, Ch. 30. 
State Law reference- Health and safety, 35 P.S. § 1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 13-1. - Public convenience stations. 
(a)  No person shall blow, spread or place any nasal or other bodily discharge, or spit, urinate or defecate on the floors, walls, partitions, furniture, fittings or on any portion of any public convenience station or in any place in such station excepting directly into the particular fixture provided for that purpose, nor shall any person place any bottle, can, cloth, rag or metal, wood or stone substance in any of the plumbing fixtures in any such station. 
(b)  No person shall stand or climb on any closet, closet seat, basin, partition or other furniture or fitting, or loiter about, or push, crowd or otherwise act in a disorderly manner, or interfere with any attendant in the discharge of his duties, or whistle, dance, sing, skate, swear or use obscene, loud and boisterous language within the public convenience station, or at or near the entrance thereof. 
(c)  No person shall cut, deface, mar, destroy or break, or write on or scratch any wall, floor, ceiling, partition, fixture or furniture, or use towels in an improper manner, or waste soap, toilet paper or any of the facilities provided in any public convenience station. 
(Ord. No. 22, §§ 1-3, 1-23-14) 
Sec. 13-2. - Banning the sale, distribution, consumption, possession and ingestion of certain chemical combinations, including but not limited to those being marketed or held out as bath salts. 
    Any and all of the following opiates, including their isomers, esters, ethers, salts, and salts of isomers, esters, and ethers, unless specifically excepted, whenever the existence of such isomers, esters, ethers and salts is possible within the specific chemical designation are hereby banned for use, sale, consumption, ingestion, lease, rent, exchange or distribution in any manner which is not already prohibited by the law of the Commonwealth, by any person, corporation and/or entity within the City of Wilkes-Barre: 
(1)  Salvia Divinorum. 
(2)  Salvinorin A. 
(3)  Divinorin A. 
(4)  3,4-METHYLENEDIOXYMETHCATHINONE (METHYLONE). 
(5)  3,4-METHYENEDIOXYPYROVALERONE (MDPV). 
(6)  4-METHYLMETHCATHINONE (MEPHEDRONE). 
(7)  4-METHOXYMETHCATHINONE. 
(8)  4-FLUOROMETHCATHINONE. 
(9)  3-FLUOROMETHCATHINONE. 
    Further, it shall be unlawful for any persons, entities and/or corporations knowing, or under circumstances where one should reasonably know, to use, sell, consume, ingest, lease, rent, exchange, distribute, in any manner, and/or possess, with the intent to deliver, any product containing the following chemicals: JWH-018; JWH-200; JWH-073; CP-47; 497; Cannabicyclohexanol, 3.4 Methylenedioxyprovalerone (MDPV); Methylone; Mephedrone; 4-Methosymethcathinone; 4-Fluromethcathinone; and 3-Fluoromethcathinone and marketed, sold and/or represented to be incense, potpourri, plant fertilizers, insect repellants and/or bath salts; 
    Any person, corporation or entity violating this section shall be punished, upon conviction, with a fine up to five hundred dollars dollars ($500.00) and/or incarceration of up to thirty (30) days. Each day the violation of this section occurs shall be considered a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 9-2011, §§ 1-3, 4-28-11) 
Secs. 13-3-13-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION[2] 

Footnotes: 

Sec. 13-16. - Establishment of board of health; members. 
    A board of health is hereby created in the City of Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania, to consist of five (5) members. 
    The members of the said board shall serve without compensation and shall be appointed by the mayor with the approval of the council. No member of city council shall be appointed as a member of the board of health. All members of the board of health shall be either residents of the city or maintain an office in the city. At least one (1), and whenever possible, two (2), shall be currently licensed or certified by the State Board of Medicine, the State Board of Examiners of Nursing Home Administrators, the State Board of Podiatry, the State Board of Veterinary Medicine, the State Board of Occupational Therapy Education and Licensure, the State Board of Osteopathic Medicine, the State Board of pharmacy, the State Board of Physical Therapy or the State Board of Nursing to be engaged in a medical, medically related or health care profession or business. If a licensed or certified medical or health care professional cannot be identified to serve on the board, the mayor, with the approval of city council, may appoint any individual who has experience or is knowledgeable of public health issues. 
    At the first appointment council shall designate one (1) of the members to serve for one (1) year, one (1) for two (2) years, one (1) for three (3) years, one (1) for four (4) years and one (1) for five (5) years, from January 8, 1980, and thereafter one (1) member of the said board shall be appointed annually to serve for the term of five (5) years from January 1 succeeding his appointment. The mayor may remove any or all of the members of said board for official misconduct or neglect of duty and may fill any vacancy for any unexpired term with the approval of council. 
(Ord. No. 30-97, § 1(1), 9-18-97) 
Sec. 13-17. - Powers and duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the board of health to enforce the laws of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania and the article of the City of Wilkes-Barre for the protection of the public health. It shall exercise all the rights and perform all the duties and obligations conferred and imposed upon like boards of health in cities of the third class of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania by all Acts of Assembly which may not be in force or hereafter passed in reference to the same. The board of health shall have power to make and enforce such orders and regulations as may be necessary to carry out its aforesaid duties and obligations so long as the council shall approve such regulations. 
(Ord. No. 30-97, § 1(2), 9-18-97) 
Sec. 13-18. - Meetings. 
    The board of health shall meet at such regular times as it designates and at such places where the general public has unhampered access to such meetings, and said board shall keep regular minutes of its meetings. It shall have the power to adopt rules and by-laws to govern its meetings and organizations. 
(Ord. No. 30-97, § 1(3), 9-18-97) 
Sec. 13-19. - Secretary. 
    The secretary of the board shall be an individual qualified in the secretarial arts and shall keep the minutes of the meetings and perform such other duties as the director may direct. 
(Ord. No. 30-97, § 1(4), 9-18-97) 
Sec. 13-20. - Director. 
    The board of health shall choose a director with the approval of the mayor. The director shall not be a member of the board of health, but shall be an individual who meets the qualifications established for such position by the Pennsylvania Department of Health and the board of health. In the event of a vacancy in the position of director, the board of health shall convene at the earliest possible time for the purpose of filling that vacancy. The salary of the director shall be fixed by the city council. The director shall execute the orders of the board and shall have and exercise for this purpose all the powers and authority of a police officer. 
(Ord. No. 30-97, § 1(5), 9-18-97) 
Sec. 13-21. - Administration. 
(a)  The director shall exercise the power to employ personnel in conformity with 16 P.S. section 21012(b), which for this purpose shall be applicable to the health board, and the Charter and Administrative Code of the City of Wilkes-Barre. All such employees shall be entitled to participate in the benefits of employment conferred on employees of the City of Wilkes-Barre with regard to pension, social security coverage, medical and hospitalization benefits, vacation and sick leave. Such employees shall be subject to removal by the director for misconduct in office or neglect of duty, excepting that where positions are covered by civil service, civil service laws shall apply. 
(b)  The director shall be the administrator of the health board. All administrative actions and procedures incident to the operation of the health board, including, but not limited to, financial administration and the making of contracts, shall be governed by the Charter and Administrative Code of the City of Wilkes-Barre. 
(Ord. No. 30-97, § 1(6), 9-18-97) 
Secs. 13-22-13-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - AIR POLLUTION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Provisions formerly codified as §§ 13-16-13-28 have been replaced by provisions enacted by Ord. No. 30-97, adopted Sept. 18, 1997. Said former provisions pertained to the board of health and were derived from Ord. No. 21-77, adopted June 21, 1977. 
Cross reference- Administration generally Ch. 2. 

Sec. 13-41. - Purpose. 
(a)  The purpose of this article is to prevent the excessive build-up of air pollutants within the corporate limits of the city, thereby preventing the occurrence of an emergency due to the effects of these pollutants on the health, safety and welfare of any person. 
(b)  Whereas, in conjunction with the air pollution program, it is desirable to adopt appropriate regulations to reduce air pollution caused by excessive soot, cinders, fly ash, dust, noxious acids, fumes and gases, the emission of which is detrimental to the health and welfare of the residents of the city. 
(Ord. No. 21-77, Art. IV, 6-21-77) 
Sec. 13-42. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Agency shall mean any official body of any political subdivision of the state having the authority or duty to enforce local ordinances or resolutions relating to the prevention and control of air pollution. (Department of health of the city, under the director of air pollution control-principal health officer). 
    Air cleaning device shall mean any article, chemical, machine, equipment or other contrivance, the use of which may eliminate, reduce or control the emission of air contaminants into the outdoor atmosphere. 
    Ambient air quality standards shall mean concentrations of air contaminants in the ambient air. (Relating to ambient air quality standards provided by the United States Environmental Protection Agency and Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Resources, Chapter 131 of State Ambient Air Quality Standards.) 
    Best available technology shall mean equipment, devices, methods or techniques which will prevent, reduce or control emissions of air contaminants to the maximum degree possible and which are available or can be made available. 
    Cinders, dust, fly ash, noxious acids, fumes and gases shall be considered to be all matter other than dense smoke, including coke, cinders, dust and soot formed as a result of the combustion of fuel, which are carried into the outdoor atmosphere. 
    Clean air act shall mean the Federal Clean Air Act, as amended by Public Law 91-604, 84 Stat. 1676 (42 U.S.C. 1857 et seq.) and the rules and regulations promulgated thereunder. 
    Combustion unit shall mean any stationary equipment used to burn fuel primarily for the purpose of producing power or producing heat. 
    Dense smoke shall mean that smoke which has a density of No. 2 or greater as established by the Ringelmann Chart. 
    Emissions shall mean air contaminants emitted into the outdoor atmosphere. 
    Malodor shall mean any odor which causes annoyance or discomfort to the public and which the health department determines to be objectionable to the public. 
    Open burning shall mean any fire, the air contaminants from which are emitted directly into the outdoor atmosphere and not directed thereto through a flue. 
    Particulate matter shall mean any material, except uncombined water, that is or has been airborne and exists as a solid or liquid (standard conditions) at seventy (70) degrees Fahrenheit and fourteen point seven (14.7) pounds per square inch absolute pressure. 
    Person shall mean any individual, partnerships, firms, associations, companies, corporations, syndicates or other groups who may employ, own, use or operate any fuel consuming device. 
    Ringelmann Chart shall mean standards published by the United States Bureau of Mines to determine the density of smoke. 
    Volatile organic compound shall mean any compound containing carbon and hydrogen or containing carbon and hydrogen in combination with any other element and which has a vapor pressure of at least one and five tenths (1.5) pounds per square inch absolute under actual storage conditions. 
(Ord. No. 21-77, Art. IV, § 1, 6-21-77) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 13-43. - Emission of air contaminants prohibited. 
(a)  Generally. it shall be unlawful for any person to permit the emission of dense smoke or any air contaminant from any source whatever. (Smoke of density equal to or greater than that density described as No. 2 on the Ringelmann Chart, published by the United States Bureau of Mines). 
(b)  Open burning operations. No person shall cause, suffer or permit the open burning of any material in the limits of the city in such a manner that: 
(1)  Malodorous air contaminants from open burning are detectable outside the person's property; 
(2)  The emissions are visible, at any time, at the point such emissions pass outside the person's property; 
(3)  The emissions interfere with the reasonable enjoyment of life or property; 
(4)  The emissions cause damage to vegetation or property; 
(5)  The emissions are or may be deleterious to human or animal health. 
(c)  Exceptions. The provisions of this section shall not be applicable to: 
(1)  Any fire set to prevent or abate a fire hazard, when approved by the fire and health departments, and when set by or under supervision of responsible public officers; 
(2)  Any fire set for the purpose of instructing personnel in fire fighting, when approved by the fire and health departments; 
(3)  Any fire set for the prevention and control of disease or pests, when approved by proper departments; 
(4)  Any fire set for the period for rekindling of fires when a furnace, boiler or other fuel consuming device is being cleaned out and a new fire is being built therein, in which event a smoke of a density equal to or greater than that described as No. 2 of the Ringlemann Chart, shall be permitted for a period of not to exceed six (6) minutes in any single period of sixty (60) minutes. 
(Ord. No. 21-77, Art. IV, § II, 6-21-77) 
Sec. 13-44. - Escape of soot, cinders, noxious acids, fumes and gases prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to permit or cause the escape of such quantities of soot, cinders, noxious acids, fumes and gases in such place or manner as to be detrimental to any person or to the public or to endanger the health, comfort and safety of any such person or of the public, or in such manner as to cause or have a tendency to cause injury or damage to property or business. The escape of such matter is declared to be a public nuisance and shall be summarily abated by the principal health officer, or by any of his representatives whom he may designate for such purpose. 
(Ord. No. 21-77, Art. IV, § III, 6-21-77) 
Sec. 13-45. - Prohibition of certain fugitive emissions. 
(a)  No person shall cause, suffer or permit the emission into the outdoor atmosphere of any fugitive air contaminants from any source except from: 
(1)  Construction or demolition of buildings or structures; 
(2)  Grading, paving and maintenance of roads and streets; 
(3)  Use of roads and streets; emissions from material in or on trucks, railroad cars and other vehicular equipment shall not be considered as emissions from use of roads and streets; 
(4)  Clearing of land; 
(5)  Tilling or applying amendments to the soil, preparing cover crops for incorporation into the soil and harvesting, while farming; 
(6)  Stockpiling of materials; 
(7)  Blasting in open pits; emissions from drilling shall not be considered as emissions from blasting; 
(8)  Other sources and classes of sources determined by the health department to be of minor significance with respect to the achievement and maintenance of ambient air quality standards or with respect to causing air pollution. 
(b)  Any person responsible for any source specified in subsection (a)(1)-(8) shall take all reasonable actions to prevent particulate matter from becoming airborne. Such actions shall include, but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Use, where possible, of water or chemicals for control of dust in the demolition of buildings or structures, construction operations, the grading or clearing of land; 
(2)  Application of asphalt, oil, water or suitable chemicals on dirt roads, alleys, material stockpiles and other surfaces which can give to airborne dusts; 
(3)  Conduct of agricultural practices such as tilling of land, application of fertilizers, etc., in such a manner as to minimize dust from becoming airborne; 
(4)  Paving and maintenance of roadways; 
(5)  Prompt removal of earth or other materials from paved streets onto which earth or other material has been transported by trucking or earth moving equipment, erosion by water, or other means. 
(c)  No person shall cause, suffer or permit fugitive particulate matter or particulate matter to be emitted into the outdoor atmosphere from any source specified in subsection (a)(1)-(8) if such emissions are: 
(1)  Either visible, at any time, at the point such emissions pass outside the person's property, irrespective of the concentration of particulate matter in such emissions; or 
(2)  Not visible at the point such emissions pass outside the person's property and the average concentration, of such emissions at any point outside the person's property, exceeds one hundred fifty (150) particles per cubic centimeter, of three (3) samples collected. 
(Ord. No. 21-77, Art. IV, § IV, 6-21-77) 
Sec. 13-46. - Standards. 
    It is intended that by the application of the provisions of this article, air quality shall be maintained at levels in areas where the existing ambient air quality is better than the applicable ambient air quality standards, and that air quality shall be improved to achieve the applicable ambient air quality standards in those areas where the existing air quality is worse than the applicable ambient air quality standards. Ambient air quality standards and all standards for sources, set by state department of environmental resources shall be used as guidelines for compliance of this article. In accordance with this intent it is the purpose of this article to insure that all new operation of sources governed by this article shall be in compliance with the applicable standards of: 
Title 25 Rules and Regulations 
Department of Environmental Resources 
Protection of Natural Resources 
Article III Air Resources 
Chapters 121, 123, 127, 129, 131, 135, 137 and 141. 
and that new sources shall not result in producing air contaminant concentrations in excess of the state department of environmental resources standards. 
(Ord. No. 21-77, Art. IV, § IV, 6-21-77) 
Sec. 13-47. - Exemptions. 
    Approval shall not be required under this article for the construction, modification, reactivation or installation of: 
(1)  Air conditioning or ventilation systems not designed to remove pollutants generated by or released from other sources; 
(2)  Combustion units rated at two million five hundred thousand (2,500,000) or less Btu per hour of heat input; 
(3)  Combustion units fueled by natural gas supplied by a public utility and used only for space heating, air conditioning or heating water; 
(4)  Sources used in residential premises designed to house four (4) or less families; 
(5)  Space heaters that heat by direct heat transfer; 
(6)  Mobile sources; 
(7)  Laboratory equipment used exclusively for chemical or physical analyses; 
(8)  Other sources and classes of sources determined to be of minor significance by the health department. 
(Ord. No. 21-77, Art. IV, § V, 6-21-77) 
Sec. 13-48. - Enforcement by health department and principal health officer. 
    The duties of the health department and principal health officer or any representatives shall be: 
(1)  To investigate all complaints of violations of this article, and to institute necessary proceedings in case of violations; 
(2)  To make annual inspections of all fuel consuming and smokeless fuel consuming devices in operation within the city where nuisances are apt to be created, and determine whether compliance is being had with the provisions of this article; 
(3)  If necessary, to promulgate and publish rules and regulations under which this article will be administered, providing in detail and with clarity the necessary information by which the public is to be guided, this information prepared only after a thorough consideration of the air pollution problem as it exists in the city; 
(4)  To do any and all other acts which may be necessary for the successful prosecution of the purposes of this article. 
(Ord. No. 21-77, Art. IV, § VI, 6-21-77) 
Sec. 13-49. - Period of grace. 
    Whenever it has been adequately demonstrated to the investigating health officials that compliance with the terms of this article cannot be effectively and immediately made, the health department or principal health officer shall have the authority to grant a temporary period for the continued operation of such noncomplying equipment, but only if the party has taken all necessary steps to secure compliance with this article. Such temporary period shall be no longer than six (6) months; at the expiration of such time, the responsible party of operation shall be deemed to be in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 21-77, Art. IV, § VII, 6-21-77) 
Secs. 13-50-13-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - COCKROACH AND VERMIN CONTROL[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 25-90, §§ 1-12, adopted July 12, 1990, was not enacted as a specific amendment or addition to the Code, and hence is incorporated herein as a new Art. III, §§ 13-61-13-72, to Ch. 13 at the editor's discretion. 
Cross reference- Garbage and refuse, Ch. 12; vermin enumerated as nuisance, § 18-2(7). 

Sec. 13-61. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Wilkes-Barre Cockroach and Vermin Control Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 25-90, § 1, 7-12-90) 
Sec. 13-62. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this article: 
    Cockroach (roach) shall mean any or all of the many types of cockroaches, including, but not limited to, the German Cockroach, the Oriental Cockroach (frequently referred to as a "waterbug"), the American Cockroach, the Brown Banded Cockroach, and any other less common varieties. 
    Infestation shall mean cockroaches or other disease-breeding insects in sufficient numbers within a given area so as to present a danger to the public health or to human inhabitants residing nearby. 
    Vermin shall mean any harmful or disease-bearing insects which constitute a present or potential danger to the public health and which tend to entrench themselves within dwelling units and other buildings to reproduce their kind therein. 
(Ord. No. 25-90, § 2, 7-12-90) 
Sec. 13-63. - Prohibiting conditions conducive to cockroach and vermin life. 
(a)  No owner, tenant or other responsible person shall create or maintain any condition within an apartment, house or other building, commercial or otherwise, yard or lot which would tend to encourage cockroach or other vermin life. This prohibition shall include all those unsanitary housekeeping practices which provide ready access to any vermin of a food supply and harborage beyond any reasonable standards set forth in existing health and housing codes. It shall be the responsibility of the bureau of health to make any determination as to what constitutes unsanitary housekeeping practices which might encourage and perpetrate cockroach and vermin life. 
(b)  A judgment that conditions conducive to cockroach and vermin life exists within an apartment, house or other building, commercial or otherwise, may be made by the city regardless of whether the specific conditions found are explicitly covered by existing city ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 25-90, § 3, 7-12-90) 
Sec. 13-64. - Investigation of premises believed to harbor cockroach and vermin life. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the bureau of health to investigate any residential property, whether apartment, rented house, roominghouse, hotel, motel, or other building, occupied or vacant, which is believed to harbor cockroach or other vermin life. Also included are public drinking and eating establishments, schools, hospitals and commercial stores or buildings. Such investigations shall be warranted when either a formal complaint is lodged with the city or the city has reason to believe, based on personal observation, information received or evident conditions, that cockroach or vermin life exists at a given location. 
(Ord. No. 25-90, § 4, 7-12-90) 
Sec. 13-65. - Right of entry. 
    The city shall have the right of entry into or onto any property for the purpose of conducting an investigation to determine the possible existence of cockroaches and other vermin at any reasonable time. The owner or occupant of any property shall be asked for verbal permission for such entry for this purpose. Consideration shall be afforded any owner or occupant so that if the time is not convenient a future appointment may be set for the inspection of the property. The city shall not be liable if the actual presence of cockroaches or other vermin is not found. The city shall have the right upon such inspection to require the responsible party to comply with eliminating any conditions found that would tend to promote cockroach and vermin life. 
(Ord. No. 25-90, § 5, 7-12-90) 
Sec. 13-66. - Determination of cockroach or other vermin infestation. 
(a)  The bureau of health shall have the authority to determine whether an infestation exists in a given property. Such a determination shall be based on first-hand observation of cockroach or other vermin or observing signs of their concealed presence. 
(b)  One (1) cockroach or other vermin shall not in and of itself constitute an infestation nor shall it be labeled as an infestation by the city. The presence of one (1) cockroach or other vermin may be viewed as a threat of future infestation and shall be deemed justification for the issuance of an order by the city to exterminate. 
(Ord. No. 25-90, § 6, 7-12-90) 
Sec. 13-67. - Notice to exterminate. 
(a)  The City of Wilkes-Barre, through its bureau of health, may order extermination of cockroaches or other vermin at a specific property or location. Notice shall be served on the responsible party to comply with a specified time. 
(b)  The responsibility for extermination shall be that of the property owner unless the prohibited conditions exist in a tenant occupied single-family dwelling unit. The responsibility then lies with the tenant of this single unit. 
(Ord. No. 25-90, § 7, 7-12-90) 
Sec. 13-68. - Liability for the spread of cockroaches and vermin. 
    No person shall knowingly move household furnishings from a cockroach or other vermin-infested dwelling unit into another dwelling unit within the City of Wilkes-Barre unless said furnishings are free from infestation. It shall be unlawful for a person to transport cockroaches or other vermin in this manner or to allow an infestation to develop within a residential or commercial unit without taking corrective action which results in the elimination of the prohibited condition. It shall constitute a violation of this article if a person when required to do so fails to undertake corrective action to eliminate a cockroach or vermin infestation and that failure results in such infestation being spread to neighboring property. 
(Ord. No. 25-90, § 8, 7-12-90) 
Sec. 13-69. - Methods of extermination. 
    If an infestation has been determined by the bureau of health to exist at a given location or property and notice has been served to correct this prohibited condition, the responsible party shall take whatever action is deemed necessary by the city to effect compliance. This includes utilization and implementation of the expert services of a trained professional exterminator. Liability for damages or human injury shall lie with the responsible party or his agent. 
(Ord. No. 25-90, § 9, 7-12-90) 
Sec. 13-70. - Period of time required for proper extermination. 
(a)  The period of time required for proper extermination shall depend upon the type of cockroach or vermin subject to extermination and the residuals (life) of the pesticides used. Such determination may be made by the bureau of health or by any certified pest control operator. 
(b)  It shall be borne in mind that egg sacs of cockroaches are not affected by most pesticides and that the incubation period for some cockroaches could exceed two (2) months during colder temperature periods. The term "extermination" shall include both the destruction of live cockroaches and vermin and their offspring. 
(Ord. No. 25-90, § 10, 7-12-90) 
Sec. 13-71. - Responsibility for reinspection. 
    The bureau of health shall have the right to inspect any property to ensure compliance with the conditions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 25-90, § 11, 7-12-90) 
Sec. 13-72. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be fined not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) or imprisoned not more than ninety (90) days, or both. 
(Ord. No. 25-90, § 12, 7-12-90) 
Cross reference- General penalty, § 1-7. 
Secs. 13-73-13-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - USE OF FURNITURE DESIGNED FOR INTERIOR USE IN EXTERIOR AREAS WHERE IT IS EXPOSED TO THE ELEMENTS AND SUSCEPTIBLE TO POSING AN UNREASONABLE HEALTH AND SAFETY RISK 

Sec. 13-101. - Prohibited furniture. 
    It shall be unlawful, within the city limits of the City of Wilkes-Barre, to place, use or keep interior-type furniture which would be adversely affected by weather elements and/or susceptible to infestation by insects, rats, or other vermin, in an area outside a structure. Such prohibited furniture shall include, but shall not be limited to, upholstered couches and chairs, or other fabric-covered articles not designed or intended for exterior use. 
(Ord. No. 22-06, § 1, 11-9-06) 
Sec. 13-102. - Removal of abandoned or prohibited furniture. 
    When the building code official or an official agent of the City of Wilkes-Barre determines that prohibited or abandoned furniture is located in an exterior property area, the said officer or agent shall cause the owner or other responsible person to be notified by certified mail or other verifiable delivery, such as by constable or police officer, and the owner and/or responsible person shall be granted five (5) days to remove the said furniture. In the event the owner and/or other responsible party fails to remove the said furniture within five (5) days of receipt of the notice, as confirmed by affidavit of service or proof of certified delivery, the owner and/or other responsible person shall 
have violated this article. Each day that the furniture is not removed shall be deemed a separate violation hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 22-06, § 2, 11-9-06) 
Sec. 13-103. - Fines and penalties. 
    Any person violating this article shall be guilty of a summary offense and shall pay a fine in an amount not to exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00). 
(Ord. No. 22-06, § 3, 11-9-06) 
Secs. 13-104-13-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - TATTOO PARLORS AND RELATED ESTABLISHMENTS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 57-2004, adopted July 23, 2006, pertained to tattoo parlors and related establishments. At the city's instruction these provisions were placed into Ch. 13. At the editor's discretion these provisions were included as Art. VI, §§ 13-121-13-131. 

Sec. 13-121. - Definitions. 
(a)  Body art. The practice of physical body adornment by permitted establishments and operators utilizing, but not limited to, the following techniques; body piercing tattooing, cosmetic tattooing, branding and scarification, and the placement of pigments, trimming or filing of the nails. 
(b)  Body piercing. The process of penetrating the skin or mucous membrane for the purpose of insertion of any object, including but not limited to, jewelry for cosmetic purposes. The term also includes the production of scars upon the body. 
(c)  Body piercing establishment. Any room or space where body piercing is practiced or where the business of body piercing is conducted or any part thereof. 
(d)  Body piercing artist/operator. Any person who actually performs the work of body piercing. 
(e)  Department. The health department of the City of Wilkes-Barre, the director of the said department, or any authorized representative thereof. 
(f)  Disinfection. The destruction of all vegetative forms of pathogenic agents by chemical or physical means. 
(g)  Equipment. All machinery, including fixtures, containers, vessels, tools, implements, furniture, display and storage areas, sinks, and other apparatus used in connection with the operation of any establishment. 
(h)  Establishment. Any place or premise, whether public or private, where any person conducts any enterprise, occupation, vocation or business, whether or not for profit and whether temporarily or permanently located. 
(I)  Facility manager. Any person who controls, operates, conducts or manages any tattooing or body piercing establishment, whether actually performing tattooing or body piercing or not. 
(j)  Hot water. Water which is at a temperature of not less than one hundred ten (110) F nor greater than one hundred twenty-five (125) F. 
(k)  Infection. The entry and multiplication of any pathogen in the body of a human or animal. 
(l)  Infectious disease. A disease of humans or animals resulting from a transmissible infection, whether or not patent, apparent, unapparent, latent, clinical or subclinical. 
(m)  Infectious waste. Waste generated in the treatment or service of a human which falls under one (1) or more of the following categories: (1) Pathological Wastes. Human pathological wastes, including tissues that are removed during medical procedures. The term does not include hair, or extracted teeth. (2) Human blood and body fluid waste including liquid waste, human blood, blood products, items contaminated with blood or dried human blood. (3) Used sharps. Needles, scalpel blades, suture needles, broken or unbroken glass or plasticware, disposable razors, scalpel blades, and other sharp objects that have cut or pierced the skin or have been in contact with infectious agents, 
(n)  Municipal waste. Garbage, refuse, industrial lunchroom or office waste and other material, including solid, liquid, semisolid or contained gaseous material resulting from operation of residential, municipal, commercial or institutional establishments and from community activities. 
(o)  Sanitization. The reduction of the population of microorganisms to safe levels as determined by public health officials. 
(p)  Sterilization. Process of destruction of all forms of life by physical or chemical means. 
(q)  Tattoo. The indelible mark, figure or decorative design introduced by insertion of nontoxic dyes or pigments into or under the subcutaneous portion of the skin of a human being. 
(r)  Tattooing. The process by which the skin is marked or colored by insertion of nontoxic dyes or pigments into or under the subcutaneous portion of the skin so as to form indelible marks for cosmetic, medical or figurative purposes. 
(s)  Tattoo artist/operator. Any person who actually performs the work of tattooing. 
(t)  Tattoo establishment. Any room or space where tattooing is practiced or where the business of tattooing is conducted or any part thereof. 
(u)  Temporary tattoo/body piercing establishment. A tattoo/body piercing establishment that operates at a fixed location for a period of time of not more than seven (7) consecutive days in conjunction with a single event or celebration. 
(Ord. No. 57-2004, 7-23-06) 
Sec. 13-122. - Certificates. 
(a)  Establishment certificate. 
(1)  No person, firm, partnership, joint venture, association, business trust, corporation or any organized group of persons may operate a tattooing or body piercing establishment unless it has received a tattooing/body piercing establishment certificate from the department. 
(2)  Any person operating a tattoo/body piercing establishment shall obtain a certificate from the Department annually. 
(3)  The applicant shall pay a reasonable fee as set by the Department for each tattooing/body piercing establishment certificate. 
(4)  A certificate for a tattooing/body piercing establishment shall not be transferable from one (1) place or person to another. 
(5)  A certificate shall automatically expire on December 31 of each year unless renewed by the department upon the request of the licensee and payment of the fee. 
(6)  A current tattooing/body piercing establishment certificate shall be posted in a prominent and conspicuous area where it may be readily observed by patrons. 
(b)  Operator certificate. 
(1)  No person shall practice the art of tattooing or body piercing within the City of Wilkes-Barre without first obtaining a certificate from the department. 
(2)  All certificates shall be valid from the date of issuance and shall automatically expire in three (3) years from the date of issuance unless revoked soon by the department. 
(3)  No certificate to practice the art of tattooing or body piercing shall be issued unless; 
a.  The applicant furnishes proof of having previously held such a certificate; and 
b.  The applicant furnishes proof of having served an apprenticeship in tattooing under an operator's certificate pursuant to this Section for a period of at least three (3) years, or apprenticeship in body piercing under an operator's certificate pursuant to this section for a period of at least eighteen (18) months; 
OR 
c.  The applicant furnishes proof of having practiced the art of tattooing or body piercing as a full-time occupation prior to the date of the passage of these regulations; AND 
d.  The applicant furnishes proof of having attended a blood borne pathogens training program given or approved by the Department within the past three (3) years; AND 
e.  The applicant pays the certificate fee as set by the department. 
f.  Upon adoption of these regulations, individuals who comply with all of the above provisions except (e) relating to blood borne pathogens training will be issued a temporary certificate valid for a period of six months. At the end of this period, upon proof of attendance, a permanent certificate (valid for three years) will be issued. 
(4)  Each application for a certificate shall set forth: 
a.  The name and address of the applicant; 
b.  A physical description of the premises where tattooing/body piercing is to be done; 
c.  Such other information as the department may require. 
(5)  No certificate shall be issued unless, following reasonable investigation by the Department, the tattoo/body piercing operator has demonstrated compliance with the provisions of this section and all other applicable regulations. 
(6)  All certificates shall be conditioned upon continued compliance with the provisions of this section as well as all other applicable regulations, 
(7)  The certificate shall be posted in a prominent and conspicuous area where it may be readily observed by patrons. 
(c)  Apprentice certificate. 
(1)  Any person certified as a tattoo/body piercing operator pursuant to this section may apply to the department for one (1) or more apprentice certificates which, upon issuance, will allow the apprentice named thereon to practice tattooing in the establishment of and under the direct supervision of the certified operator named thereon, for a period of three (3) years or practice body piercing in the establishment of and under the direct supervision of the certified operator named thereon, for a period of eighteen (18) months. 
(2)  The applicant shall pay a reasonable fee as set by the department for each apprentice certificate. 
(3)  The apprentice certificate shall be posted in a prominent and conspicuous area where it may be readily observed by patrons. 
(d)  Temporary establishment/operator certificate. Temporary establishment and, when required, operator certificates may be issued for tattooing/body piercing services provided outside of the physical site of a certified facility for the purposes of product demonstration, industry trade shows or for educational reasons. The provision of tattooing/body piercing services at a mobile facility without a temporary establishment certificate issued in accordance with this section is prohibited. 
(1)  Temporary operator and/or establishment certificates will not be issued unless: 
a.  The applicant furnishes proof of compliance with subsection (b) relating to operator certificates; and 
b.  The applicant is currently affiliated with a fixed permanent facility which, where applicable, is licensed by the appropriate state and/or local jurisdiction; and 
c.  The temporary site complies with section 13-129, temporary establishment requirements, of this regulation. 
(2)  In lieu of attendance at a blood borne pathogens training program given by the department within the past three (3) years as specified in subsection (d) above, the applicant may furnish proof of attendance at equivalent training which is acceptable to the department. 
(3)  Temporary certificates expire after seven (7) days or the conclusion of the special event, whichever is less. 
(4)  Temporary operator and/or establishment certificate(s) will not be issued unless the applicant has paid a reasonable fee as set by the department. 
(5)  The temporary establishment/operator certificate(s) shall not be transferable from one (1) place or person to another. 
(6)  The temporary establishment/operator certificates shall be posted in a prominent and conspicuous area where they may be readily observed by the patrons. 
(Ord. No. 57-2004, 7-23-06) 
Sec. 13-123. - Criteria for operating a facility. 
(a)  Each facility manager shall: 
(1)  Require each individual working within the facility premises providing tattooing/body piercing services to have a valid tattoo/body piercing operator or apprentice certification. 
(2)  Be responsible for maintaining a list of certified operators or apprentices employed at the facility for review by the Department upon request. 
(3)  Post the valid establishment, operator(s), or apprentice certificates. 
(4)  Comply with all the requirements of this regulation. 
(5)  Allow the Department representative to inspect the facility when it is open for business. 
(6)  Notify the Department in writing or in person within five (5) calendar days of closure of the facility. If the same owner reopens the facility while the license is still current, the facility operator is to inform the Department prior to resuming business. 
(b)  Tattooing/body piercing services shall not be provided outside of a certified establishment unless a temporary establishment certificate has been obtained pursuant to section 13-122 of this regulation. 
(c)  The facility shall comply with the most current version of the U.S. Department of Labor, Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Occupational Exposure to Blood borne Pathogens Standard, 29 CFR 1910.1030, including OSHA instruction CPL2-2.44C, or later editions. 
(Ord. No. 57-2004, 7-23-06) 
Sec. 13-124. - Facility requirements. 
(a)  Location. All tattoo/body piercing establishments shall be completely separated by solid partitions, or by walls extending from floor to ceiling, from any room used for human habitation, a food establishment or room where food is prepared, a hair salon, retail sales, or other such activity which may cause potential contamination of work surfaces. If such partition or wall contains a door or window, the door shall be self-closing and kept closed and the window shall not be able to be opened. When partitions are authorized to be used to separate areas within the establishment, such partitions shall not extend closer than eighteen (18) inches to the ceiling, and shall permit free circulation of air.
