NO LITTERING OR DUMPING OF GARBAGE 
NO MOTOR VEHICLES OR MOTOR BIKES 
NO DISORDERLY BEHAVIOR 
ALL ANIMALS ARE TO BE STRICTLY CONTROLLED ON LEASH 
Any person who curbs an animal in this park shall immediately remove all feces deposited by such animal. Sanitary methods of removal must be under the Board of Health Guidelines (Ordinance No. 23 Section 4:01). 
ANY PERSON VIOLATING ANY OF THESE RULES SHALL BE PROSECUTED TO THE FULL EXTENT OF THE LAW. 
(b)  Penalties. Any person who violates or fails to comply with any provision of this section shall, upon summary conviction thereof in a summary proceeding before a district justice of the City of Wilkes-Barre, be sentenced to pay a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00), plus costs and/or be imprisoned in the county jail for a period not exceeding ninety (90) days. 
(Ord. No. 15-80, § 2, 5-15-80; Ord. No. 17-88, § 2, 4-14-88; Ord. No. 1-98, § 1, 2-22-98) 
Editor's note- Former § 20-1, which pertained to an agreement for administration of the city recreation program, has been deleted pursuant to Ord. No. 8-80 which repealed Ord. No. 7-60, the ordinance from which former § 20-1 derived. 
Inasmuch as Ord. No. 15-80, enacted May 15, 1980, did not specifically amend this Code, § 2 of said ordinance is included herein as a new § 20-1 at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 20-2. - Concessions at Kirby Park. 
    Leases for concessions at F. M. Kirby Park must be let by competitive bidding, upon such terms and conditions as shall be considered most desirable and advantageous to the city and the public using the park. 
(Ord. No. 794, § 1, 6-21-32) 
Sec. 20-3. - Feeding squirrels and birds prohibited. 
(a)  The feeding of squirrels and birds in public parks, recreation areas, and streets is strictly prohibited. 
(b)  This section is to be enforced by the department of health and the police department. 
(Ord. No. 13-78, §§ 1, 2, 5-25-78) 
Sec. 20-4. - Purchase, consumption, possession or transportation of intoxicating beverages. 
(a)  A person commits an offense if he or she attempts to purchase, purchases, consumes, possesses or transports any alcohol, liquor, or malt or brewed beverage within the confines of the parks, recreation areas or conservation areas within the limits of the City of Wilkes-Barre, with one exception as hereinafter set forth in paragraph (c) of this section. 
(b)  A person commits an offense if he or she openly consumes any alcohol, liquor, or malt or brewed beverages on any public thoroughfare within the limits of the city. 
(c)  When a person or group of persons leases the Ice-A-Rama, upon meeting all four (4) requirements of this paragraph as hereinafter set forth, a person may purchase, possess, transport or consume alcohol, liquor, or malt or brewed beverages solely within the confines of the Ice-A-Rama. The following four (4) requirements must be satisfied before this section becomes operative. 
(1)  Proof of a special occasion permit, as required by the Pennsylvania Liquor Control Board under 47 P.S. section 4-408.4 must be submitted to the city attorney's office. 
(2)  Three (3) copies of proof of liquor and general liability insurance in the amount and under the conditions set by city council must be submitted to the city attorney's office at least ten (10) days prior to the scheduled event and the policies must be reviewed and approved by the city attorney, the Wilkes-Barre City Insurance Committee and the Wilkes-Barre City General Liability carrier. 
Minimum insurance coverage and conditions required for leasing of the Ice-A-Rama dispensing alcoholic beverages are as follows: 
a.  Liquor liability: 
Five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) each occurrence. 
Two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) umbrella coverage. 
b.  General liability: 
Five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) each occurrence. 
Two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) umbrella coverage. 
c.  Insurance companies must have b+ rating or better. 
d.  Policies must be written as combined single limit policies for bodily injury and property damage. 
e.  Policies must name the City of Wilkes-Barre, its employees, agents, servants, and assignees as named insureds. 
f.  The policies should either not have a deductible or, where a deductible is called for, it shall not exceed five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) and the amount of the deductible must be posted with the proper city officials. 
(3)  An indemnity agreement, as drafted by the city attorney's office, must be signed by the person or persons sponsoring the event. 
(4)  When and only when the above three (3) requirements have been satisfied, the person or persons must enter into a lease agreement with the director of recreation, parks, buildings and grounds. 
(Ord. No. 15-80, § 1, 5-15-80; Ord. No. 17-88, § 1, 4-14-88) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 26. 
Sec. 20-5. - Skateboarding on or around Public Square. 
(a)  Terms defined. The following defined terms shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of this section: 
    Designated area shall mean the central business district, bounded by North Street on the north, Ross Street on the South, the Susquehanna River on the West, and Pennsylvania Avenue on the east, their roadways, berms and adjacent sidewalks. 
    Skateboarding is that practice of riding upon a device, usually while standing, consisting of a short, oblong piece of wood, plastic or aluminum mounted on large roller-skate wheels. 
(b)  Skateboarding prohibited. No person shall skateboard within the areas above designated as prohibited. 
(c)  Penalties. Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall, upon summary conviction thereof in a summary proceeding before a district justice of the City of Wilkes-Barre, be sentenced, for a first offense, to pay a fine of not more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and costs and/or to be imprisoned in the county jail for a period not exceeding ninety (90) days. Upon conviction of a second offense, such persons shall be sentenced to pay a fine of not more than fifty dollars ($50.00) and costs and/or to be imprisoned in the county jail for a period not exceeding ninety (90) days. Upon conviction of a third and any subsequent offense, such person shall be sentenced to pay a fine of not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) and costs and/or to be imprisoned in the county jail for a period not exceeding ninety (90) days. Each and every day upon which any person shall violate or continue to violate the provisions of this section shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 59-87, §§ 1-3, 8-11-87; Ord. No. 26-90, § 1, 8-9-90; Ord. No. 10-2009, 7-14-09; Ord. No. 9-2015, 5-28-15) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 26. 
Sec. 20-6. - Glass containers. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to prohibit the use of glass containers in city parks in order to make the parks safer for use by people and animals. 
(b)  Prohibition. It shall be unlawful for any person to possess or transport, or cause to possess or transport, any glass containers within any parks owned by the city. This prohibition shall not apply to Public Square during farmers' market hours and during special events on Public Square authorized by the city. 
(c)  Penalties. Any person who violates or fails to comply with any provision of this section shall, upon summary conviction thereof in a summary proceeding before a district justice of the City of Wilkes-Barre, be sentenced to pay a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00), plus costs, and/or to be imprisoned in the county jail for a period not exceeding ninety (90) days. 
(Ord. No. 14-92, §§ 1-3, 6-18-92) 
Sec. 20-7. - Public square fountain. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to protect the health, safety and welfare of people on Wilkes-Barre's Public Square by prohibiting human contact with water from the public square fountain. 
(b)  Prohibition. It shall be unlawful for any person to bathe or otherwise have any physical contact with the water from the fountain on public square. 
(c)  Penalties. Any person who violates or fails to comply with any provision of this section shall, upon summary conviction thereof in a summary proceeding before a district justice of the City of Wilkes-Barre, be sentenced to pay a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00), plus costs, and/or to be imprisoned in the county jail for a period not exceeding ninety (90) days. 
(Ord. No. 12-2008, 6-12-08) 
Sec. 20-8. - Prohibiting the possession and use of tobacco products by minors in specified locations and prohibiting also the use of tobacco products in all city parks and recreation areas. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any minor under the age of eighteen (18) years to use or possess tobacco or tobacco products, in any form, within the city, on any city-owned property, city park, on any public street, highway, traffic way, alley or sidewalk. 
(b)  (1)  It shall be unlawful for any person of any age to use tobacco or tobacco products in any city park owned or maintained by the city, said parks to be considered and designated as tobacco free areas, which shall include, but shall not be limited to, playground areas. 
(2)  Appropriate signage will be posted designating park as tobacco free areas. 
(3)  Any property owned and/or maintained by the City of Wilkes-Barre which is formally and/or informally designated as a park, now and in the future, shall be governed by this section. 
(c)  A violation of this section shall be a summary offense, and any person who violates same shall, upon conviction, be sentenced to pay a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(d)  Definitions. 
(1)  Park. Any piece(s) or parcel(s) of land which is: (a) owned by the City of Wilkes-Barre; and/or (b) owned by any authority of the City of Wilkes-Barre; and/or (c) maintained by the City of Wilkes-Barre as a park or recreational area; and/or any piece(s) or parcel(s) of land which is/are designated as a "park" or public recreation area by the City of Wilkes-Barre and/or any governmental entity or authority, and where the land is located within the City of Wilkes-Barre. 
(2)  Playground area. Any area owned or maintained by the City of Wilkes-Barre for use by the general public or for public purposes as a playground, which shall include areas with typical and/or standard playground equipment, including, but not limited to, swing sets, sliding boards, and jungle gyms. The said playground area shall include a thirty-foot radius around the said equipment, or to the park boundary line, whichever is closer. 
(3)  Tobacco. A lighted or unlighted cigarette, cigar, pipe, or other lighted smoking product and smokeless tobacco in any form. 
(4)  Tobacco product. 
a.  Any product containing, made or derived from tobacco or nicotine that is intended for human consumption, whether smoked, heated, chewed, absorbed, dissolved, inhaled, snorted, sniffed, or ingested by any other means including, but not limited to, cigarettes, cigars, chewing tobacco, pipe or hookah; 
b.  Any electronic device that delivers nicotine or other substances to the person inhaling from the device including, but not limited to, an electronic cigarette, cigar, pipe or hookah; 
c.  Not withstanding any provision of subsections a. and b. to the contrary, "tobacco product" includes any component, part or accessory of a tobacco product whether or not sold separately. "Tobacco products" does not include any product that has been approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration for sale as a tobacco cessation product or for other therapeutic purposes where such product is marked and sold for such an approved purpose. 
    All other words shall have their ordinary and plain meanings/definitions. 
(Ord. No. 16-2008, §§ 1-4, 7-10-08; Ord. No. 21-2010, §§ 1-4, 10-14-10; Ord. No. 11-2017, 7-13-17) 
Sec. 20-9. - Dog park rules-Hollenback Park. 
    A person commits an offense if he or she violates any of the posted rules and regulations in the Hollenback Dog Park. 
(a)  Signs shall be placed within the Hollenback Dog Park which contain the following rules and regulations: 
USE AT YOUR OWN RISK. Owners are responsible for the actions and behaviors of their dog(s) at all times. 
Dog waste must be picked up IMMEDIATELY by dog owners. Waste bags are available at the entrance of each yard. 
Owners must be within the dog park and supervising their dog(s) at all times with leash readily available. 
Limit four (4) dogs per handler per visit. 
All children under the age of thirteen (13) must be accompanied by an adult. This park is not for toddlers or small children. 
Pet food and treats are allowed inside the dog park. 
Dogs must remain leased at all times when outside the park. 
Remove pinch or choke collars and leash in off leash area. 
Please leash and remove your dog if it is acting aggressively. 
Dogs in heat and puppies under four (4) months of age are not permitted in park. 
All dogs must wear a collar with a current rabies tag, license and identification. All dogs must be vaccinated. 
Don't bring a dog with contagious conditions or illness to the park. 
Owners/Handlers are responsible for damages or injury inflicted by your dog(s). 
Do not let your dog dig holes or damage park plants or property. 
Smoking is prohibited. 
No glass containers. 
Park open sunrise to sunset. 
(b)  Penalties. Any person who violates or fails to comply with any provision of this section shall, upon summary conviction thereof in a summary proceeding before a district justice of the City of Wilkes-Barre, be sentenced to pay a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00), plus costs and/or be imprisoned in the county jail for a period not exceeding ninety (90) days. 
(Ord. No. 12-2010, 5-6-10) 
Secs. 20-10-20-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RECREATION BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 8-80, enacted Mar,. 27, 1980, repealed Ord. Nos. 7-60 and 14-68, from which former Art. II, "Recreation Board," derived. 
Inasmuch as Ord. No. 9-80, also enacted on Mar. 27, 1980, did not specifically amend this Code, §§ 1-6 of said ordinance are included herein as a new Art. II at the editor's discretion. 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 

Sec. 20-16. - Established. 
    There is hereby established and created by the City of Wilkes-Barre, a recreation board to be known as the "Recreation Board of the City of Wilkes-Barre." 
(Ord. No. 9-80, § 1, 3-27-80) 
Sec. 20-17. - Authority; duties and personnel generally. 
    The recreation board is hereby vested with the authority to equip, operate, maintain and supervise recreation places as the same may be established from time to time by the city. The recreation board may make recommendations to the mayor concerning the employment of all personnel needed to equip, operate, maintain and supervise recreation programs and places. The mayor shall appoint an executive director and all personnel aforesaid in accordance with the power vested in the mayor by Article 5, Section 5.07, Subsections 6 and 7 of the Charter of the City of Wilkes-Barre and Article 4, Section 4.02, Subsections 6 and 7 of the Administrative Code of the City of Wilkes-Barre. The number of permanent employees aforesaid and their maximum rate of compensation shall be fixed by the salary ordinance as adopted by the city council each year in accordance with Article 8, Section 8.04, Subsection 1 of the Administrative Code. All personnel aforesaid shall be employees of the city. 
(Ord. No. 9-80, § 2, 3-27-80) 
Sec. 20-18. - Composition; appointments; terms; compensation; vacancies. 
    The recreation board of the City of Wilkes-Barre shall consist of eleven (11) persons, all residents of the City of Wilkes-Barre. The members of the board shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of city council and shall serve for terms commensurate with the term of the mayor, or until their successors are appointed. Members of the board shall serve without pay. Vacancies on the board occurring other than by expiration of a term shall be filled in the same manner as original appointments for the period of time remaining in the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 9-80, § 3, 3-27-80) 
Sec. 20-19. - Officers; rules and regulations. 
    The members of the recreation board shall elect their own chairman and secretary and shall select all other necessary officers to serve for a period of one (1) year. The board shall have the power to adopt rules and regulations for the conduct of all business within its jurisdiction, subject to written approval by the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 9-80, § 4, 3-27-80) 
Sec. 20-20. - Appropriations recommendations; fiscal authority limited. 
    The recreation board shall recommend from time to time to the mayor and the city council the amounts deemed advisable to be appropriated for the equipment, operation, maintenance and supervision of playgrounds, playfields and other recreation centers. The board shall have no power or authority to enter into any contracts, engagements or create any indebtedness for or on behalf of the city. 
(Ord. No. 9-80, § 5, 3-27-80) 
Sec. 20-21. - Annual reports to council. 
    The recreation board shall annually report in writing to the mayor and the city council on the status of its endeavors. 
(Ord. No. 9-80, § 6, 3-27-80) 
Secs. 20-22-20-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - F. M. KIRBY PARK BOARD[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 

Sec. 20-36. - Created. 
    There is hereby created and established a board to be styled and known as the F. M. Kirby Park board of the city. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 1, 3-8-21) 
Sec. 20-37. - Composition. 
    The Kirby Park board shall consist of three (3) members, each of the original members of the board shall be nominated by F. M. Kirby, by presenting their names to the city council and such persons so nominated shall be elected as members of the board by being confirmed by the city council by receiving a majority vote of the members of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 2, 3-8-21) 
Sec. 20-38. - Terms of members. 
    The term of the person whose name is suggested first by Mr. Kirby shall be for five (5) years. The term of the person whose name is suggested second by Mr. Kirby shall be for four (4) years. The term of the person whose name is suggested third by Mr. Kirby shall be for three (3) years. Their term of office shall commence from the date of the confirmation of their appointment by the city council. The term of any member elected or nominated after the expiration of the terms of the original members thereof, shall be for a term of five (5) years. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 3, 3-8-21) 
Sec. 20-39. - Compensation. 
    The members of the Kirby Park board shall serve without compensation of any character. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 2, 3-8-21) 
Sec. 20-40. - Vacancies. 
    Vacancies on the Kirby Park board, however caused, shall be filled for the unexpired term of the member or members by election by the surviving members, unless within thirty (30) days after a vacancy occurs, Mr. Kirby shall, in writing, present to the board the name of a person chosen by him to fill the unexpired term, in which case the names presented by Mr. Kirby, or the names of those persons nominated by the surviving members, shall be confirmed by a majority vote of the city council, and upon the expiration of the term of any member of the board, his successor shall be nominated and elected in the manner above prescribed. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 3, 3-8-21) 
Sec. 20-41. - Officers. 
    Within ten (10) days after the confirmation by the city council of the nominations by Mr. Kirby for the Kirby Park board and every three (3) years thereafter, so long as shall be necessary, the board shall organize, by electing from among its members a president who shall preside at all meetings of the board, at which he is present, and a vice president, who shall, in the absence of the president, preside at all meetings of the board. The Miners Bank of Wilkes-Barre shall be the treasurer of the board, and that all money donated to the development or improvement of Kirby Park shall be deposited with the treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 4, 3-8-21) 
Sec. 20-42. - Employees, finances. 
    The Kirby Park board may employ a secretary, who shall not be one of its members. The board shall have power to make and enter into such contracts as shall, in the opinion of the board, from time to time become necessary or advisable for the design, laying out, construction, development and improvement of Kirby Park, for park and playground purposes. Such contracts shall be executed on the part of the board by the president of the board, attested by the secretary. The board shall have power to appoint or employ such engineers, architects, landscape gardeners, gardeners, superintendents, artisans, foremen, laborers and other advisers and employees as it shall from time to time deem necessary; and shall prescribe and define their respective duties and authority and shall fix and regulate the compensation and wages to be paid to the several persons so employed. All costs and expenses incurred in the proper discharge of the powers and duties hereby imposed upon the board shall be paid out of moneys donated toward developing and improv ing the park, by warrants, drawn by the president or vice president of the board, duly attested by the secretary thereof. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 5, 3-8-21) 
Sec. 20-43. - Meetings, reports. 
    The Kirby Park board shall hold regular meetings, keep full and complete minutes and records thereof, and shall make and enforce all necessary rules and regulations which may be necessary for the proper fulfillment of the duties imposed upon the board. The board shall report in writing to the city council on the first Tuesday of January and July, and shall, on the first Tuesday of January of each year, make a detailed report to the city council of all work done during the preceding year. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 6, 3-8-21) 
Sec. 20-44. - Delegation of powers. 
    The Kirby Park board is hereby delegated the obligation and duty hitherto incumbent on the city government of designing, laying out, constructing, developing and improving certain lands known as the F. M. Kirby Park; and in addition thereto there shall be and hereby is delegated to the said board all those powers hitherto residing in the city government which may be necessary to accomplish this designing, laying out, constructing, developing and improving the park to the end that it may be highly useful and beautiful; the board to remain in existence, with all the powers hereby granted, until such time as the fund of money given by F. M. Kirby, together with the interest thereon, for the development of such park, shall have been entirely expended. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 1, 3-8-21) 
Sec. 20-45. - Exclusive control of park. 
    The Kirby Park board shall have general, detailed and exclusive control over all work of developing and improving Kirby Park, and shall make and award all contracts covering any or all of such work. They may seek the opinion and advice, from time to time, of the planning commission and city engineer, relative to such work of the development of the park, or that of any other person whom they consider may be helpful to the successful creation of a highly useful and beautiful park. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 7, 3-8-21) 
Sec. 20-46. - Contracts for improvement and development. 
    All work, whenever advisable, in the improvement and development of Kirby Park, may be performed under contract to be awarded by the Kirby Park board. The specifications for all work shall be prepared under the direction of, and shall be approved by the board before bids for any work shall be asked for by the board. 
(Ord. No. 385, § 8, 3-8-21)

Chapter 21 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Food and food handlers, Ch. 11; unlawful noise from promoting sale of merchandise, § 17-5; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 26. 
State Law reference- Peddlers, 60 P.S. § 1 et seq.; magazine solicitation, 73 P.S. § 2011 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 21-1. - Definition. 
    The word "peddler" as used in this chapter shall mean any person, whether a resident of this city or not, traveling from house to house, or from street to street, for the purpose of selling or soliciting for sale, goods, wares, merchandise or services; and shall also mean and include any person transacting a temporary business within the city at an established place of business. The word "peddler" shall include the terms "solicitor," "transient or itinerant merchant or vendor," or "transient or itinerant photographer." 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 21-2. - Exceptions to chapter. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to solicitations, sales or distributions made by charitable, educational or religious organizations which have their principal place of activity in the city except as provided in article III of this chapter. 
Sec. 21-3. - Refusing to leave. 
    Any peddler who enters upon premises owned, leased or rented by another and refuses to leave such premises after having been notified by the owner or occupant of such premises, or his agent, to leave the same and not return to such premises, shall be deemed guilty of a summary offense. 
Sec. 21-4. - Entrance to premises restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any peddler to enter upon any private premises when the same are posted with a sign stating "No Peddlers Allowed" or "No Solicitations Allowed" or other words to such effect. 
Cross reference- Similar provisions for persons distributing handbills, § 3-19. 
Sec. 21-5. - Misrepresentation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any peddler to make false or fraudulent statements concerning the quality or nature of his goods, wares, merchandise or services for the purpose of inducing another to purchase the same. 
Sec. 21-6. - Hours of operation. 
    It shall be unlawful for any peddler to engage in the business of peddling within the city between the hours of one-half hour before sunset and 8:00 a.m. the following morning, or at any time on Sundays, except by specific appointment with or invitation from the prospective customer. 
Sec. 21-7. - Fixed location in public places prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any peddler to have a fixed location on any street or other public place of the city. Such peddler shall be required to keep moving at all times while transacting business on the streets and other public places of the city. 
(Ord. No. 9-10, § 1, 11-22-10) 
Secs. 21-8-21-18. - Reserved.

ARTICLE III. - CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Solicitation of Charitable Funds Act, 10 P.S. § 

Sec. 21-44. - Permit. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit or collect for charitable or other purposes on the public streets or among the business or residential people of the city, without first having obtained a permit from the mayor or the mayor's clerk so to do, and an endorsement that the collection is for a proper charitable or other cause. 
(Ord. No. 22-12, § 1, 4-22-13);

ARTICLE IV. - STREET VENDORS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Article IV, §§ 21-60-21-64, is derived from Ord. No. 39-82, §§ 1-5, adopted March 24, 1983. Since this ordinance did not provide for a specific manner of inclusion of its provisions into the Code, it has been codified as Art. IV at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 21-60. - Definitions. 
    In this article, the following definitions shall apply: 
(a)  Street vendor shall mean any person traveling by foot, wagon, motor vehicle or any other type of conveyance from place to place, house to house, or street to street carrying, conveying or transporting goods, wares or merchandise and offering and exposing them for sale, or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers; or who, without traveling from place to place, sells or offers for sale such products from a wagon, handcart, pushcart, motor vehicle, conveyance or from his person or who solicits orders and, as a separate transaction, makes deliveries to purchasers. 
(b)  Goods, wares, merchandise shall include, but not be limited to, fruits, vegetables, farm products, fish, game, poultry, meat, plants, flowers, appliances, wearing apparel, jewelry, cosmetics and beauty aids, health products, medicines, household needs or furnishings, goods of any kind, whether or not for immediate consumption, confections or drinks or any other article or thing whatsoever. 
(c)  Conveyance shall include any public or privately owned vehicle, method or means of transporting people, bicycle, motorized or nonmotorized vehicle, handcart, pushcart, lunch wagon or any other device or thing whether or not mounted on wheels. 
(d)  Street shall mean all that area legally open to public use as public streets, and sidewalks, roadways, highways, parkways, alleys and any other public way, including Public Square. 
(Ord. No. 39-82, § 1, 3-24-83) 
Sec. 21-61. - Prohibited conduct. 
    No street vendor shall: 
(a)  Stop, stand or park any vehicle, wagon, pushcart, or any other conveyance upon any street, except the area of Public Square bounded entirely by the vehicular right-of-way, for the purpose of selling goods, wares and merchandise in accordance with the terms of this article; 
(b)  Stop, stand or park any vehicle, wagon, pushcart, or any other conveyance upon any street for the purpose of selling goods, wares and merchandise on Farmer's Market days and special event days as established by the Wilkes-Barre Recreation Board unless otherwise authorized to do so by the executive director of the Wilkes-Barre Recreation Board; 
(c)  Stop, stand or park any vehicle, wagon, pushcart or any other conveyance upon any street for the purpose of selling, or sell on any street under any circumstances during the hours when parking, stopping or standing has been prohibited by signs or curb markings or is prohibited by the Pennsylvania Motor Vehicle Code, or city ordinance; 
(d)  Stop, stand or park his vehicle or conveyance on a street nor permit it to remain there except on the sidewalks at the curb for the purpose of selling goods, wares and merchandise therefrom; 
(e)  Stop, stand, park, place nor allow his conveyance closer than thirty (30) feet from any other conveyance being used by any other vendor; 
(f)  Conduct himself or his business in such a way as to create or become a nuisance, or increase traffic congestion or delay, or constitute a hazard to traffic, life or property, or an obstruction to adequate access to fire, police or sanitation vehicles; 
(g)  Sell food, drinks, ice cream or confections of any kind for immediate consumption unless he has available for public use his own litter receptacle, which shall be clearly marked and maintained for his patrons' use nor shall any vendor leave any location without first picking up, removing and disposing of all trash or refuse remaining from sales made by him; 
(h)  Use a handcart or pushcart the dimensions of which exceed four (4) feet in width, eight (8) feet in length, and eight (8) feet in height; 
(i)  Use any conveyance, device or thing whatsoever which, when fully loaded with merchandise, cannot be easily moved and maintained under control by the licensee, his employee or attendant; 
(j)  Set up, maintain or permit the use of any tables, crates, cartons, racks, devices or thing of any kind or description to increase the selling or display capacity of his conveyance, cart or vehicle; 
(k)  Leave any conveyance unattended at any time or store, park or leave same overnight on any city sidewalk, nor park, store or leave any vehicle other than in a lawful parking place; 
(l)  Engage in the business of vending between 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m.; 
(m)  Use a conveyance which is propelled by an internal combustion engine; 
(n)  Engage in the business of vending at any location where the curb has been depressed to facilitate pedestrian or vehicular movement; 
(o)  Be permitted to have more than one licensed stand on any street where vending is permitted. 
(Ord. No. 39-82, § 2, 3-24-83) 
Sec. 21-62. - Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to those street vendors who operate their conveyance outside of the retail business district of the city bounded on the north by Union Street, on the east by Pennsylvania Avenue, on the south by Northampton Street and on the west by the Susquehanna River Common. 
(Ord. No. 39-82, § 3, 3-24-83) 
Sec. 21-63. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall, upon summary conviction therein in a summary proceeding before a district justice of the City of Wilkes-Barre, be sentenced to pay a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00), and costs. In default of the payment of such fine and costs, such person shall be imprisoned in the county jail for a period not exceeding ninety (90) days. Each and every day upon which any person violates or continues to violate the provisions of this article, shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 39-82, § 4, 3-24-83) 
Sec. 21-64. - Construction. 
    No part of this article or the article itself shall be construed to be in amplification or derogation of the rights or responsibilities of abutting property owners. Any remedy, rights or obligations provided to such owners of property or their successors in interest under the law of real property or the laws of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania shall be in addition to the remedies, rights, obligations or penalties provided hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 39-82, § 5, 3-24-83) 
Chapter 22 - PLANNING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Planning, Art. VII. 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; director of planning, Char. App. A § 2-73; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 7; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 26; utilities, Ch. 30; zoning ordinance, App. A. 
State Law reference- Pennsylvania Municipalities Planning Code, 53 P.S. § 10101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Developers of city-owned real estate-Declaration of default. 
    In cases wherein a designated developer shall fail to comply with any time constraint or restriction imposed in the legal document designating his status as developer, the city attorney is hereby authorized, empowered and directed to declare a default and initiate such legal proceedings as may be necessary to reclaim the property; provided, however, that prior to such declaration of default, the city attorney shall give to the mayor and city council, in writing, at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to the next regularly scheduled meeting of the city council, notice of his intention to so proceed. 
(Ord. No. 79-87, § 1, 10-22-87) 
Editor's note- Having not specifically amended the Code, the provisions of § 1 of Ord. No. 79-87, adopted Oct. 22, 1987, have been codified as a new § 22-1 at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 22-2-22-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLANNING COMMISSION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Authority and similar provisions, 53 P.S. § 10201 et seq. 

Sec. 22-16. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created the city planning commission. 
Sec. 22-17. - Composition, appointment. 
    The city planning commission be and the same shall consist of nine (9) members, at least six (6) of whom shall be citizen members, to be appointed by the mayor, with the approval of city council. 
(Ord. No. 924, § 1, 6-5-36; Ord. No. 18-69, § 1, 7-15-69) 
Sec. 22-18. - Residency. 
    All of the members of the planning commission shall reside within the territorial limits of which the city planning commission shall have jurisdiction, viz.: Within the city limits or for a distance of three (3) miles outside thereof, except where the city planning commission of another municipality shall have jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 924, § 3, 6-5-36) 
Sec. 22-19. - Terms of members. 
    The term of each of the members of the planning commission shall be for four (4) years, or until a successor is appointed and qualified, except that the terms of the members first appointed pursuant to this article shall be so fixed that no more than three (3) shall be so reappointed or replaced. 
(Ord. No. 924, § 4, 6-5-36; Ord. No. 15-69, § 2, 7-15-69) 
Sec. 22-20. - Compensation. 
    The members of the planning commission are to serve in their respective capacities and perform the duties of their office without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 924, § 2, 6-5-36) 
Sec. 22-21. - Vacancies. 
    The chairman of the planning commission shall promptly notify the mayor concerning vacancies in the planning commission and such vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 924, § 4, 6-5-36; Ord. No. 15-69, § 2, 7-15-69) 
Sec. 22-22. - Removal. 
    Any member of a planning commission once qualified and appointed may be removed from office for malfeasance, misfeasance or nonfeasance in office or for other just cause by a majority vote of the city council, taken after the member has received fifteen (15) days' advance notice of the intent to take such a vote. A hearing shall be held in connection with the vote if the member shall request it in writing. Any appointment to fill a vacancy created by removal shall be only for the unexpired term. 
Sec. 22-23. - Conduct of business. 
    The planning commission shall elect its own chairman and vice-chairman and create and fill such other offices as it may determine. Officers shall serve annual terms and may succeed themselves. The commission may make and alter by laws and rules and regulations to govern its procedures consistent with the ordinances of the city and the laws of the commonwealth. The commission shall keep a full record of its business and shall annually make a written report by March 1 of each year of its activities to the city council. Interim reports may be made as often as may be necessary, or as requested by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 924, § 6, 6-5-36) 
Sec. 22-24. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The planning commission shall at the request of the city council have the power and shall be required to: 
(1)  Prepare the comprehensive plan for the development of the city as set forth in the Pennsylvania Municipalities Planning Code, and present it for the consideration of the city council; 
(2)  Maintain and keep on file records of its action. All records and files of the planning commission shall be in the possession of the city council. 
(b)  The planning commission at the request of the city council may: 
(1)  Make recommendations to the city council concerning the adoption or amendment of an official map; 
(2)  Prepare and present to the city council a zoning ordinance, and make recommendations to the city council on proposed amendments to it as set forth in the Pennsylvania Municipalities Planning Code; 
(3)  Prepare, recommend and administer subdivision and land development, planned residential development regulations, as set forth in the Pennsylvania Municipalities Planning Code; 
(4)  Prepare and present to the city council a building code and a housing code and make recommendations concerning proposed amendments thereto; 
(5)  Do such other act or make such studies as may be necessary to fulfill the duties and obligations imposed by the Pennsylvania Municipalities Planning Code; 
(6)  Prepare and present to the city council an environmental study; 
(7)  Submit to the mayor a recommended capital improvements program; 
(8)  Promote public interest in, and understanding of, the comprehensive plan and planning; 
(9)  Make recommendations to governmental, civic and private agencies and individuals as to the effectiveness of the proposals of such agencies and individuals; 
(10)  Hold public hearings and meetings; 
(11)  Require from other departments and agencies of the city such available information as relates to the work of the planning commission; 
(12)  In the performance of its functions, enter upon any land to make examinations and surveys with the consent of the owner. 
(c)  In the performance of its powers and duties, any act or recommendation of the planning commission which involves engineering consideration, shall be subject to review and comments of the engineer, which shall be incorporated and separately set forth in any report, written act or recommendation of the planning commission. 
(Ord. No. 924, § 5, 6-5-36) 
Sec. 22-25. - Administrative and technical assistance. 
    The mayor may employ administrative and technical services to aid in carrying out the provisions of the Pennsylvania Municipalities Planning Code either as consultants on particular matters or as regular employees of the city. 
Sec. 22-26. - Assistance. 
    The planning commission may, with the consent of the city council, accept and utilize any funds, personnel or other assistance made available by the county, the commonwealth or the federal government or any of their agencies, or from private source. The city council may enter into agreements or contracts regarding the acceptance or utilization of the funds or assistance in accordance with the governmental procedures of the city. 
Secs. 22-27-22-37. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CITIZENS ADVISORY COMMITTEE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2. 

Sec. 22-38. - Created. 
    The city council hereby creates the citizens advisory committee of the city. 
(Ord. No. 11-73, § 1, 2-21-73) 
Sec. 22-39. - Composition. 
    The citizens advisory committee, sixteen (16) in number, is structured to represent the neighborhood planning districts of the city's comprehensive plan (Riverside Park, South Wilkes-Barre, Goose Island, Mayflower-Rolling Mill Hill, Iron Triangle, G.A.R., Heights, Central Business District, North End, East End, Brookside, Miners Mills and Parsons) and elements (such as; public, finance, health, education, welfare and labor) of the city. 
(Ord. No. 11-73, § 2, 2-21-73; Ord. No. 29-74, § 1, 12-19-74; Ord. No. 12-76, § 1; Ord. No. 6-77, § 2, 3-10-77) 
Sec. 22-40. - Selection. 
    The membership or selection of the citizens advisory committee will rest with the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 11-73, § 1, 2-21-73; Ord. No. 6-77, § 4, 3-10-77) 
Sec. 22-41. - Role. 
    The role of the citizens advisory committee will be to hear and advise the mayor and city council on the development of plans which pertain to the proper physical growth and character of the city and other missions which may be assigned from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 11-73, § 3, 2-21-73; Ord. No. 15-74, § 1, 11-7-74; Ord. No. 6-77, § 3, 3-10-77) 
Secs. 22-42-22-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - VACANT PROPERTY REVIEW COMMITTEE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 16-80, enacted June 12, 1980, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, codification of the substantive provisions of said ordinance as Art. IV, §§ 22-51-22-55, is at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Distribution of handbills on vacant premises, § 3-21; litter on vacant lots, § 12-45. 

Sec. 22-51. - Created. 
    There is hereby created, in and for the City of Wilkes-Barre, a vacant property review committee. 
(Ord. No. 16-80, 6-12-80) 
Sec. 22-52. - Composition. 
    The vacant property review committee shall consist of seven (7) members who shall be residents of the city. Said committee shall be comprised of one (1) member of the city council; one (1) representative of the board of directors of the Wilkes-Barre Redevelopment Authority; one (1) representative of the Wilkes-Barre Planning Commission; one (1) representative to be designated by the mayor from the executive branch of the City of Wilkes-Barre; and three (3) representatives of the general population of the City of Wilkes-Barre, reflecting one (1) each from the handicapped community, the minority community, and the female population. 
(Ord. No. 16-80, § 1, 6-12-80) 
Sec. 22-53. - Appointment of members; terms; compensation; vacancies. 
    The members of the vacant property review committee shall be appointed by the mayor of the city with the advice and consent of Wilkes-Barre City Council. Members shall serve for terms commensurate with the term of the mayor, or until their successors are appointed. Members of the committee shall serve without pay. Vacancies on the committee occurring other than by expiration of a term shall be filled in the same manner as original appointments for the period of time remaining in the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 16-80, § 2, 6-12-80) 
Sec. 22-54. - Chairman. 
    The members of the vacant property review committee shall annually elect a chairman from their own membership, whose term of office shall be for one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 16-80, § 3, 6-12-80) 
Sec. 22-55. - Authority; duties; quorum. 
    The committee shall have the power to adopt its own rules of procedure and shall promulgate regulations for the administration of the urban homesteading program. Four (4) members shall constitute a quorum. 
(Ord. No. 16-80, § 4, 6-12-80) 
Chapter 23 - POLICE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; police pension fund association, § 2-221 et seq.; bureau of policemen's relief, § 2-246 et seq.; duties with respect to animals, § 5-2; emergency alarm systems, Ch. 9; offenses, miscellaneous provisions, Ch. 19; interference with police emergency reporting systems, § 19-16 et seq.; conduit for police and fire alarm wires installed by person installing other conduit, § 26-10. 

Sec. 23-1. - Fee schedule; exemption. 
(a)  The fee schedule for police department records and other services is as follows: 
Accident reports $15.00 Non-reportable accident reports $25.00 Employee police records search $15.00 Event reports $25.00 Case reports $25.00 Fingerprinting $25.00 Non-arrest photographing $15.00  
    All money shall be payable to the "City of Wilkes-Barre." 
(b)  The fees provided in this section will be waived by the police department when the applicant is a party to a reciprocity agreement. 
(Ord. No. 17-61, §§ 1, 2, 9-6-61; Ord. No. 10-78, § 1, 4-27-78; Ord. No. 23-96, § 1, 10-10-96; Ord. No. 19-2014, 11-20-14) 
Sec. 23-2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6-2015, adopted April 9, 2015, repealed § 23-2, which pertained to gun permit fee and derived from Ord. No. 9-78, adopted April 27, 1978. 
Sec. 23-3. - Arrest without warrant in certain summary cases. 
(a)  Arrest without warrant. The City of Wilkes-Barre does hereby authorize its municipal police officers to arrest without warrant under the provisions of 42 Pa.C.S.A. 8902 as established by the legislature of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania as follows: 
(1)  General rule. For any of the following offenses, a police officer shall, upon view, have the right of arrest without warrant upon probable cause when there is ongoing conduct that imperils the personal security of any person or endangers public or private property: 
a.  Under Title 18 (relating to crimes and offenses) when such offense constitutes a summary offense: 
18 Pa.C.S. Section 5503 (relating to disorderly conduct); 
18 Pa.C.S. Section 5505 (relating to public drunkenness); 
18 Pa.C.S. Section 5507 (relating to obstructing highways and other public passages); 
18 Pa.C.S. Section 6308 (relating to purchase, consumption, possession or transportation of liquor or malt or brewed beverages); or 
b.  Violation of an ordinance of a city of the second class. 
(2)  Guidelines by governmental body. The right of arrest without warrant under this section shall be permitted only after the governmental body employing the police officer promulgates guidelines to be followed by a police officer when making a warrantless arrest under this section. 
(b)  Guidelines. In accordance with 42 Pa.C.S.A. 8902 (b), the City of Wilkes-Barre does hereby empower and direct the chief of police of the City of Wilkes-Barre to promulgate guidelines to be followed by police officers of the City of Wilkes-Barre when making a warrantless arrest under this empowering statute. These guidelines are to be established and maintained by general order of the chief of police and may be modified from time to time by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 63-98, §§ 1, 2, 10-22-98) 
Chapter 24 - PUBLIC LODGING HOUSES 

Sec. 24-1. - Guest register required. 
    Every public lodging house within the limits of the city shall keep a register in which shall be entered the name and address of each and every lodger, together with the time of his arrival and departure; and such register shall at all times, be open to the inspection of the police authorities of the city. 
(Ord. No. 522, § 1, 3-4-24) 
Chapter 25 - SECONDHAND GOODS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Auctions and auctioneers, Ch. 6; zoning requirements for junk, storage and sales, App. A, § 1550. 
State Law reference- Junk shops and secondhand stores, 53 P.S. § 4431 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 25-1-25-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SECONDHAND GOODS DEALERS/PAWNBROKERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 29-2010, § I, adopted Nov. 23, 2010, amended the former Art. II, §§ 25-16-25-20, and enacted a new Art. II as set out herein. The former Art. II pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 3-04, §§ 3-7, adopted July 12, 2004. 
State Law reference- Pawnbrokers License Act, 63 P.S. § 281-1 et seq. 

Sec. 25-16. - License required. 
    No person shall use, exercise or carry on the business, trade or occupation of buying or selling scrap gold, old gold, silver, jewelry, home electronics/audio and visual equipment, including musical instruments, telephones and telephonic equipment, scales, computers, computer hardware and software, typewriters, word processors, scanners, sporting goods of all kinds, antiques, silver, platinum, all other precious metals, tools of all kinds, televisions, VCR, DVR, camcorders, car stereos, firearms, or other valuable articles, hereinafter referred to as "secondhand goods or articles," or being a secondhand dealer within the City of Wilkes-Barre without having first obtained a license from the City of Wilkes-Barre Licensing Clerk as hereinafter provided. A secondhand dealer is defined as a person, association, corporation or partnership, or other entity, who, wholly or in part, engages in or operates the trade or business of buying or acquiring any article mentioned above, or other valuable articles, except from a regularly established wholesale dealer. 
(Ord. No. 29-2010, § I, 11-23-10) 
Sec. 25-17. - Application fee. 
    The City of Wilkes-Barre shall, from time to time, give and grant licenses to all proper persons, except persons convicted of receiving stolen goods, theft or burglary, who may apply for the same to use, exercise and carry on the trade or business or occupation of buying secondhand goods or articles, or being a secondhand dealer and/or pawnbroker, which said license shall state where said business is to be carried on and shall continue in force for one (1) year (unless sooner suspended or revoked) and no longer; each person applying for such license, if his/her application be approved in writing by the appropriate city official shall pay to said official a annual license fee of four hundred dollars ($400.00), and receive from the said official a license to carry out the said business. The license so granted shall only be valid for one (1) place of business. 
(Ord. No. 29-2010, § I, 11-23-10) 
Sec. 25-18. - Business on licensed premises only. 
    No person licensed as a secondhand dealer and/or pawnbroker in the city shall, by virtue of one (1) license, keep more than one (1) place of business for receiving or taking goods in pawn; nor shall he, at any time, take goods in pawn at any other place than the place for which the license was issued. 
(Ord. No. 29-2010, § I, 11-23-10) 
Sec. 25-19. - Rules and regulations. 
    All licensees shall conduct their business in conformity with the following procedures: 
(1)  Each and every person licensed shall carry said license on their person/business for inspection by any law enforcement officer or other city inspector. The licensee shall also keep a log in which shall be legibly written in the English language the name of the person, his/her address, date of birth, a valid drivers' license, valid state identification card, valid passport or a valid military identification. The licensee shall have a description of the article purchased (which will include any serial numbers and/or service tag number), the date and time purchased, the amount of money paid therefore and the signature of the seller. The log shall be available for review by any law enforcement officer and/or city inspector. 
(2)  All licensees shall fill out at the time of transaction; the forms furnished by the Luzerne County District Attorney's Office, such forms will be entered into the Luzerne County Precious Metals Database (http://nepapmdb.com) within forty-eight (48) hours of the time of purchase. 
(3)  All goods purchased by licensees under this chapter must be retained in the possession of the licensee for thirty (30) days. 
(4)  No licensee shall purchase such secondhand goods or articles or other article of value from any person under eighteen (18) years of age, or from any intoxicated person or any person known to be a thief or associate of thieves, or receiver of stolen property, or any person whom the licensee has reason to suspect or believes to be such. 
(5)  The chief of police and/or licensing clerk are hereby authorized to make any other rules and regulations necessary, in their opinion, for the proper conduct of the person or business licensed and must report such rules to the mayor and city council, after review and approval of the city solicitor. 
(Ord. No. 29-2010, § I, 11-23-10) 
Sec. 25-20. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  Any licensee failing, neglecting or refusing to comply with any of the above provisions of this chapter shall, upon summary conviction thereof in a summary proceeding before a district justice of Luzerne County, be fined a sum of not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) for the first offense, plus costs, and shall have his/her license suspended for a period of ten (10) days. This suspension shall be mandatory. In default of payment of such fines and costs, such person shall be imprisoned for a period not exceeding ninety (90) days. 
(b)  Every day that a violation continues shall be a separate violation. Each violation shall result in an additional ten-day suspension. A person or entity that violates the provisions of this chapter four (4) times in a three hundred sixty-five-day period shall have his/her license revoked for one (1) year. 
(Ord. No. 29-2010, § I, 11-23-10) 
Chapter 26 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance naming, renaming, opening, accepting or vacating streets or alleys saved from repeal, § 1-5(7); any ordinance establishing street lines saved from repeal, § 1-5(14); any ordinance relating to street paving lien procedures saved from repeal, § 1-5(16); regulation of handbills in public places, § 3-21; animals running at large, § 5-3; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 7; cemetery, Ch. 8; litter in public places, § 12-34; mobile homes and trailers, Ch. 16; loitering, § 19-101 et seq.; parks and recreation, Ch. 20; peddlers and solicitors, Ch. 21; planning, Ch. 22; subdivisions, Ch. 27; streets in floodplains, § 27-31; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 29; utilities, Ch. 30; zoning ordinance, App. A. 
State Law reference- Streets generally, 53 P.S. § 37915 et seq.; sidewalks generally, 53 P.S. § 38001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - House numbering system. 
    The present system of house numbering, known as the "New York Continuous System," on file in the office of the city engineer, shall be adopted, confirmed and ratified, and all owners of houses within the city be required to number their houses in conformity therewith. 
(Ord. of 3-28-03, §§ 1, 2) 
Sec. 26-2. - Temporary placement of goods for loading and unloading. 
    It shall be lawful for any owner or occupant of property to place temporarily upon the pavement or sidewalk in front of his premises goods, boxes, barrels or casks, for purpose of opening, loading or unloading the same; provided, that an unobstructed passage way shall at all times be kept open and that such occupation shall not continue at any one time for a longer period than two (2) consecutive hours. 
(Ord. of 3-25-1878, § 17) 
Sec. 26-3. - Temporary sidewalks during construction. 
    Whenever any sidewalk is temporarily removed by reason of the erection of a building upon the abutting premises, the owner of such premises shall be required to construct, lay and maintain in good condition, until such time as the sidewalk is relaid, a temporary sidewalk, made of wood or other material, such walk to be at least five (5) feet in width. 
(Ord. No. 15-07, § 1, 3-10-08) 
Cross reference- Building regulations, § 7-16 et seq. 
Sec. 26-4. - Cellar doors in sidewalks. 
(a)  It shall be lawful to place and maintain cellar doors in the sidewalks along the public streets of the city in accordance with the following regulations: 
(1)  All doors must be built of wrought iron or steel, must not be less than one-half of an inch in thickness and the surface thereof must be corrugated. No sheet iron doors will be allowed. 
(2)  The surface of all doors and door frames shall in all cases be level with the sidewalk, wherein such door is laid and the hinges of the doors must be on the under side thereof. 
(3)  The sizes of the doors to be placed in the sidewalks shall in no case exceed four (4) feet in length by four (4) feet in width; except on north and south main streets where the size of the doors shall not exceed five (5) feet in length by five (5) feet in width. 
(b)  All permits for the placing of doors in the sidewalks shall be granted by resolution of the council, and any permit shall be granted therefor, the person to whom the permit shall be granted, shall before placing the doors in the walk, file with the city clerk a bond in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) with one or more sureties to be approved by the city attorney, to save the city harmless from any or all damages or injuries which may occur at any time after the placing of the doors in the walk. 
(c)  The director of public works shall notify all of the owners of property who have cellar doors in the sidewalks in front of their properties which do not conform to the provisions of this section, to remove the same within ninety (90) days from service of notice upon them so to do, and to replace the same with doors as called for in this section; otherwise the director shall remove the doors and replace the same with doors as hereinbefore specified, at the cost and expense of the property owner; and if the property owner refuses to pay for removing and replacing the same, to return the cost thereof to the city attorney for collection in accordance with law. 
(Ord. No. 4-06, § 3, 12-11-06) 
Sec. 26-5. - Fence gates abutting streets shall swing inward. 
    All gates in all fences located in front of properties along the public streets throughout the city, shall be so constructed that such gates will swing inward toward the property and not outward toward the street, and that in the rebuilding or repairing of any of such fences where the gates now swing outward toward the street, they shall be changed so as to swing inward toward the property. 
(Ord. No. 454, § 1, 11-21-22) 
Sec. 26-6. - Street painting. 
(a)  No person shall begin to paint any paved street or driveway on a public paved street without first obtaining a permit from the office of the director of the department of public works. The application shall be required for each and every time a request is made to paint a paved street. 
(b)  An applicant for a permit hereunder shall file with the department of public works an application showing: 
(1)  Name and address of the owner, or agent in charge, of the property abutting the proposed work area; 
(2)  Location of the work area; 
(3)  Attached plans or description showing the details of the proposed painting. 
(c)  The following fees shall accompany an application for a permit hereunder: 
(1)  Painting the pavement for a driveway not in excess of twelve (12) feet with the word "No," seven dollars and fifty cents ($7.50); 
(2)  Painting the pavement for a driveway in excess of twelve (12) feet or for a "load and unload" zone or any other painting, twelve dollars and fifty cents ($12.50). 
(d)  No permit shall be granted unless there is presented to the department of public works a receipt from the office of the finance officer indicating that the proper fee for the permit has been paid. 
(e)  All operations for which a permit is granted hereunder shall be under the direction and supervision of the director of the department of public works. Upon application, no permit will be issued without the approval of the director of the department of public works. 
(Ord. No. 13-62, §§ 2-6, 5-2-62) 
Sec. 26-7. - Responsibility of abutting property owners to clean snow and ice from sidewalks. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the owner, tenant or occupant of any lot or land or real estate in the city to clear the sidewalks contiguous thereto of all snow or ice within forty-eight (48) hours after the cessation of any storm or fall of snow. 
(b)  If any sidewalk in front of any lot, land or real estate within the city is not cleared by the owner, tenant or occupant as directed in subsection (a), the city may cause the sidewalk to be cleared forthwith and to immediately report the cost and expense thereof to the city council and such charge shall be collected against the owner, tenant or occupant as other charges and assessments are by law collectable. 
(Ord. No. 7-62, §§ 2, 3, 4-3-62; Ord. No. 4-2015, 2-26-15) 
Sec. 26-8. - Depositing snow on streets prohibited. 
    Snow shall not be disposed of by depositing it upon the streets of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1006, § 1, 8-1-39; Ord. No. 7-62, § 4, 4-3-62) 
Sec. 26-9. - Maintenance of railroad crossings by railroad companies. 
    All railroad companies having railroad crossings that traverse the streets of the city shall make any and all necessary repairs and improvements to such crossings so as to insure the safe crossing of pedestrians and motorists using the streets of the city, and shall keep such crossings for pedestrians and motorists in good repair and condition at all times. 
(Ord. No. 22-69, § 1, 10-7-69) 
State Law reference- Construction and repair of crossings, 15 P.S. § 4101. 
Sec. 26-10. - Conduit for police and fire alarm wires installed by person installing other conduit. 
(a)  Whenever any person shall be granted permission to excavate for and place in any of the driveways of the public streets or under the sidewalks or across or on any of the public grounds, parks or parkways owned by the city, any under ground conduits, to be used for the carrying of wires or cables, such person shall be and is hereby required to construct, in addition to the ducts required for the use of such person, one duct in addition to the ducts required by such person for the use of the police and fire alarm wires owned by the city. 
(b)  Such additional duct, for the use of the police and fire alarm wires, shall be constructed by such person at the time such conduits are constructed, under the supervision of the city electrician at the cost and expense of the person to whom permission is granted to construct or place conduits in the public streets or over the public grounds of the city. 
(c)  Such person having permission to construct conduits, shall maintain and keep such duct open and ready for the use of the city at any and all times so long as the conduits shall be and remain in or under the public streets or public grounds of the city and the city hereby reserves the right and privilege to enter upon the property of such person at any time for the purpose of drawing cables through such ducts and installing and connecting up such police and fire alarm wires, and also for the purpose of making such repairs to such police and fire alarm systems as shall from time to time be necessary. 
(Ord. No. 125, §§ 1-3, 7-15-15) 
Cross reference- Emergency alarm systems, Ch. 9; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 10; police, Ch. 23. 
Sec 26-11. - Paving over shutoff valves for utilities. 
    It shall be a violation of this chapter for any contractor performing work hereunder to pave over any existing shutoff valves for utilities, including, but not limited to, water, sewer and gas lines. Any violation of this section shall result in the review and/or revocation of the license of the construction company engaging in this practice and shall subject such contractor to the following penalties: 
(1)  Violation of this section carries with it a fine not to exceed six hundred dollars ($600.00) per violation and each day that the violation continues to exist shall be considered a separate violation subject to this penalty. 
(2)  In addition to the penalties provided for above, any person violating any city ordinance is subject to a term of imprisonment not to exceed ninety (90) days. 
(Ord. No. 18-94, § 1, 5-26-94) 
Secs. 26-12-26-21. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR 

Sec. 26-22. - Responsibility of abutting property owner. 
(a)  The owner of property fronting or abutting on any public street, lane or alley in the city shall be required to construct sidewalks and keep the same in good repair and condition, and shall construct, replace and repair the same in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  After the initial installation of any sidewalk, all repairs and replacements are the responsibility of the abutting property owner. It shall also be the responsibility of a property owner abutting a sidewalk to keep the sidewalk in such condition that the same does not cause a dangerous condition to pedestrians and persons using the sidewalk. 
(Ord. No. 1038, §§ 1, 2, 5-20-41; Ord. No. 12-71, 8-17-71; Ord. No. 15-2007, § 2B, 7-12-07) 
Sec. 26-23. - Installation required upon issuance of building permit. 
    Upon the issuance of a building permit for a new building, the owner through his contractor is obligated to install sidewalks, if required, as a part of the building contract. Such installation shall be in accord with the regulations in this article. 
(Ord. No. 12-71, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 26-24. - Service of notice. 
    It shall be the duty of the sidewalk inspector to serve notices on the owner of any lot or piece of land in the city in front or on the side of which the sidewalk is out of repair, or where no required sidewalk has been laid. Where the owner cannot be found, the inspector is to cause the notice to be served on his agent, or on the tenant or occupier of such lot or piece of land, notifying such owner to repair or construct a sidewalk as required by this article. In case the owner of any vacant lot or piece of land does not reside in the city and has no agent on whom service can be made, it shall be the duty of the sidewalk inspector to cause the notice provided for under this article to be served on such owner if the same can be found, by registered mail or otherwise, at his place of residence or by posting the notice on the most public part of the property. Whenever any notice has been served under this article, the person serving shall make an affidavit of the time and manner of service and upon whom same is served. This affidavit shall be filed in the office of the director of public works or city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 9, 5-20-41) 
Sec. 26-25. - Failure of property owner to comply. 
    If any owner, subject to the provisions of this article, shall refuse or neglect to comply therewith after thirty (30) days notice so to do by the inspector of sidewalks, acting through the department of public works, then the city shall have sidewalks constructed, repaired or replaced in accordance with this article and the cost and expense of the same together with a penalty of fifteen (15) percent additional cost, shall be collected from the person so refusing or neglecting, in the manner provided by section 26-26. 
(Ord. No. 1038, §§ 2, 3, 5-20-41; Ord. No. 12-71, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 26-26. - Collection of costs incurred by city. 
    Wherever the city has constructed, replaced or repaired sidewalks, the city engineer shall certify the cost thereof to the finance officer, who shall collect such costs. Such costs shall be a lien upon the premises from the time of the filing of such certification. It shall then be the duty of the finance officer to place in the hands of the city attorney within six (6) months from the time of receiving such certification of costs and expenses against any property or properties, a list of claims against such properties showing the amount paid on each, and the city attorney shall thereupon file liens for such claims in the prothonotary's office in the proper lien docket. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 4, 5-20-41) 
Sec. 26-27. - Permit required. 
    All sidewalks constructed or repaired in the city shall require a permit from the building inspector's office. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 5, 5-20-41; Ord. No. 12-71, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 26-28. - Lines and grades. 
    All sidewalks shall be constructed or repaired to lines and grades as established and on file, or to be placed on file in the city engineer's office, and where feasible they are hereby fixed at a uniform width of four (4) feet on the respective streets from the line of the street towards the curb, gutter or cartway on each side, in accordance with resolutions hereinafter passed, except that the four-foot width may be increased by waiver, dependent upon existing conditions and location, but in no case shall such width be less than four (4) feet. Such waiver shall be in accordance with directions set forth by the director of public works or city engineer upon written application by the owner, to the department of planning and development who will so instruct the director of public works or city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 5, 5-20-41; Ord. No. 12-71, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 26-29. - Construction regulations. 
    Except by special waiver, sidewalks in the city may be constructed only of stone flagging, brick, tile or concrete, and must be constructed under the following regulations: 
(1)  Stone flagging on walks six (6) feet wide or over must consist of stone not less than four (4) feet long by three (3) feet wide and two (2) inches thick; four-foot walks must consist of stone not less than three (3) feet long by two (2) feet wide by two (2) inches thick. Such stones must be laid evenly on a base of crushed stones, porous cinders or sand not less than four (4) inches in depth with joints not more than one-half inches in width. 
(2)  Concrete shall be at least four (4) inches thick, except where driveways cross sidewalks, thickness shall be six (6) inches; the sidewalk shall be constructed of not less than one part cement, to two (2) parts sand and four (4) parts of crushed stone or gravel; concrete shall be air entrained and capable of testing to a two thousand five hundred (2,500) p.s.i. compression after twenty-eight (28) days, curing may be by natural means or chemically sprayed. All sidewalks shall be sprayed with an anti-spalling protective treatment after the twenty-eight-day period is fulfilled. Concrete shall be placed on a base of crushed stone, porous cinders or sand not less than four (4) inches in depth, with one layer of six (6) by six (6)-10/10 welded wire mesh reinforcing placed one-half way between the top and bottom of the sidewalk slab. Finish shall be steel troweled, with a light broomed or float finish. 
(3)  Asphalt or asphalt mixture shall not be used for new construction of sidewalks or driveways crossing sidewalks. Asphalt or asphalt mixtures may be used to repair an existing asphalt sidewalk provided that such repair is not in excess of forty (40) percent of the existing walk area. 
(4)  When a cut is made by a contractor, (plumbing, electrical, etc.) utility or utility contractor in any existing sidewalk; block (slab section), flaggings, concrete or asphalt shall be replaced, where damaged, in its entirety in accordance with the regulations set forth herein; where existing walk is of asphalt construction, the damaged portion shall be reconstructed so that the entire width of the existing walk is replaced with concrete as herein before regulated for a distance not less than eight (8) inches beyond the initial cut opening paralleling the street line. Where the existing sidewalk is concrete and cut is made with a saw in a straight and neat manner only the portion removed will need to be replaced subject to approval of department of public works inspector. All contractors, (plumbing, electrical, etc.), utilities, utility contractors are required to apply to the bureau of building inspection and obtain a sidewalk opening permit. The permit fee is two dollars ($2.00). Such permit shall be numbered, contain original and two (2) copies, and: Describe the applicant by name and address; direct permission for him to perform work at a designated address; provide for an explanation of purpose for the work; make provision for issuing authorities' signature. General instructions on the permit shall be stated as follows: 
a.  Backfill must be tamped in four (4) inch layers. 
b.  Sidewalk must be replaced by contractor within ten (10) days after backfilling. 
c.  Concrete sidewalks must be replaced in accordance with City Code of Ordinances, section 26-29(4). 
d.  Asphalt restoration will not be permitted; damaged or cut asphalt sidewalks shall be replaced in accordance with City Code of Ordinances, section 26-29(4). 
e.  Trenches must be properly barricaded and lighted. 
f.  No trees shall be cut or removed without permission of the city shade tree commission. 
g.  Tunneling will not be permitted without permission of the director of public works or city engineer. 
(5)  Sidewalks shall be level with the driveway grades and in no case shall step downs be acceptable. When approved by the director of public works or city engineer, sidewalks may be sloped to driveways if excessive grades prohibit a level installation. 
(6)  The sidewalk inspector shall direct the owner of properties fronting or abutting on any public street, lane or alley in the city, to repair or replace any sidewalk which in his discretionary opinion does not meet city standards, such as: 
a.  Sidewalks buckled by tree roots or frost upheaval, presenting an uneven variation in elevation between units, in excess of one to one and one-half inches or more, which would be detrimental or injurious to a person walking thereon; 
b.  Sidewalks cracked by settling, heavy truck or other vehicular traffic which present the same characteristics as noted in item a.; 
c.  Sidewalks, overly pitted or deteriorating to a point where a serious condition is prevalent and the safety of the public is endangered. 
(7)  Driveway curb cuts shall be made only after approval of the director of public works/city engineer. All cuts shall be not less than ten (10) feet in length nor more than thirty-five (35) feet in length and shall be elevated two (2) inches minimum above pavement in order to provide a proper gutter for storm water drainage. New curb recesses in new curbing shall also comply with the dimensions set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 6, 5-20-41; Ord. No. 12-71, 8-17-71) 
Sec. 26-30. - Material permitted in outskirts of city. 
    The council may, by resolution, authorize cinders, crushed stone or gravel at grade to be used on sidewalks in the outskirts of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 7, 5-20-41) 
Sec. 26-31. - Report of violations. 
    It shall be the duty of the police officers of the city to make a prompt report in writing in a record provided by the city for that purpose to the chief of police, of any violations of the provisions of this article. It shall be the duty of the chief of police to file a report in writing to the city council, containing the names of owners and occupiers of any lot or pieces of land in front or on the side of which the sidewalk is out of repair, or has not been laid. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 8, 5-20-41) 
Secs. 26-32-26-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PAVE CUTS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Paving over shutoff valves for utilities, § 26-11. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-41. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Application for a pave cut permit shall mean a form provided the utility by the city noting pertinent data for the purposes of inspection and control by the city, and constituting a receipt for services performed by the city. 
    Capital improvement shall mean preplanned to improve or upgrade an existing system or to install a completely new system providing new or additional service. 
    City pave cut log shall mean a chronological record of pave cuts as reported to the city containing pertinent data as required by the city for the purposes of inspection and control. 
    Emergency repair shall mean work necessitated by the rupture or malfunction of existing underground facilities, such that lack of immediate repair will result in extreme danger and/or immediate and substantial damage to surrounding areas. 
    Facilities means all the plant and equipment of a public utility including all tangible and intangible, real and personal property without limitations, and any and all means and instrumentalities in any manner owned, operated, leased, licensed, controlled, furnished or supplied for, by, or in connection with the business of any public utility; provided, however, that no property owned by the commonwealth, or any municipal corporation thereof at the date when this article becomes effective shall be subject to any of the terms of this article, except as elsewhere expressly provided herein. 
    Inspection means a careful or critical investigation not necessarily confined to optical observation but is understood to embrace tests and exam ination for the purpose of ascertaining quality and compliance as prescribed in this article and discovering and correcting errors. 
    Licensed contractor means the utility and subcontractor must possess a valid license under the building code of the city applicable to the type of work performed.
