That every person, firm, corporation or association operating a place or establishment that stores milk, eggs, or other refrigerated or frozen foods in the City of Wilkes-Barre shall be required to purchase an initial license in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00). Each annual license renewal shall be forty dollars ($40.00). Any establishment which requires a license herein shall be fined ten dollars ($10.00) per day for each day the establishment is in operation without a license. 
    Restaurants. That every person, firm, corporation or association operating a place or establishment that prepares and/or serves food, drink, desserts and/or ice cream shall be required to take out and purchase an initial license in the amount of three hundred dollars ($300.00). Each annual renewal shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) and shall be required of all restaurants operating or intending to operate within the limits of the City of Wilkes-Barre. Any restaurant that does not obtain a license shall be fined ten dollars ($10.00) per day for each day a restaurant is in operation without a license, at which time a citation shall be issued and the additional damages shall be assessed according to the terms of this article. Any restaurant that performs catering shall be assessed the annual catering license, which shall cover both catering and restaurants and shall be in lieu of this license. 
    Roominghouses. Any person, firm, corporation or association which owns or operates a dwelling or facility used for the business of furnishing accommodations to more than six (6) persons or lodgers for overnight stays, whether temporary or permanent, under a lease or rental arrangement to individuals shall pay an annual license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) per unit. 
    Scrap dealers/junkyards. That every person, firm, or corporation conducting business within the limits of the City of Wilkes-Barre, where rags, bones, rubber, scrap iron, metal, garbage, refuse, waste paper or junk of any kind is stored, and/or collected shall take out and pay an annual license fee of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
    Skating rink. That the owners, occupants or lessees of every skating rink in the City of Wilkes-Barre shall take out and pay a license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
    Slaughterhouses. Deleted. 
    Special events peddler. Every peddler (except food truck vendors, disabled soldiers, farmers and manufacturers disposing of their own products) selling any item whatsoever who or which does not have a permanent facility within the city limits and/or is not operating at all times out of the permanent facility and/or is selling or peddling in a transient form such as a kiosk, cart, temporary stand, or from or in the form of a non-permanent base within the limits of the city during a special event within the city limits, shall take out and pay a license fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) for each special event which is held within the city. All peddlers shall be required to obtain the permit prior to selling any item in any manner set forth above. Only a special event peddler license shall grant the peddler the right to sell on Public Square, unless otherwise excepted, and sales may only take place during the designated hours of the special event. 
    Steam heat. Deleted. (See "Utilities.") 
    Stock brokers/financial planners. Every stock broker and/or financial planner who engages in financial investments as a part of their occupation doing business within the limits of the City of Wilkes-Barre and having an office in said city, shall take out and pay an annual license fee of four hundred dollars ($400.00). 
    Tattoo/body piercing apprentice. Any person practicing tattooing/body piercing in a licensed establishment under the direct supervision of a certified tattoo/body piercing operator shall pay a license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
    Tattoo/body piercing establishment. Any room or space where tattooing and/or body piercing is practiced or where the business of tattooing and/or body piercing is conducted or any part thereof shall pay an annual license fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
    Tattoo/body piercing operator. Any person practicing the art of tattooing or body piercing shall pay a license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
    Taxicabs, coaches, limousines. That the owners or lessees of cabs, coupes, omnibuses, carts, coaches, wagons, automobiles, horse and carriages, limousines, and other vehicles of business or pleasure let for hire or employ or used in carrying articles or persons for pay within the limits of the City of Wilkes-Barre shall pay an annual license as follows: 
Every taxicab used in transporting persons about the city ..... $10.00 
Every bus, automobile or limousine used for the carrying of persons about or through the city for pay or between particular points at station intervals as follows: 
Capable of seating five (5) or less passengers ..... $20.00 
Capable of seating more than five (5) and less than seven (7) passengers ..... 25.00 
Capable of seating more than seven (7) and less than fifteen (15) passengers ..... 35.00 
Seating more than fifteen (15) passengers ..... 125.00 
    Temporary event food vendor. Any person, firm, corporation or other operator operating as a food vendor, whether mobile or stationary, on a temporary basis or at a special event, within the limits of the city, shall be required to pay the following fees: 
One-day event ..... $50.00 
Two- or three-day event ..... 80.00 
Four- to seven-day event ..... 150.00 
    Temporary tattoo/body piercing establishment. A tattoo/body piercing establishment that operates at a fixed location for a period of time of not more than seven (7) consecutive days in conjunction with a single event or celebration shall pay a license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
    Temporary tattoo/body piercing operator. A person providing tattoo/body piercing services outside of the physical site of a licensed facility for the purposes of product demonstration, industry trade shows or for educational reasons shall pay a license fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) per event. 
    Theater (two hundred fifty (250) or more). That the owners, occupants, or lessees of each theater within the limits of the City of Wilkes-Barre having a seating capacity of two hundred fifty (250) or more persons, shall take out and pay an annual license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
    Theater (less than two hundred fifty (250)). That the owners, occupants, or lessees of each theatre within the limits of the City of Wilkes-Barre having seating capacity of less than two hundred fifty (250) persons shall take out and pay an annual license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
    Transient retail merchant. That every person, firm or corporation intending or engaging in transient retail business in the City of Wilkes-Barre for the sale of goods, wares, or merchandise whatsoever, shall pay two hundred dollars ($200.00) per month, payable to the license clerk, and shall entitle said person, firm or corporation to obtain such license to continue business for a period of one (1) month. A transient retail merchant is defined as every person, firm or corporation that engages in the sale of goods or services as part of an event where a temporary stand is set up in the same location for the duration of the event. 
    Used car sales. Any person, firm, corporation or association which owns or operates a used car lot, which is defined as a place or premises from which a person, firm, corporation or association offers pre-owned automobiles, or other motor vehicles for sale, shall pay an annual license fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
    Utilities. That every telephone and/or telecommunications company, gas and water utility, electric utility and steam heat utility doing business within the limits of the City of Wilkes-Barre shall pay an annual license fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per mile of pipe or wire used throughout the city limits of the City of Wilkes-Barre, whether the same be underground or above ground. 
    Water company. Deleted. (See "Utilities.") 
    Wholesale meat. That every person, firm, corporation or association which offers for sale or purchase or which is engaged in the business of distributing meat and poultry products at wholesale in the city limits shall pay an annual fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(Ord. No. 56-04, §§ 9-58, 1-13-05; Ord. No. 1-2012, 2-9-2012; Ord. No. 26-2012, 12-28-2012; Ord. No. 11-2014, 7-10-14; Ord. No. 8-2017, 5-25-17) 
Sec. 28-98. - Licenses. 
    The licenses to be issued shall be kept in the office of the license clerk or the finance office as the administration shall so direct, and adequate and accessible records shall be kept with a stub for each license. The information and records kept shall be kept as follows, whether it be electronically or in book form: 
Number of license, date of license, name of person to whom issued, purpose for which issued, amount paid for license and date of expiration of same. All licenses issued shall be signed by the license coordinator, and shall have the name of the mayor of the City of Wilkes-Barre printed thereon. Each of said licenses issued shall contain a provision that every person, firm or corporation to whom such license is issued shall conform to the same, and to the provisions of all ordinances of the City of Wilkes-Barre applicable thereto, and to such other terms and conditions as the particular circumstances in each case shall, in the judgment of the authority issuing the license, require. That the license of any person, firm or corporation, making misrepresentations to the license coordinator at the time they make application for said license, shall be immediately revoked. 
(Ord. No. 56-04, § 6, 1-13-05) 
Sec. 28-99. - Records. 
    Records shall be kept, either electronically or in book form by the city license coordinator and kept in the office of the license coordinator or the finance office. A comprehensive list of all records shall show a classified list of all the persons, firms or corporations, required by this article to take out a license. 
(Ord. No. 56-04, § 7, 1-13-05) 
Sec. 28-100. - Liability. 
    That no license or licenses issued in accordance with the provisions of this article, shall authorize or excuse any breach of law, or any trespass upon the rights of others, or render the City of Wilkes-Barre liable for any damage that may be committed or caused under color thereof. 
(Ord. No. 56-04, § 101, 1-13-05) 
Sec. 28-101. - Nontransferability. 
    No license or licenses issued under the provisions of this article shall be transferred to a different person or place, except by special resolution passed by the city council of the City of Wilkes-Barre. 
(Ord. No. 56-04, § 102, 1-13-05) 
Sec. 28-102. - Revocation. 
    The license clerk may at any time revoke any license or license issued under the provisions of this article, for any breach of terms or condition thereof. 
(Ord. No. 56-04, § 103, 1-13-05) 
Sec. 28-103. - Interference. 
    This article shall in no way interfere with the issuing of burial or removal permits, sewer permits, milk licenses or building permits, which shall be issued by the city clerk, city engineer, building and plumbing inspector and city finance officer as heretofore. 
(Ord. No. 56-04, § 104, 1-13-05) 
Sec. 28-104. - Fee proration 
    Any new license obtained after October 31 of the current calendar year shall be one-half 1/2 of the of the license fee amount contained in Section 28-97. Any license issued after October 31 of the current calendar year shall be in effect until the last day of April the following year. This section shall only apply to license fees which need to be renewed on an annual basis. It shall not apply to the licenses related to special events (e.g., circus, special events peddler). 
(Ord. No. 9-2013, 8-13-13) 
Secs. 28-105-28-114. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - TAX ON EARNED INCOME AND NET PROFITS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Authority of city to levy, assess and collect taxes on earned income and net profits for general revenue purposes, 53 P.S. § 6902; local tax enabling act, 53 P.S. § 6901 et seq.; individual net income tax act, 72 P.S. § 3402-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 28-115. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Association means a partnership, limited partnership, or any other unincorporated group of two (2) or more persons. 
    Business means an enterprise, activity, profession or any other undertaking of an unincorporated nature conducted for profit or ordinarily conducted for profit whether by a person, partnership, association or any other entity. 
    Corporation means a corporation or joint stock association organized under the laws of the United States, the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania, or any other state, territory, foreign country or dependency. 
    Current year means the calendar year for which the tax is levied. 
    Domicile means the place where one lives and has his permanent home and to which he has the intention of returning whenever he is absent. Actual residence is not necessarily domicile, for domicile is the fixed place of abode which, in the intention of the taxpayer, is permanent rather than transitory. Domicile is the place in which a man has voluntarily fixed the habitation of himself and his family, not for a mere special or limited purpose, but with the present intention of making a permanent home, until some event occurs to induce him to adopt some other permanent home. In the case of businesses, or associations, the domicile is that place considered as the center of business affairs and the place where its functions are discharged. 
    Earned income means salaries, wages, commissions, bonuses, incentive payments, fees, tips and other compensation received by a person or his personal representative for services rendered, whether directly or through an agent, and whether in cash or in property; not including, however, wages or compensation paid to persons on active military service, periodic payments for sickness and disability other than regular wages received during a period of sickness, disability or retirement or payments arising under workmen's compensation acts, occupational disease acts and similar legislation, or payments commonly recognized as old age benefits, retirement pay or pensions paid to persons retired from service after reaching a specific age or after a stated period of employment or payments commonly known as public assistance, or unemployment compensation payments made by any governmental agency or payments to reimburse expenses or payments made by employers or labor unions for wage and salary supplemental programs, including, but not limited to, programs covering hospitalization, sickness, disability or death, supplemental unemployment benefits, strike benefits, social security and retirement. 
    Employer means a person, partnership, association, corporation, institution, governmental body or unit or agency, or any other entity employing one or more persons for a salary, wage, commission or other compensation. 
    Income tax officer or officer means a person, public employee or private agency designated by the city council to collect and administer the tax on earned income and net profits. 
    Net profits means the net income from the operation of a business, profession or other activity, except corporations, after provision for all costs and expenses incurred in the conduct thereof, determined either on a cash or accrual basis in accordance with the accounting system used in such business, profession, or other activity, but without deduction of taxes based on income. 
    Nonresident means a person, partnership, association or other entity domiciled outside the taxing district. 
    Person or individual means a natural person. 
    Preceding year means the calendar year before the current year. 
    Resident means a person, partnership, association or other entity domiciled in the taxing district. 
    Succeeding year means the calendar year following the current year. 
    Taxpayer means a person, partnership, association or any other entity, required hereunder to file a return of earned income or net profits, or to pay a tax thereon. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, 3-11-76) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 28-116. - Imposition of tax. 
(a)  A tax for general revenue purposes in the effective amount of three (3) percent is hereby imposed on earned income and net profits earned by residents of the City of Wilkes-Barre (please note that the stated rate is three (3) percent of which two and five-tenths (2.5) percent is payable to the City of Wilkes-Barre and five-tenths (0.5) percent is payable to the Wilkes-Barre Area School District), and in the amount of one (1) percent on earned income and net profits earned by nonresidents of the City of Wilkes-Barre, to the extent applicable, during the taxable period beginning on the first day of January, 2009, or the effective date of this section and continuing for each taxable year thereafter. 
(b)  The tax imposed in subsection (a) shall not be levied on the net profits of any person, institution or organization as to whom it is beyond the power of the council to impose such tax under the Constitution of the United States of America or the Constitution and laws of the commonwealth. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, §§ I, VI, 3-11-76; Ord. No. 67-98, §§ 1, 6, 11-12-98; Ord. No. 27-2008, § I, 12-11-08) 
Sec. 28-117. - Declarations, returns and payments-Net profits. 
(a)  Every taxpayer making net profits shall on or before April 15 of the current year make and file a declaration of his estimated net profits for the current year and shall pay the tax due thereon in quarterly installments and shall file a final return and pay to the officer the balance of the tax due, all as set forth in the Addendum to Ordinance No. 67-98. 
(b)  Any taxpayer who first anticipates any net profit after April 15 of the current year, shall make and file the declaration hereinabove required on or before June 15 of the current year, September 15 of the current year or December 31 of the current year, whichever of these dates next follows the date on which the taxpayer first anticipates such net profit, and pay to the income tax officer in equal installments the tax due thereon on or before the quarterly payment dates which remain after the filing of the declaration. 
(c)  Every taxpayer shall, on or before April 15 of the succeeding year, make and file with the income tax officer on a form prescribed or approved by the officer a final return showing the amount of net profits earned during the period beginning January 1 of the current year, and ending December 31 of the current year, the total amount of tax due thereon and the total amount of tax paid thereon. At the time of filing the final return, the taxpayer shall pay to the income tax officer the balance of the tax due or shall make demand for refund or credit in the case of overpayment. Any taxpayer may, in lieu of paying the fourth quarterly installment of his estimated tax, elect to make and file with the income tax officer on or before January 31 of the succeeding year, the final return as required in this subsection. 
(d)  The income tax officer may be authorized to provide by regulation for the making and filing of adjusted declarations of estimated net profits, and for the payments of the estimated tax in cases where a taxpayer who has filed the declaration required by this section anticipates additional net profits not previously declared or finds that he has overestimated his anticipated net profits. 
(e)  Every taxpayer who discontinues business prior to December 31 of the current year, shall, within thirty (30) days after the discontinuance of business, file his final return as required in this section and pay the tax due. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, § II, 3-11-76; Ord. No. 67-98, § 2(A), 11-12-98) 
Sec. 28-118. - Same-Earned income. 
(a)  Every taxpayer shall make and file returns and pay the taxes due all as set forth in the addendum to Ordinance No. 67-98. 
(b)  Quarterly returns. Every taxpayer who is employed for a salary, wage or other compensation and who received any earned income not subject to the provisions relating to collection at source shall make and file with the officer quarterly returns and shall pay quarter-annually the amount of tax shown as due on such returns, all as set forth in the addendum to Ordinance No. 67-98. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, § II, 3-11-76; Ord. No. 67-98, § 2, 11-12-98) 
Sec. 28-119. - Revenues to be turned over to finance officer. 
    The income tax officer shall turn over to the finance officer of the City of Wilkes-Barre at the expiration of each respective quarter those amounts duly collected by him as revenues of the tax promulgated through the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, § IV, 3-11-76; Ord. No. 67-98, § 4, 11-12-98) 
Sec. 28-120. - Refund of income tax paid on business expenses. 
    The income tax officer shall refund, on petition of, and proof by the taxpayer, earned income tax paid on the taxpayer's ordinary and necessary business expenses, to the extent that such expenses are not paid by the taxpayer's employer. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, 3-11-76) 
Sec. 28-121. - Interest and penalties on delinquencies. 
    If for any reason the tax imposed by this article is not paid when due, interest at the rate of six (6) percent per annum on the amount of the tax, and an additional penalty of one-half of one percent of the amount of the unpaid tax for each month or fraction thereof during which the tax remains unpaid, shall be added and collected. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, 3-11-76) 
Sec. 28-122. - Suits for recovery. 
(a)  The income tax officer may sue in the name of the city for the recovery of taxes due and unpaid under this article. 
(b)  Any suit brought to recover the tax imposed by this article shall be begun within three (3) years after such tax is due, or within three (3) years after the declaration or return has been filed, whichever date is later; provided, however, that this limitation shall not prevent the institution of a suit for the collection of any tax due or determined to be due in the following cases: 
(1)  Where no declaration or return was filed by any person although a declaration or return was required to be filed by him under provisions of this article, there shall be no limitation. 
(2)  Where an examination of the declaration or return filed by any person, or of other evidence relating to such declaration or return in the possession of the officer, reveals a fraudulent evasion of taxes, there shall be no limitation. 
(3)  In the case of substantial understatement of tax liability of twenty-five (25) percent or more, and no fraud, suit shall be begun within six (6) years. 
(4)  Where any person has deducted taxes under the provisions of this article, and has failed to pay the amounts so deducted to the income tax officer, or where any person has willfully failed or omitted to make the deductions required by this article, there shall be no limitation. 
(c)  Where suit is brought for the recovery of any tax under this article, the person liable therefor shall, in addition, be liable for the costs of collection and the interest and penalties imposed by this article. 
(d)  This section shall not be construed to limit the city from recovering delinquent taxes by any other means provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, 3-11-76) 
Sec. 28-123. - Suit for recovery of erroneous refunds. 
    The income tax officer may sue for recovery of an erroneous refund made under this article provided such suit is begun two (2) years after making such refund, except that the suit may be brought within five (5) years if it appears that any part of the refund was induced by fraud or misrepresentation of material fact. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, 3-11-76) 
Sec. 28-124. - Failure to receive forms no excuse for failure to make declarations or returns. 
    The failure of any person to receive or procure forms required for making the declaration or returns required by this article shall not excuse him from making such declaration or return. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, 3-11-76) 
Sec. 28-125. - Confidentiality of information gained under article. 
    Any information gained by the income tax officer or his agents, or by any other official or agent of the city, as a result of any declarations, returns, investigations, hearings or verifications required or authorized by this article, shall be confidential, except for official purposes and except in accordance with a proper judicial order, or as otherwise provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, 3-11-76) 
Sec. 28-126. - Rules and regulations for administration and enforcement of article. 
    The income tax officer charged with the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article is hereby empowered to prescribe, adopt, promulgate and enforce, rules and regulations relating to any matter pertaining to the administration and enforcement of this article, including provisions for the reexamination and correction of declarations and returns, and of payments alleged or found to be incorrect, or as to which an overpayment is claimed or found to have occurred, and to make refunds in cases of overpayment, for any period of time not to exceed six (6) years subsequent to the date of payment of the sum involved, and to prescribe forms necessary for the administration of this article. No rule or regulation of any kind shall be enforceable unless it has been approved by resolution of the city council. A copy of such rules and regulations currently in force shall be available for public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, 3-11-76) 
Sec. 28-127. - Violations. 
(a)  Any person who fails, neglects or refuses to make any declaration or return required by this article, any employer who fails, neglects or refuses to register or to pay the tax deducted from his employees, or fails, neglects or refuses to deduct or withhold the tax from his employees, any person who refuses to permit the officer or any agent designated by him to examine his books, records and papers, and any person who knowingly makes any incomplete, false or fraudulent return, or attempts to do anything whatsoever to avoid the full disclosure of the amount of his net profits or earned income in order to avoid the payment of the whole or any part of the tax imposed by this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be sentenced to pay a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, and costs, and, in default of payment of such fine and costs to be imprisoned for a period not exceeding thirty (30) days. 
(b)  Any person who divulges any information which is confidential under the provisions of this article, shall, upon conviction thereof, be sentenced to pay a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, and costs, and, in default of payment of such fines and costs to be imprisoned for a period not exceeding thirty (30) days. 
(c)  The penalties imposed under this section shall be in addition to any other penalty imposed by any other section of this article. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, 3-11-76) 
Secs. 28-128-28-135. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - INCOME TAX OFFICER GENERALLY 

Sec. 28-136. - Designation. 
    The council of the City of Wilkes-Barre shall designate by appropriate resolution the income tax officer who shall perform his duties in accord with the rules and regulations as set forth in the addendum to Ordinance No. 67-98, and such rules and regulations relating to administration and enforcement of this article as may be approved by council, and shall receive such compensation for his services and expenses as determined from time to time by the council of the City of Wilkes-Barre. Such officer shall have the powers and duties, and be subject to the penalties provided and set forth in the addendum to Ordinance No. 67-98. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, § IV, 3-11-76; Ord. No. 67-98, §§ 4, 5, 11-12-98) 
Sec. 28-137. - Compensation. 
    The income tax officer shall receive such compensation for his services and expenses as determined from time to time by the council. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, § V, 3-11-76) 
Sec. 28-138. - Bond. 
(a)  The income tax officer shall be bonded in accordance with provisions as set forth in the addendum to Ordinance No. 67-98, and the custodian of said bond shall be the finance officer of the City of Wilkes-Barre. If the city shall by resolution designate any bond previously given by the income tax officer as adequate, such bond shall be sufficient to satisfy the requirements of this subsection. 
(b)  The bond required by this section shall be joint and several, with one or more corporate sureties which shall be surety companies authorized to do business in this commonwealth and duly licensed by the insurance commissioner of this commonwealth. 
(c)  The bond required by this section shall be conditioned upon the faithful discharge by the income tax officer, his clerks, assistants and appointees of all trusts confided in him by virtue of his office, upon the faithful execution of all duties required of him by virtue of his office, upon the just and faithful accounting or payment over, according to law, of all moneys and all balances thereof paid to, received or held by him by virtue of his office and upon the delivery to his successor or successors in office of all books, papers, documents or other official things held in right of his office. 
(d)  The bond required by this section shall be taken in the name of the city and shall be for the use of the city and for the use of such other persons for whom money shall be collected or received, or as their interest shall otherwise appear, in case of a breach of any of the conditions thereof by the acts or neglect of the principal on the bond. 
(e)  The city may sue upon the bond provided for in this section in its own name for its own use. 
(f)  The bond required by this section shall contain the name of the surety company bound thereon. The city shall fix the amount of the bond at an amount equal to the maximum amount of taxes which may be in the possession of the officer at any given time. 
(g)  The city may, at any time, upon cause shown and due notice to the income tax officer, and his surety, require or allow the substitution or the addition of a surety company acceptable to the city for the purpose of making the bond sufficient in amount, without releasing the surety first approved from any accrued liability or previous action on such bond. 
(h)  The custodian of the bond required by this section shall be the finance officer of the city. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, § IV, 3-11-76; Ord. No. 67-98, § 4, 11-12-98) 
Sec. 28-139. - General duties. 
    It shall be the duty of the income tax officer to collect and receive the taxes, fines and penalties imposed by this article. It shall also be his duty to keep a record showing the amount received by him from each person or business paying the tax and the date of such receipt. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, 3-11-76) 
Sec. 28-140. - Examination of books and records of employees and taxpayers. 
(a)  The income tax officer and agents designated by him are hereby authorized to examine the books, papers and records of any employer or of any taxpayer or of any person whom the income tax officer reasonably believes to be an employer or taxpayer, in order to verify the accuracy of any declaration or return, or if no declaration or return was filed, to ascertain the tax due. 
(b)  Every employer and every taxpayer and every person whom the income tax officer reasonably believes to be an employer or taxpayer, is hereby directed and required to give to the income tax officer, or to any agent designated by him, the means, facilities and opportunity for such examination and investigations, as are hereby authorized by this section. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, 3-11-76) 
Sec. 28-141. - Authority to establish different filing, reporting and payment dates. 
    The income tax officer is authorized to establish different filing, reporting and payment dates for taxpayers whose fiscal years do not coincide with the calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, 3-11-76) 
Secs. 28-142-28-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COLLECTION OF INCOME TAX AT SOURCE 

Sec. 28-151. - Registration of employers. 
    Every employer having an office, factory, workshop, branch, warehouse or other place of business within the city, who employs one or more persons, other than domestic servants, for a salary, wage, commission or other compensation, who has not previously registered, shall, within fifteen (15) days after becoming an employer, register with the income tax officer his name and address and such other information as the officer may require. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, § III, 3-11-76) 
Sec. 28-152. - General duties of employers to withhold tax, file return thereon and make payment thereof. 
    Every employer having an office, factory, workshop, branch warehouse or other place of business within the corporate limits of the City of Wilkes-Barre shall deduct the tax imposed by this article on the earned income due to his employee or employees and shall file quarterly returns and final returns and pay quarterly to the officer the amount of taxes deducted, all as set forth in the addendum to Ordinance No. 67-98. Such return unless otherwise agreed upon between the income tax officer and employer shall show the name and Social Security number of each such employee, the earned income of such employee during such preceding three-month period, the tax deducted therefrom, the fact that the city is imposing the tax upon such employee, the total earned income of all such employees during such preceding three-month period, and the total tax deducted therefrom and paid with the return. No employer shall be required to register, deduct taxes, file return or pay taxes in the cases of domestic servants. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, § III, 3-11-76; Ord. No. 67-98, § 3, 11-12-98) 
Sec. 28-153. - Monthly return and payment by delinquent employers. 
    Any employer who for two (2) of the preceding four (4) quarterly periods has failed to deduct the proper tax, or any part thereof, or has failed to pay over the proper amount of tax to the city, as required by this division, may be required by the income tax officer to file his return and pay the tax monthly. In such cases, payments of tax shall be made to the income tax officer on or before the last day of the month succeeding the month for which the tax was withheld. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, § III, 3-11-76) 
Sec. 28-154. - Employer's annual returns. 
(a)  On or before February 28 of the succeeding year, every employer shall file with the income tax officer: 
(1)  An annual return showing the total amount of earned income paid, the total amount of tax deducted, and the total amount of tax paid to the income tax officer for the period beginning January 1 of the current year and ending December 31 of the current year; 
(2)  A return withholding statement for each employee employed during all or any part of the period beginning January 1 of the current year, and ending December 31 of the current year, setting forth the employee's name, address and social security number, the amount of earned income paid to the employee during such period, the amount of tax deducted, the fact that the city is imposing the tax upon such employee, the amount of tax paid to the income tax officer. Every employer shall furnish two (2) copies of the individual return to the employee for whom it is filed. 
(b)  Every employer who discontinues business prior to December 31 of the current year, shall, within thirty (30) days after the discontinuance of business, file the returns and withholding statements required in this section and pay the tax due. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, § III, 3-11-76) 
Sec. 28-155. - Liability of employer for taxes not withheld. 
    Every employer who willfully or negligently fails or omits to make the deductions required by this division shall be liable for payment of the taxes which he was required to withhold to the extent that such taxes have not been recovered from the employees. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, § III, 3-11-76) 
Sec. 28-156. - Failure of employer to withhold tax does not relieve employee from payment or duty to file declarations and returns. 
    The failure or omission of any employer to make the deductions required by this division shall not relieve any employee from the payment of the tax or from complying with the requirements of this article relating to the filing of declarations and returns. 
(Ord. No. 7-76, § III, 3-11-76) 
Secs. 28-157-28-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - REAL PROPERTY TAXES 

Sec. 28-176. - Basis for annual assessment. 
    The [tax] assessor shall make, or cause to be made, during the year 1982, and every year thereafter, a full, just, equal and impartial assessment of all property, taxable according to the laws of this commonwealth for county purposes, and all matters and things within the city subject by law to taxation for city purposes, and a just and perfect list of all property exempt by law from taxation, with a just valuation of the same. But nothing hereinbefore contained shall be construed as making taxable for city purposes the classes of personal property which by law are made taxable exclusively for county purposes at the rate of four (4) mills. With his assessment he shall return such dimension, description or quality of each lot or parcel of land as will be sufficient to identify the same, together with the number and kind of improvements. At the next annual assessment following the effective date of this section, the assessor shall, if council by ordinance so directs, classify all real estate in such city in such manner and upon such testimony as may be adduced before him so as to distinguish between the buildings on land and the land exclusive of the buildings, and he shall certify to the council the aggregate valuations of all real estate subject to taxation for city purposes within each such classification. In all cases he shall value, or cause to be valued, the property at the actual value thereof. In arriving at such value the price for which any property would separately bona fide sell, or the price at which any property may bona fide actually have been sold, shall be considered, but shall not be controlling. Instead, such selling price, estimated or actual, shall be subject to revision by increase or decrease to accomplish equalization with other similar property within the taxing district. It shall be the further duty of the assessor to return annually, a list of all the inhabitants over twenty-one (21) years of age. 
(Ord. No. 41-81, 12-29-81) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 41 of 1981, enacted Dec. 29, 1981, did not specifically amend this Code; hence, codification of the substantive provisions of said ordinance as § 28-176 is at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 28-177. - Millage rate. 
(a)  Millage increase. As of January 1, 2017, the millage levied against real property within the City of Wilkes-Barre shall be one hundred forty-one and thirty-three one hundredths (141.33). This millage shall be in effect until changed by ordinance. 
(b)  Discount and penalty. All taxpayers subject to payment of the real estate tax herein levied and assessed shall be entitled to a discount of one (1) percentum from the amount of such tax upon making payment of the whole amount thereof within one (1) month after the date of the tax notice. All taxpayers who fail to make payment of any such tax charge against them for three (3) months after the date of the tax notice shall be charged a penalty of fifteen (15) percentum which penalty shall be added to such tax by the director of administrative services as the tax collector and be collected by him. Overpayments less than one ($1.00) dollar will not be refunded unless requested in writing. 
(Ord. No. 3-04, §§ I, II, 2-12-04; Ord. No. 28-2008, § I, 12-11-08; Ord. No. 26-2012, 12-28-2012; Ord. No. 21-2016, § I, 1-12-17) 
Secs. 28-178-28-189. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - PROPERTY TAX EXEMPTION FOR CERTAIN DETERIORATED INDUSTRIAL, COMMERCIAL AND OTHER BUSINESS PROPERTY[7] 
Footnotes: 

DIVISION 1. - PINE RIDGE AREA 

Sec. 28-190. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meaning set forth below: 
(a)  Deteriorated property means any industrial, commercial or other business property owned by an individual, association or corporation and located in a deteriorating area, as designated herein, or any such property which has been the subject of an order by a government agency requiring the unit to be vacated, condemned or demolished by reason of noncompliance with laws, ordinance or regulations. 
(b)  Improvement means repair, construction or reconstruction, including alterations and additions, having the effect of rehabilitating a deteriorated property so that it becomes habitable or attains higher standards of safety, health, economic use or amenity or is brought into compliance with laws, ordinances or regulations governing such standards. Ordinary upkeep and maintenance shall not be deemed an improvement. 
Sec. 28-191. - Eligible areas. 
(a)  The city council of the City of Wilkes-Barre hereby determines that the portion of the city commonly known as 'Pine Ridge," more specifically defined as follows, contains deteriorated areas as defined in the LERTA statute; and is hereby declared eligible for tax exemption hereunder: 
Boundaries of Pine Ridge Park 
    Beginning at a point located in the 20th Ward of the City of Wilkes-Barre, on the southwesterly side of East Thomas Street, said point being the point of conjunction between East Thomas Street and lands now or formerly of the Central Railroad of New Jersey; 
    Thence south 13° 18' 29? west 860.00 feet along lands now or formerly of the Central Railroad of New Jersey; 
    Thence south 13° 18' 29? west 167.48 feet along the same land now or formerly of the Central Railroad of New Jersey; 
    Thence south 56° 03' 50? east 5.34 feet along the same land now or formerly of the Central Railroad of New Jersey; 
    Thence south 13° 18' 29? west 1,193.65 feet along the same land now or formerly of the Central Railroad of New Jersey; 
    Thence south 67° 53' 00? west 170.00 feet along the lands now or formerly of the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company; 
    Thence north 59° 00' 00? west 432.52 feet along the same lands now or formerly of the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company; 
    Thence north 63° 20' 00? west 373.38 feet along the same lands now or formerly of the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company; 
    Thence north 55° 55' 38? west 326.09 feet along the same lands now or formerly of Metropolitan Wire Company; 
    Thence north 39° 32' 07? east 1,081.85 feet along a 25-foot right-of-way now or formerly of the Delaware and Hudson Railroad; 
    Thence south 56° 03' 50? east 10.05 feet along the same 25-foot right-of-way now or formerly of the Delaware and Hudson Railroad Company; 
    Thence north 39° 32' 07? east 694.02 feet along the same 25-foot right-of-way now or formerly of the Delaware and Hudson Railroad Company; 
    Thence 184.77 feet along the arc of a 1,265.00-foot radius curve to the right having a chord north 43° 43' 11? east 184.61 feet to a point at the corner of the 35-foot right-of-way of the Delaware and Hudson Railroad Company and East Thomas Street; 
    Thence south 38° 41' 46? east 93.27 feet along the lands now or formerly of John Baker; 
    Thence south 47° 29' 57? east 75.88 feet along the same lands now or formerly of John Baker; 
    Thence south 20° 15' 35? west 21.80 feet along the lands now or formerly of Victoria Nitch; 
    Thence north 88° 05' 15? east 90.21 feet along the same lands now or formerly of Victoria Nitch; 
    Thence north 20° 15' 35? east 89.85 feet along the same lands now or formerly of Victoria Nitch to a point at the corner of said lands now or formerly of Victoria Nitch and the southwesterly side of East Thomas Street; 
    Thence south 75° 54' 51? east 27.00 feet along the southwesterly side of East Thomas Street to the point of beginning. 
    Containing 1,671,615 square feet or 38.375 acres of land, more or less. 
(b)  Persons making improvements to eligible industrial, commercial or other business properties within the definition contained in this article and located in any of the foregoing eligible areas may apply for, and the city assessor may grant, a real estate tax exemption upon such improvement in the amount and in the manner hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 75-86, § 2, 8-12-86) 
Sec. 28-192. - Exemption amount. 
(a)  The amount to be exempted shall be limited to that portion of the additional assessment attributable to the actual cost improvements. 
(b)  The exemption shall be limited to that improvement for which an exemption has been requested in the manner set forth below, and for which separate assessment has been made. 
(Ord. No. 75-86, § 3, 8-12-86) 
Sec. 28-193. - Exemption schedule. 
(a)  Following is the schedule of exemption effective immediately following the year upon which the improvement becomes assessable: 
Year 1-100% 
Year 2-100% 
Year 3-80% 
Year 4-60% 
Year 5-40% 
Year 6-20% 
Year 7-0% 
After Year 6, the exemption shall terminate. 
(b)  The exemption from taxes granted under this article shall be upon the property and shall not terminate upon the sale or exchange of the property. 
(Ord. No. 75-86, § 4, 8-12-86) 
Sec. 28-194. - Procedure for obtaining exemption. 
    Any person desiring tax exemption pursuant to this article shall notify the city on a form to be provided by the assessor's office at the time such person secures a building permit. Upon completion of the improvement or new construction, such person shall notify the City of Wilkes-Barre so that an assessment may be made of the improvement or new construction for the purpose of calculation the amount of assessment eligible for tax exemption in accordance with this article. The appropriate city authorities shall then notify the applicant of the amounts of the assessment eligible for exemption. Appeals from such assessment and/or from the determination of amount eligible for exemption may be taken as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 75-86, § 5, 8-12-86) 
Sec. 28-195. - Termination. 
    Unless otherwise repealed by subsequent legislation, this article shall remain in full force and effect. If this article should subsequently be repealed, any property tax exemption granted hereunder shall be permitted to continue according to the exemption schedule as set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 75-86, § 6, 8-12-86) 
DIVISION 2. - STEGMAIER BREWERY AREA 

Sec. 28-196. - Eligible area. 
    The boundaries of the area within the city known as the Stegmaier Brewery Area, as depicted on the maps attached to the ordinance from which this division derives, and denoted as "Exhibit A," are hereby affixed as the boundaries of a deteriorated area and all industrial, commercial and other business property located therein shall be considered deteriorated property for the purpose of the Local Economic Revitalization Tax Assistance Act. 
(Ord. No. 6-96, § 1, 3-14-96) 
Sec. 28-196.1. - Schedule of tax exemptions. 
    The following schedule of tax exemptions, with respect to the improvement of deteriorated properties provided in the Local Economic Revitalization Tax Assistance Act, is hereby adopted with the exemption to be granted on the increase in assessment attributable to the actual costs of improvements, regardless of the dollar amount.
