Secs. 28-197-28-209. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - REALTY TRANSFER TAX[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Article X of Ch. 28, is based on Ord. No. 72-88, adopted Dec. 8, 1988, which enacted a realty transfer tax for the year 1989. In order to avoid unnecessary printing costs in future supplements, subsequent realty transfer tax ordinances which re-enact this tax and which change only the tax year and contain no other substantive provisions have not been included herein but will be listed below as part of this note for the convenience of the user. 
Ord. No. Adoption 
Date Ord. No. Adoption 
Date 63-89 12-14-89 58-94 12- 8-94 57-90 12-13-90 41-95 12- 7-95 38-91 12-12-91 36-96 12-12-96 36-92 12-10-92 39-97 12-11-97 46-93 11-23-93  
Cross reference- Residence tax, § 28-34 et seq. 
State Law reference- Local tax enabling act, 53 P.S. § 6901. 

Sec. 28-210. - Definitions. 
    The following words or phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except when the context indicates a different meaning: 
    Consideration. The amount paid for the interest or title transferred or conveyed, which shall include the value of property or anything of value paid for the real property or any interest in real property transferred and shall include purchase money obligations assumed and the actual amount of all liens, mortgages, or other encumbrances subject to which the sale or transfer is made. 
    Person. Any natural person, artificial person, corporation, partnership, association, or unincorporated enterprise. As applied to any association or partnership, the term "person" shall include the members or partners thereof and as applied to corporation, the officers thereof. The singular shall include the plural and the masculine shall include the feminine and neuter. 
    Physical possession. Any exercise of dominion or ownership done on the land by the grantee or purchaser. 
    Transfer. A transaction whereby all or part of the interest of any person in lands, tenements, hereditaments, or any real property or of any interest in real property situate within the City of Wilkes-Barre passes to another person by deed or other instrument of conveyance. 
(Ord. No. 13-2008, § I, 12-3-08) 
Sec. 28-211. - Levy and assessment. 
    For the fiscal year beginning on January 1, 2009, a tax for general revenue purposes is hereby levied under this provision at a rate of two and one-half percent (2.5) of the value, consideration or sale price, but shall thereafter be imposed upon each transfer of real property or any interest in real property within the limits of the City of Wilkes-Barre, regardless of where the instruments making the transfers are made, executed, or delivered, or where the actual settlements on the transfers take place, to the same extent that such transactions are subject to the tax imposed by the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania pursuant to Article XI-C of the Tax Reform Act of 1971, 72 P.S. Sect. 8101-C, et seq., and any and all provisions which are inconsistent therewith shall not be applicable to transfers which occur on or after that date. 
(Ord. No. 13-2008, § II, 12-3-08) 
Sec. 28-212. - Exceptions. 
    There is hereby excepted from the tax levied, assessed and imposed in section 28-211 above any of those types or classes of transfer from which local authorities are debarred from the imposition of tax by virtue of provisions of the Local Tax Enabling Act, 53 P.S. section 6902(1), as the same be amended from time to time. 
Sec. 28-213. - Irrelevance of the place of execution of the deed of transfer. 
    The tax levied in section 28-211 above shall become payable upon each such transfer of title, interest or possession of or to real property without regard to the place where the making, executing, delivery or acceptance of the instrument of transfer shall have been done or accomplished. 
Sec. 28-214. - Special computation for real property located partially within the boundaries of the city. 
    In case of any land, tenements, hereditaments, real property or interest therein partly within and partly without the boundaries of the city, such tax shall be computed only on the consideration paid for that portion lying within the boundaries of the city. 
Sec. 28-215. - Payment of tax. 
    Upon passage of this article, and thereafter, the tax levied under this provision shall be administered, collected, and enforced under the Act of December 31, 1965 (P.L. 1257, No. 511), as amended ("Local Tax Enabling Act"), provided, however, that if the correct amount of the tax is not paid by the last date prescribed for timely payment, as provided in Section 1102-C of the Tax Reform Code of 1971, P.S. Sect. 8102-C, the Pennsylvania Department of Revenue is authorized and directed, on behalf of the City of Wilkes-Barre, to determine the tax, interest, and penalty as provided in Section 1109-D of the Tax Reform Code of 1971, 72 P.S. Sect. 8109-D, and is also authorized and directed to collect and enforce the tax, interest, and penalty in the same manner as tax, interest, and penalty imposed by the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania pursuant to Article XI-C of the Tax Reform Act of 1971, 72 P.S. Sect. 8101-C, et seq. 
(Ord. No. 13-2008, § III, 12-3-08) 
Sec. 28-216. - Penalty and lien of tax. 
    All taxes imposed by this article which are not paid when due shall bear interest thereon at the rate of one (1) percent per month until paid. This tax, when due and unpaid, shall become a lien on the lands, tenements, hereditaments, real property or any interest therein which are described in a deed, transfer or conveyance upon which this tax is due and shall be collected as other taxes are collected. 
Sec. 28-217. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person who shall fail, neglect or refuse to comply with any of the terms of this article or of any regulation or requirement pursuant thereto and authorized thereby shall, in addition to other penalties provided by law, upon summary conviction before a district magistrate of competent jurisdiction, be sentenced to pay a fine not to exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00), and the costs of prosecution, and/or to undergo imprisonment for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days. Any such penalty levied under this section shall be in addition to any other penalty imposed by any other section of this article. 
Sec. 28-218. - Sharing information. 
    The finance officer or other authorized representative may divulge to the Pennsylvania Department of Revenue any information concerning the administration or collection of the tax imposed hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 13-2008, § IV, 12-3-08) 
Secs. 28-219-28-229. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - BUSINESS PRIVILEGE TAX[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Being not specifically amendatory of the Code, the provisions of Ord. No. 71-88, §§ 1-11, adopted Dec. 8, 1988, have been included herein as a new Art. XI to Ch. 28. 
In order to avoid unnecessary printing costs in future supplements, subsequent business privilege tax ordinances which re-enact this tax and which change only the tax year and contain no other substantive provisions have not been included herein but will be listed below as part of this note for the convenience of the user. 
Ord. No. Adoption 
Date Ord. No. Adoption 
Date 60-89 12-14-89 49-93 11-23-93 54-90 12-13-90 59-94 12- 8-94 43-91 12-12-91 38-97 12-11-97 38-92 12-10-92  
Cross reference- License tax, § 28-91 et seq. 
State Law reference- Authority to levy and collect taxes, 53 P.S. § 37601. 

Sec. 28-230. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Business Privilege Tax Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 71-88, § 1, 12-8-88) 
Sec. 28-231. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business. Any activity carried on or exercised for gain or profit in the City of Wilkes-Barre, which is not subject to the Mercantile License Tax Ordinance, including, but not limited to, the performance of services and the rental of personal property and/or real estate or any interest therein. 
    Calendar year. The period from January 1 to December 31, which calendar year is also, by definition of the Wilkes-Barre City Home Rule Charter, the fiscal year for the City of Wilkes-Barre and may be so referred to herein. 
    Gross volume of business. All cash, credit and barter transactions. 
    License year. The period beginning July 1 and ending on June 30, inclusive. 
    Person. Any individual, partnership, limited partnership, association, firm or corporation. Whenever used in any clause prescribing or imposing a penalty, the term "person," as applied to associations, shall mean the partners or members thereof and, as applied to corporations, the officers thereof. 
    Taxpayer. A person subject to the payment of the tax imposed by this article. 
    Tax administrator. The person duly appointed by the City of Wilkes-Barre to administer and collect the within tax. 
Sec. 28-232. - Business privilege tax levied. 
    There is hereby levied, assessed and imposed for each license year, a tax for general revenue purposes on the privilege of doing business within the City of Wilkes-Barre. 
Sec. 28-233. - Business privilege license. 
(a)  Application. After the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived, any person desiring to conduct, or to continue to conduct, any business, as herein defined, within the city shall file with the tax administrator an application for a business privilege license. 
(b)  Procurement required. Beginning on the first day of January and for the balance of the calendar year, every person desiring to continue to engage in, or hereafter to begin to engage in, business, as herein defined, shall on or before the first day of January procure a business privilege license for his place of business, or if more than one (1), for each of his places of business in the City of Wilkes-Barre, from the business privilege tax collector as required by law. 
(c)  Posting of license. The license issued shall be conspicuously posted at all times in the place of business for which such license is issued and shall remain in effect for the license year or fraction of year for which such license was issued. In cases where more than one (1) place of business is conducted, a separate license shall be issued for each place of business. Any taxpayer who is in default in payment of tax due hereunder shall be refused a license until such tax is paid in full. 
Sec. 28-234. - Rate and basis of tax. 
    The rate of the tax on each and every dollar of the whole or gross volume of business transacted within the territorial limits of the City of Wilkes-Barre shall be one and one-half (11/2) mills. One and one-half (11/2) mills shall mean one dollar and fifty cents ($1.50) per one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) of gross volume of business. 
Sec. 28-235. - Rate when same tax is imposed by two taxing bodies. 
    If any person is liable for the same tax on the same subject imposed under the Local Tax Enabling Act 1965, December 31, Pamphlet Law 1257 and its amendments, to the city and one (1) or more political subdivisions of the state, then and in that event the tax shall be apportioned by such percentage as may be agreed upon by such political subdivisions, but in no event shall the combined taxes of both subdivisions exceed a maximum rate of tax as fixed by said Enabling Act permitting the imposition of such taxes. 
Sec. 28-236. - Computation of volume of business. 
(a)  For businesses commencing at least one year prior to license year. Every person subject to the payment of the tax hereby imposed who has commenced his business at least one (1) year prior to the beginning of the license year shall compute his annual gross volume of business upon the actual gross amount of business transacted by him during said immediately preceding calendar year. 
(b)  For businesses commencing less than one year prior to license year. Every person subject to the payment of the tax hereby imposed who has commenced or who commences his business less than one (1) full year prior to the beginning of the license year shall compute his annual gross volume of business for such license year upon the gross volume of business transacted by him during the first month in business multiplied by twelve (12). 
(c)  For businesses commencing subsequent to license year. Every person subject to the payment of the tax hereby imposed who commences his business subsequent to the beginning of the license year shall compute his annual gross volume of business for such license year upon the gross volume of business transacted by him during the first month of his engaging in business multiplied by the number of months he engaged in business in such license year. 
(d)  Temporary, seasonal or itinerant businesses. Every person subject to the payment of the tax hereby imposed who engages in a business temporary, seasonal or itinerant by its nature shall compute his annual gross volume of business upon the actual gross amount of business transacted by him during the license year. The aforementioned shall be required to make a minimum payment in an amount determined by the tax administrator prior to their engaging in business. 
(e)  Payment under protest; refund of overpayment. The tax administrator is hereby authorized to accept payment under protest of the amount of business privilege tax claimed by the city in any case where the taxpayer disputes the validity or amount of the city's claim for tax. If it is thereafter judicially determined by a court of competent jurisdiction that the city has been overpaid, the amount of the overpayment shall be refunded to the taxpayer. The provisions of this section shall be applicable to cases in which the facts are similar to those in a case litigated in a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(f)  Credit towards mercantile license tax. Payments made under the mercantile license tax for business to which this tax is applicable shall be credited to this tax and vice versa. 
Sec. 28-237. - Determination of gross or whole volume business. 
    Gross or whole volume of business upon which the tax hereunder is computed shall include the gross consideration credited or received for or on account of sales made, rentals and/or services rendered subject only to the following allowable deductions and exemptions: 
(1)  Any commissions paid by a broker to another broker on account of a purchase or sales contract initiated, executed or cleared with such other broker. 
(2)  Bad debts, where the deduction is also taken in the same year for Federal Income Taxation purposes. 
(3)  Taxes collected as agent for the United States of America, the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania or any other taxing entity of competent jurisdiction. 
Sec. 28-238. - Persons, businesses and receipts exempted. 
(a)  Persons and businesses. Persons employed for a wage or salary, nonprofit corporations or associations organized for religious, charitable or educational purposes, agencies of the government of the United States or of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania and the business of any political subdivision, or of any authority created or organized under and pursuant to any act of assembly are exempt from the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Privilege, transaction, subject and occupation. No such tax shall be assessed and collected on a privilege, transaction, subject or occupation which is subject to a state tax or license fee, and which tax or license fee has been held by the courts of Pennsylvania to be the basis for exemption from the imposition of a business privilege tax by a municipality. 
(c)  Utilities. No such tax shall be assessed and collected on the gross receipts from utility service of any person or company whose rates of service are fixed and regulated by the Pennsylvania Public Utility Commission or on any public utility service rendered by any such person or company or on any privilege or transaction involving the rendering of any such public utility service. 
(d)  State tax on tangible property. No such tax shall be assessed and collected on the privilege of employing such tangible property as is subject to a state tax except on sales of admission to places of amusement or on sales or other transfers of title or possession of property. 
(e)  Others. Any other person exempt by law from the imposition of this tax. 
Sec. 28-239. - Partial exemptions. 
    Where gross or whole volume of business in its entirety cannot be subject to the tax imposed by this article by reason of the provisions of the Constitution of the United States or any other provision of law, the tax administrator shall establish rules and regulations and methods of allocation and evaluation so that only part of the gross or whole volume of business which is properly attributable and allowable to doing business in the city shall be taxed hereunder. 
Sec. 28-240. - Records. 
    The taxpayer, to obtain the foregoing enumerated exclusions and deductions, shall keep books and records of his business so as to show clearly, accurately, and separately the amount of such sales and services as are excluded from the tax and the amounts of such sales and services which he is entitled to deduct from the gross volume of business as hereinbefore provided. 
Sec. 28-241. - Payment of tax and penalties for late payment. 
    The business privilege tax levied pursuant to this article shall be due and payable on the date on which the taxpayer is required to file a return as set forth herein, and if the same is not paid on said date, a penalty of one (1) percentum of tax due for each month or fractional month delinquent plus interest of one-half of one percentum (1/2 of 1%) of tax due for each month or fractional delinquency shall be added thereto until paid. Overpayments less than one dollar ($1.00) will not be refunded unless requested in writing. 
Sec. 28-242. - Returns. 
(a)  Form; certification of correctness; verification of accuracy. Every return shall be made upon a form furnished by the tax administrator. Every person making a return shall certify the correctness thereof by affidavit. Each return shall be documented by appropriate schedule to verify their accuracy. 
(b)  Businesses commencing at least one year prior to license year. Every person subject to the tax imposed by this article who commenced his business at least one (1) full year prior to the beginning of any license year shall on or before the fifteenth day of April file with the tax administrator a return setting forth his name, his business and business address, and such other information as may be necessary in arriving at the actual gross amount of business transacted by him during the preceding calendar year and the amount of the tax due. 
(c)  Businesses commencing less than one year prior to license year. Every person subject to the tax imposed by this article who has commenced his business less than one (1) full year prior to the beginning of any license year shall on or before the fifteenth day of April file with the tax administrator a return setting forth his name, his business, business address, and such other information as may be necessary in arriving at the actual gross amount of business transacted by him during the first month of business and the amount of the tax due. 
(d)  Businesses commencing subsequent to license year. Every person subject to the tax imposed by this article who commences business subsequent to the beginning of any license year shall within forty (40) days from the date of commencing such business file a return with the tax administrator setting forth his name, his business and business address, and such information as may be necessary in arriving at the actual gross amount of business transacted by him during his first month of business and the amount of the tax due. 
(e)  Temporary, seasonal or itinerant businesses. Every person subject to the payment of the tax imposed by this article who engages in a business temporary, seasonal or itinerant by its nature shall, within seven (7) days from the day he completes such business, file a return with the tax administrator setting forth his name, his business address, and such information as may be necessary in arriving at the actual gross amount of business transacted by him during such period and the amount of tax due. 
(f)  Ceasing business. Any person going out of or ceasing to do business shall, within seven (7) days from the date of ceasing to do business, file a return showing the actual gross volume of business conducted and done by such person during that tax year in which said person ceased doing business, and pay the tax due as computed thereon at the rate herein provided for at the time of filing said return. If such tax has been previously paid based upon estimated gross receipts, the taxpayer shall be entitled to a refund, without interest, of any excess tax paid for the tax year in which business was terminated. 
Sec. 28-243. - Confidential nature of returns, etc. 
    Any information gained by the tax administrator or any other official, agent or employee of the city as a result of any returns, investigations, hearings or verifications required or authorized by this article shall be confidential, except in accordance with proper judicial order or as otherwise provided by law. 
Sec. 28-244. - Receipt. 
    The tax administrator shall, upon payment to him of the business privilege tax, give the person paying the same a receipt therefor. 
Sec. 28-245. - Duties of the tax administrator. 
(a)  Receipt of taxes, etc.; records of receipts; remission to city. The tax administrator is charged with the duties of receiving the taxes, fines and penalties imposed by this article. It shall be his duty to keep a record showing the amount received by him from each person paying the tax and the date of such receipt. It shall be his duty to remit collections to the city as soon as practical but not later than one (1) month from the date of receipt. 
(b)  Adoption of rules and regulations. The tax administrator and his duly appointed deputies are hereby empowered to prescribe, adopt and promulgate rules and regulations relating to any matter pertaining to the collection, administration and enforcement of this article, including provisions for the examination and correction of returns, and payments alleged or found to be incorrect, or as to which an overpayment is claimed, or found to have occurred, and charged with enforcing the provisions of this article and any rules and/or regulations promulgated pursuant hereto. 
(c)  Assessment authority. In the event the person to be assessed neglects or refuses to make a return, then in such case the tax administrator or his duly appointed deputies shall assess said person or persons on such an amount of whole or gross volume of business as the tax administrator or his deputies deem reasonable and appropriate. In all cases of assessment, the tax administrator or his duly appointed deputies shall give the parties assessed a notice in which shall be stated the trade, business, occupation or class, and the amount of the business privilege tax imposed or levied. 
(d)  Maintenance of records and accounts; authority to examine books, papers and records of persons subject to tax. The taxpayer shall maintain such records and books of account as will enable him to make a true and accurate return in accordance with the provisions of the article. Such accounts and records must disclose in detail the gross receipts and other data pertaining to the taxpayer's gross volume of business and must be sufficiently complete to enable the tax administrator or his deputies to verify all transactions. The tax administrator or his deputies are hereby authorized to examine the books, papers and records of any person or persons subject to or supposed to the tax imposed by this article in order to verify the accuracy of the return made, or if no return was made, to ascertain the tax due. 
(e)  Right of appeal. Any person aggrieved by any decision of the tax administrator shall have the right to appeal to the court of common pleas, as in other cases. 
Sec. 28-246. - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall conduct, transact or engage in any of the businesses subject to the tax imposed by this article without having first secured a business privilege license for the year, or any person who shall fail to file a tax return as required by the provisions of this article, or any person who shall willfully file a false return, shall, upon summary conviction before any district justice of competent jurisdiction, be sentenced to pay a fine not to exceed the sum of three hundred dollars ($300.00) for any offense, plus costs of prosecution and/or imprisonment for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days. 
Sec 28-247. - Continuing offense. 
    Each day on which any person shall violate the provisions of this article shall be considered as a separate offense and punishable as such as aforesaid. 
Sec. 28-248. - Suit on collection and penalty. 
(a)  The tax administrator or his duly appointed deputies shall have the power in the name of the city to institute proceedings against any and all persons who violate the provisions of this article. 
(b)  If for any reason the tax is not paid when due and suit is brought for the recovery of any such tax, the person liable therefor shall, in addition, be liable for the costs of collection and interest and penalties herein imposed. 
Chapter 29 - TRAFFIC AND MOTOR VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance designating one-way streets, no parking zones, and any other designation of streets for traffic purposes saved from repeal, § 1-5(12); placing of handbills on vehicles, § 3-22; throwing of litter from vehicles, § 12-37; mobile homes and trailers, Ch. 16; unlawful noise from horns and warning devices, § 17-2; unlawful noise from defect in vehicle or load, § 17-6; unlawful noise from screeching of tires, § 17-7; sound trucks, § 17-25 et seq.; offenses, miscellaneous provisions, Ch. 19; streets, sidewalks and other public places, Ch. 26. 
State Law reference- Vehicle Code, 75 P.S. § 101 et seq.; powers of local authorities, 75 P.S. § 1103. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 29-1. - Definitions. 
    Words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in the vehicle code of the commonwealth, except as otherwise defined in this section: 
    Abandoned motor vehicle: One that is not capable to move under its own power; or a vehicle with a deflated tire; or one without current license tags or stickers; or a partially disabled, wrecked or junked vehicle when allowed to remain in such condition for a period of forty-eight (48) hours. 
    Crosswalk: That portion of a street ordinarily included with the prolongation of curb and property lines at intersections, or any portion of a street clearly indicated for pedestrian crossing by lines or other markings on the surface. 
    Intersection: The area embraced within the prolongation of lateral curblines or, if none, then the lateral boundary lines of two (2) or more streets which join one another at an angle whether or not one such street crosses the other. 
    Parking meter: A device intended to assist public authorities in enforcing ordinances limiting the time during which vehicles may be parked on any street within a parking meter zone. 
    Parking meter zone: Streets, or portions thereof, on which parking meters are installed, operated and used. 
    Police officer: Every person in the city's bureau of police or every person authorized by the city to direct or regulate traffic or to make arrests for violation of traffic regulations. 
    Public property Any real estate and other tangible objects owned or controlled by the city. 
    Safety zone: The area of space officially set aside within a street for the exclusive use of pedestrians and which is so plainly marked or indicated by proper signs as to be plainly visible at all times while set apart as a safety zone. 
    Sign: Any device, mark, marker, board, plate or other contrivance, designed for the purpose of guiding traffic or informing of traffic regulations. 
    Street: Every way or place of whatever nature dedicated to the use of the public as a matter of right, for purpose of vehicular traffic. The term "street" shall not be deemed to include a roadway or driveway upon grounds owned by private persons, colleges, universities or other institutions. 
    Traffic-control device: Any sign, signals, markings and devices not inconsistent with this chapter placed or erected as herein provided, or any temporary warning signs placed by recognized agencies for the purpose of guiding, directing, safeguarding, warning or regulating traffic. 
    Truck: Any vehicle designed or operated for the transportation of property, and whose body weight or whose combined body and load weight exceeds ten (10) tons. 
    Deviating truck: Any truck which leaves and departs from a truck route while traveling inside the city. 
    Truck route: A way over certain streets, as designated in article IV of this chapter, over and along which trucks coming into or going out of the city must operate. 
    Vehicle: Any device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a public street or highway, excepting tractors, agricultural machinery or devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Ord. No. 2-75, § 2, 3-6-75) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 29-2. - Traffic-control maps. 
(a)  Preparation. The city engineer, with the assistance of departments deemed necessary, shall prepare and maintain official traffic-control maps of this city. Such official maps shall become part of this chapter. 
(b)  Contents. Such traffic-control maps shall contain information showing the location of the following traffic regulations, restrictions and devices: 
(1)  One-way streets; 
(2)  Signalized streets and intersections; 
(3)  Zones which prohibit parking at any time. 
(c)  Changes. Amendments to the traffic-control map shall be made by ordinance. This section shall not restrict the authority of the division of traffic and patrol to establish any traffic regulations for a period not exceeding ninety (90) days, in conformity with section 29-36. 
(d)  Procedure for recommended amendments. The traffic committee or the division of traffic and patrol shall submit to the mayor specific recommendations, whenever necessary, for additions, changes or deletions to the traffic-control maps. The division of traffic and patrol shall include in such recommended additions, changes or deletions, any permanent change in traffic-control or parking areas requested by the chief of police. This section shall not restrict the power of council to amend the traffic-control maps without prior recommendation from the traffic committee or the division of traffic and patrol. 
(e)  Maintenance. At least one set of traffic-control maps, as currently amended, shall be kept on file by each of the following: 
(1)  The division of traffic and patrol; 
(2)  The bureau of engineering; 
(3)  The department of planning and development. 
The keeping of such maps to date shall not be a requisite condition for the prosecution of any violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2-75, Art. VI, §§ 1-5, 3-6-75) 
Sec. 29-3. - Obedience to police. 
(a)  No person shall fail to comply with any lawful order, signal or direction of a police officer. 
(b)  Police officers shall have the power and authority to direct vehicles to proceed in a direction other than that in which the operator intended to proceed lawfully for the purpose of avoiding or relieving traffic congestions, during emergencies or to enforce temporary restrictions incident to street repairs and improvements. 
(Ord. No. 2-75, Art. VII, § 1, 3-6-75) 
Sec. 29-4. - Obedience to official traffic equipment; exception. 
    No person shall fail to comply with the indications of any official traffic equipment unless otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(Ord. No. 2-75, Art. VII, § 2, 3-6-75) 
Sec. 29-5. - Damage to traffic-control devices, tags, notices or summons. 
    No unauthorized person shall deface, damage, move, remove, obstruct, destroy, change the wording of, alter or otherwise interfere with any traffic-control device or part thereof. No unauthorized person shall deface, change the wording of, discard, destroy or throw away any traffic tags, notices or summons. 
(Ord. No. 2-75, Art. VII, § 3, 3-6-75) 
Sec. 29-6. - Penalty for violations. 
(a)  Whoever violates any provisions of this chapter, where another penalty is not provided, shall be subject to a fine not more than fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(b)  Fines and penalties provided in the State Motor Vehicle Code will supersede subsection (a), when such fines and penalties are in excess of those provided in subsection (a). 
(Ord. No. 2-75, Art. VII, §§ 4, 5, 3-6-75) 
State Law reference- Discretion regarding fines imposed, 75 P.S. § 1206. 
Sec. 29-7. - Prohibiting the use of an interactive wireless communication device while in operation of a motor vehicle with the city. 
(a)  Definitions. For purposes of this section, the following words or phrases shall have the following meanings unless context clearly indicates otherwise: 
    Driver. A driver is a person who is operating a motor vehicle at any time. 
    Hands free mode. Use of an interactive wireless communications device that allows the user to engage in communication without the use of either hand by means of an internal feature or function or an attachment or device. 
    Interactive wireless communication device. An interactive wireless communication device shall include, but shall not be limited to, a wireless telephone, cellular phone, personal digital assistant, smart phone, portable or mobile computer, laptop computer, and/or blackberry, which is or can be used for voice communication, texting, emailing, browsing the internet or instant messaging. This term shall not include a device being used only as a global positioning or navigation system, or a device which is physically or electronically integrated into the motor vehicle. 
    Use shall mean dialing, answering, texting, typing, browsing, surfing, or physically handling. 
(b)  Prohibitions. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any driver to use an interactive wireless communications device within the city limits of the City of Wilkes-Barre for a purpose other than voice communication through the use of the interactive wireless communications device while in hands free mode. 
(2)  No driver who has a learner's permit or a junior driver's license shall drive a motor vehicle within the City of Wilkes-Barre while using an interactive wireless communications device for any purpose. 
(c)  Exceptions. The following shall be exceptions to subsection (b) above: 
(1)  A driver using an interactive wireless communication device to contact a 911 system or a wireless 911 service; 
(2)  A driver using an interactive wireless communication device when the vehicle is stopped and the transmission is in neutral or park, and the vehicle is not in any lane of traffic; 
(3)  Operators of emergency vehicles who use an interactive wireless communications device for voice communication for the purpose of responding to an emergency, while engaged in the performance of their official duties; 
(4)  Volunteer emergency responders who use an interactive wireless communications device for voice communication for the purpose of responding to an emergency, while engaged in the performance of their official duties. 
(d)  Category of offense. Violation of this section shall serve as a primary offense against the driver. 
(e)  Penalties. Any person convicted of violating this section shall be guilty of a summary offense and shall be subject to a fine of not less than seventy-five dollars ($75.00), plus the costs of suit. 
(Ord. No. 3-2010, §§ 1-5, 4-8-10) 
Secs. 29-8-29-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration generally, Ch. 2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 29-21. - Authority of the police generally. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the chief of police to enforce this chapter and all ordinances and regulations of the state, vehicle code. 
(b)  The bureau of police is hereby authorized to direct all traffic by voice, hand or other signals. In the event of a fire or other emergency, or to expedite traffic, or to safeguard life and property, the bureau of police may direct traffic as conditions may require. 
(c)  Members of the bureau of fire and personnel of the bureau of civil defense, when at the scene of a fire or other emergency, may direct or assist the police in directing traffic thereat or in the immediate vicinity. 
(Ord. No. 2-75, Art. II, § 8, 3-6-75) 
Sec. 29-22. - Written report of accidents. 
(a)  The operator of a vehicle involved in an accident resulting in bodily injury or death to any person, or damage to the property of any one person in excess of two hundred dollars ($200.00), shall, if such accident was not then and there personally investigated by a police officer of the city, within five (5) days after such accident, make a report of such accident to the bureau of police. 
(b)  Whenever the operator of a vehicle is physically incapable of making a required accident report and if there was another occupant capable of making a report, such occupant shall, if such accident was not then and there personally investigated by a police officer of the city, within five (5) days after such accident make a report of such accident to the bureau of police. 
(Ord. No. 2-75, Art. II, § 9, 3-6-75) 
Sec. 29-23. - Department of public works. 
(a)  City council may provide by ordinance for the selection of such a number of employees under the department of public works to act as duly authorized representatives of the bureau of police; provided no additional wage cost accrues to the city. 
(b)  The authority of such personnel shall be limited to the placing of notices of violation upon vehicles parked in violation of section 29-145. 
(c)  Such personnel will remain under the control and direction of the department of public works and shall place notice of parking violations on such illegally parked vehicles only when such vehicles interfere with the completion of tasks duly assigned the department of public works. 
(d)  Such personnel will remain separate from the bureau of police and shall not be covered under provisions of the state civil service act; nor will they be entitled to benefits under the police pension plan. 
(Ord. No. 2-75, Art. III, §§ 1-3) 
Sec. 29-24. - City engineer. 
    The city engineer is hereby empowered to: 
(1)  Prepare and maintain, with the cooperation of other departments, an official traffic-control map of this city; 
(2)  Determine the installation and proper timing and maintenance of traffic-control devices; 
(3)  Conduct engineering investigations of traffic conditions; 
(4)  Conduct engineering analyses of traffic accidents and to devise remedial measures with the cooperation of the division of traffic and patrol and the traffic committee; 
(5)  Assist the traffic committee in planning the operation of traffic on streets and highways of this city; 
(6)  Cooperate with the traffic committee, the division of traffic and patrol and other city officials in the development of ways and means to improve traffic conditions. 
(Ord. No. 2-75, Art. IV, § 1, 3-6-75) 
Sec. 29-25. - Use of devices for timing speed of motor vehicles. 
(a)  The Wilkes-Barre City Police Department is hereby authorized and empowered to use any and all mechanical, electrical, electrical-mechanical and/or electronic devices for the timing of motor vehicle speed, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Speed Chek. An electrical device approved by PennDot for use in timing the rate of speed of motor vehicles. (Title 67, Chapter 105, Sub-Chapter D, Para. 105.51 (3)) 
(2)  Vascar Plus (Visual Average Speed Computer And Recorder). An electrical-mechanical device approved by PennDot for use in timing the rate of speed of motor vehicles. (Title 65, Chapter 105, Para. 105.91) 
(b)  The authority hereby granted shall relate to all public roadways within the City of Wilkes-Barre. 
(Ord. No. 3-84, §§ 1, 2, 1-26-84) 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 3-84, §§ 1, 2, adopted Jan. 26, 1984, was nonamendatory of the code; hence, codification herein as § 29-25 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 29-26. - Division of parking enforcement. 
(a)  Established. There is hereby established in the Wilkes-Barre Police Department a division of parking enforcement within the City of Wilkes-Barre. The division of parking enforcement will be composed of civilian parking enforcement officers. 
(b)  Powers and duties. It shall be the duty of the division of parking enforcement to enforce parking laws and regulations within the City of Wilkes-Barre. Parking enforcement officers are hereby authorized to enforce all state laws and city ordinances regulating the parking of vehicles within the City of Wilkes-Barre. Parking enforcement officers are to be considered law enforcement officers within the meaning provided for in the Pennsylvania Rules of Criminal Procedure. 
(Ord. No. 41-98, §§ 1, 2, 6-4-98; Ord. No. 3-2015, 2-10-15) 
Secs. 29-27-29-30. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - DIVISION OF TRAFFIC AND PATROL 

Sec. 29-31. - Established. 
    There is hereby established in the bureau of police a division of traffic and patrol to be under the control of an officer of police appointed by and directly responsible to the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 2-75, Art. II, § 1, 3-6-75) 
Sec. 29-32. - Duties generally. 
    It shall be the duty of the division of traffic and patrol with such aid as may be rendered by other members of the bureau of police to enforce the street traffic regulations of this city and all of the state vehicle laws applicable to street traffic in this city, to make arrests for traffic violations, to investigate accidents and to cooperate with the city engineer, traffic committee and other officers of the city in the administration of the traffic laws and in developing ways and means to improve traffic conditions, and to carry out those duties especially imposed upon the division by this chapter and other ordinances of this city. 
(Ord. No. 2-75, Art. II, § 2, 3-6-75) 
Sec. 29-33. - Records of traffic violations. 
    The division of traffic and patrol shall keep a record of all violations of traffic ordinances of this city and of state vehicle laws of which any person has been charged, together with a record of the final disposition of all such alleged offenses. Such record shall be so maintained as to show all types of violations and the total of each. Such record shall accumulate during at least an eight-year period and from that time on the record shall be maintained complete for at least the most recent eight-year period. 
(Ord. No. 2-75, Art. II, § 3, 3-6-75) 
Sec. 29-34. - Investigation of accidents. 
    It shall be the duty of the division of traffic and patrol, assisted by other police officers of the bureau, to investigate traffic accidents, to arrest and to assist in the prosecution of those persons charged with causing or contributing to such accidents. 
(Ord. No. 2-75, Art. II, § 4, 3-6-75) 
Sec. 29-35. - Traffic accident studies. 
    Whenever accidents at any particular location become numerous, the division of traffic and patrol shall issue a written communication to the city engineer and cooperate with him in conducting studies of such accidents and determining remedial measures. 
(Ord. No. 2-75, Art. II, § 5, 3-6-75) 
Sec. 29-36. - Temporary and experimental regulations. 
(a)  The division of traffic and patrol upon the advice of the chief of police is hereby empowered to make regulations necessary to make effective the provisions of this chapter and to make and enforce temporary regulations to regulate traffic and parking to cover emergencies or special conditions and to make and enforce temporary regulations as set forth by the traffic committee, to allow for the test and experimental determination of the feasibility and desirability of permanent changes in this chapter relative to traffic and parking. Such emergency and experimental regulations shall be enforced in the same manner as permanent regulations and such regulations shall not remain in effect for more than ninety (90) days. 
(b)  The temporary period shall begin upon the posting of signs or other appropriate notice to the public in close proximity to the area or areas affected by such regulation. 
(c)  During the first week of the temporary period, a written communication shall be sent to the mayor to notify council of such proposed regulation and the reasons therefor. 
(d)  If an ordinance embodying any temporary regulation, or any part thereof, fails to be enacted by council, such regulation or any part thereof shall, at the end of such temporary period of ninety (90) days, cease to be effective. 
(e)  If council directs by resolution that any temporary traffic regulation shall be discontinued immediately, the traffic-control devices effecting such temporary regulation shall be removed at once and the regulation shall be void. 
(Ord. No. 2-75, Art. II, § 6, 3-6-75) 
Sec. 29-37. - Weekly traffic reports to the mayor. 
    The division of traffic and patrol shall prepare a weekly traffic report which shall be filed with the mayor. Such a report shall contain information on traffic matters in this city as follows: 
(1)  The number of traffic accidents, the number of persons killed, the number of persons injured and other pertinent traffic accident data; 
(2)  The number of traffic accidents investigated and other pertinent data on the safety activities of the division of traffic and patrol; 
(3)  Plans and recommendations of the division for future traffic safety activities. 
(Ord. No. 2-75, Art. II, § 7, 3-6-75) 
Secs. 29-38-29-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TRAFFIC COMMITTEE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 2-87, adopted Feb. 12, 1987, amended Art. V, § 1 of Ord. No. 2-75, adopted March 6, 1975, from which §§ 29-46-29-51, concerning the traffic committee, were originally derived. Section 1 of Ord. No. 2-87 enacted provisions relative to the same subject matter which have been included herein as new §§ 29-46-29-48, 29-50 and 29-51. 

Sec. 29-46. - Established. 
    A traffic committee is hereby established. 
(Ord. No. 2-75, Art. V, § 1, 3-6-75; Ord. No. 2-87, § 1, 2-12-87; Ord. No. 25-89, § 1, 6-6-89) 
Sec. 29-47. - Composition. 
    The traffic committee shall consist of the following eleven (11) members, who shall serve without compensation: 
(1)  The chief executive or his designee. 
(2)  The city engineer. 
(3)  The director of planning. 
(4)  The director of public works. 
(5)  The chief of police. 
(6)  The captain of traffic and patrol. 
(7)  The chief of fire.

(Ord. No. 2-75, Art. V, § 1, 3-6-75; Ord. No. 8-72, § 1, 2-22-79; Ord. No. 10-84, § 1, 4-26-84; Ord. No. 2-87, § 1, 2-12-87; Ord. No. 25-89, § 1, 6-6-89) 
Sec. 29-48. - Appointment of citizen members. 
    The four (4) citizens on the traffic committee shall be appointed to the committee by the chief executive subject to the approval of city council. Citizen representatives on such committee shall serve for a period of three (3) years, and not more than one (1) term shall expire in any given calendar year and such appointees shall serve until reappointed or replaced. 
(Ord. No. 2-75, Art. V, § 1, 3-6-75; Ord. No. 2-87, § 1, 2-12-87) 
Sec. 29-49. - Reserved.
